HEADLINE: Founder of Program to Build Students' Self-Respect, and Houses, Wins 'Genius' Grant

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER 

DATELINE: BOSTON, June 17

 BODY:
Many of Dorothy Stoneman's friends went south to join the civil rights movement after college. Ms. Stoneman, who graduated from Harvard in 1963, went to Harlem, and stayed for 25 years. She founded a community service program that gave alienated, unemployed young people hope -- and skills -- by putting them to work rebuilding poor neighborhoods.
That program grew into Youthbuild U.S.A., which has become a national model. Today Ms. Stoneman, as president of Youthbuild, was awarded a $325,000 prize by the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation. Ms. Stoneman, 54, who earns about $45,000 a year after taxes, and each year raises $5 million for Youthbuild, whose main office is in Somerville, Mass., said she planned to use the money "on something that might not be funded." 
 "I feel determined," she said in a telephone interview from New York, where she attended a board meeting of Youth Action, the program she started in East Harlem in 1978. "It's sort of my job to produce hope. It's my function to be determined, to never give up, to make sure we don't let anyone turn us back."
Youthbuild, which has 100 programs in 34 states, builds young people's self-respect, teaching them leadership as well as carpentry skills. The students, age 17 to 25, spend alternating weeks going to classes and learning carpentry by renovating abandoned housing for the poor in places like Portland, Me., Eugene, Ore. and York, Pa., as well as Harlem and Boston. They earn $100 a week.
"This mass of young people who have been treated as if they were worthless, and who have been thrown away, and assumed to be without value because they dropped out of school have a deep, very powerful desire to play a constructive role in the world," said Ms. Stoneman, whose organization also gets private and government financing. "You put an ad in the Daily News, you get 500 applications in a week."
Ms. Stoneman, who also helped start a summer pre-school in Harlem, and ran the East Harlem Block Schools, an alternative school, said she learned early on that communities must be given control over their own schools and programs. "Anything that's going to work needs to be accountable to that community, to be rooted there," she said.
Each Youthbuild class elects a committee that interviews candidates for teaching jobs and has the last word on whom to hire.
"It's the adult responsibility to make a path," Ms. Stoneman said. "We're making a mini community in which young people can get the support, the love, the opportunity, the structure, the friends to build their own path to the future."
Ms. Stoneman is married to John Bell, the director of training for Youthbuild. They have two children, Sierra, 20, and Taro, 8. They live in Belmont, Mass.
Each year, the MacArthur foundation awards what are often called "genius grants," to people who it believes have pushed the boundaries of their field. Recipients can spend the grant any way they want.
Twenty other people received grants today:
James Angel, 55, an astronomer in Tuscon, Ariz., who is searching for planets around other stars, $330,000.
 Joaquin Avila, 48, of Fremont, Calif., a lawyer involved in voting-rights cases, $295,000.
 Allan Berube, 49, of San Francisco, a social historian focusing on minorities, $300,000.
 Barbara Block, 38, of Monterey, Calif., an animal physiologist, $245,000.
 Joan Connelly, 42, of New York, an archeologist and art historian, $265,000.
 Thomas Daniel, 41, of Seattle, a biologist whose work combines zoology, engineering and mathematics, $260,000.
 Martin Eakes, 41, of Durham, N.C., director of a self-help organization, $260,000.
 Rebecca Goldstein, 46, of Highland Park, N.J., a novelist with a strong philosophical bent, $285,000.
 Robert Greenstein, 50, of Washington, a policy analyst on issues affecting low-income families, $305,000.
 Richard Howard, 66, of New York, a poet, translator, critic and editor, $375,000.
 John Jesurun, 45, of New York, a theater director and writer who combines media in his performance pieces, $280,000.
 Richard Lenski, 39, of East Lansing, Mich., a biologist in the fields of evolution and microbial ecology, $250,000.
 Louis Massiah, 42, of Philadelphia, a documentary filmmaker, $265,000.
 Vonnie McLoyd, 45, of Durham, N.C., a psychologist who studies the effects of poverty, $280,000.
 Thylias Moss, 42, of Ann Arbor, Mich., a poet and English professor, $265,000.
 Eiko Otake, 44, and Koma Otake, 47, of New York, dancers and choreographers, $290,000.
 Nathan Seiberg, 39, of Princeton, N.J., a physicist and professor, $250,000.

HEADLINE: Stocks Are Mixed as Dow Posts a Slight Gain

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Stocks were mixed yesterday as a rally in bonds failed to shake investor concern that profits would fall short of expectations later this year.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 3.33 points, to 5,652.78, ending five straight days of losses. The broader Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 0.69 point, to 665.16, while the Nasdaq composite index slipped 5.54 points, to 1,207.64. 
 In the bond market, expectations of slowing growth, coupled with optimism that the Federal Reserve will not raise interest rates next month to quell inflation pressures, helped drive the yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond lower for a third session. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction of a bond's price, fell two-hundredths of a percentage point, to 7.06 percent.
Lower rates, and the prospect of lower borrowing costs, pushed the Dow industrials up more than 28 points at one point late in the day, but fears about corporate earnings pared the gain.
"We're very concerned about the profit outlook," said Kip Wright, portfolio manager at Kirr, Marbach & Company in Indianapolis, which oversees $800 million in investment assets. "We're hearing that business is O.K., not booming. A lot of companies are leery about being too optimistic about the next six months."
The Philip Morris Companies led decliners in the Dow industrials, falling 1, to 104 3/8, after the prosecuting attorney in a Mississippi anti-tobacco lawsuit said six new industry insiders had come forward to assist the state's case.
Semiconductors slid for a third day. Cyrix fell 2 1/16, to 23 1/2, after an analyst at the Southcoast Corporation who recently took over coverage of Cyrix cut the former earnings estimate for the current quarter by more than half.
Intel shed 1, to 72.
Brooktrout Technology Inc. and Smith Micro Software Inc., two small computer software publishers, slid amid concern about the current quarter's earnings estimates, analysts said. Brooktrout fell 5 3/4, to 32 3/4, and Smith Micro retreated 1 7/8, to 11 1/2.
Aptar Group Inc., a maker of aerosols and pumps for fragrance and health care manufacturers, said its second-quarter earnings would not meet expectations because of weak perfume and cosmetic sales in Europe. Aptar fell 3 3/8, to 36 3/8.
Oil shares gained, following crude prices higher. A standoff between United Nations inspectors and Iraq led to speculation that the recent agreement allowing Iraq to sell oil might be delayed or shelved, tightening supplies. Exxon rose 1, to 84 1/2; Texaco rose 5/8, to 84 1/8, and Chevron advanced 3/8, to 60.
Glaxo Wellcome P.L.C.'s American depository receipts gained after analysts said the company would report promising results in the development of a new AIDS treatment at a conference next month. Shares of the British drug maker, the world's largest producer of AIDS medications, rose 7/8, to 27 3/8.
I.B.M. rose 7/8, to 102 1/2, after saying it would begin selling laser printers designed for computer networks, in competition with the market leader, Hewlett-Packard, whose shares fell 5/8, to 99.
Beverage companies, whose profits can grow regardless of the economy's performance, gained amid expectations of less frenetic growth. Coca-Cola rose 3/8, to 46 1/8, and Pepsico added 1/8, to 33 1/4.
First Union rose 1/2, to 60 1/2, after it said it would buy two smaller East Coast banks, Center Financial of Waterbury, Conn., and Home Financial of Hollywood, Fla., for a total of about $715 million in stock.
Center Financial shares rose 1 1/4, to 24 1/8, while Home Financial fell 9/16, to 13 1/16 on the offer.
Kansas City Power and Light rose 1 1/2, to 27 3/8, after Western Resources said it had sweetened its bid for the utility to $31, a share from $28.
Syquest Technology rose 1 7/8, to 11 1/4, after the company said it met qualifications for listing on the Nasdaq stock market, after raising $20 million from investors by selling preferred shares.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Mark Rises Against the Dollar On Yeltsin Showing in Voting

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The German mark rose to a one-month high against the dollar yesterday as Russia's President, Boris N. Yeltsin, led in the first round of balloting.
Prospects for political stability in Russia often help the mark because of the close economic ties between Russia and Germany, Russia's largest trading partner and biggest creditor. 
 "Yeltsin winning this round was a relief for the market," said John McCarthy at ING Capital Markets. "So the pressure the election exerted on the mark last week was quieted."
Also bolstering the mark were statements from Germany's central bank. While calling the mark's recent decline good news for German exports, Bundesbank officials indicated yesterday that the dollar had risen enough. The dollar settled at 1.5204 marks in New York trading, down from 1.5272 on Friday.
The dollar also slipped in New York to 108.98 yen from 109.12 after Japan said its merchandise trade surplus shrank 60.5 percent in May from a year earlier. A decline means Japanese exporters have fewer dollars to sell for yen when bringing profits home.
The British pound rose to $1.5435 from $1.5375.
In its report for June, the Bundesbank said that last year's rise by the mark against the dollar had been reversed. The dollar fell about 8 percent against the mark last year and has gained 6 percent this year.
Hans Tietmeyer, the president of the Bundesbank, said in a television interview that the value of the dollar against the mark reflected the two countries' policies and economies more fairly than it did last spring.
"The comments suggest that the Bundesbank is not a big advocate of a stronger dollar," said Kevin Weir, currency salesman at the ABN-Amro Bank in Chicago.
Traders were wary that the persistent sluggishness in the German economy could prompt the Bundesbank to cut its 14-day repurchase rate in coming weeks, which could hurt the mark by reducing the returns on German deposits.
The Bundesbank said the evidence of a recovery was patchy at best. The German economy, Europe's biggest, shrank for the last two quarters. "The Bundesbank, at one point or another, is going to ease," said Lizbeth Goldberg at the Bayerische Hypotheken und Wechsel Bank.

HEADLINE: Critics Attack Senate Bill To Aid Timber Company

BYLINE: By JANE FRITSCH 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 17

 BODY:
Last week, Senator Frank H. Murkowski of Alaska introduced a bill to give a highly unusual long-term timber contract to the Ketchikan Pulp Company, saying the arrangement was vital to the economy of the small town of Ketchikan in Alaska's panhandle.
"I cannot stand idly by and watch the town of Ketchikan die," Mr. Murkowsky said. He said hundreds, if not thousands, of jobs would be lost without the contract, which would guarantee the company timber from the Tongass National Forest until 2019. 
 But the proposed contract has an advantage that Mr. Murkowski did not mention: it would shore up First Bank of Ketchikan, in which he holds more than $1 million in stock and on whose board his daughter sits. The bank does not have a direct interest in Ketchikan Pulp, but bank officials have been pushing for the contract because it would guarantee a robust economy in the region, and in turn would be good for the bank.
Mr. Murkowski, a Republican in his third term, said today that he saw no ethical problem with his role.
"I can't think of a better way to represent my constituents in the State of Alaska than to try and fight for the only year-round manufacturing facility in the entire southeastern Alaska region," he said.
Officials of the United States Forest Service, who manage timber cutting in the national forests, have opposed the extension. But Mr. Murkowski, who is chairman of the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee, has significant power over the Forest Service and has been holding hearings on its timber policies, which he has criticized.
Environmental groups have called the bill a special-interest giveaway that would allow excessive cutting of ancient trees that provide the best and most diverse wildlife habitats. And they point to Ketchikan Pulp's history of environmental problems. In 1995, the company, a subsidiary of Louisiana Pacific Corporation, paid $6 million in fines and pleaded guilty to a felony and 13 misdemeanor violations of the Federal Clean Water Act going back to the 1980's.
"Here we have the world's last remaining temperate rainforest and this company that's almost the definition of a special interest," said Steven E. Kallick, director of the Alaska Rainforest Campaign. "Senator Murkowski is apparently unconcerned about the national interest and focused solely on this special interest, which he is far too close to."
The Tongass National Forest is a vast expanse of islands and lush valleys that cover most of the Alaska panhandle. Its 500-year-old hemlock, spruce and cedar trees are among the oldest on the planet, some of them possibly 1,000 years old.
Ketchikan Pulp has been logging in the Tongass since 1954, when it won a 50-year contract with the Federal Government, which offered the long-term deals as an incentive to open up what was then viewed as the Alaskan frontier. One other company was given such a contract, but it went out of business several years ago. Since then, logging companies have competed for short-term rights to cut specific sections of national forests around the country.
Mr. Murkowski's bill would guarantee Ketchikan Pulp 15 more years of logging in the Tongass after its contract expires in 2004.
His proposal also guarantees the company 192 million board feet of timber each year rather than the roughly 160 million it now gets. (One thousand board feet is the equivalent of a 100-foot-tall spruce tree with a 28-inch diameter at chest height.) The proposal also virtually guarantees the company a profit. The most unusual feature, critics say, is a provision that the contract cannot be terminated or changed without Ketchikan Pulp's agreement.
"The Forest Service always has the power to cancel contracts for environmental damage," said Charles M. Clusen, senior policy specialist for the Natural Resources Defense Council. "This makes it a one-way street."
Ketchikan Pulp argues that it needs the certainty of a 15-year extension if it is to install millions of dollars of anti-pollution equipment. A decision on whether to remain in the town will be made soon, the company says, and the choice will hinge on whether the extension is approved. About 25 percent of the employment in Ketchikan, home to some 9,000 people, is provided directly and indirectly by Ketchikan Pulp.
Mr. Murkowski, a banker before joining the Senate in 1981, said today that he had inherited the First Bank stock from his parents. Financial disclosure forms filed with the Senate place the value at more than $1 million. In 1995, he received dividends worth $50,001 to $100,000 from the bank, a subsidiary of First Bancorp. His daughter Lisa A. Murkowski, an Anchorage lawyer, is a member of the bank's board.
Mr. Murkowski said the legislation was necessary because the Forest Service had shown that it would not grant the extension on its own. Ketchikan Pulp is in a special situation because the only source for timber in Alaska is the Forest Service.
The bill's importance to the bank was underscored by its president, William G. Moran Jr., last April when he testified at state hearings in Juneau. Without a long-term agreement, Mr. Moran said, lending would slow significantly. "The commercial activity kind of goes into hibernation," he said.
But Mr. Clusen said: "All the other pulp mills in the country don't get this kind of deal. It's undermining the Tongass plan and interfering with the free-market process."

HEADLINE: U.S. and China Agree on Pact To Fight Piracy

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: BEIJING, June 17

 BODY:
After a month of intense negotiations, China and the United States reached a broad agreement today on how to crack down more effectively on the piracy of music, movies and computer software in China, and Washington halted plans to impose $2 billion in trade sanctions.
In three final days of round-the-clock talks, with today's deadline for United States sanctions looming, the Chinese agreed to new measures to ban the reproduction and sale of pirated intellectual property. The Chinese and American negotiators ended their intricate game of brinksmanship when the Chinese relented slightly on two final issues, announcing they had closed down two more pirate compact disk factories -- bringing the total closed this year to 15 -- and expanded permission for foreign music and movie companies to produce and sell their products inside China. 
 United States officials hailed the agreement as an important step forward in reducing the piracy of music, movies and software. Yet they also portrayed the talks as one piece in the larger political tangle of American-Chinese relations, calling the agreement a successful example of the Clinton Administration's policy of engagement with China.
"What engagement means is that we do not avoid our differences, but that we work together constructively," said Charlene Barshefsky, the acting United States trade representative, as she announced the agreement at a news conference tonight.
China agreed last year to stop illegal production, but failed to carry through with adequate controls. The heart of today's accord involves improved enforcement, and Ms. Barshefsky pointed to a series of steps she said the Chinese authorities pledged to take to make it more difficult to operate as a pirate in China. Although the steps are a clear improvement on paper, they appear to contain flaws that make it hard to tell whether they will be more effective in practice.
In the past, factories that were shut down for illegal copying, for example, have often re-opened after a short period, sometimes operating at night to avoid detection. In today's agreement, American officials failed to obtain approval to verify factory closings independently. Instead, they must rely on the word of local officials, who may be beholden to local interests. In some cases, pirate factory managers have protected themselves by sharing profits with military or local officials.
"Over the long term, the real test lies in the strength of the underlying enforcement regime," Ms. Barshefsky said. "The ultimate test is implementation."
Perhaps the most significant change in this agreement is China's willingness, for the first time, to employ police officers to carry out investigations of illegal compact disk factories instead of using administrative officers, who have less authority.
Police officers carried out several successful raids on compact disk factories in recent weeks in Guangdong Province, but those raids were evidently timed to impress the American negotiators, so it is not clear whether the police will remain as active.
Another advance lies in a new system of verifying that the title of a compact disk to be produced has been obtained legally. From now on, any factory producing a disk must first obtain approval from the National Copyright Administration in Beijing, which can check with the studio where the music or movie originated to make sure its rights were obtained properly.
As a result of the crackdown on piracy in Guangdong Province in recent weeks, Ms. Barshefsky said that 15 compact disk factories -- half of the more than 30 known factories -- have now been closed down, their licenses revoked and their equipment confiscated. She said the closings had been verified by American officials or industry agents and added that she expected more to be closed as investigations continue in the coming weeks.
Another American official said that Chinese negotiators had withheld the names of two of those factories until the last day of talks. The announcement of the two closings, paired with the contentious issue of improved access for Americans to Chinese markets, were concessions that helped Ms. Barshevsky agree to discard the threat of sanctions, the official said.
Market access, or the right of American music and movie companies to produce and sell within China, was cited by Ms. Barshefsky as an area where incremental advances were also made. But the issue of market access was left out of the final agreement, apparently a sign of how sensitive Chinese officials remain about allowing any loosening of control over creative ventures.
Ms. Barshefsky also pointed out that the seven-page document was not a supplement or a replacement for the landmark agreement on intellectual property that was reached last year.
Although this year's talks sometimes seemed a replay, with accusations and counteraccusations on each side followed by a last minute agreement, they were actually much simpler. Last year, negotiators devised a lengthy agreement; this year they debated how to enforce it better.
In its own announcement, the Chinese Government reflected a sensitivity to national pride and tried to dispel any impression that a foreign power was dictating the terms of any international agreement.
"The agreement once again shows that the only way to solve the differences between countries is consultations on an equal footing," the New China News Agency reported. "Sanctions and retaliations will do no good to the settlement of any issues. Instead, they will make the differences more complicated."
The sanctions, formally announced in Washington on May 15, would have raised the tariffs on Chinese textiles, garments and electrical goods by 100 percent. The Chinese announced a reciprocal list of $2 billion worth of American imports to be hit with its own sanctions.
After the agreement was reached today, Shi Guangsheng, the deputy trade minister who sat across the negotiating table from Ms. Barshefsky, announced that China's threatened sanctions would be rescinded as well.
In Washington, officials expressed relief that they had found a way to sidestep the imposition of sanctions, which had been opposed by many American companies that do business with China.
Perhaps with an eye to the election, Administration officials from Secretary of State Warren Christopher to the Commerce Secretary, Mickey Kantor, argued that increased enforcement of anti-piracy laws would translate into jobs in the United States.
"It will help protect the jobs of American workers, open up opportunities for American companies, and promote the integration of China into the world economy," Mr. Christopher said today. Mr. Kantor was equally enthusaistic, inisting that the agreement "went from the abstract to effective, concrete action."
In private, however, Administration officials acknowledged that beyond the closing of the worst-offender plants, which they said was a major accomplishment, it was difficult to tell whether China would keep up the pressure on pirate producers.
The accord was largely hailed by the recording industry, Hollywood and software producers, who said they viewed any form of stepped-up enforcement as progress. Several industry officials noted, however, that the accord only calls for the destruction of some of the pirate firms' equipment, making them wonder whether the compact disk presses that have been seized by Chinese authorities could reappear in other factories.
At her news conference, Ms. Barshefsky accused the New China News Agency, the official Government organ, of attempted piracy by its recent demands that foreign news agencies selling economic information in China turn over their proprietary software and details of their business operations to the agency. Under rules adopted in January, the news agency is meant to supervise, regulate and compete with agencies like Reuters and Dow Jones.
"This is a massive IPR violation scheme," said Ms. Barshefsky, referring to intellectual property rights and adding that she raised the issue with senior Chinese officials. "It is designed to capture the benefits of U.S. software and U.S. data collection abilities without regard to the licensee."
In the end, Ms. Barshefsky said she did not underestimate the obstacles involved in China's attempts to come to grips with the issue of protecting intellectual property.
"Three years ago, IPR enforcement was an abstract concept," she said. "Now, the Chinese authorities are taking concrete and tangible actions.
"Halting piracy is a long-term and complex process, here and elsewhere in the world," she said. "China is certainly not there yet."

SPECIAL ENFORCEMENT PERIOD: The police assume responsiblity for the investigation of compact disk factories, and include intellectual property violations in a nationwide crackdown on crime.
 
BORDER ENFORCEMENT: Chinese Customs officers are supposed to better coordinate their enforcement with prosecutors. Customs officials will also work with industry experts on how to watch for and identify illegally made compact disks.

Local supervisors will keep records of regular audits, and show the records to U.S. officials in periodic visits. HEADLINE: THE RUSSIAN VOTE: THE KINGMAKER;
From War Hero to Populist Politician

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, June 17

 BODY:
The retired general who came in third in Sunday's presidential race, and whose endorsement is now avidly sought by Boris N. Yeltsin, has been caricatured as a strident nationalist determined to rebuild the Russian empire on the ashes of the old Soviet Union.
But judged by his platform and his manner, Aleksandr I. Lebed is more Colin Powell than Vladimir Zhirinovsky. An Afghan war hero whose face bears the scars of a boxing career, Mr. Lebed is well known in the West for his impolitic prediction that the Soviet Union would be partly recreated. 
 But it is Mr. Lebed's steely independence, his reputation of incorruptibility, and his image of being above the seamy world of ordinary politics that endeared him to millions of Russian voters.
Indeed, during the last several months Mr. Lebed, who received 15 percent of the vote on Sunday, has played down nationalist themes and softened his image.
He has, for example, unveiled a pragmatic program for Russia's problems, which carries the uninspirational title "Ideology of Common Sense."
It is a plan that plays upon many Russians' deep longing for a strong man to fight crime at home and introduce probity in government, without pandering to those who yearn to recapture an empire and punish the rich.
Striking pro-reform themes, the new Mr. Lebed has also called for evacuating the Russian population from the embattled province of Chechnya and giving Chechens the freedom to chose independence; Mr. Yeltsin has spent more than 30,000 lives to keep Chechnya under Russian control.
And Mr. Lebed has denounced Communist economics as "a dead end."
"Without a market and private property, people work much worse," Mr. Lebed declared in an interview with the newspaper Trud.
Mr. Lebed is uneasy discussing the details of economics. But like much American support for General Powell, much Russian support for Mr. Lebed is a matter of mystique rather than specific views. "The caricature is that he is a nationalist," said Michael A. McFaul, a expert at the Moscow-based Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. "But he is not a nationalist as much as a populist. It is clear that he is not against reform. He is not against the course that Yeltsin has set."
The evolution of the 46-year-old Mr. Lebed from a sharp-edged former general to a somewhat gentler authoritarian figure speaks volumes about what Mr. Lebed has learned about politics in the new Russia.
In the December parliamentary elections, when Mr. Lebed made his political debut, he shared a slate with Yuri Skokov, a former Yeltsin aide and head of the nationalist Congress of Russian Communities.
There were tensions over who would take the lead and Mr. Skokov kept Mr. Lebed on a tight leash. As a result, Mr. Lebed seemed awkward and unprepared during campaign appearances and the party did poorly during the election.
But since then Mr. Lebed has become his own man and hired high-powered political consultants, who have crafted a sophisticated and appealing television advertising campaign casting the former general as a crime-fighter and foe of corruption.
This is not to say that the former general does not have his weaknesses.
Many Russians are uncomfortable with the idea of a military man running the country. Mr. Lebed's aides have taken to festooning their campaign offices with pictures of President Dwight D. Eisenhower and Charles de Gaulle to give their candidate a sense of legitimacy.
An alliance between Mr. Yeltsin and the paratrooper-turned-politican would seem to hold decided advantages for both.
It could help insulate Mr. Yeltsin against charges of corruption and favoritism that have dogged his campaign, while giving Mr. Lebed real power, as well as a base to nurture his future presidential ambitions.
Encouraging speculation of an alliance, the former general said that he has ruled out working with the Communists. "We have gone past Communism and left this shore forever," he said today.
But, self-assured to the point of arrogance, Mr. Lebed indicated that his support would not come cheaply. He said he was interested in a post with real decision-making authority in which he could "organize the fight against crime and prevent extremists of left and right from plunging the country into an abyss of bloodshed."
Just a year ago, an alliance between Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Lebed seemed to be very far-fetched indeed.
Mr. Lebed grew up in Novocherkassk, a town near Rostov where Soviet troops fired on demonstrators in 1962. In his Trud interview, Mr. Lebed denounced the Communist Party's failure to condemn this shooting.
"In this case, failing to condemn is a crime in itself," he said.
Mr. Lebed joined the army and became a paratrooper. After the collapse of the Soviet Union, he rose to prominence when he headed the 14th Army group, which defended ethnic Russians in the Trans-Dneister region of the newly formed republic of Moldova. Although his critics recall that campaign as a defense of the Soviet empire, Mr. Lebed portrays it as an obligation to a beleaguered minority of his countrymen.
The general locked horns with Mr. Yeltsin last year after repeatedly criticizing Gen. Pavel Grachev, Mr. Yeltsin's Defense Minister, over the invasion of Chechnya and over the Government's decision to disband the 14th Army's headquarters.
After President Yeltsin announced Mr. Lebed's resignation last year, the gravel-throated general barely flinched.
"I guess that Yeltsin got sick and tired of me, and I am sick and tired of him as well," he said.

Voice Control Systems Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the Voice Processing Corporation, a developer of speech-recognition computer technology, for more than $40 million. SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 4; Science Desk 

LENGTH: 1927 words

HEADLINE: SCIENTIST AT WORK: Richard S. Lindzen;
A Skeptic Asks, Is It Getting Hotter, Or Is It Just the Computer Model?

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS 

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
AS climate experts firm up their view that human activity is seriously altering the atmosphere, one voice stands out in clarion dissent. It is that of Dr. Richard S. Lindzen of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, a shoemaker's son from the Bronx who has risen through the academic hierarchy as a leading expert on the physical processes of the atmosphere.
Is there truly cause to worry that emissions of waste industrial gases that trap heat like carbon dioxide could disrupt the world's climate? 
 Dr. Lindzen does not equivocate. "We don't have any evidence that this is a serious problem," he says flatly, with precise diction, in a friendly voice that resonates strongly in his 17th-floor office overlooking Boston across the Charles River. A clutter of folders and papers, coupled with Dr. Lindzen's untrimmed black beard and hornrim glasses, suggest the academic theorist he is.
His opinions attacking the formal consensus about climate change have made the 56-year-old Dr. Lindzen a bete noir to environmentalists who trumpet the dangers of global warming and a champion to political conservatives and industrial interests who minimize the threat. Admirers see him as a force for intellectual honesty in a highly politicized debate. Critics fault him for professing unwarranted sureness in a field of research rife with uncertainty. Many say he is simply wrong.
But everyone takes him with the utmost seriousness because of a reputation for brilliance that got him elected to the National Academy of Sciences at age 37. It is in this sense that his voice stands out from the relatively small group of greenhouse scientists who speak out boldly and publicly in dissent.
Last fall, a panel of scientists convened by the United Nations to advise the world's governments concluded for the first time that greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide are probably responsible, at least in part, for a changing global climate. The panel also predicted that if emissions of the gases are not reduced, the average global temperature will increase by 1.8 degrees to 6.3 degrees Fahrenheit -- with a best estimate of 3.6 degrees -- by the year 2100. The predicted warming, according to the United Nations panel, would be accompanied by widespread climatic disruption.
Bunk, says Dr. Lindzen. He says the conclusions are based on computerized models of the climate system so flawed as to be meaningless. Everyone recognizes that the models are imperfect, but Dr. Lindzen goes much farther. "I do not accept the model results as evidence," he says, because trusting them "is like trusting a ouija board." Furthermore, he argues, the physics of the atmosphere permit only a minor and untroubling warming despite the buildup of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere.
His assertions have subjected him to a barrage of criticism from the modeling community and its many scientific allies. Dr. Lindzen has "sacrificed his luminosity by taking a stand that most of us feel is scientifically unsound," said a longtime acquaintance, Dr. Jerry D. Mahlman, director of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's Geophysical Fluid Dynamics Laboratory at Princeton University, which runs one of the computer models Dr. Lindzen scorns. Dr. Mahlman nevertheless describes Dr. Lindzen as "a formidable opponent."
Does Dr. Lindzen feel beaten up on?
"That's a matter of how thick one's skin is," he said over fried calamari at a Cambridge restaurant. It helps, he said, that he gets many calls and letters from silent skeptics in the scientific community who thank him for his stand. They often do not themselves speak out, he says, because it doesn't pay to be a skeptic. "Who needs to be in controversies, who needs any of this?" he said. "And in a time of budgetary restraint, climate has gotten good funding. Why spoil a good thing?"
By the same token, he says, there is a financing advantage in being on the greenhouse bandwagon. Are some people trying to maintain a sense of crisis to get research grants? "Yes," he says, "and it's unconscious and it's natural."
One who says he basically agrees with Dr. Lindzen's view is Dr. William Gray of Colorado State University, best known for his predictions of hurricane activity. "A lot of my older colleagues are very skeptical on the global warming thing," said Dr. Gray. He calls Dr. Lindzen's stand "courageous." While some of the criticisms delivered by Dr. Lindzen may have some flaws, said Dr. Gray, "across the board he's generally very good."
Another atmospheric scientist cited by Dr. Lindzen as a fellow skeptic, Dr. John M. Wallace of the University of Washington, said there are "relatively few scientists who are as skeptical of the whole thing as Dick is." Many more, said Dr. Wallace, take the question of climate change seriously but think that assertions of climate change already in progress have been exaggerated, as he does.
The object of the conflicting opinions was born in Webster, Mass., in 1940, after his parents fled Hitler's Germany. His shoemaker father later moved the family to the Bronx, where, Dr. Lindzen says, "I think we were the first Jewish family in an Irish-Catholic neighborhood." There he developed a lifelong enthusiasm for amateur radio and won Regents' and National Merit scholarships at the Bronx High School of Science (class of 1956). He also acquired the middle-class native New Yorker's hardened "G" (as in Lon-GIH-land) that faintly modifies his otherwise straightforward academic accent today.
The scholarships propelled him as a student first to Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute and then to Harvard University, where he was attracted by classical physics, and then atmospheric physics. By his mid-30's he had produced landmark work in atmospheric dynamics, mainly involving "tides," or regular changes in atmospheric pressure, and the periodic shift in direction of high-level equatorial winds that affect global circulation patterns. After various academic posts, he joined the M.I.T. faculty in 1983, where he is the Alfred P. Sloan Professor of Meteorology.
In recent years, while pursuing his main interest of atmospheric dynamics in trying to help "figure out how climate works," he has leveled a variety of criticisms at the idea of serious climatic change, some with telling effect. For instance, he points out, the computer models do not reflect the climate's natural variability very well -- a key shortcoming in trying to gauge the human effect on climate, one that is readily conceded by the modelers.
But the Lindzen idea that has attracted most attention is based on a fundamental point of physics: that carbon dioxide and the other waste gases generate only a small amount of warming. Something has to amplify that warming for the larger amount of warming predicted by the United Nations panel to materialize. The main candidate, whose presumed amplifying effect is built into the computer models, is water vapor -- also a heat-trapping gas, and the most powerful one since there is so much of it and it is so pervasive. The theory is that a warmer atmosphere holds more water vapor, thereby increasing the warming even more. Without this amplification, Dr. Lindzen argues, the average global temperature will rise by only about a degree Fahrenheit if atmospheric carbon dioxide is doubled.
"With all due respect to alarmism," he says, "I don't think anyone has argued that's going to be a major change in life as we know it."
The amount of warming produced by the doubling of carbon dioxide has become a standard measure of the climate system's sensitivity to change; the United Nations panel figures it at 3 to 8 degrees. But Dr. Lindzen argues that the models which produced those numbers do not properly reflect the physics of the water vapor question. While it is well known that warmer air generally holds more vapor, he says, "we don't know what determines upper level water vapor," a factor he says is crucial, and central to the predictions of future climate change. He has postulated over the years a number of possible atmospheric mechanisms that might nullify the supposed greenhouse amplification. It was Dr. Lindzen himself who later found the first of these possible mechanisms to be trivial in its effect, but he has advanced others.
Modelers, who insist that the amplifying effect of water vapor is supported by real-world data, sharply dispute Dr. Lindzen on this point and say he has no evidence to prove his nullification hypothesis. But other atmospheric scientists say the issue is not yet resolved. "To be fair," Dr. Lindzen says, "the answer at this stage is that we don't know" what the vapor effect is. And in fact, some important aspects of the issue are left uncertain in the United Nations panel's report.
In the meantime, he is exploring other ways to test the climate's sensitivity to change. One avenue involves volcanic eruptions. If the climate is not very sensitive, Dr. Lindzen says, the cooling effect produced by the haze from eruptions should dissipate quickly; if it is very sensitive, the effect should linger. So far, he says, it appears that the volcanoes are indicating low sensitivity -- bolstering, if he is right, his over-all argument about warming.
To some critics, Dr. Lindzen's confidence about the climate's low sensitivity to carbon dioxide emissions embodies more certitude than the facts allow. "I don't know what line from God he has," says Dr. Stephen Schneider of Stanford University, who cites what he sees as the overprecise estimate Dr. Lindzen gives.
Dr. Lindzen replies that he at least gives some reasons for his estimate rather than simply following a "herd instinct" that he says is very common in science. All in all, he says, "I don't think we've made the case yet" that serious climate change is in prospect, and he therefore sees no cause to worry now. To Dr. Mahlman, Dr. Lindzen is saying, "we don't know nearly as much as we need to know, therefore we shouldn't have any concern." This view, Dr. Mahlman asserts, is "deeply fallacious."
Dr. Lindzen traces his decision to begin voicing his doubts to a speaking engagement at Tufts University in the spring of 1989. After he stated his case, he recalled: "One person after another got up, saying scientists can have their doubts but we don't have any. I developed this awful feeling that here was an issue that was running away, developing a reality that transcended the science."
He says he prizes the environment, but that global warming and other issues have prompted environmental groups to go "off the deep end" and produce "a drum roll that gets rid of perspective." One consequence, he says, is that "if you are questioning the basis of global warming, you are definitely treated as someone who hates the earth -- and that's a little bit odd, because it is, after all, a scientific question."
Dr. Lindzen has always been a Democrat, too, but he says the global warming controversy has caused him to change parties. The notion that "extremely weak science" could set into motion policies with long-term implications for the economy made him "queasy" about governmental action, he said. In the academic community, he volunteers, laughing, his turn to the Republicans "must have been like coming out as a gay 25 years ago."
In 5 or 10 years, Dr. Lindzen says, direct observations of the climate's behavior might well make it clearer who is right in the greenhouse debate. Could he turn out to be wrong when all is said and done?
"I think it's unlikely," he said, "but it can happen."

SECTION: Section C; Page 15; Column 1; Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 1062 words

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
Fe, Fi, Fo, Whoa! The Inner Giant Has Taken Over.

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:

THE SIBLING SOCIETY
By Robert Bly
319 pages. Addison-Wesley. $25.
 As you can discover in any chapter of Robert Bly's new jeremiad, he is outraged by a society in which children grow up without fathers and with rotten schools, their brains stupefied by television, their imaginations squelched by computers, their sensibilities coarsened by rock music and exploitative movies, their dreams corrupted by advertising. Instead of growing into maturity with the help of older mentors who can pass along the experience of generations, they remain in a state of perpetual adolescence: selfish, acquisitive, spiritually flattened, dangerous. Welcome to "The Sibling Society."
The indictment, less original than the label, is a cousin to "Iron John," Mr. Bly's best seller, which generated a sort of men's movement in America. Here again, he draws on myth, religion, fairy tales, poems and even science of sorts for evidence of the wisdom that he argues has been discarded by a society that disdains the past. To borrow his language, we now live laterally, keeping an envious eye on one another, rather than vertically, in the glow of wise authority. 
 The book begins with an elaborate exegesis of "Jack and the Beanstalk," especially the nature of the Giant whom Mr. Bly likens to the primitive human brain, to the nafs, which, he reports, is the ever-demanding soul of Muslim and Sufi tradition, and to the Freudian id, all of which keep human beings in perpetual battle to satisfy insatiable appetites. As for Jack, he "represents all men and women who live in a fatherless and, increasingly, motherless society."
Mr. Bly is an accomplished storyteller, and his affection for the tales of many peoples over many centuries can be catching. But when it comes to the contemporary condition, his propheteering arias seem as out of control as the nafs: "The teen-agers in our inner cities are expressing the presence of the Giant, who is fundamentally opposed to life. He is the one who stabs people in the library and eats children." And beware: "We don't realize that when we put a computer or television in a child's own room, we are sending that child to be alone with the Giant."
Before you know it, Mr. Bly is attributing the growth of armed militias, unemployment and all manner of other ailments to siblingitis. For him, politics is psychology; he finds the roots of the North American Free Trade Agreement and the opposition to affirmative action in societal dysfunction.
Some of the presumable facts he tosses in as evidence of the national disarray are risible. Lamenting the flat language bred by television, he writes: "A poll a few years ago revealed that the average American father talked to his child for about 10 minutes a day. We know by contrast that in certain parts of Russia, earlier in the century, the Russian father spent more like two hours engaging in such talk. Russians have a word for 'soul-talk,' and it wasn't unusual for a grandfather to say to a granddaughter, 'Let's go out by the tree and have some soul-talk.' "
And he combines a vacuum-cleaner approach to the world's problems with a salesman's bent for wildly disproportionate comparisons. After lumping together the slaughters in Bosnia, Rwanda, Somalia and Cambodia as expressions of siblingdom triumphant, he adds, "Our sibling society came into existence by different means, but there is a comparable elimination of elders, accompanied by increasing anger on the part of youth."
Toward the end of his new book, Mr. Bly complains that most reviewers, trapped in "the flat, literal or sociological mode in which there is only one world," treated "Iron John" in a simplistic way. But the notable thing about his first book of prose was its success. With help from a Bill Moyers interview on PBS, it stayed on the best-seller list of The New York Times for more than a year, several weeks as No. 1. It was like a second coming of Joseph Campbell. As for reviews, most of those I have read swallowed the whole thing.
Credit for that success must go largely to Mr. Bly's enthusiasm for myth, his talent as a storyteller and the fact that he was onto a serious subject, the pathology of sons without fathers. It also offered the novelty of a men's movement as a sort of counter to or sibling of the women's movement and the promise of self-improvement cultivated by public broadcasting.
"The Sibling Society" has some of the same appeals. It should also please liberals. Noting that "our first thoroughly sibling Congress" is not about to "defend children, nor wetlands, nor blacks, nor women, nor full-growth forests, nor the Alaska wilderness," he concludes, "Some sibling meanness has interrupted the understanding people had in the 1960's that we are all related." Was that really "the understanding" in the 1960's?
If I cannot rouse more enthusiasm for "The Sibling Society," it may be because grandpa never took me out by the tree for some soul-talk. That is probably why I do not share the author's admiration for such hierarchical or God-directed communities as medieval monasteries, mistrust his treatment of history and find his rhapsodies to supposedly more spiritual cultures a touch smoky. ("Native Americans felt horror that white people would take peyote with no elders present, no one to clear the air or protect the souls from invasions by those spirits who do not wish us well.") And generally, the use of myth to make points in political argument strikes me as no favor either to myth or to politics.
The book ends with a charming telling of a great story from Sweden, the "Lind Wurm": When the queen is delivered of a tiny snake, as her first offspring, the midwife throws it out the window, with momentous consequences. Typically, Mr. Bly reduces a rich tale to fit his by now predictable litany: "Because of 'downsizing,' parental neglect and bad schools, almost every member of Generation X, or the Day-Care Generation, feels thrown out the window."
No, don't throw his book out the window. At least read the fairy tales. "The Sibling Society" is by turns engaging and exasperating, suggestive and tendentious, a mix of imagination, scholarship and remarkable silliness. Although he announces, in his take-no-prisoners way, "Television is the thalidomide of the 1990's," I wouldn't be surprised if Mr. Bly showed up on PBS again soon.

HEADLINE: A New View On Training Food Experts

BYLINE: By MARIAN BURROS 

 BODY:
FOR years, the study of food, often narrowly defined as home economics, has been something of a backwater.
That may change this fall when, for the first time, all aspects of food -- from esthetics to dietetics, from anthropology to food policy -- will be gathered into a single program at New York University. It is an opportunity for the study of food to achieve the recognition it has always lacked in the academic community. 
 "Food has never been trivial, but it has been treated as trivial," said Dr. Amy Bentley, a food historian at the University of Colorado, who will run the undergraduate part of the N.Y.U. program. "Food is an emerging field in the humanities. Food was undeveloped because traditionally it was a domestic thing. History was about wars. Food now is seen as a way to study history."
For the first time, dietitians will have to learn about taste and pleasure, and chefs will have to learn about arteries and saturated fat. Bachelor's, master's and Ph.D. degrees will be offered in food studies. Undergraduates, who will be required to take half of their credits in the liberal arts, will study nutrition, restaurant management, food science, and food and society. Electives will include food photography, Chinese cuisine and catering.
The program was put together by Dr. Marion Nestle, the chairwoman of the Department of Nutrition and Food Studies at N.Y.U. "Food is such an important part of society, social life, culture and history," she said. "Home economics has always had a second-class reputation, largely because it was a woman's field, but it was the only option available to women interested in science. All that has now changed."
Julia Child, who has often referred to dietitians as nutritional terrorists, is delighted. "If one can major in photography, the dance, physical education, medicine and architecture, one should certainly be offered the same opportunities in food," she said. "For years, anything to do with food was considered purely artisanal. However, during the last 20 years or so it is being recognized as a real and important part of culture in general, involving not only the culinary arts, but sociology, economics and history. The vast subject of human nutrition alone gives it a very real and vital importance in our world today."
"Besides," she added, "you can eat your work."
Dr. Nestle said a number of chefs had already applied to the school to earn a master's degree. "We are designing just exactly the program we all wish we could have taken," she added.
The idea for the food-studies program has been marinating for a number of years. Dr. Nestle was one of the first scientists to reach across the great divide that separates nutritionists, culinarians and cultural historians. She has a doctorate in molecular biology and a master's in pubic health and was once an associate dean at the University of California School of Medicine and later the managing editor of the Surgeon General's Report on Nutrition and Health.
A frequent participant in conferences run by Oldways Preservation and Exchange Trust, a culinary organization that brings together historians, anthropologists and chefs, Dr. Nestle has had lots of opportunities to talk with people who look at food in different ways: as a pleasurable phenomenon (chefs and food writers) and from a historical and cultural perspective (academicians). "I realized how interesting food was as a way to look at society, economics and industry," she said. "And I realized you didn't have to have two completely separate cuisines: one that tasted good and the other that was healthy."
But it was Dr. Nestle's chance meeting with Clark Wolf, a food consultant in New York, that crystallized her experiences. On a 70-block walk from the Upper East Side to Greenwich Village about a year ago, they began to plot. Both agreed the time was ripe to go beyond occasional meetings of the various food factions. Dr. Nestle asked Mr. Wolf to be the chairman of the Food Studies' Advisory Committee, which helped determine what areas of study should be offered.
"It took me 15 years to learn these things on my own," said Mr. Wolf, who started out as food retailer. "In the food-studies program you are having them handed to you on a silver platter."
In most colleges and universities, these elements are not tied together, although they might be available. It would be possible for a student at Cornell University, for example, to search out the courses in various departments and put together such a program. At the Culinary Institute of America, similar courses are offered, but the emphasis is on cooking. At Boston University there is a master's program in gastronomy, but it has no cooking component.
Not everyone is as excited about the food-studies program as Dr. Nestle or Mrs. Child. Although she praises the program's concept, Alice Waters, the owner of Chez Panisse in Berkeley, Calif., often described as the mother of modern American cooking, is disappointed with what she sees as a serious gap. "The program needs real emphasis on the agriculture side," she said. "The students should have to go out and grow tomatoes and harvest potatoes."
Dr. Joan Gussow, professor emerita of nutrition at Teachers College at Columbia University, who has emphasized the connection between what people eat, who they are and how they treat their environment, said that she wished she could have taught interdisciplinary courses but that food had generally been viewed in a much more segmented way.
"My biggest misgiving is about jobs," she said. "At this time, education is training: you teach what the market wants."
A similar concern was raised by Dr. John Sutthie, a professor of biochemistry and nutritional sciences at the University of Wisconsin in Madison. While acknowledging that nutrition scientists lack an appreciation of the importance of the taste of food, he said: "It's difficult for me to get enthused about the program. Interdisciplinary is a big buzzword among administrators, and the people who are trained that way are trained to do nothing."
In setting up the program, Dr. Nestle and her advisory committee compiled a list of entry-level jobs that might be available to a graduate with a degree in food studies. They include food writer, stylist or photographer; caterer or cook; research assistant or test-kitchen assistant; food consultant, product developer and broker, and food and beverage assistant.
But will this make people eat better? "It's a great idea for the next generation of food people to be more responsible," said Paula Wolfert, the cookbook author. But she doubts that even better-educated professionals will make the public more aware of food's complex contributions to culture, society and personal nutrition. "I don't think it will make that much difference. Nothing has so far. Most of the country doesn't pay any attention. I don't know how to change it, but I don't think a course at N.Y.U. is going to make any difference."
Others believe the time has come for the creation of such a program. Dr. Harvey Levenstein, a professor of history at McMaster University in Hamilton, Ontario, whose speciality is food history, said that training is often too narrow.
"People who do the science of food have a tendency to ignore the sociological context," he said. "They downplay the kinds of things that can't be measured and shortchange the importance of nonmeasurable factors in human food like choice and taste. And the people involved in the preparation and selling of food tend to be ignorant of and downplay the health and scientific aspects. It's not a bad thing to get them together, along with historians. It's a step in the right direction."
Dr. Adam Drewnowski, the director of the human nutrition program at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor, where epidemiology has been emphasized, said it was time for people to understand all facets of food.
"In the past we've dealt with food as fuel, and we should be dealing with it as our connection to culture and to land," he said. "The interaction between anthropologists, archeologists and nutritionists is finding a home. Nutrition has become respectable because it is a major tool of chronic-disease prevention. But the issue of pleasure and enjoyment has been very much understudied. A good diet needs to do wonders for physical health and mental health."

HEADLINE: New Windows on a New World;
A Jazzy Decor for Dining in the Sky

BYLINE: By PAUL GOLDBERGER 

 BODY:
CAN a meteor, once it hits the ground, soar again? That is the question posed by the reopening of Windows on the World next week, as the restaurant that became the emblem of New York City's revival in the late 1970's, and then went into decline itself, tries to take off all over again.
This time it is costing $25 million, not the $7.5 million it took to do Windows the first time. That is a lot of money, considering that the site is the same, the 107th floor of the north tower of the World Trade Center, and much of the infrastructure, like parts of the kitchens and bathrooms, has been carried over from the original Windows. But almost everything the public will see now is completely new and different in myriad ways from what was created in 1976, when the first Windows on the World brought its sleek, glitzy presence to the top of the trade center. 
 The success of that restaurant, opening at the top of New York's most disliked building toward the end of one of the city's most painful recessions, stunned everyone except its creator, Joseph Baum. But when Windows became both a mega-tourist attraction and a destination for New Yorkers who rarely ventured below 14th Street, it seemed to symbolize the change in the city's fortunes.
But as things turned upward for New York in the 1980's, they declined for Windows, which faded as Mr. Baum moved on to other projects, like his restaurant Aurora and his restoration of the Rainbow Room atop 30 Rockefeller Plaza. After the World Trade Center bombing in 1993, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the building's owner, chose to invite proposals for the restaurant's renovation, rather than reopen it along with the rest of the building. Numerous restaurateurs competed, but Mr. Baum and his associates, David Emil, Michael Whiteman and Dennis Sweeney, won the Port Authority's heart with a promise to create something that would be as much a badge of the 1990's as the original Windows had been to the 1970's. At first, the intention was to re-use as much as possible of the original design. Then the discovery of asbestos, not to mention the gradually inflating ambitions that also affect every homeowner who has ever renovated so much as a kitchen, turned the project into an all-but-new restaurant.
And that is the sumptuous, jazzy and yet relaxed Windows that will open to the public next week. It was designed by Hugh Hardy of Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer Associates, the same architect who restored the Rainbow Room in 1987, but this project was more daunting: Windows, which includes a main dining room, a huge bar, reception areas and private banquet rooms on the 106th and 107th floors, not only is vastly bigger than the Rainbow Room, but also has nothing like the admired Art Deco details that provided the architect with a starting point for that design. The banal World Trade Center offers only views, not architecture, and as for Warren Platner's original Windows design, it seemed neither fresh enough to provide direct inspiration nor strong enough to be the stuff of historic preservation.
It did, however, offer a general layout that Mr. Hardy retained: the main dining room, reduced from 250 to 240 seats, fills the northeast corner, with a view to the midtown skyline; a huge bar occupies the southeast corner, and private banquet rooms are strung along the west. The theme of the new design, if there is one, is a kind of generalized fantasy about dining in the sky, which in Mr. Hardy's hands translates into an architectural riff about cities, about urban energy, about the pleasures of texture and color and light, and about recollections of American design from the 1950's and 1960's.
Not that the new Windows is a period piece; far from it. But there is a certain slightly arch tone of homage to the 1950's in some details, like furniture in the bar that recalls the work of the designer Vladimir Kagan and the swooping forms of the green and natural-stain wood veneer and undulating ceilings in the 107th floor banquet areas: the 50's rendered a bit thinner, a bit sleeker and more nimble, as if they had been boiled down to their purest essence.
This is not classical elegance, and it is not Art Moderne or modern or much of anything else easily characterized. The new Windows on the World is a kind of architectural jazz, full of syncopation, its essence a series of allusions to design themes that are played out in a lighthearted yet never too whimsical way: swoops and curves and angular, origami-like surfaces; striped multicolor fabrics on the walls and carpets, with patterns imprinting the street plan of world cities. None of it would seem to work together, but by and large it does, in part because the colors are almost invariably soft and easy, and the juxtapositions subtle and painstakingly wrought.
The bland architecture of the trade center, not grand luxe and not even good modernism, still creates a dull first impression (there is not even a sign outside with the designer Milton Glaser's stunning logo). It gets better off the express elevators at the 107th floor, where visitors tumble out into a lobby that hides the view (deliberately, since on this huge floor the windows are just too far away from the elevators) and sets the tone of fantasy with a huge mural of floating clouds by Mr. Glaser. The mural is duplicated in a layer of glass beads that hang before it, and changing lights allow the mood to shift from crisp to feathery soft.
If the whole place is a kind of jazz symphony, the bar is where Mr. Hardy becomes the most syncopated. Different both conceptually and architecturally from what was at Windows before, it is a sprawling, informal mix of alcoves, banquettes, bars, platforms, nooks, dance floors and performance areas, immodestly named the Greatest Bar on Earth. The furniture, designed by Mr. Hardy (which I saw before it was placed in the space), is colorful, quirky and comfortable, and the space is designed to be part discotheque, part piano bar and part informal dining area, casually sliding during the evening from one identity to another.
If Windows on the World came to be known, particularly in its later years, as a place populated largely by tourists who came for the view, this room is intended as an attempt to bring back the locals. It's not exactly the TriBeCa Grill, but in its somewhat self-conscious casualness it is a lot more downtown in feeling than anything else that has ever been on the 107th floor.
The main dining room is more august, more formal, than the bar, and yet calmer and more relaxed than it was in Mr. Platner's day. Hugh Hardy has made a room that is grand and surprisingly sensuous, with soft textures and just the right amount of whimsy. The colors (but for a wonderful green carpet) are relatively calm, almost neutral, deferring to the extraordinary view, to the intense yellow and blue of Milton Glaser's gloriously spirited plates and to the colors of flowers, food and people that will occupy the tables.
Yet, this is hardly a plain design: there are sections of the ceiling that are folded in and out like origami or twisted versions of geodesic domes; frequent level changes break up the space and increase a sense of closeness to the views. But the overall feeling is one of ease, space and softness without much hauteur.
The ceilings and the floor coverings -- and the furniture -- are invariably the most striking things here: the walls are there for the views. If anything, Mr. Hardy has worked to bring people even closer to the views, removing brass rails near the windows and the pointless half-round columns that Mr. Platner inserted in the mullions between windows in the hope that they would soften the room. There is less effort to deny the architecture of the trade center than there was in 1976 -- a sense that these 20 years have made for some mellowing, and a willingness to go with this foolish building, rather than against it.
And the view itself -- this, too, has mellowed after 20 years. It has changed considerably, growing denser in these two decades; when the first Windows on the World opened, there was no Battery Park City, no World Financial Center, no midtown made more crowded by 1980's overbuilding. There is more to see out these windows now.
But the really striking thing is how this view no longer startles in the same way. When the first Windows was new, it felt like looking at the city from an airplane, almost too high to be real, and you could not take your face away from the glass. Now, this view has been around a while, and the great joy of this new restaurant is not just to look outside, but to turn back inside and take pleasure in the comfort of what has been designed within.
 
Time for a $19.96 Lunch
 
NY96, the summer restaurant promotion, starts Friday and Saturday, with 232 restaurants around New York City serving small plates of food for $3 to $5 each to benefit hunger relief programs run by City Harvest and Citymeals-on-Wheels.
The weekend events will be followed by Restaurant Week, which officially starts Monday and will run through June 30. Restaurants will offer prix-fixe lunches for $19.96, plus beverages, tax and gratuities.
Despite the promotional hoopla, including a tower of 4,000 H & H bagels to be built Friday at Wall and Broad Streets, 50 fewer restaurants will participate Friday and Saturday. And Restaurant Week, which grew from 25 participants in 1992, the year it began, to 125 last year, will have 106 this year.
"I don't get a feeling it has become less popular," said Alan Stillman, who is a member of the event's steering committee, with Joseph Baum and Danny Meyer, restaurateurs, and Tim Zagat, the restaurant guide publisher. "From the standpoint of public perception, I think it has grown. Perhaps more restaurants are doing well and don't feel they need to join the program."
Each restaurant pays $1,500 to participate. Some restaurants are offering $19.96 lunches without joining the promotion.
Though it began as a benefit for visitors to the city during the Democratic National Convention in 1992, New Yorkers, not tourists, are the ones who have taken advantage of the bargain meals.
The majority of participating restaurants plan to continue serving three-course prix-fixe lunches through Labor Day. At some the lunch promotion is available all year.
A list of the restaurants may be had by sending a stamped, self-addressed envelope to N.Y.C. Restaurants, New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, 2 Columbus Circle, New York 10019. They can also be picked up at the bureau.

HEADLINE: Security Myth Surrounds F.B.I. and Its Files

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It is legitimate to question whether the White House had a proper purpose in asking the Federal Bureau of Investigation for several hundred investigative files (editorial, June 17), but the case raises other basic questions, too.
 Should the F.B.I. be in the business of personnel investigations in the first place? It conducts these inquiries (as distinguished from criminal investigations) in numerous contexts for various agencies. It would make sense to turn them over to the Office of Personnel Management, which now conducts many security-type investigations of civilian agency personnel. 
 Of course, any investigation that developed information relating to criminal or subversive activity would be referred to the F.B.I. But the aura and mythology surrounding the bureau and its files evoke a much more hysterical and emotional reaction than would be the case if the files were developed by another agency. And decoupling personnel investigations from the F.B.I.'s high-profile law enforcement functions would allow more proportionate public consideration of episodes like the White House affair.
How useful are the personnel checks anyway? Are they worth the many hundreds of millions of dollars we spend on the investigations, the evaluations, the supporting personnel and the complex procedures for their care and feeding?
Thirty years ago, I did a study of the Atomic Energy Commission's vaunted Q-clearance program, which looked for such information as subversive propensities as well as drug or alcohol abuse, poor credit and, in those days, homosexual conduct or tendencies. Of the 717,000 full field investigations, mostly by the F.B.I., for Q-clearance from 1947 to 1963, incredibly only about 1 percent yielded any significant derogatory information at all.
My figures have never been challenged and, to the best of my knowledge, no one has produced more recent data. But even the most thorough F.B.I. investigation can't dredge up more than a small fraction of the individual's background. Even if it weeds out relatively few people, the system creates a false sense of security if it leads us to believe all is well because the Government has hired, or given White House passes to, only those who are certifiably pure based on F.B.I. inquiry.
It is the very existence of millions of dossiers in the F.B.I.'s hands that is the real threat. The utility of the routine investigations that produce these dossiers, especially in light of the end of the cold war, should be reconsidered. We should use the current episode to pierce the mythology of security and take a realistic view of what we need and how we can get it effectively, economically and efficiently.
 
HAROLD P. GREEN
Boca Raton, Fla., June 18, 1996
 
The writer is professor emeritus of law, George Washington University.

HEADLINE: In Mexico, Pain Relief Is a Medical and Political Issue

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, June 18

 BODY:
Everyone in the building knew that the old woman in the first-floor apartment was suffering unspeakable pain. Her screams echoed through the lobby day and night.
The woman, Maria Teresa Nogueda de Acevedo, was dying of lung cancer. The strongest pain killer she could get, Demerol, reduced the awful hurt for a few hours, but when the drug wore off, the pain flooded back. A doctor recommended morphine, but in Mexico it was almost impossible to get. 
 A woman who lived on the eighth floor of the building, a local radio journalist, was so shaken by the screams that she called the Mexican Secretary of Health and demanded he do something. She nagged him on her daily radio program. Finally, the official allowed Mrs. Nogueda's family to bring in morphine from the United States.
She died peacefully a few days later.
That was in August 1990. And even though the Government signed an international agreement to make morphine widely available for medical uses the month before Mrs. Nogueda died, most cancer patients in Mexico except the rich and the well-connected still cannot get the drug, which the World Health Organization has recognized as essential for alleviating chronic pain.
In the West in recent years, doctors have increasingly recognized the importance of aggressively treating pain as part of medical care, and that even powerful narcotics like morphine do not cause long-term addiction problems in most patients.
But in Mexico and many other parts of Latin America, unfounded fears of addiction and the inadequate training of young doctors about medical uses of morphine have meant that it is not readily available, leaving thousands of people to suffer needlessly. Although morphine is not considered expensive, it is used so sparingly in Mexico and the rest of Latin America that the region accounts for only about 1 percent of all the morphine consumed in the world.
There is another important factor limiting the medical use of powerful drugs in Mexico: the worry here that the United States will oppose any attempt to increase the availablility of morphine because it could find its way into the illicit market.
That fear, justified or not, has made Mexican regulators sensitive to signals from Washington about the use of morphine. One doctor even charges that the United States Drug Enforcement Administration has interfered in legitimate drug shipments to Mexico.
Dr. Juan Ignacio Romero, who headed the World Health Organization's Cancer Pain Relief Program in Mexico from 1988 to 1990, said that in 1988, the D.E.A. scuttled a plan to import about 10,000 tablets of a narcotic called Dilaudid. The drug, like morphine, is made from the gum of opium poppies.
"They were afraid we would not be able to control the morphine and that it would end up on the black market in the United States," Dr. Romero said. "That's an insult."
No one at the American drug agency could remember the incident, D.E.A. officials said.
Eventually Dr. Romero, with the help of the World Health Organization, a United Nations agency, managed to import about 20 pounds of morphine -- enough for about 650,000 morphine tablets. That represented practically all the morphine used in Mexico from 1987 to 1995.
Current regulations on the use and distribution of narcotics are so restrictive that even Dr. Francisco Higuera, the Mexican Government's chief medical regulator, acknowledges that the system forces most doctors to use Demerol and other pain killers that are less effective than morphine but easier to get.
No matter where they practice, doctors have to come to Mexico City to get special prescription booklets to prescribe morphine. The maximum allowable dosage is usually less than what patients need, and the process has to be repeated every month.
If a patient manages to get a prescription, having it filled is nearly impossible. Most pharmacies do not have the security measures or the university-trained pharmacist that the Government requires.
The National Cancer Institute is almost alone in regularly administering morphine, but most Mexicans outside the largest cities do not have access to the institute's programs. And some here fear that the problem goes unresolved because well-connected people who would have the power to demand change simply fly to Houston for medical attention.
Morphine first came to Mexico in a substantial way during World War II, when the United States encouraged the growth of opium poppies to replace Asian sources shut off by the war. Traffickers still clandestinely cultivate poppy plantations, especially in the states of Guerrero and Chihuahua, where local Indians are enticed or forced to enter the trade.
Scientific studies in the 1940's and 1950's suggested that the medical use of morphine could lead to addiction. But later studies have uniformly shown that the chance of addiction is minuscule, and that the good derived from easing a patient's pain can far outweigh the risk.
Nonetheless, Helen Carvell, a nurse investigator at the National Cancer Institute, said she had given a speech on pain relief at a symposium in December and asked which of the 100 Mexican doctors there had ever prescribed morphine.
Not one hand went up.
"Part of the problem here is the myth," Mrs. Carvell said. "It says that if you are anywhere near the smell of narcotics and something goes wrong, you'll end up in jail."
Dr. Charles Cleeland, director of the Pain Research Group at the University of Wisconsin Medical School and an ardent supporter of the use of morphine for pain, said many American drug companies refused to export morphine to countries like Mexico because they fear it will be diverted to illegal street use.
In December, Mexico finally certified one laboratory, Technofarma, to produce a morphine tablet. Camerino Figueroa Lara, director of sales for Technofarma, said the Mexico City company could produce enough tablets to meet national demand.
But he would not say how many tablets were being sold.
Health officials say they are considering ways to ease restrictions and make morphine more widely available. That could go a long way toward fulfilling the agreement Mexico signed in 1990, but Dr. Silvia Allende Perez, director of the pain clinic at the National Cancer Institute, doubts that the Government has the will to make such changes.
"Countries like Spain and Japan have increased their use of medicinal morphine without any increase in illicit use, and Mexico could do the same," Dr. Allende Perez said. Even Colombia has managed to make morphine more available in recent years without any noticeable change in illicit use.
"But Mexican bureaucrats would rather just restrict the use of morphine altogether and avoid problems," she said. "That means that as always, it is the patients who need the drug who have to be sacrificed."
