HEADLINE: Yeltsin's Edge: Fear of the Past

BYLINE: By Richard Pipes; Richard Pipes, professor emeritus of history at Harvard, is the author of "A Concise History of the Russian Revolution."

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
The world can sigh in relief. Sunday's Russian elections did not reproduce the experience of December 1993, when the party of the chauvinist and anti-Semite Vladimir Zhirinovsky received the largest number of votes for parliament, nor that of December 1995, when the Communists won a plurality. This time, Boris Yeltsin outmaneuvered his opponents.
Employing modern campaign techniques and making the most of his control of television, Mr. Yeltsin succeeded in gaining a slender but incontestable edge. He skillfully confronted voters with a stark alternative: either a return to the past or progress toward the future. 
 As a Russian friend of mine put it, the contest was not over personalities or programs. It was a clash of two emotions: fear and hatred -- fear of losing freedom and hatred of the West. As of now, it appears that fear, and hope, have prevailed.
Mr. Yeltsin's victory was in good measure the result of divisions within the Communist camp. The hard core of the Communist Party is made up of unregenerate Leninist-Stalinists who will be satisfied with nothing less than a return to the old ways in both domestic and foreign policy. Judging by some of his pronouncements, its leader, Gennadi Zyuganov, apparently shares this vision. But aware that a reactionary platform would alienate many voters, he formulated a more moderate program, modeled on Western social democracy.
Mr. Zyuganov's agenda might have enabled him to defeat Mr. Yeltsin had it not been sabotaged by Communist hard-liners who, confident of victory, dismissed it as the party's "program minimum," a cover for its true long-term objective, the "program maximum," restoring full-fledged Communism.
Undoubtedly, the voters' reasonable suspicion that it was the hard-liners who articulated the real goals of the party caused mass defections to Mr. Yeltsin and the dark horse candidate, retired Gen. Aleksandr Lebed, who came out of nowhere to win half as many votes as each of the two leading contenders.
Mr. Lebed, who quit the armed forces a year ago with a reputation of a tough nationalist, shifted toward a more centrist position. He now stresses the need to restore law and order, a very popular slogan. He scorns Communism and supports small private enterprise.
His strength, however, lies not in the promises he makes but in the personal image he projects, which is that of a doer, not a talker. The very act of speaking appears painful to him, since the movement of his lips is unaccompanied by any changes in the facial muscles.
In his new capacity as head of Mr. Yeltsin's Security Council (which deals with both foreign and domestic issues), he will be in a position to tackle bureaucratization, corruption and crime, the prevalence of which in post-Communist Russia has done a great deal to discredit both democracy and capitalism.
He is superbly positioned to step forward as Mr. Yeltsin's replacement should the President, for reasons of health, find himself unable to carry out his duties. Mr. Lebed represents for some Russians a version of Gen. Augusto Pinochet of Chile, who combined harsh political authority with economic liberalism and a certain measure of intellectual freedom. Mr. Lebed himself has referred to General Pinochet with admiration.
It is likely that Mr. Yeltsin will carry the day in the runoff election because he should be able to attract the votes cast for other pro-reform candidates as well as much of the Lebed constituency, whereas Mr. Zyuganov can at best attract the rather insignificant Zhirinovsky vote. It matters a great deal that Mr. Yeltsin not only win in July but that he win with a solid majority. If his margin is narrow, he will have to shift still further to the right, slowing economic and legal reforms and assuming a defiant attitude toward the West.
But even as one feels relief that Russians have moved away from the extremists, there is cause for worry. Russia appears fairly evenly split between two groups that have little in common and therefore will have difficulty developing a viable political system. One group, with a preponderance of the aged and the less skilled, including a high proportion of farmers, sees democracy as synonymous with crime and capitalism as merely a license to rob the poor. The other, younger, better educated voters like the opportunities that democracy and capitalism provide. The former yearn, first and foremost, for security; the latter are prepared to forgo security for the chance to better themselves.
Moreover, the Communists and nationalists are determined to bring the former Soviet republics back into the fold by force, while the democratic coalition, although not entirely free of nostalgia for the imperial past, is unwilling to jeopardize Russia's reconstruction and foreign connections for the sake of territorial aggrandizement. The differences bode ill for democracy, which requires the voters to share certain basic values. Mr. Yeltsin's alliance with Mr. Lebed may be interpreted as an effort to bridge the gap.
Viewed in broad perspective, Russia seems to be moving toward a fusion of liberalism and conservatism. We cannot tell at this time whether such an uneasy ideological pairing will last.
Personalities, too, are likely to play a part. As Mr. Lebed's handling of some officers' opposition to the dismissal of Defense Minister Pavel Grachev has shown, he is not a man to take the back seat or to show sensitivity for those who disagree with him.
But as of now, the cause of democracy appears strengthened, and the prospects for a restoration of Communism dimmer than ever.

HEADLINE: Something Must Be Done

BYLINE: By Richard C. Leone; Richard C. Leone is the president of the Twentieth Century Fund.

 BODY:
Confused? You are not alone. Here's what the experts (sometimes the same one) think.
We must have 6 percent or so unemployment to avoid high inflation, but everyone should be required to work, especially welfare recipients and, soon, people over 65. 
 The rich need more money to encourage them to work harder (as in lower capital gains taxes), but the poor need less (as in a lower earned income tax credit).
We must reduce the trade deficit but also cut the gas tax, thus encouraging consumption of the single largest American import.
The nation had very high rates of growth and savings when top tax rates were very high -- more than 90 percent -- but now we have neither because tax rates are too high.
The overwhelming majority of parents think that their public schools do a good job, but we need to dismantle and privatize the system.
The coming election is about the economic fears of middle-class white men, so unless a candidate has a pro-choice position on abortion, he loses.
Social Security, for the first time in history, is accumulating a substantial surplus in its trust fund, but it is on the verge of collapse.
The Federal Aviation Administration should be abolished in the interest of more deregulation, but why isn't it doing more inspections of new low-cost airlines?
White Americans rank first in the world in longevity, knowledge and income; black Americans rank 31st. But we no longer need affirmative action.
China had a $34 billion trade surplus with the United States in 1995, but we should stop nagging Beijing about human rights or it won't trade with us.
The media get everything wrong and are ruining family values. But we're in trouble because nobody reads or watches the news anymore.

HEADLINE: Spared by Washington's Budget Cutting, Research Universities Still Fear the Ax

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

 BODY:
While Congress in recent weeks has spared leading universities from major cuts in Federal financing for research, those institutions say they increasingly fear that the estimated $13 billion a year they receive from the Government will become a target for reductions in the future.
As a result, the universities have been lobbying Congress to protect their financing, while looking for other sources of money and re-examining the scale of their research efforts. 
 In November the Massachusetts Institute of Technology wooed Congress by releasing a study detailing how its research benefited the nation. That study calculated that the licensing of M.I.T. inventions added more than $20 billion and 150,000 jobs to the economy every year.
Harvard University has taken another approach, streamlining the administration of its research operations, while seeking more support from industry and foundations.
University leaders say the private sector is no substitute for Federal support. Although a few relatively small institutions like Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh have been extremely successful in attracting corporate sponsors, the giants, like Johns Hopkins University, the nation's largest recipient of Federal financial support, have been much less so.
Despite stepped-up efforts to attract corporate sponsorship throughout the 1990's, Johns Hopkins drew less from that source last year, nearly $13 million, than it received in 1993, when it obtained more than $15 million. Moreover, the annual totals were scarcely a drop in the bucket for Johns Hopkins, which received nearly $1 billion from the Government last year.
Dr. Daniel Nathans, the interim president, said corporate support for research would never significantly replace the loss of Federal money for an institution like Johns Hopkins, because "it is so different in magnitude and is usually limited to developing specific products."
Research budgets at the top 125 universities have grown virtually unchecked since the early 1950's, when the Government began investing heavily in pure research and research with practical applications. Both categories have generated undoubted, and sometimes unimagined, benefits.
For example, federally sponsored research on heart valves undertaken as a curiosity at the University of California at Berkeley in the early 1970's, led to the development of the inkjet printer a decade later at the I.B.M. Almaden Research Center in Almaden, Calif.
Federally financed research on data compression at the Lincoln Laboratory of M.I.T. in the early 1950's led to the development of the CD player in the early 1980's.
If the Government cuts support for such research, university leaders fear, the United States could have to rely on other countries for innovations in areas like magnetic fusion, biomedical equipment and electric automobiles.
"I'm very nervous," said Charles Vest, president of M.I.T., who has become the unofficial spokesman for the universities. "It looks as if we've done all right this year. But when Congress tries to balance the budget over the next six or seven years, research is likely to be cut so severely that it may compromise America's competitiveness and position as a world leader in innovation."
The fears have been fueled partly because of the widespread perception that all discretionary spending by Congress will be in jeopardy and partly for philosophical reasons.
At the Senate Republican Conference on Science and Technology in March, Senator Ted Stevens, the Alaska Republican who heads the subcommittee on military appropriations, told more than 20 university presidents that unless Congress and the Administration reached an agreement to insure long-term annual savings there would be no discretionary spending whatsoever by 2010. That could virtually wipe out Federal support for university-based research, he said.
Other legislators like Representative Robert S. Walker, the Pennsylvania Republican who heads the House Science Committee, want to reduce Federal research grants because they have a philosophical commitment to make private industry assume some burdens from the Federal Government.
"We can't go on as we have been," Mr. Walker said. "I'm very strong on the Government's being a major player in scientific research for defense. But in the future, the private sector must take over applied research and product development. That's not the Government's business."
Earlier this year, Congress was threatening to slash the budgets of the National Institutes of Health and the National Science Foundation, which dispense large shares of the Federal money to research institutions. But in January Congressional leaders agreed to increase the 1996 budget of the institutes by 5.7 percent and, more recently, to finance the full budget for the science agency.
Sometimes the expenditures on science and technology are easier to justify than others. For example, Representative John Edward Porter, a Republican from suburban Chicago who heads the House Subcommittee on Labor, Health and Education, had a relatively easy time securing the 5.7 percent increase for the National Institutes of Health this year.
"All the costs of N.I.H. over its 50-year history were paid for by the health-cost savings of just one of its projects, the development of the Salk vaccine," Mr. Porter said.
On the other hand, Representative Jerry Lewis, the California Republican who heads the House subcommittee responsible for the National Science Foundation budget and is also a strong proponent of research, has a much harder time persuading his colleagues that fields like astrophysics, molecular biology and plasma physics are worthy of public support.
In 1994 the largest recipient of Federal funding was Johns Hopkins with $613 million, followed by the University of Washington with $276 million and M.I.T. with $267 million.
Among the most successful in obtaining corporate assistance has been Carnegie Mellon, which receives $40 million a year, or a quarter of its total research budget, from non-Federal sources. And the amount is growing, said Robert Mehrabian, president of the university.
But some researchers fear that a reliance on sponsorships from highly competitive businesses could inhibit the free exchange of information and weaken support for projects not likely to pay off commercially.
Mr. Mehrabian acknowledged that the proprietary interests of corporate sponsors could conflict with a university's ideals.
"We have to be careful in what we accept," he said. "We wouldn't agree to develop a specific drug for a pharmaceutical company. But if they were interested in the next generation of computing technology to predict the structure of a molecule we could go along with that. In general, we have to work on generic problems."
Ultimately, the solution may lie in the creation of an independent financing agency for science and technology. Senator Mark O. Hatfield, the Oregon Republican who heads the Senate Appropriations Committee, said that before he retired at the end of the year he hoped to lead Congress to create a medical research trust fund that would draw on a combination of public and private revenue to give $5 billion a year to the N.I.H. Such a fund could become a model for Federal support for research.
Congressional staff members say the idea, even considering Mr. Hatfield's influence as a committee chairman, is unlikely to be adopted this year. On the other hand a university lobbyist asked, "Do we really have to wait for another Sputnik?"

HEADLINE: Turnaround by the F.A.A.

 BODY:
The Federal Aviation Administration's belated decision to ground Valujet Airlines as a safety hazard amounts to an admission of how wrong-headed the agency had been in its previous efforts to regulate the troubled low-cost airline. Five weeks ago the F.A.A. Administrator, David Hinson, and Transportation Secretary Federico Pena rashly assured the public that Valujet was safe to fly one day after one of its planes crashed in the Florida Everglades. Now they have been forced to acknowledge that Valujet is not up to standards, and Mr. Hinson has acknowledged that the F.A.A.'s inspections were not adequate to assure the airworthiness of Valujet's fleet.
Both Mr. Hinson and Mr. Pena, while maintaining that their earlier statements were based on the best information then available to them, have at last taken the first necessary steps toward mending the F.A.A.'s ways and insuring the safety of the flying public. 
 Even before the May 11 crash the F.A.A. had catalogued a spate of Valujet mishaps, none causing fatalities, that added up to an accident rate well above the industry's average. Federal investigations turned up maintenance and other problems, but the F.A.A. judged them not serious enough to ground the airline. Yet now, over the five weeks since the crash, investigators have exposed maintenance problems so severe that the F.A.A. no longer regards Valujet as safe to fly. The obvious question, which Congress will no doubt pose when it opens hearings next week, is why the pre-crash investigations failed to uncover the severity of the problems.
Mr. Hinson admitted yesterday that F.A.A. inspections do not adequately track carriers that contract out most of their maintenance to outside companies. He pledged to correct the weakness. For his part, Secretary Pena will go to Congress to ask for a change in the F.A.A.'s mission so that it is responsible only for safety and not the economic health of the carriers. This is a crucial reform that will relieve the agency of its divided loyalties between the carriers and the public and increase the credibility of its declarations.
Mr. Hinson also, in effect, dismissed his chief safety official, Anthony Broderick, though Congress may want to check whether Mr. Broderick has been scapegoated to take the heat off the rest of the organization. Congress should also inquire whether, as many outside experts have determined, the F.A.A. needs additional inspectors.
Valujet announced yesterday its intention to return to the air next month. But for that to happen, the F.A.A. must first spruce up its inspection procedures so that unsafe practices never again go undetected or uncorrected.
Last month's crash is still under investigation, and its cause is not yet definitely known. Yet the crash exposed serious problems in both the F.A.A. and Valujet. Yesterday the F.A.A. took the first curative steps. Whether Valujet follows suit will determine whether it ever flies again.

HEADLINE: A Prudent Agreement on Chinese Piracy

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration has reasonably withdrawn the threat of trade sanctions against China after Beijing renewed its commitment to stop pirating American copyrighted property. The Chinese have violated similar promises in the past, but it is worth testing their word before acting. A trade war would damage both the American and Chinese economies and poison diplomatic relations.
The Chinese agreed last year to close factories that were illegally knocking off American compact disks, computer software, movies and other copyrighted materials, but after a brief lull the violations resumed. The Administration drew up a list of targets last month for steep tariff hikes if the Chinese did not end the piracy. The threat was justified. The hard-fought political consensus for open trade would not survive if Washington tolerated contempt for fair trade rules. Because China does not belong to the World Trade Organization, the United States could not refer the dispute to an impartial jury. 
 The Administration's strategy has worked so far. Over the past few weeks the Chinese have closed 15 factories turning out illegal compact disks, confiscated machinery, prosecuted scores of individuals and shut distribution centers and theaters showing stolen movies. China also agreed to stop exporting pirated intellectual materials, promised to approve joint ventures to produce music and films and said it would maintain no quotas on imported movies, all steps urged by American entertainment companies. The Administration could not persuade the Chinese to allow American inspectors to monitor C.D. factories, but it did win agreement by China's police to enforce the accord.
The Chinese Government has found it difficult to control illegal factories, some of which are run by high-ranking military officers and other powerful officials. The threat of American sanctions may have bolstered Chinese officials who want to live by the Government's commitments. It makes sense for Mr. Clinton to wait and see which forces within the Chinese Government prevail before launching a trade war.

HEADLINE: Technology Issues Fall, With Dow Off 24.75

BYLINE: By The Associted Press 

 BODY:
Technology shares fell sharply yesterday, leading a nervous market lower, as investors grew concerned about difficult market conditions for high-technology companies.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 24.75, to 5,628.03. The blue-chip barometer held a slight gain until midafternoon, then trailed lower along with bonds as a weak report on new housing construction failed to calm worries about inflation and interest rates. 
 "The market's wallowing in indecision and lack of conviction and rapidly shifting opinions," said Eric Miller, chief strategist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities in San Francisco.
The Nasdaq composite index, which is heavy with technology stocks, tumbled 24.56, to 1,183.08, its first close below 1,200 in more than a month. Since setting a record high of 1,249.15 on June 5, the Nasdaq has slid more than 5 percent amid a series of warnings by industry leaders about market pressures squeezing profits. The Nasdaq market has been hurt by a shift in sentiment among individual investors, Mr. Miller said. "There was some suggestion last week that the flow of money into technology sector funds had tailed off," he said.
Broader measures also fell, although not as sharply as the Nasdaq composite.
The Big Board's composite index fell 1.34, to 355.58; the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 3.10, to 662.06, and the American Stock Exchange's market value index fell 1.54, to 588.99.
Declining issues outnumbered advancers by a margin of 12 to 11 on the New York Stock Exchange, where volume totaled 373.3 million shares as of 4 P.M., up considerably from Monday's sluggish pace.
Bonds initially led stocks higher after the Commerce Department reported that housing starts fell 4.7 percent, to 1.43 million, in May. Many analysts had predicted a drop only to the 1.48-million level.
But by midday, bonds started retreating and the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond -- a key determinant of corporate and consumer borrowing costs -- rose to 7.10 percent from late Monday's 7.06 percent.
Early last week, the yield jumped to a 13-month high at 7.20 percent in the aftermath of the latest in a series of robust employment reports.
Investors have been concerned about recent indications of rising payroll and wage levels, which could translate into too much consumer demand, pushing up prices. Many analysts expect the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates in early July to slow borrowing and spending.
"There's still an ambiguity to these releases," Mr. Miller said in reference to the economic reports. "They haven't had a great consistency." That picture may remain cloudy until the first week of July, when the Fed's policy makers meet and a series of key economic reports will be released, he added.
Among technology stocks on the Nasdaq, Intel slid 1 5/8, to 70 3/8; Cisco Systems fell 1 1/2, to 52 7/8, and Microsoft fell 2 1/4, to 122 3/8. In active Big Board trading, Motorola fell 1 7/8, to 62 3/8; Digital Equipment fell 1 1/2, to 44 1/8; Hewlett-Packard fell 1 3/8, to 97 5/8, and I.B.M. fell 1 1/4, to 101 1/4.
Airline stocks rose on prospects for improved business after the discount competitor Valujet agreed to temporarily halt operations. Federal regulators have made allegations of maintenance deficiencies following last month's deadly crash of a Valujet DC-9 in the Everglades.
ValuJet shares tumbled 3 1/2, to 6 1/2, but competing airlines rose, lifting the Dow Jones transportation index by more than 1 percent. Direct rivals benefited the most from the news, with Delta Air Lines adding 3 3/8, to 83 5/8; USAir gaining 3/4, to 18 3/4, and Southwest Airlines rising 1, to 28 5/8.
Shares of Lattice Semiconductor fell 8 7/8, to 25 3/8, after the company cautioned late Monday that lower prices and overstocked customer inventories were hurting sales of its programmable computer chip products. Lattice said revenue for the three months ending June 29 could be off as much as 10 percent from the $53 million in the prior quarter.
Presstek, a maker of printing technology, saw its stock fall 14, to 56, after it revised its first-quarter earnings downward. Presstek said its independent auditors had changed previous advice related to income tax benefits from the exercise of certain employee stock options.

HEADLINE: U.S. Bonds End Lower After Rally

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended lower yesterday, after failing to hold on to early gains on a housing report that showed unexpected weakness.
A decline in the dollar, higher commodity prices and caution ahead of today's Federal Reserve survey of regional business conditions helped cut short the morning bond rally. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 13/32 of a percentage point, to 86 15/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 7.10 percent, from 7.06 percent on Monday.
Bonds rallied after the Commerce Department reported that housing starts fell 4.7 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.43 million units in May. The decline, which erased a gain of 4.6 percent in April, suggested that higher mortgage rates had caught up to the housing sector and was hindering growth.
"Investors have been long awaiting the time they could find corroborating evidence that would support the notion that the current higher rates would lead to slower growth," said Anthony Chan, vice president and chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisers Corporation in Columbus, Ohio.
The data heartened market participants, he said, by indicating that it would be just a matter of time before other interest-rate sensitive sectors of the economy also begin to show weakness.
Another sign that the economy's strong pace might be slowing a bit was seen in the Johnson Redbook weekly report on retail sales, which showed a 1.3 percent decline for the first two weeks of June.
Mr. Chan said that report, as well as another weekly retail sales survey yesterday -- by the Bank of Tokyo/ Mitsubisi Schroder Wertheim -- indicated that consumption was likely to slow in the second half of the year.
Still, he noted, "one of the reasons why the market has not reacted more positively, is that it is difficult to overcome the considerable amount of cynicism that has built up in the market over the past few months."
Also restraining the market, Mr. Chan said, were comments by the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, William J. McDonough. Speaking at the Institute of Banking and Financial Service at the College of St. Rose in Albany, Mr. McDonough said, "Consumer price inflation, while up slightly during the first quarter of this year, gives no indication that it will accelerate persistently over the months ahead," Bloomberg Business News reported.
But Mr. McDonough also said that the Fed would remain vigilant on inflation, suggesting to some market participants that one or two instances of weak economic numbers might not be sufficient to put the fear of increased interest rates to rest.
Mr. Chan said, "With comments like these, credit markets are likely to focus from one number to the rest without the luxury of drawing any sustainable comfort from one or two weak economic statistics."
Traders said that despite yesterday's reports there was not much upside expected from today's Federal Reserve survey.

HEADLINE: Thomas Kuhn, 73; Devised Science Paradigm

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
Thomas S. Kuhn, whose theory of scientific revolution became a profoundly influential landmark of 20th-century intellectual history, died on Monday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 73.
Robert DiIorio, associate director of the news office at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said the scholar, who held the title of professor emeritus at M.I.T., had been ill with cancer in recent years. 
 "The Structure of Scientific Revolutions," was conceived while Professor Kuhn was a graduate student in theoretical physics and published as a monograph in the International Encyclopedia of Unified Science before the University of Chicago Press issued it as a 180-page book in 1962. The work punctured the widely held notion that scientific change was a strictly rational process.
Professor's Kuhn's treatise influenced not only scientists but also economists, historians, sociologists and philosophers, touching off considerable debate. It has sold about one million copies in 16 languages and remains required reading in many basic courses in the history and philosophy of science.
Dr. Kuhn, a professor of philosophy and history of science at M.I.T. from 1979 to 1983 and the Laurence S. Rockefeller Professor of Philosophy there from 1983 until 1991, was the author or co-author of five books and scores of articles on the philosophy and history of science. But Dr. Kuhn remained best known for "The Structure of Scientific Revolutions."
His thesis was that science was not a steady, cumulative acquisition of knowledge. Instead, he wrote, it is "a series of peaceful interludes punctuated by intellectually violent revolutions." And in those revolutions, he wrote, "one conceptual world view is replaced by another."
Thus, Einstein's theory of relativity could challenge Newton's concepts of physics. Lavoisier's discovery of oxygen could sweep away earlier ideas about phlogiston, the imaginary element believed to cause combustion. Galileo's supposed experiments with wood and lead balls dropped from the Leaning Tower of Pisa could banish the Aristotelian theory that bodies fell at a speed proportional to their weight. And Darwin's theory of natural selection could overthrow theories of a world governed by design.
Professor Kuhn argued in the book that the typical scientist was not an objective, free thinker and skeptic. Rather, he was a somewhat conservative individual who accepted what he was taught and applied his knowledge to solving the problems that came before him.
In so doing, Professor Kuhn maintained, these scientists accepted a paradigm, an archetypal solution to a problem, like Ptolemy's theory that the Sun revolves around the Earth. Generally conservative, scientists would tend to solve problems in ways that extended the scope of the paradigm.
In such periods, he maintained, scientists tend to resist research that might signal the development of a new paradigm, like the work of the astronomer Aristarchus, who theorized in the third century B.C. that the planets revolve around the Sun. But, Professor Kuhn said, situations arose that the paradigm could not account for or that contradicted it.
And then, he said, a revolutionary would appear, a Lavoisier or an Einstein, often a young scientist not indoctrinated in the accepted theories, and sweep the old paradigm away.
These revolutions, he said, came only after long periods of tradition-bound normal science. "Frameworks must be lived with and explored before they can be broken," Professor Kuhn said.
The new paradigm cannot build on the one that precedes it, he maintained. It can only supplant it. The two, he said, were "incommensurable."
Some critics said Professor Kuhn was arguing that science was little more than mob rule. He replied, "Look, I think that's nonsense, and I'm prepared to argue that."
The word paradigm appeared so frequently in Professor's Kuhn's "Structures" and with so many possible meanings prompting debate that he was credited with popularizing the word and inspiring a 1974 cartoon in The New Yorker. In it, a woman tells a man: "Dynamite, Mr. Gerston! You're the first person I ever heard use 'paradigm' in real life."
Professor Kuhn traced the origin of his thesis to a moment in 1947 when he was working toward a doctorate in physics at Harvard. James B. Conant, the chemist who was the president of the university, had asked him to teach a class in science for undergraduates majoring in the humanities. The focus was to be historical case studies.
Until then, Professor Kuhn said later, "I'd never read an old document in science." As he looked through Aristotle's "Physics" and realized how astonishingly unlike Newton's were its concepts of motion and matter, he concluded that Aristotle's physics were not "bad Newton" but simply different.
Professor Kuhn received a doctorate in physics, but not long afterward he switched to the history of science, exploring the mechanisms that lead to scientific change.
"I sweated blood and blood and blood, and finally I had a breakthrough," he said.
Thomas Samuel Kuhn, the son of Samuel L. Kuhn, an industrial engineer, and the former Annette Stroock, was born on July 18, 1922, in Cincinnati.
In 1943, he graduated summa cum laude from Harvard with a bachelor's degree in physics.
During World War II, he served as a civilian employee at Harvard and in Europe with the Office of Scientific Research and Development.
He received master's and doctoral degrees in physics from Harvard in 1946 and 1949. From 1948 to 1956, he held various posts at Harvard, rising to an assistant professorship in general education and the history of science.
He then joined the faculty of the University of California at Berkeley, where he was named a professor of history of science in 1961. In 1964, he joined the faculty at Princeton, where he was the M. Taylor Pyne Professor of Philosophy and History of Science until 1979, when he joined the faculty of M.I.T.
Professor Kuhn was a Guggenheim Fellow in 1954-55, the winner of the George Sarton Medal in the History of Science in 1982, and the holder of honorary degrees from many institutions, among them the University of Notre Dame, Columbia University, the University of Chicago, the University of Padua and the University of Athens.
He is survived by his wife, Jehane, and three children, Sarah Kuhn of Framingham, Mass., Elizabeth Kuhn of Los Angeles and Nathaniel Kuhn of Arlington, Mass.

HEADLINE: Lucille Maurer, 73, Treasurer of Maryland

 BODY:
Lucille Darvin Maurer, a Maryland legislator whose expertise in public finance led her to the post of State Treasurer, died on Monday at her home in Silver Spring. She was 73.
The cause was a brain tumor, her family said. 
 Mrs. Maurer, a Democrat, represented Montgomery County for 18 years in the House of Delegates, the lower house of the General Assembly, Maryland's legislature.
The General Assembly elected her Treasurer in 1987. Stricken by her fatal illness, she resigned in January.
Mrs. Maurer, a native of New York City, graduated in economics from the University of North Carolina and earned a master's degree in general studies at Yale.
She is survived by her husband of 51 years, Ely Maurer; three sons, Stephen B., of Swarthmore, Pa., Russell A., of Pepper Pike, Ohio, and Edward N., of Lido Beach, L.I.; a brother, Eugene Darvin of Pearl River, N.Y., and seven grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Starts of Housing Fall 4.7% As Mortgage Rates Climb

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 18

 BODY:
Builders, concerned that rising mortgage rates would choke off sales, cut the construction of new homes in May to the lowest level in five months, the Commerce Department said today.
Housing starts fell 4.7 percent, to a seasonally adjusted 1.43 million annual rate, erasing April's 4.6 percent gain. Starts were down in every region except the South, the Commerce Department said. 
 Analysts said the weaker-than-expected report suggested a moderating economy. It also eased fears that the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates next month to slow growth and prevent inflationary pressures.
"The Fed obviously is looking at this number," said David Lereah, an economist at the Mortgage Bankers Association. "This gives them cause to pause. A hike at their July 2-3 meeting is unlikely now."
Analysts noted that 30-year fixed-rate mortgages rose above 8 percent in May, more than a point above the January average. The increase means a $70 rise in the monthly payment on a $100,000 mortgage.
"Builders are saying there is some impact out there," said David F. Seiders, an economist with the National Association of Home Builders. "When they feel that way, when inventory levels are as high as they are, they cut back on starts."
The pace of new construction fell in May to its lowest point since December. As a result, Mr. Seiders said, April's 1.51 million rate "probably was the high point for the year."
Separately, the Labor Department reported that productivity rose at an annual rate of 2.1 percent in the first quarter to the highest level in more than two years.
The Labor Department report contained little sign of inflation. It said unit labor costs, typically two-thirds of the price of a product, slowed to a 1.2 percent increase, from 3.7 percent the previous three months.
But it also showed that so far many businesses were not increasing worker pay. Compensation rose at an annual rate of just one-tenth of 1 percent from January through March, when adjusted for inflation.
The Commerce Department report did not offer any hope for a rebound in housing starts in June. It said applications for building permits dropped 1.9 percent in May, to a 1.43 million rate. It was the first decline in four months.
Still, while many analysts expect starts to fall from recent peaks, they predict new construction will remain above the 1.35 million pace last year. For the first five months of the year, starts were 13.5 percent above those of the corresponding period in 1995.
Construction of single-family homes, about 80 percent of total starts, fell 5.9 percent, to a 1.13 million rate, the lowest since November.
Regionally, starts rose nine-tenths of 1 percent in the South, but fell elsewhere -- down 13.7 percent in the West, 8.8 percent in the Northeast and 3.4 percent in the Midwest.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Strong Japan Economic Data Spur Selloff of Dollars vs. Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar slumped against the Japanese yen and hit a two-month low against the German mark yesterday, weakened by news of a surprisingly strong Japanese economy.
The selling was exacerbated by signs of economic weakness in the United States as well as a rising demand for marks, reflecting a growing belief that the German central bank will not further reduce interest rates. 
 Currency traders said most of the dollar's weakness came early in the day after the Japanese Economic Planning Agency said the economy grew at an annual rate of 12.7 percent in the first quarter.
The report stunned the foreign exchange market, where traders had assumed the growth rate would be far less, in line with other evidence of a tentative recovery in Japan after a three-year-long stagnation.
The dollar fell as low as 107.60 yen before settling in New York at 107.75 yen, down from 108.98 yen on Monday and its lowest level since May 30. The dollar also traded at 1.5123 marks, down from 1.5204 marks. The British pound was unchanged at $1.5435.
Many currency traders have speculated that the dollar would continue rising against the yen, partly on the assumption that Japanese interest rates would remain at historic lows while the country's economic recovery slowly progresses.
But after the first-quarter economic report came out, traders scrambled to buy yen on the assumption that rates would soon rise.
The dollar came under more selling pressure when the Commerce Department reported May housing construction fell to the lowest level in five months. The data suggested less inflationary pressure in the United States and aroused speculation that the Federal Reserve would not raise interest rates next month.
The prospect for lower rates in Germany, meanwhile, continued to dim, helping to strengthen the mark. Edgar Meister, a member of the policy-making council of the Bundesbank, told a German audience that lower interest rates were still possible. But he also said "everything possible has been done by the Bundesbank to shepherd interest rates lower."

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
Fare Rises Seen After Shutdown By Valujet

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
Valujet's sudden shutdown this week will sharply increase fares along the routes previously flown by the low-cost carrier, according to travel agents and others who watch air fares closely.
Tom Parsons, editor of Best Fares magazine, predicted yesterday that fares could increase as much as 70 percent in Valujet's former markets, while Blake Fleetwood, owner of Planetarium Travels in New York, predicted those fares would at least double. 
 A recent Department of Transportation study, estimating that Americans saved $6.3 billion last year flying low-cost carriers, also says the low-cost carriers now compete in markets that account for almost 40 percent of domestic travelers. But because they are niche carriers, most low-cost lines have largely carved out markets that do not compete head-to-head with the major carriers, and rarely with one another.
When the big carriers do match their low-cost competitors' fares, they do so with a limited number of seats, and they require a round-trip ticket and a Saturday stay.
If not many corporate travelers flew Valujet, or fly other budget carriers, many self-employed business travelers do. So do other people who can afford the higher fares. Mr. Fleetwood cited the example of Patrick McEnroe, the tennis player, who recently flew to Chicago on short notice. "I told him I could book him round trip on United for $800, or for $200 on Kiwi," Mr. Fleetwood said. "He chose to save $600."
 
On the Road
Some 80 percent of summer vacations will be by auto or other road vehicles, according to the American Automobile Association and the Travel Industry Association of America, and the average summer vacation will cost $126 a day.
A recent round trip by auto between New York and Miami suggests that the $126 average is probably reasonable while on the road, but would require considerable belt-tightening for anyone not staying with family or friends once travelers arrived at their destination. For not only are gas prices still higher than normal, hotels and motels now cost more.
For example, a clerk at a Bass P.L.C.'s Holiday Inn Express in North Carolina sought to justify the property's surprisingly high room rate by explaining that the word "Express" -- the designation for Holiday Inn's economy brand, with rates usually 15 to 20 percent lower than its full-service properties -- referred only to the speed of checking in and checking out.
That aside, motorists should prepare to be nickeled, dimed and dollared to death in many other ways. Here are some examples:
Free road maps have long disappeared from gas stations, replaced by maps that now cost $2.25 to $5.50. (Most state welcome centers still provide them at no cost.) Free air is rapidly becoming another relic at gas stations, where the cost to inflate tires is typically 25 to 50 cents.
Many public telephones charge 25 cents for calls to those supposedly free "800" numbers, while obtaining an out-of-state telephone number can cost almost as much as the call.
A.T.M. machines are popping up everywhere from gas stations to convenience stores, charging fees of up to $3 a transaction. Even many bank A.T.M.'s routinely tack on a service fee in addition to the fee charged by the user's own bank. One enterprising A.T.M. at a bank on Georgia's St. Simons Island stipulates that it will add a fee, but doesn't say how much.
Those "tip cups" that grace counters at almost every coffee shop in metropolitan New York have spread farther afield. A bakery in Cape May, N.J., has a tip cup bedecked with a reminder, "Your tips are precious." A sign atop the cash register of a Kettle Restaurant pancake house restaurant in Jacksonville, N.C., asks customers not only to tip but also to "please give a generous tip."
In addition, the free "Continental breakfast" ballyhooed by motels often amounts to a cup of weak coffee with powdered milk and doughnut. On the plus side, however, many roadside restaurants that feature buffets no longer proclaim "All you can eat," which is often an invitation to waste and gluttony, but say instead, "All you care to eat."
On the other hand, asked why a Shoney's Restaurant in Myrtle Beach, S.C., served 10 fried shrimp when the menu promised a dozen, an apologetic employee said that it was the policy recently decreed by the regional office. A spokeswoman for Nashville-based Shoney's denied any such policy, saying it was simply an "honest mistake or misunderstanding" by one of the company's many employees.

HEADLINE: Albany Democrats Offer Welfare Plan

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 18

 BODY:
The Democrat-controlled State Assembly released a welfare plan today that would impose time limits on all cash benefits, but would continue to provide extensive services for recipients unable to find jobs.
The plan came under immediate attack from Gov. George E. Pataki, who said it would not move people off the welfare rolls fast enough. The Governor has called for welfare limits of five years over a lifetime for mothers with children and 60 days a year for a total of five years, over a lifetime, for single adults and childless couples. 
 But today the Assembly Democrats said their plan would reduce welfare dependency in a more compassionate and effective way than Mr. Pataki's proposals. It would impose five-year limits in cash benefits, but those payments would be continued if the economy took a downturn. It would also provide recipients with vouchers for housing and food once their cash benefits are exhausted.
"This is a proposal that makes sense," the Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, said during an afternoon news conference announcing the Democratic plan. "I do not believe we should balance a budget entirely on the backs of the poor people of this state, as the Governor is."
In releasing their own plan, the Assembly Democrats appeared to be trying to protect themselves against Republican charges that they have been blocking any changes in the state's welfare system. The Republicans have said they plan to turn welfare into an issue in the November elections, when all 211 seats in the Legislature are up.
The Assembly has been slow to release its plan because the debate over revamping the welfare system has threatened to split that house's Democrats between liberals from New York City and conservative upstate and suburban lawmakers.
The plan was criticized by advocates for the poor, who said the Assembly was caving in during an election year. "It's disappointing to see the Assembly Speaker endorsing time limits," said Timothy Casey of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies. "This policy violates the basic principle that there is a responsibility to support the needy so long as they comply with the eligibility requirements."
But Republicans criticized the Assembly plan as a half-hearted measure that did not go far enough. "If you examine the Speaker's plan, then you see that there are really no time limits," said Thomas M. Reynolds, an Assemblyman from western New York Statet who leads the Assembly Republicans. "After cash benefits expire, welfare recipients would receive noncash vouchers."
The Assembly plan differed from the Governor's in other ways. The Governor proposed reducing the amount of the monthly welfare check by 26 percent, to about the same level as New Jersey's, to help close a $4 billion budget gap.
But the Assembly Democrats said their plan included no such cuts. Further, recipients would be allowed to continue receiving cash benefits beyond the five-year limit if the economy had so declined that there were not enough jobs available. That would be determined by tracking the number of people who apply for unemployment benefits each quarter.
The plan would also require recipients to work for benefits and look for jobs, as the Governor has proposed.

HEADLINE: Mexico Plans To Repay U.S. $4.7 Billion

BYLINE: By JULIA PRESTON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, June 18

 BODY:
Taking advantage of new confidence in world financial markets, Mexico announced today that it would obtain private financing for $4.7 billion of the money it borrowed from the United States during last year's financial crisis, more than three years ahead of schedule.
Mexico will pay off the loans, which amount to 45 percent of its outstanding debt to Washington by refinancing its loans at lower cost or with longer terms. The first of the operations to privatize its debt to the United States Treasury began today, with the syndication of $3 billion in five-year notes to private banks. 
 The announcement will allow the Clinton Administration to argue that its risky bailout of Mexico has been successful, and that nearly half of the $12.5 billion it lent to the Mexican Government has now been repaid. Last year many in Congress, led by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, tried to block the rescue package, asserting that the United States would never get its money back. But the early repayment, Clinton Administration officials insisted tonight, defused the Mexican bailout as a potential election issue.
"This is good news," said Deputy Secretary of the Treasury Lawrence H. Summers, the architect of the bailout package last year. "The Mexican economy is recovering. Mexico is regaining access to the capital markets. Most important, American interests are being protected as American support is repaid and American exports to Mexico increase."
Clinton officials have also noted that the United States has made money from the deal, since Mexico has paid more than $750 million in interest.
To aid in the refinancing, the United States Treasury has agreed to release its hold on some of the collateral that Mexico provided for the original loan, Mexican officials said.
To guarantee the $12.5 billion it borrowed, Mexico, in an unprecedented arrangement, gave the United States the right to draw on earnings from its oil exports in case of default.
But senior American officials said tonight that the United States would not release all its claims on Mexico's oil revenue yet. Mexico plans to use the rights that the United States relinquished to secure the notes it began to offer today, Mexican finance officials said.
 The moves today may cause some consternation in Europe and Japan, because Mexico is paying off the United States before it pays back the International Monetary Fund, which also contributed to the bailout.
That decision seems tinged in American Presidential politics, as Mexico tries to repay President Clinton for the high-stakes and unpopular gamble he took in February 1995, when he reached into a special currency stabilization fund to offer Mexico loans to avert financial collapse after the disastrous devaluation of the peso and the accompanying severe squeeze on credit.
But particularly in 1996, President Ernesto Zedillo's officials have begun to steady the economy and to regain the confidence of the international markets sooner than most analysts had expected.
And although Mexican wage earners are still struggling with the worst economic recession in six decades, most experts here say that the economy has reached its bottom and that signs of gradual recovery are multiplying.
Among the heartening indicators, Mexico announced today that it had earned $8.04 billion from exports in May, a record.
Mexico has had several successes this year in placing longer-term debt on the markets. Officials are confident that the bonds they began to sell today will generate most of the money needed to repay the United States.
Mexico was not scheduled to make any payments on the loans from the United States until 1997. After a repayment of $1.3 billion in January, it owed $10.5 billion.
Officials here said the timing had everything to do with the recuperation of the economy and the logic of debt management and nothing to do with election-year politics in the United States.
"This deal has all the advantages," Finance Minister Guillermo Ortiz said in a telephone interview. "It is a clear financial plus for everyone."
The five-year floating-rate note was made available today at 2.125 percentage points over the three-month London interbank offered rate, for an interest rate of 7.655 percent. The Libor, as the London rate is known in the shorthand of credit markets, is a benchmark interest rate that international banks charge each other for loans denominated in dollars. The note issue is being underwritten for $1 billion each by J. P. Morgan and the Swiss Bank Corporation, Mexican officials said.
Mexico will complete the $4.7 billion repayment, to be made in mid-August, with $1.7 billion it earned from two other recent bond offerings.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Roots in Japan, Vision in China

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI

 BODY:
The Japanese retailing tycoon Kazuo Wada's latest gamble might seem like a long shot: he has built the world's second-biggest department store after Macy's in New York and stocked it with everything from a fire-engine-red Ferrari to imported cosmetics in this city whose population can mostly just gawk at such luxuries.
But Mr. Wada has always liked to take risks. Inspired by his first encounter with a modern supermarket in America in the 1960's, he returned home and transformed his family's vegetable business into a chain of general stores that competed with Japanese retailing giants. A decade later, he opened a couple of stores in Sao Paulo, Brazil, largely because he had heard that that city had a big ethnic-Japanese population. At about the same time, he tried his luck in Singapore, even though it was still a mostly poor city-state struggling to industrialize. And in 1984, defying the advice of bankers and industrialists, he chose a fishing village rather than a downtown location as the site for his first store in Hong Kong. 
 Not all the ventures succeeded. But enough did to enable Mr. Wada to build his Yaohan group of companies into a retailing, restaurant and property conglomerate with annual revenue approaching $3 billion and interests on four continents, including supermarkets and department stores in the United States and a restaurant in New York City.
Today, he is pursuing his most ambitious project to date, the Nextage department store across the mud-brown Huangpu River from downtown Shanghai. Nextage, built on land on which water buffalo worked rice fields a decade ago, attracted a million people when it opened its doors in December.
All day, the crowds surged across a marbled esplanade, pushing past bowing women in red berets under soaring arches before pouring into the 10-floor emporium. But while Shanghai is a prosperous city by Chinese standards, with a per capita annual income of nearly $2,000, the store's wares were out of the reach of most shoppers.
The Ferrari was priced at $350,000, or 636 years worth of wages for the average Chinese. A black Cadillac Fleetwood could be had for $95,000. Also on prominent display were designer suits, wide-screen Toshiba televisions, Hallmark cards and pricey firming makeup made by Princess Marcella Borghese.
After the curiosity seekers got their fill, traffic plummeted and revenue thinned. But Mr. Wada remains unperturbed. He has always specialized in moving into promising areas just a little too soon -- and then reaping the rewards when his market catches up with his ambition.
"I see China's era as the 21st century," Mr. Wada said in an interview in his opulent Hong Kong home, Sky High, the 42,000-square-foot former residence of the taipan -- or "big boss" -- of the Hong Kong and Shanghai Bank, a building perched on the summit of Victoria Peak. "My philosophy is doing things at the best time. Everyone is pessimistic now, so things are right now."
Mr. Wada's supporters say China's favorable economic outlook supports his investment theory. "Wada-san is looking 10 years into the future," said a Japanese economist who requested anonymity. "They don't have to make a profit for five years. The rich Shanghaiese are increasing every year. In Shanghai, Yaohan only needs 3 percent of the population."
The 68-year-old Mr. Wada cuts a gnomish figure as he pads into his cavernous living room, a gaggle of aides fluttering in his wake. He favors blue suits and dark ties, but his conservative demeanor masks a flamboyant business style. In 1990, in a move without parallel in Japanese corporate history, he shifted Yaohan's headquarters to Hong Kong to escape what he calls his homeland's suffocating business climate.
"I thought that if I stayed in Japan, I would not be able to create an international conglomerate," Mr. Wada explained. "In Japan, the top leader can't make a decision; everything has to come from the bottom." Unless it changes its ways, he adds, "Japan will miss the train."
Enthralled by China's economic boom, Mr. Wada announced plans to move his headquarters to Shanghai this month and become the first big Asian corporation to base itself inside China. He has already opened 23 supermarkets around the country and hopes to create a China-wide empire of department stores, warehouses, supermarkets, restaurants and fast-food outlets.
That is quite a vision for a company that traces its roots to a vegetable shop opened by Mr. Wada's father and mother in 1910 in Atami, a coastal town south of Tokyo. In his youth, Mr. Wada showed little interest in the family business, preferring to join the Communist Youth League and lead a protest at his university over a tuition increase. After his militancy resulted in his expulsion, his mother dragged him to a retreat of the Seicho No Ie, or House of Growth, a religious sect that emphasizes the values of family, fealty and self-awareness.
That experience, Mr. Wada says, awakened him to the idea that running a vegetable business was a respectable undertaking. His second, and far more rude, awakening came in 1950 when the vegetable stand burned down and was uninsured because he had forgotten to take out a fire policy. "I made up my mind to someday own the top vegetable store in Japan," he told a Japanese interviewer in 1994.
He helped his father rebuild the store, but it was his visit to a supermarket in the United States in 1962 that opened Mr. Wada's eyes to the possibilities of large-scale food marketing. Back in Japan, he quickly went about building the family business into a network of stores selling everything from pots and pans to bed sheets and clothing.
But he had to compete against two deep-pocketed Japanese chain-store giants and contend with Japan's endless business regulations. Again, inspiration struck. Impressed by Sony's expansion overseas, Mr. Wada began looking for opportunities overseas. In 1971, he opened his first store, in Sao Paulo.
"A respected teacher of Seicho No Ie told me that there were many Japanese in Brazil and invited me there," Mr. Wada said. "So I went."
He opened a second store in 1973, and business boomed. Then the world oil crisis unleashed hyperinflation in Brazil, and Yaohan's Brazilian operations, based on dollar loans that the company could no longer pay, came crashing down. "I have really learned bitterly about country risk," Mr. Wada sighed.
By then, he had also swiveled his attention back to Asia, where he had opened a department store in Singapore in 1972. Again, his timing was perfect -- he arrived a little bit too early. "The national per capita income was only about $1,500," he said, "but I was convinced the Singapore Government was very firmly established. Singaporeans were hard-working people, and I predicted that economic growth was going to be tremendous."
Once again, he flouted convention, ordering his stores to stay open until 10 P.M. and on Sundays. "This was kind of revolutionary in shopping," he said with a laugh. But it pulled in customers.
He was keeping an eye on Hong Kong but balked at the high rents. Then in 1984, he was offered space in a housing development being built in the village of Shatin in the New Territories, Hong Kong's bit of the mainland. "Everybody I spoke to -- banks, newspaper people, retailers -- said that Shatin would not be a success," he recalled. "People didn't think a small fishermen's village could grow and change the way it would. But I saw this as my chance."
He took the risk, and Shatin blossomed into a parade of apartment towers, parks and its own business district. His department store flourished, and Mr. Wada continued to build department stores, not in the glittery business district or the chrome-splashed malls frequented by Hong Kong's Gucci set, but in the middle-class neighborhoods that were springing up throughout the New Territories. Today, Yaohan has nine department stores across Hong Kong.
Mr. Wada's management philosophy is a mixture of pragmatism and spirituality. He begins and ends board meetings with meditations, "thanking our ancestors and our founder," says Shozo Sawa, Yaohan's personnel manager. And every morning, he requires the recital of the Yaohan declaration at his stores: "Through proper understanding and ever practicing the Truth of Life's Philosophy, we, the Yaohan International Group, resolve to establish the management principles to contribute for the good of people all over the world and to become a model business group in the world."
Although Mr. Wada has built a retailing conglomerate of more than 450 businesses employing 25,000 people in 16 countries, the Shanghai venture has yet to prove itself. And China, for all its spectacular economic growth, still faces formidable obstacles to modernization and is dogged by political uncertainty. Anna Donald, an analyst at the Daiwa Institute of Research in Hong Kong, thinks investment in China may be a good long-term strategy but warns that the Nextage department store is "unlikely to bring in profits for the next five years."
That assessment is unlikely to perturb Mr. Wada unduly. In contrast to the caution of many of his competitors, he has clearly decided that aggressive risk-taking was the way forward in Asia. Combining a belief in the long-term potential of emerging economies with a willingness to defer profits, Mr. Wada has plunged into markets that were scarcely identifiable as markets. Now, with his startling shift to Shanghai, he has signaled his faith in the explosive growth of China and its incipient upper and upper-middle classes.
"Of course people have different views of the same situation," said Mr. Wada, who each morning writes adages suffused with positive thinking in his diary. "One is the brighter side, one is the darker side. I like to take the brighter side. But on the other hand, there is a certain risk."

HEADLINE: Governors Island Historic District Created

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

 BODY:
More than half of Governors Island was designated a historic district yesterday, giving protection to the island's past but leaving its future still unpredictable.
As expected, the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission designated 90 of the island's 175 acres as the city's 67th historic district, covering some 100 buildings dating as far back as the early 1800's. Five structures in the new district, which covers the island's northern half, had already been given individual landmark status. 
 The historic label is appropriate because Governors Island is "an area of the city with a distinct sense of place" and a military history dating to the 1700's, said a commission spokeswoman, Deborah Sack.
While the commission's action offers further protection to historic buildings and their surroundings, it does not answer the biggest present-day question about the island: What exactly will happen when the Coast Guard leaves, which it has said it will do by the end of 1998?
The departure of the Coast Guard from what had been its largest base in the country is expected to open a whole new history whose main characters will be real estate developers and builders. If they want to develop, build or renovate within the district, their plans must be approved by the commission, which would be unlikely to allow, say, a 19th-century building to be demolished to make way for a fast-food restaurant.
The commission held a public hearing in February on the proposed historic district and heard no opposition, Ms. Sack said. The City Council will review the commission's action and could modify the designation.
It is "way, way too early" to envision what Governors Island will look like a few years from now, Deputy Mayor Fran Reiter said yesterday. She heads a task force appointed last fall by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to study the future of the island. Members include representatives of the Economic Development Corporation, the City Planning Commission and the Landmarks Preservation Commission.
No one disputes that Governors Island has appreciated in value since the Dutch bought it from the Manahatas Indians in 1627 for two ax heads, some beads and nails. But Ms. Reiter and the city's planning director, Joseph B. Rose, were wary yesterday of the astronomical figures that have been given for its value.
"People are just grabbing numbers out of the air," Mr. Rose said, referring in particular to a Congressional Budget Office estimate that the island ought to fetch $500 million.
Yes, the island has a great view of the Manhattan skyline, and no one is making any new land around New York. But the island is still just that: a piece of land reachable only by ferry or helicopter.
Legislation to give New York City or New York State the right of first refusal to buy the island has been pending in Congress since last year.
The five landmark buildings within the new district are the early 19th-century Georgian-style Governor's House; the 19th-century block house and the commanding general's quarters, both in Greek Revival style, and two of the city's first forts, Fort Jay and Castle Williams, both erected early in the 19th century.
Troops were stationed there as early as 1755. The Army operated Governors Island from 1821 to 1966, when the Coast Guard took it over. Since then, some 4,000 Coast Guard members and relatives have lived there, with their own nine-hole golf course, bowling alley, movie theater and Burger King restaurant.

HEADLINE: Spread the Word on Asia Rights Abusers;
Nike's Wages

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Nike and other companies "are drawn to Indonesia like flies to garbage," says Bob Herbert (column, June 14). Such rhetoric plays into the hands of authoritarian rulers who dismiss American criticisms as the product not of empathy but contempt. 
 Questionable too is the idea of banning investment in Indonesia to avoid moral contamination. The pay employees receive from Nike may seem "pathetic," but typically such wages are higher than in comparable jobs elsewhere in the Indonesian economy.
 
DONALD K. EMMERSON
Madison, Wis., June 14, 1996
 
The writer is a professor of political science, University of Wisconsin.

HEADLINE: The Mean Streets That Nurture Art;
A Photographer Finds Support And Community in East Village

BYLINE: By ROBIN POGREBIN 

 BODY:
It was two years ago in March, the month she turned 27, that Meryl Levin resigned herself to the reality that she might never make a living doing what she loves.
She also resolved to do it anyway. At least for now. 
 So, every morning, Ms. Levin climbs down from the loft bed in her 300-square-foot apartment, showers in the bathtub that sits in the middle of her kitchen, pulls on her lace-up boots and jangle of silver bracelets, and sets out to capture corners of the world with her wide-lens camera.
Ms. Levin, who grew up in Rockland County, developing pictures in the darkroom where her dentist father, Stan, processed his dental X-rays, is a long way from becoming a prominent photographer. But she is not toiling in complete obscurity.
She is known to the photo agency Impact Visuals, a cooperative of photographers that accepted Ms. Levin as a member in 1991; to Susan Meiselas and Gilles Peress, the renowned documentary photographers for whom Ms. Levin has worked as an assistant, and to the New York Foundation for the Arts, which in 1994 awarded Ms. Levin a $7,000 fellowship.
These signs of recognition have helped reassure Ms. Levin that she is not completely crazy. Others know she is out there trying to make it.
Living below 14th Street has helped Ms. Levin feel she is not entirely alone. Others like her are out there trying to make it too.
The East Village has long been a destination for emerging artists, offering low rents, cheap restaurants and a creative community. On Ms. Levin's block of East Third Street she knows at least five photographers near her age.
On the surrounding streets, sandwiched between Second Avenue and Avenue D, in unheated studios and overheated apartments as far down as Delancey Street, are painters, sculptors, writers, video artists, film makers and performing artists, many under 30.
They include painters like Ruth Root, 28, whose work is being shown in SoHo, featuring a series of canvases that depict hulking masses of brown hair, inspired by a year of migraine headaches.
Or Andrew Bordman, who has been exploring images of Jewish mysticism with pen on archival paper. His sources of inspiration range from medieval manuscripts to Sears catalogues.
Their distinctive, alternative turf, vibrant with body-piercing shops, people in neon platform shoes and coffee bars like the one named Limbo, is affirming in its freewheeling way.
But lately, as money for the arts has diminished and following the heart has come to seem more foolhardy than courageous, young artists like Ms. Levin sense they may be among a dying breed of dreamers.
"It's an incredibly scary moment," Ms. Levin said. "There is the sort of feeling like, 'Oh my God, how are we going to survive?' And I don't know that it's idealism so much as a brand of stupidity. I mean, the writing is on the wall."
In her walk-up studio apartment, Ms. Levin wakes to the smell of garlic wafting in through her second-floor windows from Mama's Food Shop across the street, and falls asleep to the whistles of drug dealers plying their trade on Avenue B.
She makes the most of her cramped living space by being organized and inventive. Each thin drawer of a squat storage cabinet is carefully labeled: "stamps," "resume paper," "white gloves" (for looking at black-and-white archival prints). The alcove underneath her loft bed doubles as a dressing area and darkroom (she hangs black velvet over the window to block out the light). Her sink triples as a bathroom sink, kitchen sink and photography sink.
"It's that whole, your-sink-is-your-darkroom-sink-do-you-really-want-to-be-cooking-in-it problem," Ms. Levin said.
Though rising East Village rents have sent artists fleeing to other boroughs, many still feel the pull of downtown Manhattan.
"This seemed like the center of the universe," said Ms. Root, who grew up in Miami and helps support herself by painting people's apartment walls. She lives on Orchard Street and works in a studio on Avenue B that she shares with five people: a metalsmith, a writer, another painter, and two wood sculptors who hack away in the basement (Ms. Root plays music to drown out the sound of the saws).
Mr. Bordman, who grew up in the suburbs of Philadelphia and works during the day as an administrative assistant at the Rockefeller Foundation, has been sketching in his bedroom on Essex Street while he looks for a studio space he can afford. Part of the reason he has been working with ink lately is that painting with oil so near his bed has made it difficult to sleep because of the turpentine fumes.
He says concern about his finances fluctuates from day to day. "Some days, I'm very worried about it, and I'll eat a slice of pizza for lunch and a slice of pizza for dinner," he said. "Other days, I'll splurge on an expensive art book or a nice pair of shoes."
Ms. Levin supports herself primarily by working for Ms. Meiselas, the photographer, which brings in about $17,000 a year, and through occasional freelance assignments for employers like Local 1199, the hospital workers' union, and The Village Voice.
Ms. Levin said she has managed to keep up with the rent, telephone and electric bills. Nevertheless, she calculates every sandwich and subway token, and saves money by traveling to appointments via bicycle or Rollerblades, which is also how she exercises, since she cannot afford a health club.
There are ways Ms. Levin could be playing it safer. She could earn considerably more money doing commercial work, like fashion photography. She could try to get a steady newspaper job. Instead, she has chosen to pursue long-term projects she is passionate about that may never see the light of day, much less pay the bills.
"I've made the decision that I'm not just going to use my talent to earn a living all the time," Ms. Levin said. "I'm going to do the kind of work that I want to do, and figure out some other way to support that."
Artists in their 40's and 50's say young artists like Ms. Levin are right to give themselves time.
"One of the reasons why you're a young artist at 40, with rare exceptions, is that it takes a while to actually serve your apprenticeship in the arts," said Stephen Westfall, 43, who has exhibited his work at prestigious venues like the Andre Emmerich Gallery and the Daniel Newburg Gallery. "Not just paying the rent and having a job, but finding your own voice and understanding your own sensibility. You're kidding yourself if you think you can skirt that process and be an original in your mid-20's."
Ideally, Ms. Levin would like to publish books of her photographs. She is working on one now, chronicling efforts to seek health care by people in the South Bronx. So far, she has failed to win a grant to support the project -- she has applied for three -- and has yet to show it to a publisher.
But she is proceeding with the work anyway. During the last year, she has followed three people, documenting daily rituals as mundane as rolling up sleeves for blood tests and standing in line to cash welfare checks, as profound as leaving the hospital to die at home.
Ms. Levin has chosen to document a world that many people do not to want to see. She said she feels supported in her choice by mentors like Ms. Meiselas, best known for her work in Central America.
"Meryl knows what she's up against," said Ms. Meiselas, who works out of a studio on Mott Street and is completing a visual history of the Kurds. "She's as willful as I think she needs to be. And whether or not the world will open up to her, as I would hope it would, that's the fate that no one can predict."
While Ms. Levin takes comfort in the company of her compatriots, she said she cannot help feeling competitive. "Everyone and their brother is a photographer," Ms. Levin said. "They all live in this town."
The economics of a photographer's existence have grown increasingly Darwinian, Ms. Levin said. Whereas once photographers could count on living off the resale of their stock footage, now, as photographs go out over the Internet, that nest egg is no longer secure.
All of this has made even the most seasoned of artists newly cautious and many people at Ms. Levin's level downright conservative.
"When I was growing up," she said, "it was the 80's: 'You can do anything you want, it's out there.' And I sort of felt, by the time I graduated, it was 'Well, actually you really can't.' Yet I still sort of feel like somewhere back there I have this drive of, 'But give it a try anyway, and maybe you'll work something out.' "
Other artists, like Ms. Root, seem to live fiercely in the present, refusing to entertain the worst.
"I guess I have doubts, but I don't have the great doubt that would make me become a veterinarian," Ms. Root said. "I guess in New York, especially in this neighborhood where it's like post-apocalypse sometimes, I kind of feel this is my job."
Mr. Bordman, who took premedical studies in college and had a 10-year plan to become a doctor, said: "Now I can't really see that far. I'm just kind of blind about it. I just want to keep working."
Beneath their rational eloquence and street-smart stoicism, one cannot help sensing a basic fear.
"When it's just me not making any money, it's O.K.," Ms. Levin said. "I can figure out how to make it work. But I do want to have a kid and I do want to be a full partner in a partnership and I do want to be able to provide in all kinds of ways."
Whatever happens, whether she makes it work or ultimately decides to move in another direction, Ms. Levin said she cannot imagine doing anything different.
"I have to go through this," she said. "I think I'm sort of down for the count. This is the long haul."
