HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW;
Agreed: It Was a Jungle, In the Bad Old Days

BYLINE: WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
If truth-in-advertising laws were applied to television titles, tomorrow night's edition of "Firing Line" would be in for it. The proclaimed subject, "Resolved: The Marketplace Is Not a Social Enemy," is scarcely on the minds of the affirmative forces led by William F. Buckley Jr., known as Mr. Conservative, or the negatives, led by Robert Kuttner, co-editor of The American Prospect, known as a liberal journal.
All present agree that the American marketplace has been regulated for a century or so precisely to prevent it from behaving as a social enemy. Even Mark Green, a certified liberal and New York City's Public Advocate, grants that "the market is no enemy." And none of his opponents call for a return to the bad old days. 
 There is some banter about the proper amount of regulation, but the main argument is the enduring one over whether the bosses ought to be so much richer than the workers. And even that does not produce a lot of class-struggle heat. Listen to Jerry J. Jasinowski, the president of the National Association of Manufacturers, acknowledging that the pay of some chief executive officers is "excessive," and to Mr. Buckley conceding the need for labor unions.
Surrounded by students and others at Bard College and moderated by Robert Shrum (taking over from Michael Kinsley, who has gone off to try his luck in the on-line marketplace), these debaters are a touch too undoctrinaire for the good of their encounter. Edward Luttwak, once an adviser to Ronald Reagan but on the liberal side in this matter, sees "sort of a disturbing consensus here emerging," and David Levy, vice chairman of the Jerome Levy Economics Institute of Bard College, host to the debate, laments with fair accuracy that "we find ourselves repeating each other."
Knockout arguments are absent. Pressed for his approach to the consequences of accelerated globalization, the technological revolution and deregulation, Mr. Luttwak proposes eliminating self-service gas stations as a way of increasing jobs. Mr. Buckley counters with a call for a crackdown on "illegitimacy, crime, miseducation and divorce." Take your choice.
Viewers are also at the mercy of conflicting assertions and rebuttals about current conditions. Robert D. Hormats, the vice chairman of Goldman, Sachs, says there is still plenty of upward mobility in America; Mr. Kuttner challenges his statistics. Andrew Stern of the Service Employees Union tells Mr. Buckley that his statistics are wrong; Mr. Jasinowski, the manufacturers' voice, tells Mr. Stern that his statistics are wrong.
The exchanges are cordial; the audience is polite. Mr. Shrum, who may want to keep his new job lest he become another statistic, says, "This has been a wonderful debate."
 
A FIRING LINE DEBATE

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains as Bank of Japan Denies Report of Rate Rises

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against most leading currencies in volatile trading yesterday after the Bank of Japan denied a report that it might raise interest rates as early as July.
Currency traders said the dollar was also helped by new doubts about a Japanese Government report depicting a powerful first-quarter economic surge, the main reason for the dollar's slump on Tuesday. 
 But traders said the dollar's seesaw behavior during the day reflected new uncertainty in the longer-term direction of the currency, which has been on a relatively steady climb against the Japanese yen and German mark for months.
"Right now there's still disbelief and a little bit of confusion," said Joseph Klettner, a technical analyst of foreign exchange at Chase Securities in New York. "As this confusion lingers on, you'll probably get a bit of a choppy market here."
In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar stood at 107.85 yen, up slightly from 107.75 yen on Tuesday. The dollar also traded at 1.5210 marks, up from its two-month low of 1.5123 Tuesday. The British pound was unchanged for the second consecutive day at $1.5435.
The dollar began the trading day by rallying in Asia and Europe as traders reassessed Tuesday's report by the Japanese Economic Planning Agency on first-quarter performance, which showed an annual growth rate of 12.7 percent in the first quarter, the fastest in 23 years.
They said much of the strength was concentrated in Government public works spending and housing construction, not necessarily enough to help Japan pull out of its prolonged slump. Some traders also noted that the report was inconsistent with other evidence of a much milder economic recovery in Japan.
"There's just a realization that it is old data," said Jack Griffin, a vice president of foreign exchange at Fuji Bank Ltd. in New York. "More recent data hasn't confirmed it."
But the dollar dropped abruptly in early New York trading after the Kyodo news service reported the Bank of Japan had concluded the figures were strong enough to reconsider its interest rate policy, and that it might raise rates next month.
The Bank of Japan quickly denied the report, saying that nothing had been decided and that it was continuing to "carefully watch the recovery situation." Traders who had been selling dollars then began to bid the dollar higher again.

HEADLINE: Essay;
The Shaker-Upper

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM

 BODY:
Coping with the least of his prob lems moving into a new, fortified residence -- Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu calmed the decorating concerns of his wife, Sara: "They're just not used to what we're trying to do."
That goes for the entire enterprise of the ninth Israeli leader. His own party was not used to his idea of filling the most powerful cabinet posts with outsiders. It promptly rebelled. The way he rolled with the intra-party punching is revealing. 
 Ariel Sharon, who unified the right and enabled Netanyahu to run against Shimon Peres one-on-one, had an ironclad right to expect the post of Finance. When offered the lesser post of Housing, he refused. The man Sharon had persuaded to stay out of the race, David Levy, then refused to accept Foreign Minister, which Sharon had brokered.
At the Knesset lectern for his low-key maiden speech as Prime Minister, Netanyahu looked down at the front row, where two empty seats were as startling as a couple of missing front teeth. The Parliament gasped as he temporarily held those two portfolios for himself.
After a finger-wagging lecture from Peres (whose recovery from a near-catatonic state came two weeks too late for Labor's campaign), the Prime Minister induced Levy to accept the Foreign Ministry by whipping together a new super-ministry -- of "Infrastructures" -- for Sharon. That heavy-set hard-liner is thinking it over, but Levy's quick acceptance lessens his leverage.
A Likud moderate, Dan Meridor, one of Netanyahu's generational rivals, did better after being overlooked. The Prime Minister was forced to name him to Finance, but created a new job for the financial professional he wanted: head of a U.S.-style council of economic advisers that will provide the business-trained Prime Minister the staff he needs to manage the economy.
Upshot: The new P.M. pushed, pulled back, created some new facts on the political ground, bruised some egos, and wound up with more than half the loaf he wanted.
That was the easy part of beginning to create a new mindset; now he has to negotiate one on the world scene. And the place to start is in building a fresh relationship with Israel's key ally, the United States.
When the Israeli comes to Washington, where Moshe Arens may be his Ambassador, he must explain to President Clinton why Arab leaders, European bureaucrats and Russian spymaster-diplomats are treating his election as an offense to world peace. Their dudgeon suits their interests, which are not necessarily our interests.
Egypt, for example, seizes this election as cause for an emergency Arab summit meeting, in a bid to re-establish Cairo as the center of the Arab world. France wants a meeting of the European Union, to castigate Israel and snatch back business from America in the Middle East. And Yevgeny Primakov, Saddam Hussein's friend, called from the Yeltsin Foreign Ministry to urge Netanyahu to accept Russian co-sponsorship of Madrid II, thereby projecting Moscow's influence in the region.
Whoa. This is not the time for Mr. Clinton to say "Ain't summits fun?" Perhaps Mr. Netanyahu can persuade him to suggest to fellow world leaders that the U.S. disapproves of such pre-emptive diplomatic strikes against Israel. Clinton should review U.S. policy toward terrorist Syria, occupier of Lebanon, transporter of Iranian rockets that rain on Israel, home to terrorists attacking Turkey and Jordan, in light of that appeasement's eight-year failure.
The old mindset makes a test of leaving Hebron; the new mindset explores ways to guarantee personal security to Israelis living in the West Bank and job security to Palestinians working there and in Israel. The old permits foreign ministers to visit Palestinian representatives in Jerusalem; the new raises no false hope of dividing Israel's capital.
Mr. Netanyahu should thank Congress fervently for voting to move the U.S. Embassy to Jerusalem, and startle us all by taking up A. M. Rosenthal's idea of phasing out U.S. economic aid.
We are just not used to what this shaker-upper is trying to do. I am long out of the speechwriting dodge, but can recommend a line of Lincoln's: "We must think anew and act anew. We must disenthrall ourselves."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 4; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 166 words

HEADLINE: Maximum Wage? Tell It to Movers and Shakers

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Corporate Greed, Meet the Maximum Wage" (Week in Review, June 16) refers to a suggested maximum wage for executives at 50 times the minimum wage of the company's lowest-paid employee. Socialism does not work. The profit motive works. The promise of great wealth is what spurs the creators of the world. It drives the economy's engine. 
 People like Bill Gates, the chairman of Microsoft, would not say, "Sure I'll put out the same effort for a lot less money." It didn't work in the Soviet Union or any Communist country. A modified socialism, like tying the wages of executives to other employees, will not work either.
Start a company, invest your time and money and all your effort, and then pay yourself only 50 times what you pay your lowest-paid employee: once you've tried it, perhaps the example of Mr. Gates's successful entrepreneurship will seem to have some merit.
 
FRAYDA LEVIN
Saddle Brook, N.J., June 16, 1996
 
The writer owns a small business.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Bonds Lose Gains To End Flat

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended little changed yesterday, retreating from early gains after an announcement on next week's sales of new two-year and five-year notes revived concerns about supply.
The retreat erased earlier gains made after a Federal Reserve survey showed that wages and prices remained largely in check even amid a pickup in the pace of growth. Some market participants interpreted the findings of the survey, a compilation of anecdotal reports from the 12 Federal Reserve districts, to mean that the Fed would delay an expected increase in interest rates. 
 The price of the 30-year bond ended unchanged at 86 14/32, leaving its yield also unchanged at 7.10 percent.
Bond prices were pressured at the start of trading on a report by a Japanese news service that the Bank of Japan was considering raising interest rates. Such a move would diminish the relative attractiveness of United States Treasury securities. Indeed, a number of investors have taken advantage of the low lending rates in Japan, borrowing there and investing in higher-yielding United States Government securities.
The dollar also dropped sharply after the report, by the Kyodo news service. The report was quickly denied by Bank of Japan officials, and the dollar recovered.
Treasury prices were further bolstered after the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, Mo., which complied the Fed survey known as the beige book, said that while "the pace of growth accelerated recently," signs of higher wages "remained scattered."
Sung Won Sohn, chief economist at the Norwest Corporation, Minneapolis, said the Fed report indicated "that we have a wonderful combination of economic growth and little inflationary pressures."
"So this implies that a strong economic growth doesn't have to lead to higher inflation and interest rates," he said.
Mr. Sohn said he believed that the report damped the probability that Fed policy makers would increase rates when they meet next month. "The beige book report changed very little from April, and so the question is, what has changed since April to warrant a tighter monetary policy?" he asked.
Mr. Sohn says Fed policy makers might decide to give the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, the directive to raise rates between meetings if economic conditions justify. It would better, he said, if Fed policy makers waited until their Aug. 20 meeting to raise rates, when they would have had two more employment reports and second-quarter gross domestic product data to digest.
Bonds were pressured after the Treasury announced the size of its note auctions for next week. While the size of the auctions was unchanged from the previous sale, the prospect of new securities coming to market revived concerns about the ability of the market to absorb them.
The Treasury said that it would sell $18.75 billion of two-year notes on Tuesday and $12.5 billion of five-year notes on Wednesday.
In when-issued trading late yesterday, the two-year note was being offered at a price to yield 6.32 percent and the five-year note was being offered at price to yield 6.74 percent. The Treasury plans to auction $19.25 billion of new one-year bills today.
Also today, the market will get to see the April trade balance numbers, a survey from the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia, and the weekly initial jobless claims report.
In the corporate bond market, issuance is beginning to heat up, and the largest sale expected this week will be done by an issuer who is no stranger to large offerings, having done a $3.5 billion deal just over a month ago in the biggest high-grade issue ever. The Lockheed Martin Corporation plans to sell $1.25 billion debt securities in three parts this week through underwriters led by CS First Boston.

HEADLINE: Teacher Is Sentenced For Taking a Bribe

BYLINE: The Associated Press 

 BODY:
A New York high school teacher was sentenced to six months in prison and fined $2,500 yesterday for taking a bribe from a student in exchange for a passing grade, District Attorney Richard A. Brown of Queens said.
The teacher, Kenneth D. Cotton, 44, who taught economics at two high schools, was convicted on charges of receiving bribes, falsifying records and official misconduct. Mr. Cotton, whose salary was $62,331, was also placed on probation for four and a half years and is required to perform 500 hours of community service. 
 Testimony showed that Mr. Cotton instilled "fear in a student, who allegedly had excessive absences from his night school classes" at Jamaica High School last year, and that he demanded $290 for a passing grade. The student, 18, informed authorities, who arrested Mr. Cotton last June 22.
Mr. Cotton also taught at Adlai E. Stevenson High School in the Bronx.

HEADLINE: Dow Rises 20.32, but Broader Market Falls

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average rose yesterday, but most stocks slid again as bonds failed to improve and investors remained cautious before the next Federal Reserve Board meeting in July, where it issues its verdict on inflation.
The Dow industrials advanced 20.32 points, to 5,648.35, down from a midday gain of 46 points, when the Dow briefly broke free of the narrow, indecisive trading range that has been characterized this week and last. 
 Declining issues outnumbered advancers by about 7 to 5 on the New York Stock Exchange, where volume totaled 383.6 million shares, making it the sixth straight session below 400 million, underlining the cautious tone in the market.
Most broad-market indexes ended lower after struggling higher with bonds earlier in the session.
"A lot of people are just pulling to the sidelines and don't want to play," said Larry Rice, chief investment officer at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross. "Until bond yields fall below 7 percent, I don't see how stocks can make any meaningful advance."
Bonds struggled to advance several times in the session, inspiring some stock buying as interest rates dipped, but then finished almost unchanged. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond -- a key determinant of corporate and consumer borrowing costs -- held steady at 7.10 percent.
"It was a really unconvincing bounce," Mr. Rice said. "This is a market that shows no conviction." He attributed some of the early strength in bonds to the Bank of Japan's decision not to raise interest rates, which could make Japanese investments more enticing relative to United States Treasuries.
The Big Board composite index fell 0.26, to 355.32, its ninth straight decline, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 0.10, to 661.96, the eighth straight decline for that blue-chip measure. The American Stock Exchange's market value index fell 0.06, to 588.93, its seventh straight decline.
Technology stocks stabilized after Tuesday's slide on growing worries about slack demand in the computer industry.
The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index, which tumbled nearly 25 points on Tuesday, fell 3.81, to 1,179.27, but several computer-industry bellwethers rebounded. Intel rose 1, to 71 3/8, and Cisco Systems rose 1/2, to 53 3/8.
Compuserve slipped 1/2, to 22 3/4, after announcing a smaller-than-expected loss in the first quarterly report since H & R Block spun off the on-line service. Late Tuesday, Compuserve reported a $1.1 million loss for its fourth quarter, which ended April 30.
Tele-Communications Inc. rose 1/2, to 18 3/8 after its board authorized a spinoff of the unit that holds TCI's interest in the Primestar direct broadcast satellite venture. Primestar leases 36-inch satellite dishes to customers who can then receive cable, pay- television and sports programming. The venture is owned by a consortium that includes TCI, Comcast, Time Warner and Cox Communications.
Shares of HMT Technology climbed 3, to 17 1/4. The company withdrew its offer to sell 4 million common shares and $150 million in convertible notes, citing recent weakness in stock market prices for disk-storage companies.
Since announcing plans to sell the stock and notes in late May, HMT shares have lost nearly half their value. HMT said it was proceeding with expansion plans.
Boeing announced plans yesterday to double production of its best-selling jet, the 737, amid booming demand. The announcement eased concern that 1996 earnings will fall short of last year's results. Advancing with Boeing on the New York Stock Exchange were shares of the Procter & Gamble Company, the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company and the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company.
Retail shares dropped, leading the decline in the S.& P, a day after the Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi/Schroder Wertheim reported that weekly same-store sales were little changed in the second week of June.
Among retailers, Wal-Mart Stores slid 5/8, to 24 5/8; Sears, Roebuck & Company fell 1/4, to 49 7/8, and the J. C. Penney Company dropped 7/8, to 51 7/8.

HEADLINE: Survey by Fed Says Economy Is Strong, With Little Inflation

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 19

 BODY:
Despite fresh strength in the economy, wages and prices remain largely in check, a survey by the Federal Reserve found today.
The lack of quickened inflation was taken by private analysts as a crucial factor weighing against action by the central bank to tighten monetary conditions at its policy meeting early next month. Stock prices promptly climbed after the survey was issued at noon, while bond prices rose in early trading but finished slightly lower. 
 "Nearly all districts report expanding activity, and several indicate the pace of growth accelerated recently," said the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, which compiled this round of the periodic anecdotal reports from the 12 districts. But despite tight labor markets for both skilled and entry-level workers, it said, signs of higher wages "remained scattered."
The poll, which is part of the Fed's preparation for meetings of the Open Market Committee, covered the six-week period through June 11, one marked by statistics that mostly portrayed a resurging economy after a near stall in the early part of the year.
"This confirmed that there was an improvement in the economy since the last F.O.M.C. meeting,"said Stuart G. Hoffman, chief economist at the PNC Bank in Pittsburgh. He said the strength came particularly in housing, retailing and even manufacturing. "But it is without any signs yet of worsening consumer inflation or pressures on wages," he added.
Nonetheless, there were the usual geographic variations and contrary trends within districts. For example, while the New York and Boston districts were among the nine showing improved factory activity, these two were said to be the only districts with lagging retail sales.
A second survey published today found 64 forecasters predicting that gross domestic product would grow at a 4 percent annual rate in the April-June quarter, up from the 2.3 percent rate in the first three months of the year. This survey, issued by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia, predicted that the growth rate would moderate to 2.4 percent in the second half of the year.
According to the Federal Reserve's survey, called the beige book for the color of its cover, the economy "continued to advance at a moderate pace" during May and early June, with retail business and services generally stronger, factories busier and home and commercial construction also brisker in most districts.
On the other hand, mortgage lending declined, wet weather hampered home building in the Chicago district and elsewhere, and drought seriously hurt agriculture in several districts. Wheat farmers in Kansas and Oklahoma may harvest less than half their normal crop, the Fed was told.
Tourism was especially buoyant, with hotel occupancy in New York City remaining at a 16-year high, strong attendance gains at Florida theme parks, rising gambling revenues in Mississippi and swelling, double-digit airport traffic in Atlanta, site of next month's Olympic Games.
One of the tightest labor markets is the Boston district, the Fed indicated, with businesses finding it necessary to recruit professional workers from other regions and factories being forced to raise wages.
Other of the relatively few signs of wage inflation across the country were some fast-food restaurants in the St. Louis district offering "signing bonuses" of up to $250 and then paying "well above" the minimum wage; higher entry-level wages in Atlanta related to the Olympics, and shortages of workers in Virginia, central Ohio, northern Kentucky and the Upper Midwest.
The Minneapolis district, in fact, reported that a growing number of companies seeking skilled workers have stopped advertising for them because of a lack of candidates. A state official suggested calling this a situation of "discouraged employers."
Still, most districts reported wages essentially contained, suggesting increases no more than about 3 percent, the current 12-month rate of consumer inflation.
The Dallas Fed, echoed by others, found "wage pressures were minimal, except for a few respondents who were concerned about rising costs" if Washington enacted a higher minimum wage, a prospect that has diminished markedly in the last few weeks.
The Dallas district also reported that increased orders for nearly all factory goods with the notable exception of semiconductors, "which continued to plunge" along with prices.

HEADLINE: Navistar to Cut Jobs and Move Truck Production

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

 BODY:
The Navistar International Corporation, North America's biggest producer of trucks and school buses, said yesterday that it would eliminate 3,000 of the 5,000 jobs at its huge factory in Springfield, Ohio, and move its heavy truck production elsewhere by 1999.
Andy Opila, a spokesman for Navistar, said that no decision had been made on where the company would move the heavy truck production. "We are evaluating our options," he said. 
 But Steve Shelton, the president of the United Automobile Workers Local 402, which represents workers at the factory, said there had been speculation at the plant that Navistar would move the operation to Mexico. One of Navistar's rivals, Paccar Inc. of Bellevue, Wash., has just begun establishing a heavy truck factory in Mexico, shortly after shutting one in Canada when workers went on strike.
Navistar, based in Chicago, said in a statement that it was reviewing whether to cancel its agreement to license manufacturing technology to Consorcio G Grupo Dina S.A., a Mexican truck manufacturer, and replace it with a new one "to serve the Mexican market over the longer term."
Mr. Opila said that Navistar already produced some trucks in Mexico for the Mexican market but said that the company was evaluating its options on whether to produce trucks in Mexico for the United States market.
If Navistar does move production to Mexico, the result would be one of the largest single factory losses of jobs since the North American Free Trade Agreement took effect on Jan. 1, 1994. The agreement is phasing out over 10 years the previously prohibitive tariff of 25 percent on truck imports from Mexico.
The Labor Department has certified the loss of 74,205 jobs because of the North American Free Trade Agreement, but the numbers are incomplete because many workers and unions choose not to apply for certification for complex legal reasons. The Clinton Administration and most economists say that the agreement has created far more jobs in the United States than it has eliminated by letting companies take advantage of the economies of scale offered by a North American market with few barriers to trade.
Navistar will continue to produce medium trucks and school buses at the Springfield factory and will invest $200 million to retool the factory for a new generation of medium-sized trucks.
A heavy truck is classified by the Government as a tractor that can pull a trailer of more than 33,000 pounds, while a medium truck can pull 16,000 to 33,000 pounds.
Mr. Opila said that Navistar's plans for job reductions in Springville assumed that the company could negotiate changes in the three-year contract that it reached with the U.A.W. last year. Mr. Shelton said it was too soon to predict the outcome of any such negotiations, adding that while he was grateful the company was planning to invest more money, the scope of the planned job cutbacks stunned him.
About 1,500 employees in Springfield have served for 30 or more years and are eligible for retirement, Mr. Shelton added.
Navistar's planned negotiations with the U.A.W. could prove an interesting test of labor-management relations. The company extracted health care and pension concessions from the union in 1993 by agreeing to place a third of its stock, with no voting rights, into a special trust that is intended some day to supplement the pensions of U.A.W. workers.
If the union fights the movement of heavy-truck production, it would likely hurt the value of the trust fund on which its members depend for their retirement, said Frank J. Prezelski, an analyst at Ladenburg Thalmann in New York. "The unions are caught between a rock and a hard place," he said.
Jack Laskowski, the vice president of the U.A.W.'s national leadership who oversees the union's relationship with Navistar, was cautious in responding to yesterday's announcement, saying only that union officials intended to meet with the company soon.
Navistar included the announcement of layoffs halfway down a news release about its spending plans. With public criticism of layoffs increasing, many American corporations have been reluctant to trumpet their job cuts.
Darryl Herring, the assistant city manager of Springfield, a community of 70,000 in southwestern Ohio, said that local officials had expected some cutbacks at Navistar. The company's decision to invest more money in the factory partly offsets the pain of the layoffs, he said.
The city has an unemployment rate of 6.9 percent while Clark County, which includes Springfield, has an unemployment rate of only 5.4 percent. But it would be hard to replace the loss of so many jobs at the city's biggest employer, Mr. Herrin said.
"The city, from an economic development standpoint, is very dependent on Navistar and on the work force at Navistar," Mr. Herring said.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Teen-age childbearing: the cost is put at $8.9 billion a year.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
AN ambitious study issued last week by the Robin Hood Foundation in New York called "Kids Having Kids" will no doubt convince any remaining skeptics that teen-age childbearing is an economic as well as a social disaster.
But the research will disappoint those who assume that anyone going to the trouble to document these costs must have a fix in mind. "We haven't got the slightest idea what to do about teen-age pregnancy," said Douglas Besharov, a resident scholar at the American Enterprise Institute who was an adviser to the authors of the study. 
 Nor, for that matter, do social scientists hold out more than a glimmer of hope that public intervention can offset the economic consequences once the teen-agers give birth. The latest findings from Ohio's experiment in using financial incentives to keep teen-age mothers in school, reported last month by the Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation, are only marginally encouraging.
The Robin Hood Foundation, a New York-based charity dedicated to reducing poverty, commissioned a series of research papers on teen-age motherhood and hired Rebecca Maynard, an economist at the University of Pennsylvania, to put the pieces together. The story she tells is not pretty.
In 1993 some 175,000 babies were born to girls 17 or younger. Just 3 percent of the babies were put up for adoption. And since fewer than one in six of the mothers were married or well educated, most of the children were left to grow up in impoverished, single-parent families.
To those children, the mere fact that they were born to teen-age mothers will influence the rest of their lives. Extrapolating from recent history,teen-age mothers will be only marginally more dependent on welfare than their socioeconomic counterparts who wait an extra four years to give birth. But their children will be 50 percent more likely to repeat a grade in school, 42 percent more likely to drop out, 13 percent more likely to end up in prison, 30 percent more likely to be unemployed as young adults and 22 percent more likely to bear children themselves before the age of 18.
Ms. Maynard calculates that the problems associated with adolescent childbearing -- as distinct from the general problems of growing up in poor or dysfunctional families -- will cost taxpayers about $7 billion this year. That comes mostly from higher outlays on foster care, medical treatment and criminal justice, plus lost tax revenues. The overall costs to society, including the estimated productivity lost by the mothers, add up to $8.9 billion.
In Mr. Besharov's view these figures undoubtedly underestimate the economic consequences of teen-age pregnancy: parental age may matter, he says, but marital status matters even more. "A married teen-age mother is less likely to go on welfare than an unmarried 25-year old mother," he says.
Ms. Maynard agrees that the numbers are conservative, but for different reasons. A good chunk of the real cost, she argues, is borne by the young parents and their children, and is thus not easily measurable. Much of the rest, the cost to the nation of tolerating chronic poverty in the midst of plenty, is spiritual rather than economic.
By Mr. Besharov's reckoning, that tolerance is less a matter of public indifference than frustration. The common approaches to deterring early pregnancy -- better access to contraception and abortion, intervention to support teen-agers' self-esteem and hope for economic advancement -- are "insufficient to turn the tide."
And what about mitigating the damage, once girls become mothers? Some 20 states now demand that young mothers on welfare go to school. Ohio goes a step further, adding $62 to the monthly checks of those who attend and subtracting $62 from the checks of dropouts.
But the Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation's analysis of Ohio's LEAP experiment suggests that the impact has been modest. Compared with a control group, the percent of mothers employed in the previous three months was somewhat higher and the percent on welfare lower. "If the employment rate holds up it's very promising," said Judy Gueron, the president of M.D.R.C. But the high school graduation rate, probably the best single indicator of the economic prospects of teen-agers, rose in only one city, Cleveland. And once mothers do drop out, the evidence from Ohio and elsewhere points to unhappy endings. "You have to do more than change welfare incentives," Ms. Gueron concludes.
The problem of early pregnancy resists easy solution. But surely one mark of a healthy society is that defeat does not lead to defeatism. Hence the virtue of reminding Americans of the dimensions of the scourge. "The real value of looking at the narrow dollars and cents calculation," Ms. Maynard concludes, "is that people will pay attention."

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
Plan Is to Keep the Kids And Hope for the Best

BYLINE: By Claire Smith 

 BODY:
Joe Torre and Bob Watson emerged from the muck and mire of the Yankees-Twins rainout yesterday with two sets of priorities.
Torre, the manager, had to figure out how to get a starting rotation that is thin, young and in one case ailing through a four-game weekend series in Cleveland. 
 Watson, the general manager, has to figure out how to get the rotation through the season while keeping the club atop the American League East.
Because he has most of his "A" team on the disabled list (Jimmy Key, David Cone, Melido Perez) and because Scott Kamieniecki is struggling to find confidence and control in the minors, Watson is concerned about the current situation. Dwight Gooden and Kenny Rogers -- plus lots of crossed fingers regarding the ailing Andy Pettitte and the young and unproven Brian Boehringer and Ramiro Mendoza -- fill the rotation.
He's concerned, Watson acknowledged, "but I'm not concerned enough to do something stupid."
Stupid, as in making the decision, either right or wrong, that will disappoint George Steinbrenner, the owner whose modus operandi assures that he will want Watson to fix what ails Yankee pitching, then will pick over why such means were used to reach whatever end Watson manages.
Thus, the conundrum: Bring a winning team in, but not by blowing Steinbrenner's budget or the Yankees' future by trading kids for veterans. And thus, Watson's conservative approach.
"Right now, our scouts out there tell me that our kids are as good as some of the veterans throwing out there right now," Watson said. "And the price for those veteran guys in terms of money and the talent that I would have to give up is not worth it. That's why we've made the decision to go with the kids right now."
Those kids, Boehringer and Mendoza, are a combined 1-4, with earned run averages tipping the scales at over 8.00. What their numbers will look like after tomorrow could be frightening, considering that those two rookies get to start both ends of a day-night doubleheader against the powerful and defending American League champion Indians.
Stumble in Cleveland and both kids could be made to disappear before Rogers takes the mound on Saturday. Watson knows that just because the owner has been passive thus far doesn't mean he will stay that way. And the g.m. admitted: "It's been a pretty tough sale for Mr. Steinbrenner to have some household names supposedly to come in and do something. But myself, the scouts, Joe Torre and Mel Stottlemyre all believe this is the right way to go.
"The coaches have got to coach. The manager's got to manage. And there's only so much money you can spend and there's only so many kids you can trade. This organization gave up quite a few kids last year in trades and there's not that many left."
One thing that could change the Yankees' thinking in a hurry is the status of Pettitte, one of only two 11-game winners in the league, but a pitcher with tightness in his left elbow. "That's a wild card in this whole thing," conceded Watson, who awaits a workout by Pettitte today that will determine if the left-hander starts on Sunday or heads to the disabled list.
Watson's protective stance over the Yankees' pool of minor league untouchables leaves few other avenues for action. The club could pick over other teams' castoffs. But the Yankees opted not to go near Greg Swindell, a hard thrower both Watson and Stottlemyre were familiar with from their days in Houston. "We just didn't want to go down that path," Watson said of the pitcher the Astros released and Cleveland subsequently signed.
The Yankees did sign Wally Whitehurst after the former Met-turned-journeyman was released last week from Montreal's farm system. Whitehurst is trying to win favor in the minors by outdoing pitchers like the shellshocked Kamieniecki.
But let's face it: The answer can't be Wally Whitehurst, a pitcher who last appeared in the majors in 1994 -- when he and his 4-7 record and 4.92 e.r.a. were released by San Diego. If the Boehringers and the Mendozas aren't the answers, either, Watson will have to go trawling. The waters may look more appealing if that fishing expedition coincides with the inevitable fire sale conducted by noncontenders seeking to dump salaries.
And what if Kansas City decides to unload a Kevin Appier or Cincinnati a John Smiley or Toronto a Juan Guzman? Could any of the above be the next pennant-stretch find, a la David Cone?
"Those are guys in another echelon," Watson acknowledged. "But the thing of it is, I've got those kinds of guys coming back myself -- Key, Perez and, knock on wood, Cone. So I've always told everybody I would listen to anything if it made baseball sense and economic sense. Some of these don't make either."

HEADLINE: Alarm Bells Sounding as Suburbs Gobble Up California's Richest Farmland

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: FRESNO, Calif.

 BODY:
Born and raised in this, the most fruitful farm county in America, David Mas Masumoto sighed as his van passed the pastel swaths of suburbia that have displaced many of the vivid orchards, vineyards and strawberry fields of his childhood.
As if mocking the vanished bounty, the clusters of ranch houses, lawns and new blacktop here in Fresno County bear faux-farm names like Vineyard Glen and Harvest Park. The names brought a sad smile from Mr. Masumoto, a peach grower. 
 "Ironically, it's only a harvest of houses," he said. "Meanwhile, in the last hour, one acre of farmland has been yanked out somewhere in the Central Valley."
The lament over uncontrolled growth is virtually California's state anthem. The signature method of planning -- or failing to plan -- development has always been simple sprawl.
But now that breakneck suburbanization has come to the sunny Central Valley, the incomparable cornucopia of 250 crops that fill supermarket produce sections from New York to Anchorage, it is prompting a new groundswell of alarm. The concern is reaching as far as Congress and as near as individual farmers like Mr. Masumoto.
"If growth patterns don't change, the Central Valley will become another Los Angeles," said Ralph Grossi, president of the American Farmland Trust, a national nonprofit group seeking to protect farmland. "In our view, it's a national treasure, a strategic resource that needs to be protected."
The Central Valley, the 50-mile-wide basin between the Pacific coastal mountains and the Sierra Nevada, stretches 300 miles from above Sacramento in the north to below Bakersfield in the south. Agriculture experts say the Valley has the richest farmland in the United States and perhaps the world.
A recent report of the American Farmland Trust, based on the California Department of Finance's projections of current growth rates, found that the Valley's population would triple by 2040 to 12 million and that housing would eat up more than 1 million of the 6.7 million acres of irrigated Valley farmland.
Rudy Platzek, an urban planner, predicts that by 2080, only about one lifetime from now, the Valley will not even be able to feed itself, let alone continue to harvest its current $13 billion in produce each year. Mr. Platzek's work is the cover story for California Farmer magazine this month under the apocalyptic headline, "An Urban Central Valley?"
Such projections have mobilized a variety of groups to start agitating for better protection of farmland, from the first Farmland Protection Caucus, formed in Congress this year, to local groups like the proposed Fresno County Growth Alternatives Task Force.
Last fall, the California Legislature passed a statewide cropland protection program to help compensate farmers who prohibit development on their land, and the farm bill signed by President Clinton this year provides for the first time for Federal matching matching for states with such programs.
The Central Valley is not the only place with the problem of urban sprawl; in South Florida, suburbia is expanding especially rapidly into rich farmland. Nationwide, one million acres of productive farmland gives way to development each year.
The change is most dramatic in places like Fresno, where signs promising inexpensive houses, "from the $90's," or dangling the prospect of "$760 a month and you're home" draw escapees from the nearly New York-level prices around San Francisco and Los Angeles.
In 1994, Fresno County alone turned out $3 billon in agriculture produce, $500 million more than the second-most-productive American county, Tulare, just to the south.
The Valley's population growth stems both from the influx of house-seekers and from the big families still common among the large Hispanic and Southeast Asian immigrant populations, officials say. Its growth has proceeded apace in recent years despite the slowdown in Southern California's economy.
The subdivisions in Clovis, just north of Fresno, are springing up so fast that they leave the likes of Tua Yang, a tenant strawberry farmer originally from Laos, shuttling from one plot to another as houses and streets eat up cropland.
Last year, Mr. Yang said, he grew a healthy crop of strawberries on four acres. This year, that land is occupied by the California Rosewood Collection development, its houses on "extra large lots" sprouting as fast as mushrooms after rain.
The Yangs had invested in fumigation of their land that would have lasted for two years, they said, but they had to move after one. This year's crop, on less productive land, is small and misshapen.
"It gives me a heartache to see that my parents have been pushed out," said Xua Yang, 27, Mr. Yang's daughter. "It hurts."
The coalescing alliances of farmers, conservationists and politicians seeking to protect farmland acknowledge that growth and development in the Valley are inevitable. They say they are fighting for smarter growth and coordinated zoning that preserves active farmland and requires housing to be denser, thus using up less land.
The American Farmland Trust report calculated that if Central Valley developments averaged six houses per acre -- instead of the current three -- 500,000 acres of farmland would be saved by 2040.
That leaves would-be preservers of farmland with the task of persuading the American people to relinquish the four-bedroom, half-acre suburban dream. It is not an easy task, they acknowledge.
"We can't seem to associate quality of life with any development pattern except the traditional single-family house with your fence and your yard,' said Karen Humphrey, Mayor of Fresno from 1989 to 1993 and now a planning consultant.
Many Central Valley cities and towns do draw zoning lines around themselves and try to limit sprawl, but they tend to lack the political will to stand against market pressures.
Advocates of farmland protection are also pushing for "conservation easements," in which private, state or Federal money could compensate farmers who prohibit development on their land rather than selling out for a retirement nest egg. For example, the California measure passed last year created a program to help compensate farmers who write into the deeds of their property that it can be used only for agriculture.
The difference between selling farmland to a developer and selling it for continued farming can be giant, said Bill Allison, manager of the Fresno County Farm Bureau. Around here, farmland sells for $10,000 to $15,000 an acre, while development land goes for more than $50,000, Mr. Allison said.
That gap leaves farmers divided over plans that might keep them from realizing top profit for their land after years of sweat.
Mr. Masumoto, a writer as well as a farmer, whose latest book about his organic farm is "Epitaph for a Peach" (Harper Collins 1995), said many farmers despaired about their prospects for continuing farming when growth encroaches. As the land around the farmers is suburbanized, the competition for water mounts, and neighbors do not take kindly to typical farm activities like the spraying of pesticides and early-morning tractor work.
"It's tough because the battlegrounds aren't on our farms," he said. "They're at public hearings and in politicians' offices, and we're not used to that. We're used to working on our own territory."
It is also a subtle battle that the farmland preservers are waging, one that requires trying to influence thousands of local decisions that, taken together, determine the shape of the Valley's development.
The American Farmland Trust says it is making progress in getting out the word that denser development is better, that states need programs to conserve farmland and that sprawl means scarcer water as well as higher taxes because it saps municipal services.
But old hands like Mr. Allison at the Farm Bureau, wonder whether anything can really stop growth. Fifty years ago, he noted, Los Angeles County, not Fresno County, was the country's most productive farming county; now it is a megalopolis.
Mr. Allison said he did not know who could say, No, you can't build on this farmland. After all, he said, "it's been going on since the white settlers came here."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Brewers localize their ad campaigns to get the down home flavor into their Texas commercials.

BYLINE: By David Barboza 

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
THE nation's premier brewers are jockeying for position in one of the largest markets -- Texas, and the resulting trend is a three-headed stallion galloping around the bend in advertising's latest sport: regional marketing.
While most major brands start nationwide print and television ad blitzes, large beer producers such as Miller, Budweiser and Coors are increasingly turning toward regionalized marketing -- the use of state and regional themes, icons, mannerisms and even stereotypes -- to take aim at consumers in distinctive states like Texas. 
 For instance, in recent years, the three big brewers have conjured up tornadoes, dust storms, rodeos and Tejano music fests in their television spots, hoping portrayals of such Texas perennials will appeal to native tastes. And while California has inspired Bud Light's "Left Coast, Right Beer" campaign, Texas can boast of having its flag used as the backdrop in beer advertising spots.
"In Texas, we just completed a stand-alone campaign," said Susan Henderson, director of marketing at the Miller Brewing Company in St. Louis, which recently broke its "Livin' Grande" campaign with the Tejano music star Emilio Navaira. "The creative message is increasingly becoming localized and there is no better example than Texas."
While leading brands often supplement their national spots with regional ads in big states like California and Florida, Texas is one of the few states where regional pushes have spawned national campaigns, such as Miller's "Life is Good" theme and Bud Light's "Spot Light" campaign. As a result, brewers say that success here has yielded a variation on Thomas P. O'Neill Jr.'s insight that "all politics is local."
Miller Lite, Bud Light and Coors Light have all adopted the ubiquitous icon of the state of Texas in their campaigns. While Miller frames its neon signs in the shape of Texas, a single can of Bud Light casts a shadow shaped like Texas on regional billboards.
"Texas is a different state of mind," Victor Ornelas, president of Ornelas & Associates in Dallas, an advertising agency that aims at the Hispanic market, said. "And the best way to demonstrate to the consumer that we understand and embrace your life style, your culture and your history is to do this type of advertising."
Although some attribute these Texas-specific campaigns to the pride people take in their culture here, others note that Texans buy nearly 17 million barrels of beer a year, more beer than is consumed in Ireland and Portugal combined, according to the Beer Institute, a trade group in Washington.
With so much revenue at stake, some ad executives say brewers are more willing to invest extra money to supplement national campaigns with Texas spots, or to have an entirely fresh, stand-alone campaign.
"Increasingly, brewers are tending to localize their campaigns," said Benjamin Steinman, editor of Beer Marketer's Insights, an industry newsletter based in West Nyack, N.Y. "It's the age-old cliche: they want to get closer to the customer."
Mr. Steinman and others also say that while national brewers are extremely competitive, growth has been sluggish. "Everybody's fighting for a bigger piece of a pie that's not growing," he said. "What's really growing at a rapid rate are smaller brewers."
In fact, some suggest that the explosive growth of microbrews has helped expand regional marketing efforts. In Texas alone, sales of specialty beers rose 40 percent last year, and many of those smaller breweries are pushing their homespun Texas ties.
For instance, ads for one of the state's fastest-growing microbrews, Shiner Bock, brewed at the Spoetzl Brewery in Shiner, Tex., proclaim, "For Those Who Wish Texas Was Still Independent."
Meanwhile, ads for Ziegen Bock, the beer the Anheuser-Busch Companies created just for Texas, refer to the microbrew as a "Texas Beer with a German Accent." One print ad, created by Gleason Calise Associates in Dallas, portrays the Texas state flag, using froth and brown lager.
While only a few national advertisers, like the Coca-Cola Company, have substituted regional marketing for national spots, beer marketers insist it is a proven strategy. "The Texas campaign allows us to take it to the grass roots," said Jim Schumacker, director of marketing for Bud Light in St. Louis, who noted that sales of the beer are up 26 percent in Texas this year.
So when Bud Light was looking to translate its "Ladies Night" spots for a Texas audience, it hired DDB Needham Dallas and its Texas-born chief creative director, Jim Ferguson, to develop television spots of its cross-dressing comedians touring Texas and winning a beehive hairdo contest.
Mr. Ferguson, who returned to Texas after 10 years at Leo Burnett in Chicago, said it opened up a burst of creative energy. After viewing the new Texas "Ladies Night" spots on a television monitor in his office, he chuckled and said: "You couldn't do big hair in New York. They wouldn't get it."

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Gray Hair And Golden Ambitions

BYLINE: By DAVE ANDERSON 

DATELINE: ATLANTA

 BODY:
GRAY hair. You don't expect to see an Olympic track and field athlete with gray hair, but less than two weeks away from his 35th birthday on July 1, Carl Lewis has gray hair.
Not much. Just some flecks in his black hair that he has been known to dye, but those flecks are gray. 
 "I kind of like that gray hair," he has said. "It ties in with everything else about this year."
Yes, this year, the year he now has made the United States Olympic team for a fifth time, including in 1980 when President Jimmy Carter ordered an American boycott of the Summer Games in Moscow because of the Soviet Union's invasion of Afghanistan.
In his three other Olympic years, it was never a matter of his having to make the team, only how many gold medals he would win. Over all, his number turned out to be eight: four in 1984 at Los Angeles, two in 1988 at Seoul, South Korea, and two in 1992 at Barcelona, Spain.
Most people think of Carl Lewis as a sprinter, but he soared to the gold medal in the long jump in each of the last three Summer Games. He has another two golds in the 100-meter dash, one in the 200 and two in the 4x100 relay.
And last night in the Olympic trials in the new Olympic Stadium, in a long jump that began with rumbles of thunder and flashes of lightning in the Georgia sky, he made the Olympic team again after having missed Saturday in the 100.
He is the first male track and field athlete to qualify for five American teams. Willye White qualified for five consecutive women's teams from 1956 through 1972.
"Once you get to the Olympics, anyone can win," Lewis was saying now. "And even if I make the team in the 200, there's nothing before the long jump for me."
Qualifying starts tomorrow in the 200 for Sunday afternoon's final, but even if he doesn't finish in the top three, as a member of the Olympic team, he could be inserted in the 4x100 relay, a possible 10th gold medal. But for all his gold medals as a sprinter, the long jump has always been his best event.
"And it's my favorite event," he said. "Before high school it was the only event I had success in. It's always been there for me."
It was there again last night, by one inch. Had Mike Conley, the Olympic triple jump gold medalist at Barcelona, not aborted his final jump on the runway after having felt a strain in his left hamstring following his fifth jump, he might have knocked Lewis out of third place and off the team.
Instead, with a leap of 27 feet 2 3/4 inches on his second jump, Lewis made the team with Mike Powell, who soared 27-6 1/2 on his final jump, and Joe Greene, who leaped 27-4 1/2.
In other eras, Olympic track and field athletes seldom competed long enough to develop gray hair. For decades they had to get a real job or exist on what was inside the envelopes slipped under the table by meet promoters.
Jesse Owens, for example, sprinted and long-jumped to four Olympic gold medals in 1936 at Berlin, but upon his return, his financial reward was a virtual circus act: racing a horse.
But the timing of Lewis's career blended with the timing of the change in Olympic economics. Just as he arrived on the scene, the International Olympic Committee woke up to reality. It permitted world-class track and field athletes to keep meet-appearance money and income from endorsements and commercials.
Jesse Owens had to race a horse. Carl Lewis could race a stock tip or a mutual fund or a bank's interest rate.
Win or lose in the Olympics next month, Lewis deserves the victory ceremony he never had for the 100 at Seoul. He was declared the winner there after Ben Johnson was stripped of the gold medal, as well as his world record of 9.79 seconds, and banned for four years after having tested positive for anabolic steroids.
"He was handed his gold medal in an office," said Jim Dunaway, a self-described "track nut" for four decades, who is now an on-line sports columnist on the World Wide Web.
Dunaway has campaigned for an eighth victory ceremony for Lewis. "We owe him that victory ceremony, the one that Ben Johnson robbed him of," he said. "The place to do it is in Atlanta."
And the way to do it is to drape that Seoul gold medal over Carl Lewis's head for all to see, even if that head had some flecks of gray.

TITLE: SPORTS OF THE TIMES (TIMES COLUMN)

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 5; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 1245 words

HEADLINE: Bill Aims to Bar Iran Investment From Overseas

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 19

 BODY:
The House of Representatives today unanimously passed harsh economic sanctions against foreign companies that invest in Iran, widening the split between the United States and its allies over the use of American economic power to force other nations to isolate rogue states.
The White House has already said President Clinton is likely to sign the legislation, which would require the President to choose at least two sanctions against any business that invests more than $40 million in Iranian oil and gas development. Among the more severe sanctions would be a measure barring American banks from lending more than $10 million to the offending companies, and another that would exclude those companies from exporting any goods or services to the United States. 
 The bill also calls for less severe sanctions against Libya for its role in the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 in December 1988, which killed 270 people.
A similar bill passed the Senate in December and it is widely expected that the Senate will adopt the House version or something close to it.
The action today was the second time this year that Congress, with the Administration's blessing, has threatened to punish foreign companies in an effort to bring other countries' trade policies in line with Washington's efforts to isolate another nation; the first action was directed at Cuba.
The State Department warned top executives of Canadian and Mexican companies last week that they may be barred from entering the United States because their companies do business with Cuba. The legislation that led to that warning, the Helms-Burton Act, has already caused sharp exchanges with America's biggest trading partners, most recently during a meeting between President Clinton and leaders of the European Union.
Other nations argue that the United States has no right to impose sanctions against companies not based in the United States, and point out that Washington fought such secondary boycotts when Arab nations threatened foreign companies that did business with Israel.
They are expected to repeat those arguments to Mr. Clinton next week, at the annual meeting of the leaders of the Group of Seven industrial countries. The three-day meeting begins next Thursday in Lyons, France.
European officials said today that they were likely to take the United States to the new court of international trade disputes, the World Trade Organization in Geneva, in an effort to force the United States to overturn the legislation or suffer trade sanctions. That would mark the first major showdown over international trade policy at the organization, which the United States fought to create.
But in the interim, some countries may retaliate; Canada is so angry about the Cuba legislation that it is ordering its companies to ignore the American threats.
Cuba, however, is a tiny market. Iran, in contrast, is the site of billions of dollars in European oil investment, and it has been increasingly attractive to Asian companies that want to guarantee their access to oil supplies in the Middle East.
France has been particularly aggressive in investing there, and the Congressional legislation was sparked by a deal that Total S.A., a French oil company, signed with Iran after President Clinton forced Conoco Inc. to give up plans to develop two large offshore oilfields for Iran. The Conoco episode, involving what some analysts valued at $1 billion, led President Clinton to impose an embargo on all American investment in Iran. But not a single ally of the United States has joined the embargo.
It is hard to determine how many companies will be affected by the sanctions because the bill affects future investments in the oil sector, rather than existing foreign-financed operations in Iran. But a number of French and German companies, along with oil-service companies in Japan and South Korea, among other countries, are likely to be the first to face the question of whether to defy the measure.
Today, seeking to deflect criticism from abroad, Administration officials took the offensive, arguing that only the United States has shown the courage to use its economic power against terrorist states.
"You know, when the G-7 meets we all agree that these issues about terrorism are important, and we all ought to do something," Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said in his office this morning. "And then we are the only ones who do anything."
At the State Department, Nicholas Burns, the spokesman, said: "We think it's very important to isolate Iran economically. And here we have a difference of opinion with some of our allies in Europe, because of Iran's intention to build a nuclear weapons capability. And we are convinced that that is what Iran intends to do." Iran and Libya are both on the State Department's list of nations that support terrorism.
The legislation that passed in the House today is considerably watered down from a bill first proposed last year by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York. He sought to punish foreign companies that conduct any trade with Iran -- rather than those that invest heavily there -- and he sought the most severe punishment Washington can muster: banning them from selling their products in the United States.
The White House argued that that measure was too inflexible, and spent months negotiating with Mr. D'Amato and others on the wording of the bill that passed today, 415 to 0. It gives the President far more discretion to calibrate sanctions as he wishes against companies that invest more than $40 million in Iran in a year. While the figure sounds high, it is considered fairly minimal in the oil business, where the costs of finding and developing offshore oil fields are often staggering.
The menu of sanctions include some that are considered relatively minor: denying loans and loan guarantees from the Export-Import Bank of the United States, which helps American companies invest in projects abroad, and denying export licenses for United States goods to companies investing in Iran.
Other potential sanctions, however, are more severe. The President could, for example, bar American banks from making loans of more than $10 million to companies or countries that are sanctioned, and he could bar financial institutions that violate the embargo from serving as primary dealers in United States Government bonds, cutting them out of a very lucrative business on world financial markets. He could also ban the offending companies from selling goods to the United States Government and he could bar all imports from the foreign companies.
Many in the business community, however, say they fear the legislation will ultimately hurt American companies. "It will force many U.S. companies to avoid the international arena," said Robin West, president of the Petroleum Finance Company. Other oil industry executives said they expected the bill would hurt oil-service companies hoping to enter joint ventures with European and Asian companies.
"The Germans are absolutely apopleptic about this bill," Mr. West added. "Throughout Europe, there is a fear that Congress will use this kind of mechanism more and more to preempt the foreign economic policy of other countries."
But in Congress and within the White House, the predominant view is that Europe invited this action by failing to face up to evidence that Iran is still sponsoring terrorism and seeking to acquire nuclear weapons.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1718 words

HEADLINE: Counterfeiters of a New Stripe Give Japan One More Worry;
Fake Cards Thwart Efforts to End Pinball Scams

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 19

 BODY:
Why is it that every time someone gambles with metal, the Sumitomo Corporation takes a bath? Everyone knows by now of the $1.8 billion loss that was caused by a rogue trader in copper futures. But only a month ago, Sumitomo was in the headlines as a victim of one of the largest electronic crimes in history -- involving, of all things, pinball.
The Japanese fritter away billions of dollars a year sitting in garish parlors playing pachinko, a pinball-like game that is a form of gambling. The infatuation has long been considered a corrupting social force: some parlor owners evade taxes and funnel cash to organized crime, and profits of Korean parlor owners are a big source of cash for North Korea's teetering economy. 
 So it seemed like a good idea when the National Police Agency, with help from Sumitomo and other blue-chip companies, hatched a plan to tame the pachinko industry.
The solution? Get rid of the cash and encourage players to use prepaid magnetic cards, similar to those used in the subways in Washington, San Francisco and New York.
The problem was that counterfeiters figured out how to forge the cards, despite assurances by the card's creator, Japan's main telephone company, that this would be next to impossible. The result: the system meant to deter crime instead created more of it.
When the dust had settled, the two companies that had issued the cards -- one backed by Sumitomo and one by the Mitsubishi Corporation -- reported last month that they had lost almost $600 million, and Japan Inc. had suffered another profound embarrassment.
The pachinko caper echoes far beyond Japan, serving as a cautionary tale as the world moves toward digital cash, with money reduced to ones and zeros on a card or in a computer. It could be far easier to manipulate computer codes than to rob a bank or create counterfeit bills.
"This is a tip-of-the-iceberg problem," said Peter G. Neumann, a computer security expert at SRI International, a research institute in Menlo Park, Calif. "You are going to put a lot of money out there and someone is going to figure out how to take it away from you."
The forged pachinko cards were "an almost endless source of money," lamented Minoru Makihara, president of Mitsubishi. Its Nippon Leisure Card System Company lost 55 billion yen, or about $510 million. Mitsubishi itself, which owned 19 percent of the card company, set aside 5 billion yen, or $46 million, to cover its share of the losses.
Sumitomo was luckier because its pachinko card subsidiary, the Nippon Game Card Company, focused on Osaka while the forgers congregated in Tokyo. Nippon Game Card lost 8 billion yen, or about $75 million, small enough that it still managed to turn a profit for the last fiscal year.
The losses show the risks Japan's trading companies are incurring as they diversify. Their traditional business is diminishing with Japanese companies now able to handle importing and exporting by themselves. Until the recent counterfeiting headaches, pachinko cards had been a fast-growing business for Sumitomo.
And for Japan as a whole, the forgeries serve as a rude awakening.
Electronic security is not rigorous here, in part out of a general belief that people are honest. But Japan is no longer isolated. Indeed, of the 1,400 people arrested for making, using or selling counterfeit pachinko cards between January 1995 and April 1996, more than 900 were foreigners, many of them members of Chinese gangs.
Experts say it is not too difficult to forge cards that feature magnetic stripes, both credit cards and prepaid cards. But the prepaid cards are widely used -- especially in Japan, where many pay phones no longer even accept coins -- because they are convenient and are less expensive than newer, more secure cards imbedded with computer chips.
The stripes, not much different from magnetic tape, can be copied just as tapes can be dubbed. And just as it is easy to record one song over another on a cassette, with the proper equipment new information can be written on a magnetic stripe, adding value to a card. To forge telephone cards, criminals steal public phones, which have card-writing mechanisms inside, then figure out how to write the desired information.
In most cases, there is only a limited incentive to counterfeit a card. There are only so many long-distance calls one can make or trains one can ride. The only way to turn a counterfeit phone or train card into money is to sell it.
Forged pachinko cards, though, can be converted almost directly into cash. Criminals use the forged cards to get pachinko balls, which, like casino chips, can be cashed in for money. One does not even have to play the game.
Pachinko is basically a vertical pinball game in which the goal is to win more balls.
Because gambling is technically illegal in Japan, the player is not supposed to be permitted to turn the balls in for cash, only for prizes like a box of cookies or a watch. But players in the know opt for seemingly worthless trinkets, which they take to a window in a nearby back alley and exchange for a set amount of cash.
Pachinko is big business. There are more than 18,000 pachinko parlors, each beckoning with neon lights, and 4.7 million machines, or about one for every 26 Japanese. Some 300 million prepaid pachinko cards are issued each month. The parlors' annual revenues are estimated at $300 billion, roughly matching the worldwide sales of Japan's 11 auto makers.
Customers sit shoulder to shoulder on small stools in a haze of cigarette smoke, staring as if in a trance at falling balls. The Japanese, it is said, can find solitude in the anonymity of the pachinko parlor and peace amid the cacophonous din of boinging balls, beeping machines, rock music and constant exhortations over loudspeakers.
Players can easily fritter away $100 in half an hour. And while some players can win hundreds of dollars in a day, the odds favor the house. Players buy balls for about 4 yen apiece but cash them in for only 2.5 yen.
The move toward prepaid cards began in the late 1980's, when the two companies were started to provide cards and card machines, with some former police officials in their executive ranks. The NTT Data Communications Systems Corporation, a subsidiary of the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, supplied the card technology.
Since pachinko operators need police permission to open a shop, it was not hard for the police to persuade parlors to adopt the card systems. Now, 70 percent of parlors have card-reading machines.
Officials of the pachinko industry say they worried about forgeries from the beginning because there had long been a problem with the forging of phone cards. But officials said they were assured by NTT Data that the pachinko cards would be more secure. "Every time we asked they said, 'Don't worry,' " said Mamoru Uchida, secretary general of the Japan Pachinko Hall Industry Association.
They turned out to be anything but secure.
The magazine Weekly Asahi quoted an anonymous boss of a forging ring describing the feeding frenzy at one Tokyo parlor: "About 300 people, all with forged cards and 80 percent of them foreigners, lined up in front of the shop at 6 A.M. When the shop opened at 10, the 'customers' rushed in to get to the card-reading machines."
Another problem was the way the system was set up. Card companies are paid when cards are bought. Then, when a card is used to buy balls, the card company reimburses the shop, minus a commission.
The parlors thus are reimbursed whether the player uses a real card or a fake. Parlor operators not only have little incentive to stop forged cards -- some who tried ended up being stabbed -- but fake cards actually help their business.
In a few cases, parlor owners -- some not the most reputable characters to begin with -- fed fake cards into machines themselves to inflate their revenues.
Ryozo Ohno, an executive at NTT Data, said the pachinko cards have three security features. The card itself, made of a sophisticated magnetic material, is physically hard to fabricate. The data on the card are encrypted. And multiple magnetic levels introduce interference that makes it hard to simply copy the data.
The first two, it turns out, did not help much, he said. Forgers did not need to fabricate cards -- they simply used old ones, filling the punched holes that indicated the card had been used. And the encryption did not matter because the forgers did not need to break the code -- they simply copied information from a legitimate card.
The difficulty in reading and writing data did prevent wide-scale copying for a time, Mr. Ohno said. But people eventually figured out how to build card-copying machines.
To help in the process, counterfeiters stole card-reading machines from pachinko parlors. Some 127 machines were stolen from a parlor in Fukushima Prefecture, north of Tokyo, in what appeared to be an inside job. And industry officials say card machines mysteriously vanished from parlors that collapsed in last year's earthquake in Kobe.
Now, the losses from forgers are on the wane. The card companies stopped the use of cards worth 5,000 yen and 10,000 yen, or about $50 and $100, leaving only smaller denominations in use. And they are getting tougher with parlors that tolerate fake cards.
NTT Data and the two card companies are now working on a new, more secure system that will involve magnetic stripes plus some other technology to insure authenticity.
Other companies hope to enter the field with different technologies.
The Advance Company, a Tokyo maker of encryption technology, hopes to see its encoding techniques used. The American Banknote Corporation, a New York company that prints food stamps, Treasury checks and other value-laden documents, is working with a group of Japanese companies on a system using holography to verify the authenticity of pachinko cards, said Morris Weissman, chairman and chief executive.
The president of Nippon Leisure Card was recently changed. And Mr. Ohno of NTT Data is now sadder but wiser.
"Electronic money, digital cash, the Internet -- it's so convenient and so many people envision a dreamy future," he said. "But once you consider the security, it's quite vulnerable."

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

House Approves Sanctions Against Investment in Iran
The House of Representatives unanimously approved harsh economic sanctions against foreign companies that invest in Iran, widening the split between the United States and its allies over the use of American economic power.
The White House has said President Clinton is likely to sign the legislation, which also calls for less severe sanctions against Libya. [Page A1.]
 
The Clinton Administration agreed to honor a ruling against the United States by the World Trade Organization, saying that it would change the way it applies environmental regulations to imported gasoline. [D4.]
 
Bank of New York Adds to Reserves
The Bank of New York will put $350 million into its reserves for future losses in its credit-card portfolio, more evidence that banks are running into unexpected trouble with their consumer loans. [D2.]
 
Thomson Deal Clears Hurdle
The Justice Department conditionally approved Thomson's $3.4 billion purchase of West Publishing. But Thomson has to sell 58 legal publications and license services to rivals to avoid stifling competition in on-line legal research. W. Michael Brown, Thomson's chief executive, said his company accepted the provisions. [D6.]
 
Valujet Accused of Ignoring Defects
The F.A.A. detailed its reasons for grounding Valujet, saying it flew DC-9's that it knew to have broken or malfunctioning parts, without inspecting or repairing them. [A10.]
 
Alco Standard to Split
In the dismantling of a former conglomerate, Alco Standard will split into two companies -- one a distributor of paper products, the other of office copiers and fax machines. [D5.]
 
Gap Widens Between Rich and Poor
Using new methods of data collection that it said provide a more accurate picture of incomes, the Census Bureau said the gap between the most affluent Americans and everyone else had widened. [A1.]
 
Tele-Communications Spinoff
Tele-Communications, the nation's largest cable operator, said it would spin off its direct-to-home satellite business. [D6.]
 
London Metal Trading Under Review
Responding to Sumitomo's copper trading scandal, British regulators plan to conduct a six-month investigation into trading on the London Metal Exchange. The board is already investigating possible involvement of British dealers in trades with Yasuo Hamanaka, left, Sumitomo's top copper trader, who acknowledged losing $1.8 billion as a result of unauthorized trades over 10 years. [D4.]
 
Downsizing Hits Europe
Downsizing is coming to Western Europe's white-collar workers, straining families, communities and politics on a continent where 11 percent of workers are unemployed, double the rate in the United States. [A1.]
 
Texas Instruments Wins Dispute
Texas Instruments claimed victory in a six-year dispute concerning the invention of the computer-on-a-chip. The company said the United States Patent Office had affirmed that one of its former engineers invented the single-chip microcontroller. [D5.]
 
General Mills Cuts Cereal Prices
General Mills followed other cereal makers, cutting prices about 11 percent on such brands as Cocoa Puffs and Trix. [D3.]

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk
