HEADLINE: EUROPE, DOWNSIZED -- A special report.;
In Europe, a Wave of Layoffs Stuns White-Collar Workers

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: ROME

 BODY:
Downsizing is coming to Western Europe's white-collar workers, and fast. It is straining families, communities and politics on a continent on which 11 percent of available workers are already unemployed, double the rate in the United States.
Many of the discarded workers are people in their 50's who take large early-retirement packages and suffer little if any financial hardship, like Heinz Thannheiser, a 57-year-old lawyer and manager at a Munich bank. He will give up his $83,000-a-year job for a lump sum that combined with generous government benefits will assure him a comfortable retirement. 
 But these generous packages are burdening European companies and governments, which provide supplemental benefits for people who lose their jobs. And this is happening even as businesses try to cut their costs and as European nations try to impose a financial austerity so they can meet the strict requirements necessary to introduce a single currency by 1999. As a result, many Europeans expect that future severance packages will be far less generous.
As early retirements prove insufficient for companies looking to cut costs, the downsizing is spreading to younger workers like Daniel Roux, a 33-year-old bond salesman laid off earlier this year by a Paris bank not long after being told how important he would be in the company's expansion. After some looking, Mr. Roux found another job, but the expectation is that such searches will become increasingly difficult.
The swiftness and size of the cuts have shocked many people on a continent where cradle-to-grave security was a given and where companies played a big role in assuring that. A lifetime job is increasingly a thing of the past.
"As in the United States in the 1980's, the cold shower is hitting us," said Kurt Vogler-Ludwig, a labor-market expert at the IFO Institute for Economic Research in Munich. "The net effect on jobs is negative. The positive side is only in share prices. It has gone faster than anyone thought possible."
For more than a decade after downsizing began in earnest in the United States around 1980, European nations were able to resist the tactic because of a web of government restrictions that helped discourage layoffs. Given the difficulty of dismissing workers except in dire situations, European business became exceedingly cautious about adding employees and about taking risks on new investments that might create even more jobs. The result, experts now agree, is that employment growth stagnated and European businesses, including those in technology, telecommunications and finance, developed a hardening of the arteries that threatened to leave them further and further behind in global competition.
As businesses in other parts of the world, including the United States, have streamlined, European companies have become downright uncompetitive. At the same time, they are feeling mounting pressure from shareholders, tempted by higher returns elsewhere, to reduce costs to widen profit margins. Hence the job cuts.
[On Wednesday, for example, shares of the French appliance maker Moulinex soared 21 percent after the company disclosed plans to cut as many as 2,600 jobs, a fifth of its work force.]
European jobs have been evaporating for more than two decades in farming and in industries like steel and mining. The number of people working in these businesses fell by about 15 percent, to about 64 million between 1980 and 1993, when excluding workers in the former East Germany.
Now, however, the cuts are spreading to white-collar employees, previously considered immune, and even at companies that are profitable. In the economically healthy decade ending in 1992, the number of people working in service industries like banking and insurance rose more than 20 percent, to nearly 104 million, according to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. But in 1993, the latest year for which figures were available, the number of service workers fell 3 percent, and everyone agrees the number has continued to fall since then, with further losses expected.
Worsening the problem is that far fewer jobs have been created in European nations than in the United States, meaning fewer opportunities for those cast off. The United States, which has only about two-thirds as many people working as Europe, has added a net total of 24 million jobs to its economy since 1980, while the European Union increased the number of people with jobs by fewer than nine million, excluding workers in eastern Germany. And, as in the United States, many of the new jobs are either part time or of limited duration, with lower pay and fewer benefits than was customary.
Jobs will be the main topic on June 21 and 22, when European heads of state and government leaders meet in Florence. And next month, when the annual gathering of leaders of seven major industrial powers takes place in France, unemployment will be an important subject.
Downsizing is a particularly sticky topic because lifetime employment is so ingrained here. Many economists and business people say that only by giving employers more leeway in firing and hiring can Europe hope to remain competitive. But the idea is still repulsive to many Europeans. Mr. Vogler-Ludwig, the Munich labor expert, said the fundamental questions would be: "With what rules can you construct a flexible system? Where is the optimal point between structure and flexibility?"
 
The Scope
From Olivetti To Big Banks
Hiring continues in some businesses, of course, like software development and entertainment. But in many others, the cuts have been large.
Olivetti S.p.A., Italy's giant office equipment and telecommunications company, nearly halved its work force to fewer than 30,000 employees from 58,000 in 1989 as part of a recovery plan after years of losses. Explaining the job cuts, many of them managers, Olivetti's chairman, Carlo De Benedetti, said the company had "underestimated the rapidity of change in the industry, and the pressure on margins."
And, likening the magnitude of his job cuts to those by American companies, he added, "That is half of the company, the way I.B.M. or Digital Equipment did it."
Olivetti is no longer alone. In Italy, more than 70,000 middle- and upper-level managers have been laid off since 1992. In France last year, 10 of the largest banks and corporations, including Credit Lyonnais and Michelin, cut more than 25,000 jobs, their first significant reduction. In Germany, labor unions are bracing for major job cuts in banking, insurance and telecommunications.
Among the hardest hit have been major centers of financial services like London, where, according to the British Bankers Association, more than 81,000 banking jobs have been slashed since 1991. Others, like Paris, Frankfurt and Munich, are certain to follow.
Large layoffs also loom in telecommunications, where state-owned giants are trimming down for privatization. Already, British Telecommunications, which went private a decade ago, has cut employment by 90,000, or more than a third of the total. In Germany, Deutsche Telekom foresees eliminating 70,000 jobs, or about a third of the total, by the year 2000.
Large mergers, once rare, are becoming more common and costing jobs. The recent merger of two of Switzerland's largest chemical and pharmaceutical companies, Sandoz and Ciba-Geigy, will lead to a 10 percent cut in jobs worldwide, including more than 6,000 in Europe.
 
The Approach
Early Retirement Versus Layoffs
What distinguishes jobs eliminated in Europe from cuts in the United States is that by far the largest number have come through early retirement, rather than by laying off younger workers. In Germany, the average retirement age is now 57, down from around 60 a decade ago; in France, only one in four employees reaching 60, the retirement age for most, is still employed.
Generous severance agreements assure European employees retirement benefits that most Americans can only envy. The package awaiting Mr. Thannheiser when he leaves the bank on Sept. 1 is typical.
Mr. Thannheiser helped manage the legal department at Germany's sixth-largest bank, Bayerische Hypotheken-und Wechsel-Bank. After the fall of the Berlin wall, Hypo Bank, as it is called, joined dozens of other German banks in a rush into formerly Communist East Germany, opening 80 branches. At its Munich headquarters, support services like data processing and legal affairs were beefed up to handle the expected new business.
But the hoped-for turnaround in eastern Germany has been slow in coming, and last year Hypo Bank asked consultants at McKinsey & Company how to cut costs. Part of the answer was to cut 600 of 3,000 jobs at headquarters, including Mr. Thannheiser's.
Under an accord reached with unions (most white-collar Europeans are represented by unions), Hypo Bank will pay Mr. Thannheiser about $170,000 in severance, or about twice his annual salary.
In addition, he will qualify for unemployment benefits roughly equal to 65 percent of his final pay; their start will be delayed by about six to nine months because of the amount of his severance package. Those benefits will support him until he turns 60 in two years, when he will qualify for a monthly pension paid from the Government social security fund, his bank's pension plan, and a labor union pension fund. That payment will be only slightly less than his final salary.
Since his house near Munich is paid off, his wife, a physical therapist, works, and his daughter, 27, a cabinet maker, is independent, Mr. Thannheiser acknowledges that from a material point of view he is well off and, like many such workers, doesn't need to find a new job. Yet, he says: "To put it brutally, I sold my job. And it is a shock to know you're not needed."
As companies decide that early-retirement packages like Mr. Thannheiser's are too expensive, they are looking for younger workers to cut as well. This is what happened to Mr. Roux at Banque Nationale. Hired two years ago when the bank was bent on expanding bond sales and trading, Mr. Roux, now 33 and with two small children, was one of many employees, mostly traders and sales personnel, who found themselves on the street when management decided earlier this year to retrench. Unlike Mr. Thannheiser, Mr. Roux received only several months pay as severance.
 
The Solutions
New Attempts To Create Jobs?
The prospect of younger Europeans like Mr. Roux without employment has ignited an impassioned debate among European leaders about how to create new jobs. There is a growing awareness that Europe's future prosperity, even its political stability, hinges on its ability to allow more Europeans to remain productive longer.
Indeed, companies and governments must bear the growing cost of unemployment and retirement benefits. That merely accelerates the exodus of jobs from Europe to America and East Asia where personnel costs are lower.
In 1995, complains Friedhelm Ost, the chairman of the German Parliament's economics committee, German companies invested $73 billion overseas, while foreign investment in Germany totaled only $10 billion. "The more social costs rise, the fewer jobs there are and the more people have to pay to support the system," he said. "We must intervene to break the cycle."
Britain was the first to do something about this; in the 1980's it reduced the cost of benefits and overcame union opposition in simplifying hiring and firing.
Now, in Germany, Chancellor Helmut Kohl has pledged to cut unemployment by half before the year 2000 with a legislative package designed to create jobs by cutting benefits like paid sick leave, simplifying the rules for part-time or temporary employment, and slashing the thicket of regulations regarding everything from environmental safeguards to the hours bread can be baked on Sundays.
As Germany goes, so often goes the rest of Europe. In Italy and Scandinavia, governments are also looking to cut social costs, clear regulatory obstacles, and allow part-time and temporary work.
Germany's powerful labor unions, for decades Europe's pace-setters in seeking to spawn jobs mainly by reducing the hours individual employees work, have begun a painful process of rethinking their beliefs.
Other countries, regardless of the politics of their governments, are following suit.
In Spain, the former Socialist-led government braved a general strike two years ago to enact legislation that made it easier for companies to fire people. Rigid employee protection laws, a relic of the Franco dictatorship, had given Spain a 23.9 percent unemployment rate, double the European average. The trend has now reversed, with job growth of more than 2 percent and the first drop in unemployment since 1991, to 22.7 percent.
In Italy, industry, unions and the new leftist-led Government are seeking agreement to make pay rates more flexible.
"It is absurd to have the same pay scales in our northeast, where the labor market is saturated, and in the south, where you have 50 percent youth unemployment," said Giampaolo Galli, chief economist of the Italian Industry Association.
Yet politically, Europeans are increasingly using the vote, or labor action, to protect the social safety net to which generations have grown accustomed.
When President Jacques Chirac told the French last year that they would have to brace for years of austerity -- lower pay raises and reductions in benefits, for example -- as the unavoidable cost of restoring economic growth, a wave of strikes forced the Government to backtrack. In Italy, the recent elections producing a coalition government that includes for the first time since World War II cabinet ministers from the once-Communist Party of the Democratic Left reflected concerns for the social net.
Thus many of the contemplated job-creating measures may prove elusive. After all, Europe is still a place with much less of a free-market spirit than the United States.
It was only recently that the German Government, after decades of debate, finally agreed to expand slightly the number of hours stores may remain open; most economists agree that more such liberalization will create jobs in retail trade. In France, protests by independent store owners were met by President Chirac with a pledge to halt by law the construction of large suburban shopping centers. [Moulinex's plans, announced Tuesday, to cut 2,600 jobs touched off a debate in the French Government, with Industry Minister Franck Borotra calling the job cuts unacceptable, but Finance Minister Jean Arthuis conceding that Moulinex "needed restructuring."]
"There's a feeling in Europe that the economy is like a static pie," said David L. Aaron, the United States Ambassador to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, in Paris, which is advising governments on job creation. "If you allow shopping centers in the suburbs, they believe, you won't have spending in the cities. We think you have to focus on increasing the size of the pie."
 
The Damage
Sense of Loyalty Turns to Betrayal
Many middle-aged Europeans leaving their jobs, born and bred in a more caring corporate world, fear abrupt change will strip their societies of the dedication and loyalty that were part of Europe's success.
Antonio Paolo Braghin, now 56, is one of 3,000 employees, many of them managers, who were let go five years ago by Olivetti. He says his hometown, Ivrea, Olivetti's headquarters, in northwest Italy, is a company town, and downsizing has shaken it. He remembers how the company used to runtraining schools and summer camps and donated libraries to the town. "The company that dismissed me is not the same one that hired me," he said.
Some Europeans emphasize that corporate paternalism created a sense of loyalty toward employees that was often repaid with dedication and greater effort. Gianni Petris, an overseas sales manager at Fiat, Italy's giant auto maker, was showing Fiat dealers from Thailand around Turin in 1994 when he got a letter telling him that, at age 50, he had been dismissed. He fondly recalls attending Fiat's day-care center as a child in a smock with "Fiat" embroidered on it.
"We never worked 8-hour days, but 10," Mr. Petris said. "When I took a trip abroad, if my appointments started Monday morning, I left Saturday, to start on time."
Formerly, he said, he preached to his son, Massimo, a student in Turin, "dedication, honesty and loyalty toward the company."
"Today, I have to tell him, 'Look, Massimo, it's all baloney.' "
He drives a Fiat; his son refuses to.
He distributes business cards that say, "Gianni G. Petris, Consultant," but there is little consulting work to be had.
Many of those let go feel robbed of a sense of purpose in their lives, as well as isolation, loss of social contacts and shame.
Gabriella Favero Flecchia, who ran a team of marketing managers at Fiat, lost her job at age 52 after 29 years with the company, and ever since has suffered from severe insomnia. "The next generation will say about us, 'They sacrificed themselves -- but for what,' " she said.
Still, some of the younger generation of Europeans appear to draw different conclusions. In Paris, Mr. Roux said he gives much thought to the future of his profession, and is prepared to accept that he may have to switch jobs, or at least functions, again in his career. After three months searching, Mr. Roux has found a job.
"I am perfectly conscious," he said, "that the old way of thinking is over in France."

HEADLINE: Federal Judge Upholds Law on Violence Against Women

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON 

 BODY:
For the first time, a Federal District Court judge has upheld the constitutionality of the Violence Against Women Act of 1994, a Federal law that made crimes against the opposite sex a violation of the victim's civil rights.
The judge, Janet Bond Arterton in New Haven, ruled in a case involving a Connecticut woman identified in court papers as Jane Doe. Her husband's lawyers had challenged the constitutionality of the civil rights provision as "an open and sweeping invitation to the Federal Government to intervene almost at will in almost any area of anyone's life." 
 But the judge, after reviewing the four-year legislative history of the statute and the conclusions that Congressional committees reached before the bill went to a vote, concluded that the Violence Against Women Act was "narrowly tailored and reasonably adopted to accomplish a constitutionally permitted end."
The woman suing under the 1994 law moved out of the couple's home in Darien, Conn., last year and now lives in Riverside, Conn. She said her husband repeatedly threatened to kill her, beat her and threw household objects at her. Her suit said he forced her "to be a 'slave' and perform all manual labor."
The civil rights provision allows women -- and men -- to file civil suits for crimes against the opposite sex. Lawyers say this gives women more legal options than they had in the past, when their only recourse was to rely on prosecutors who decide whether to file state charges in rape and sexual assault cases.
Judge Arterton ruled that the Violence Against Women Act does not block those legal remedies for victims of domestic abuse. "It complements them," she wrote, "by recognition of a societal interest in insuring that persons have a civil right to be free from gender-based violence."
Judge Arterton said it was appropriate for Congress to expand protection for victims of domestic violence because the United States House of Representatives had "found that both existing state and Federal criminal laws were inadequate to protect against gender-motivated violence."
Mrs. Doe's lawyer, Deborah S. Chang of Stamford, said the ruling was "a very detailed decision and I think it's important, especially for thousands and thousands of women who've been holding their breaths because of the importance of the statute."
The Justice Department filed a friend-of-the-court brief in support of Mrs. Doe's arguments, as did the the NOW Legal Defense and Education Fund. Julie Goldscheid, a lawyer with the fund, called Judge Arterton's decision "straightforward."
"But to us, Congress was acting well within its authority in enacting this law," she said.
Norman Pattis of New Haven, the husband's lawyer, termed the decision "frightening" because Judge Arterton upheld the idea that domestic violence was covered by the commerce clause of the Constitution. He had tried to liken the Violence Against Women Act to the Gun-Free Zones Act, a 1990 law that made possessing a firearm within 1,000 feet of a school a Federal crime. The Supreme Court held that it was an impermissible violation of the commerce clause.
Enumerating her reasons why the Violence Against Women Act was covered by the commerce clause, Judge Arterton quoted a Senate report that said that "gender-based" crimes prevent women from "full participation in the national economy." The report said that to escape abusive spouses, victims of domestic violence often have to quit their jobs and move to quarters they cannot afford. It also said they often face health care expenditures because of the injuries they have sustained.
"The problem with Judge Arterton's decision is it falls prey to the Humpty-Dumpty syndrome: Congress can point at whatever it likes and, voila, it becomes commerce," Mr. Pattis said. "If that's the case, what's the limit of Federal power?"
Mr. Pattis said he would appeal Judge Arterton's ruling, which cleared the way for a trial on Mrs. Doe's original claims. Her lawsuit asserted that her husband had "systematically and continuously inflicted a violent pattern of physical and mental abuse and cruelty" over their 17-year marriage. It said she lived as a recluse from November 1993 to April 1995, "imprisoned in the house against her will, in continual and agonizing pain, with daily physical and mental torture."
The suit said her husband, identified in court papers as John Doe, had violent outbursts several times a week and had threatened to kill her, shouting that he was going to "bury you." It said he later kept a loaded shotgun in the house and threatened to kill her "on a weekly basis."
Mrs. Doe's complaint contended that Mr. Doe had affairs with at least 50 women and had a longtime relationship with a woman described as his mistress. Mrs. Doe also maintained that her husband had refused to have sex with her since 1982.

HEADLINE: New York Arrests 46 City Workers In Welfare Fraud

BYLINE: By ADAM NOSSITER 

 BODY:
For the second time in a year, prosecutors have charged dozens of New York City employees with welfare fraud, accusing them of illegally obtaining thousands of dollars in public assistance while they were collecting city paychecks.
Forty-six current and former city workers, including several teachers, have been charged with grand larceny, District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan and Commissioner of Investigation Howard Wilson announced yesterday. 
 Almost exactly a year ago, 100 city employees were charged with state and Federal welfare fraud. Yesterday's announcement was a result of a similar effort to weed out city employees fraudulently receiving welfare benefits, by matching listings of city workers with listings of welfare recipients. Most of those charged are relatively low-level employees, and officials said there was no indication that any of the suspects were acting together.
"The city's own employees corrupted the city's efforts to aid those in need," Mr. Wilson said in a statement.
Despite the fanfare with which last year's big fraud case was announced, the penalties that resulted from those charges were light. All 73 people who faced state charges admitted their guilt, but none received jail sentences, or even probation. Instead, they agreed to pay back most of the money illegally received -- about two-thirds in all, officials said -- and were barred from receiving any welfare benefits for six months.
In addition, 50 resigned or were dismissed from their city jobs, 11 had some other disciplinary action taken against them and 12 cases are pending.
"These were all people who had no prior records and were working people, and the amounts of money were relatively small," Mr. Morgenthau said, explaining why none were jailed. A spokesman for the United States Attorney's office in Manhattan was unable to give the disposition of last year's Federal cases yesterday afternoon.
Characterizing the economic status of the city employees charged both last year and this time, Mr. Morgenthau said: "They're certainly at the low end generally."
In the new case, besides the city employees, 20 others have been charged with fraudulently receiving subsidized housing, for a total of over $1 million in benefits illegally collected, officials said. Nineteen city employees were charged with receiving both cash benefits and subsidized housing for which they were ineligible.
Some of those city workers charged yesterday were paid as little as $18,988, like Sylvia McClain, an employee of the Board of Education accused of stealing $33,779 in welfare benefits and $24,191 in rent subsidies between January 1987 and July 1995. Officials said Ms. McClain failed to disclose her city income in applying for the benefits.
To be eligible for public assistance in New York State, a family of four must have an income of no more than $15,266, according to the city's Human Resources Administration.
Barbara Thompson, a spokeswoman for Mr. Morgenthau, said it would be difficult to speculate on what sort of penalties the latest group of defendants could face, since their previous arrest records have not yet been examined. But Ms. Thompson noted that some of the defendants in the current case are charged with stealing larger amounts -- several are accused of stealing over $50,000 -- and so could be charged with felonies.
The mere fact of employment by the city is not necessarily a disqualification for receiving welfare benefits. Still, Mr. Wilson said, city efforts to weed out employees wrongly receiving such benefits would continue.
"Vigorous screening of city employees for this type of fraud is a continuing part of the Department of Investigation's efforts to fight corruption," Mr. Wilson said. "Hopefully, since a major point of prosecution is to deter others, there will be fewer cases in the future."
Of those charged yesterday, four are teachers employed by the Board of Education. Other agencies whose employees were charged include: the Human Resources Administration, the Administration for Children's Services, the Department of Correction, the City University of New York, the Police Department (no officers were charged), the Department of Health, the Department of Employment, the Law Department, the Department of Homeless Services, the Department of Juvenile Justice, and a seasonal worker in the mayor's office.
In several of yesterday's 20 housing fraud cases, those charged are accused of continuing to collect rent subsidies for tenants who died. William Robinson, an employee of Greater Harlem Nursing Home, told housing authority officials his wife's grandmother was still alive, when she had died in 1988. He has been charged with stealing more than $35,000 in rent subsidies.

HEADLINE: THE TRAIL OF 'THE ZODIAC': THE SUSPECT;
Recluse With Message of Good and Evil

BYLINE: By PAM BELLUCK 

 BODY:
Gripping a Bible in his hand, Heriberto Seda would stalk around his scarred and battered East New York neighborhood, always at night, always alone. He would stride up to drug dealers in the alleys and on the corners and rail about good and evil, God and the Devil.
"He was always preaching, talking a lot about God," said Jose Martinez, a neighbor on his block of Pitkin Avenue. "He would take on the drug dealers. People he saw dealing drugs here, he would preach to them." 
 Some neighbors said Mr. Seda didn't just preach. He would also call the police with tips about who was selling drugs on the block.
All the while Mr. Seda was conducting his anti-drug ministry, he was also stockpiling weapons, a homemade arsenal, the authorities said: 13 zip guns, 2 pipe bombs and bomb-making materials.
Late Tuesday, they said, Heriberto Seda confessed to being the Zodiac gunman, responsible for shooting eight people, three of them fatally, in two crime sprees from 1990 to 1993.
In confessing to the crimes, he invoked his religious zeal once again.
"He said he had to kill them because they were evil," said an investigator, who spoke on condition of anonymity.
"He was very religious," said another detective. "He kept talking about Jesus and good and evil and salvation."
Yesterday, people in the neighborhood described Mr. Seda as a solitary figure whom they hardly ever saw during the day. Tall with longish hair pulled back in a ponytail, he dressed in black and emerged at night, to take walks and rebuke drug dealers. Many people said they did not know him at all, although they knew the mother and half-sister with whom he lived in the three-story brick apartment building.
But as the outlines of Mr. Seda's personality began to emerge, they offered a striking resemblance to the psychological portrait of the Zodiac gunman that detectives had drawn six years ago.
The gunman, a task force of 50 detectives theorized in 1990, would be somebody who spent hours by himself, somebody desperate for attention. He was probably unemployed and had little education, and he probably lived in East New York, Brooklyn, near where three of the shootings took place.
Ultimately, psychologists and the police guessed, the Zodiac gunman, like most serial criminals, would be someone who, at least subconsciously, wanted to be caught.
Mr. Seda dropped out of high school, and nobody in the neighborhood can recall his holding a job. On Tuesday, hours after he was arrested on charges of shooting his half-sister in the back and holding officers at bay for three hours, Mr. Seda gave up a clue that linked him with the Zodiac shootings. He scrawled on his statement to police one of the Zodiac gunman's symbols: a circle and a cross with three 7's, one at the top and at each of the two side points of the cross.
Those closest to him said his strongest characteristic was religious fervor. His belief, they said, seemed to come into sharper focus about two years ago, after the last shooting attributed to the Zodiac gunman.
Early every Sunday for the last two years, Mr. Seda grabbed his Bible and went to Mass at St. Fortunato Roman Catholic Church near his home.
The priest, the Rev. James W. Ryan, remembers the tall young man with the long hair as a regular in the pews, always alone. He was given to lingering after Mass, waiting outside the church to greet the priest as he walked out.
"I always found him quiet and respectful," Father Ryan said. "He'd just say 'Hello, how are you, Father?' And that was it."
Connie Catapano, who lives nearby, said Mr. Seda's religious beliefs seemed to influence many of his decisions. "My friend found him to be really strange, so he asked, 'Have you ever been with a woman before?' " Ms. Catapano said. "He mentioned God didn't want him to have sex yet. He didn't want to until God told him to.' "
Indeed, Mr. Seda told detectives, the crime that led to his apprehension on Tuesday, and later to his confession as the Zodiac gunman, was motivated by his preoccupation with the evils of drug dealers.
He said that he shot his half-sister in the back on Tuesday, and later held the police at bay for hours, because he was concerned that she was falling in with a wicked crowd.
"He was mad at his sister because she was hanging around with the wrong people," Detective Joseph Herbert said. "Drug dealers, trouble makers, and he didn't like that."
Ms. Catapano and another neighbor said that Mr. Seda's half-sister, Gladys Reyes, whose nickname was Chachi, had become friends with many of the drug dealers who sold heroin from the half-vacant city-owned building they lived in.
"Chachi was a good girl," Ms. Catapano said. "But she knew all the drug dealers."
Mr. Seda, whose Zodiac sign is Leo, shared the two-room apartment with his half-sister and his mother. Neighbors said the tight quarters created tension in the apartment. Another daughter lives nearby, while a third lives in Queens. As far as neighbors knew, Mr. Seda's father had no contact with the family.
Neighbors said Mr. Seda's mother worked in Manhattan, possibly for a city welfare office. His half-sister, Gladys, gregarious and spunky, had worked for the last few months at the Ancora Bakery a few blocks away and was studying for a high school equivalency diploma, a bakery employee said.
The Zodiac gunman's three-year shooting spree came as murder and other crimes were at record levels, and few areas were more besieged than Mr. Seda's neighborhood. In 1993, there were 129 murders in the 75th Precinct in East New York.
Mr. Seda's only prior arrest was in 1994, when he was picked up in a crackdown and charged with criminal possession of a weapon.
It was in this still crime-ravaged section of Brooklyn that Mr. Seda built his weapons and began his campaign against drug dealers, one that seemed to land him on the side of the law. The police said yesterday there was no record of Mr. Seda's trying to help them catch drug dealers.
Ms. Catapano said that a friend of hers told Mr. Seda, "They're going to kill you if you keep the snitching up around the neighborhood." Mr. Seda replied: "I'll kill all of them."
For years, Mr. Seda lived one life by day, another by night, always remaining a stranger.
"He always lived here and he never left for anywhere," said Josefina Torres, who lives on the first floor of Mr. Seda's building. "He was never with friends, always alone, very alone."

HEADLINE: THE TRAIL OF 'THE ZODIAC': THE OVERVIEW;
Police Say Zodiac Suspect Admits Attacks That Killed 3 and Hurt 5

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD 

 BODY:
Saying he had to kill them "because they were evil," a reclusive man obsessed with guns and the Bible has admitted slaying three people and wounding five others in two calculated waves that bound many New Yorkers in a fitful terror and became known as the Zodiac shootings, police officials said yesterday.
The stunning admission to the twin crime sprees -- one during a compressed period in 1990 and the second from 1992 to 1994 -- apparently closes one of the city's most notorious unsolved cases, a chilling episode of a killer who, under the cover of darkness, mockingly promised to methodically deliver one death for each of the 12 signs of the Zodiac. 
 Until yesterday, the police said, they never knew with firm conviction whether the two deadly rampages were actually the work of a single person, and they had wondered if a culprit would ever be caught.
Heriberto Seda, 28, who was arrested Tuesday in Brooklyn after shooting his half-sister and engaging in a gun battle with hundreds of police officers, was portrayed yesterday as a withdrawn man smitten with weaponry and the teachings of the Bible and who preached damnation to drug dealers. [Page B7.]
The distinctive way he wrote several letters and a telltale symbol he scrawled on his statement to the police about the Brooklyn gun fight led a police detective to match his fingerprints and connect him to the 1990 Zodiac shootings. During four hours of interrogation, the police said, he then admitted those crimes as well as the latter attacks.
Police Commissioner Howard Safir said that authorities remained mystified about his motive, and there seemed to be no obvious parallels among the eight victims. An investigator who spoke on the condition of anonymity said, "He said he had to kill them because they were evil."
Two years ago, the police seemingly came within a whisker of linking Mr. Seda to the Zodiac shootings, when he was arrested on a weapons possession charge, his only other arrest. His fingerprints would then have been routinely sent to Albany to be compared with prints stored in the statewide fingerprint identification system. But six days later, before the full set of fingerprints were mailed, the case was dismissed and the fingerprints destroyed.
The happenstance capture of Mr. Seda echoed the manner in which a serial attacker was tied last week through a fingerprint obtained in a subway fare-evasion case to four brutal attacks on women, including the murder of a dry cleaner and a near-fatal beating in Central Park.
As he did in announcing that arrest, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani profusely praised the Police Department yesterday and declared that the latest arrest "gives the victims and their families a sense of justice that helps the healing process."
Richard A. Brown, the Queens District Attorney, said Mr. Seda would probably be charged today in the three deaths and one shooting that occurred in Queens. The Brooklyn District Attorney, Charles J. Hynes, said Mr. Seda would also be charged with attempted murder of police officers in Tuesday's shootout.
The police said that Mr. Seda, in his rambling statement, offered no insight into how he selected his victims or mapped out the astrological underpinnings of the attacks before dawn. "He doesn't respond to the whys or wherefores," a detective said. "He just got the feeling, he'd go out and select the victim." Seven of the eight victims had a different Zodiac sign, though only one recalled a stranger who asked him about his birth date.
Investigators did say that he mentioned being fascinated by a documentary he watched about a Zodiac killer who stalked San Francisco in the 1960's and 1970's and that he was intrigued by how the killer held a city in fear and eluded capture. He ascribed his lapses in activity, a detective said, to "heat" from the manhunt for him.
According to detectives, Mr. Seda said that he chose his targets randomly, paying no attention to race, sex or creed, and had no knowledge of their astrological signs. But the police discounted that explanation, since he wrote letters alluding to their horoscopes.
Mr. Seda signed a 10-page statement confessing to the eight Zodiac crimes, investigators said. But the confession was slight in details, and so to jog his memory he was driven by the police in an unmarked surveillance van yesterday morning to four of the crime sites. Police said he then signed a second statement that furnished richer specifics.
Late last night detectives searched his house, removing four large paper bags full of evidence, including books, magazines, newspaper articles and a bow and arrow, which the police said had never been used.
Inside his room were more than a dozen plastic models of military equipment including Cobra attack helicopters and aircraft carriers, and assorted gun magazines, including a Remington catalogue and a gun parts catalogue. There were also basketball trading cards, G.I. Joe comic books, a magician's kit and several pornographic videotapes.
The event that led to Mr. Seda's arrest was apparently a warped expression of sibling concern. Authorities said that Mr. Seda, whom they depicted as devoutly religious, was upset because his 17-year-old half-sister, Gladys Reyes, was associating with disreputable friends.
"He was mad at his sister because she was hanging around with the wrong people," said Sgt. Joseph Herbert, the detective who made the Zodiac link. "Drug dealers, troublemakers -- and he didn't like that."
Detectives said that he began a heated argument with Ms. Reyes, whose boyfriend was at the apartment, and then he shot her in the back. She underwent surgery and is listed in stable condition.
Neighbors said that Mr. Seda abhorred drug dealers and used to tip off the police about them. Clutching a Bible, he would also preach to dealers. "He was very religious," a detective said. "He kept talking about Jesus and good and evil and salvation. But he never explained how he made his jump from a Roman Catholic upbringing to a Zodiac serial killer."
Mr. Seda shared a third-floor apartment on Pitkin Avenue in East New York with his half-sister, who worked at a neighborhood bakery, and his mother. He was unemployed, and Mr. Safir said that he resorted to petty crime, including stealing from pay phones. He often wore camouflage pants, and neighbors characterized him as a creature of the night who slept all day.
When he surrendered, Mr. Seda filled three buckets with 13 homemade zip guns. Inside the apartmentthe police said they found two completed pipe bombs and enough materials to build at least nine more.
Detective Herbert, now assigned to the 75th Precinct, had been involved in the hunt for the Zodiac killer, and aspects of the case were imprinted in his mind. After his arrest on Tuesday afternoon, Mr. Seda wrote out a confession to his role in the shootout. Then Detective Herbert looked at it.
"The way he wrote his s's and t's, the way he had all these words underlined, I knew it in a second," he said. "He even put his little symbol." That symbol was an upside-down cross overlapping a circle with three 7's, one above the cross and at each of the two side points.
At once, Detective Herbert asked for a fingerprint check through the police computer, and it matched Mr. Seda's prints with one found at the scene of a 1990 attack in Central Park, as well as a print on a 1994 letter mailed to The New York Post.
When the police confronted Mr. Seda with this evidence, a detective said, he stared straight ahead and began to squirm in his chair. One detective told him, "You're going to be a lot better off if you just tell us what happened."
Over the next four hours, detectives said, he did just that.
The police said that he knew unpublicized details of several attacks. For instance, detectives said he told how he had desecrated the body of a woman who was stabbed 100 times in 1992. They said he also told them that the bullets in two shootings had no ridges because they were fired from a homemade gun.
Mr. Safir said that there was ballistic evidence that connected Mr. Seda to the Zodiac attacks.
Until Tuesday, the Zodiac killer had apparently been silent for two years, and the memory of the helpless panic that had swept New York City had long faded.
He wrote before he acted. In November 1989, he sent a letter to the police and boasted of a demented plot to slaughter people, one for each of the dozen astrological signs. He alluded to Orion, also known as the Great Hunter, a constellation bordering the celestial equator. At first, the police thought it was a hoax.
He picked Thursday mornings in the blackness before dawn. He waited multiples of 21 days between strikes. He began in Brooklyn on March 8, 1990, and his victim was a Scorpio. Mario Orozco, 49, was on his way home from his job washing dishes at a coffee shop. He was on Atlantic Avenue, a few blocks from Mr. Seda's East New York apartment, when he said he was confronted by a man in a ski mask clasping a gun. When Mr. Orozco turned to flee, the man shot him in the back. He said the gunman then stood over his crumpled body and pointed the gun at his head. Since he didn't move, he thinks the gunman thought he was dead.
Mr. Orozco walked home, made a cup of coffee and called the police.
Twenty-one days later, the assailant found a Gemini, Jermaine Montenesdro, 33, on Nichols and Jamaica Avenues, again just blocks from the apartment. Mr. Montenesdro was returning home after visiting friends in the Bronx. He remembered being struck on the head and shot in the side. He, too, recovered.
The gunman moved his sights to Queens and to a Taurus. The third attack, on May 31, 1990, made him a murderer. He came upon Joseph Proce, 78, a retired ice delivery worker, as he walked with his cane to buy a newspaper near 87th Road in Woodhaven. The stranger approached and asked for a glass of water. Before Mr. Proce could reply, the stranger shot him and fled. A note found nearby bore a pie-shaped picture with the symbols for the signs of the first three victims scrawled inside it. The note read simply: "Zodiac -- Time to die!"
Three weeks later Mr. Proce died of an infection from the gunshot.
On June 21, 1990, the gunman shot a homeless man asleep on a bench in Central Park. His name was Larry Parham, 30, a Cancer. Mr. Parham told the police that a stranger had earlier asked him about his astrological sign. Mr. Parham also gave some details that allowed the police to release a sketch. They had no idea how the attacker knew the birth dates of the previous victims.
A note, decorated again with the circle but now including the astrological sign of the fourth victim, was found on that park bench. On that note, the police found a single fingerprint that they hoped one day would mean something.
A special police task force was then assembled to find the suspect. People were cautioned to be wary of anyone who tried, no matter how casually, to learn their birth date.
By then, the gunman was writing to the news media as well as the police. In one letter, the police said, he claimed to be the same Zodiac killer who stalked San Francisco between 1966 and 1974 and claimed to have killed some 40 people. That killer was never caught, but the police said that the handwriting of the two killers did not match.
Innumerable calls and leads that inundated the police failed to produce the capture of the man. Fifty suspects were questioned.
Months lapsed, and then years. Nothing was heard from the Zodiac.
And then something was. The second wave came quietly, with nothing drawing attention to the attacks as being related until they were all done. It was a Leo he chose on Aug. 10, 1992. Patricia Fonte, 39, was stabbed 100 times near the reservoir in Highland Park, Queens. She died. The police do not know why he used a knife rather than a gun.
And then, inexplicably, nearly a year passed before he got very busy.
On June 4, 1993, he shot James Weber, 40, a Libra, in the leg while he was walking on Vermont Street and Cypress Avenue in Queens.
A little over a month later, on July 20, the gunman crept up on a homeless man named named John DiAcone, 47, a Virgo, and shot him at point-blank range in the neck while he was walking along Interboro Walkway in Queens. He died.
In the fall, on Oct. 2, Diane Ballard, 40, was also shot in the neck as she walked through Highland Park near Jamaica Avenue in Brooklyn. She survived, but has been left partly paralyzed and still takes daily medication. She walks with a cane. She was a Taurus, the only duplicate sign among the shooter's targets.
It was not until a letter supposedly sent by the original Zodiac gunman arrived at The New York Post in August 1994 that Zodiac fear revisited the city. The writer claimed that he was back and was responsible for five attacks between June 1992 and October 1994. The police were able to confirm that four of the incidents had occurred and were unsolved but found no record of a June 11, 1994, shooting, as the letter claimed.
At first dubious that the letter was from the same attacker, the police concluded that it was not a hoax but were unsure whether it was written by the same person or by someone who knew of the assaults.
And, then, after announcing his return, the Zodiac withdrew again. As far as the police know, that was it. For two years and eight months, whatever drove one man to attack eight strangers in such sinister fashion, stayed quiescent within him. Then he argued with his sister.

HEADLINE: INCOME DISPARITY BETWEEN POOREST AND RICHEST RISES

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 19

 BODY:
Using new methods of collecting data that it says provide a more accurate picture of incomes, the Census Bureau said today that the gap between the most affluent Americans and everyone else was wider than it has been since the end of World War II.
Looking at five different indicators to measure household income distribution, the Census Bureau has determined that from 1968, when the gap began to widen, to 1994 -- the last year for which complete data are available -- despite some yearly fluctuations each indicator has shown a pronounced increase in the gap between the incomes of the well-to-do and those of the poor and the working class. 
 And, during the first two years of the Clinton Administration the report indicated that the share of national income earned by the top 5 percent of households grew at a faster rate than during the eight years of the Reagan Administration, which was often characterized as favoring the rich.
But the report said it was difficult to determine how much of the soaring fortunes of the rich in 1993 and 1994 represented real gains at the top of the earning ladder and how much was simply because of changes collecting data.
Census Bureau officials say the acceleration in income inequality is partly explained by the bureau's beginning to use computers for the first time in January 1994 to assist interviewers conducting surveys on household income, employment and other data. Also, in March 1994, the Census Bureau lifted its upper limit on reported income from $300,000 a year, allowing households for the first time to report up to $1 million in earnings.
Both changes tended to boost household incomes reported in the higher income brackets, producing a more accurate picture of income distribution. But the change also made it look as though income disparity was widening more rapidly.
Even discounting the effect of the methodology change, the Census Bureau report, entitled A Brief Look at Postwar U.S. Income Inequality, confirmed a well-known trend. From 1968 to 1994, it noted, the share of the nation's aggregate income that went to the top 20 percent of its households increased to 46.9 percent from 40.5 percent. During the same time the share of income earned by the rest of the country's households either declined or remained stagnant.
Looking at the data another way, the bureau determined that the average income for the top 20 percent of households grew to $105,945 in 1994 from $73,754 in 1968, a jump of 44 percent after being adjusted for inflation. In contrast, the bottom 20 percent of households saw their income go up in constant dollars to $7,762 from $7,202, a 7 percent increase during the same period.
Regardless of the the methodological changes, Census Bureau officials said the rise in income inequality was significant. "Whether it's gone up 15 percent or 20 percent, it's still gone up," said Daniel Weinberg, Chief of the Housing and Household Economic Statistics Division at the Census Bureau. "That's the basic story, and I hope that people don't get misled by this apparent dramatic increase since 1992."
Sheldon Danziger, a professor of social work and public policy at the University of Michigan, and other scholars using such data say the methodological changes made it likely that past disparities appeared smaller and recent ones larger than they would have been. But they agreed with Mr. Weinberg that income disparity was still showing significant growth now.
The Census Bureau report also underscores the view that the widening disparity in the fortunes of American workers is becoming an entrenched fixture of the economy. Household incomes grew closer from 1947 to 1968. But since then, the household income gap has steadily increased, rising inexorably through booms and busts, inflationary spurts and recessionary troughs, Republican and Democratic administrations.
"Something is going on here that's beyond politics," said Bruce Bartlett, a senior fellow with the National Center for Policy Analysis, a conservative public policy research organization. "A lot of people have tended to draw the conclusion that we cut taxes in the 1980's, and the rich got richer. Here we've increased taxes in the 1990's, and they still got richer."
The report points out one major incongruity of the last mid-term elections. While the incomes of affluent households seem to have grown dramatically under Mr. Clinton, 55 percent of voters with annual incomes of more than $100,000 voted for Republican Congressional candidates in 1994. Meanwhile, voters earning under $15,000 a year who has seen their household incomes increased at a much slower pace, gave an overwhelming 62 percent of their votes to Democratic candidates.
Among the phenomena that have contributed to the disparity over the long haul are: the shift in the economy away from manufacturing jobs that paid higher wages for relatively low-skilled workers; the decline in the number of workers who are unionized; the increased reliance in industry on the use of computer and computer-assisted technology which places a premium on higher skills and education, and the increasing use of part-time workers.
Also there have been demographic changes that have greatly contributed to the growing disparity in household incomes.
In past eras, some social scientists noted, well-educated, highly skilled men were likely to marry well-educated women who then left the work force to rear children, or who, because of discrimination against women, worked in jobs that were beneath their ability levels. Today, the biggest increase in working wives comes from well-educated, highly skilled women who are married to well-educated, highly-skilled men. Together, they create households with very high incomes.

HEADLINE: Nike Pays Good Wages to Foreign Workers

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Contrary to Bob Herbert's June 10 and June 14 columns on Nike's operations in Asia, Nike has been concerned with developing safe and healthy work environments wherever it has worked with contractors in emerging market societies.
Nike has paid, on average, double the minimum wage as defined in countries where its products are produced under contract. This is in addition to free meals, housing and health care and transportation subsidies. 
 Underdeveloped countries must trade or see deeper declines in living standards. History shows that the best way out of poverty for such countries is through exports of light manufactured goods that provide the base for more skilled production.
If we did not produce in the same low-income societies as our competitors, we would be out of business, and our more than 10,000 United States employees would be unemployed. In 1984, our last year of United States production, we lost $10 million on United States-produced footwear.
In South Korea and Taiwan, where Nike has a larger presence than any other athletic footwear company, many workers earn middle-income wages in economies with as much as a 97 percent employment rate. In Indonesia, thanks to Nike and other multinational corporations, real wages have risen 55 percent since 1990.
Nike directly employs 15,500 people in high-wage, high-skill jobs around the world. Add to this the 200,000 people employed by our contractors at the factory level and you have a company that began in my basement and today creates wealth where none existed before. Our global payroll and contracted labor outlay in the fiscal year 1996 amounted to more than $1 billion.
We have an oversight system that works, and we do our best to insure that labor abuses do not occur. Every Nike subcontractor is subject to systematic, unannounced evaluation carried out by Ernst & Young, an international audit firm with expertise in assessing labor practices.
Mr. Herbert has never set foot inside a Nike-subcontracted facility. Is it a better story to compare Michael Jordan, the most famous athlete of our day, at the peak of his fame and career, with people who are paid more than their countrymen but little by United States standards? The contrast is irresistible to reporters who sacrifice enlightenment for hype.
 
PHILIP H. KNIGHT
Beaverton, Ore., June 18, 1996
 
Chmn. and Chief Executive, Nike

HEADLINE: Stop Inflation Before It Starts

BYLINE: By Stephen S. Roach; Stephen S. Roach is chief economist of Morgan Stanley & Company.

 BODY:
It's back-slapping time on the inflation watch.
A price war in the cereal business, a plunging copper market and well-behaved consumer and producer price indexes all appear to reflect a new era of stable prices. Indeed, the latest beige book, the Federal Reserve's own compilation of economic trends, reports few signs of any inflationary pressures. 
 Politicians are particularly eager to celebrate the death of inflation. With the dreaded beast of the 1970's at bay, they can embrace a pro-growth agenda that eases the angst of the 1990's work force.
Yet for an economy now in its sixth year of expansion, this is precisely the moment to guard against complacency on inflation.
As always, the story starts with supply and demand. That's particularly true in the labor market, where the nation's unemployment rate is 5.6 percent, quite close to what most economists consider full employment.
Any significant lowering of this level could lead to labor shortages, causing rises in wages and then prices.
Just such a possibility is, in fact, quite likely later this year. The reason: sustained and vigorous economic growth. Most economists have been surprised by the economy's strength in the first half of 1996.
But they shouldn't have been. American consumers are spending more in response to their now rising incomes, exports have been supported by a cheap dollar and, in a quest for efficiency, companies have invested heavily in technology.
In addition, the next phase in the inventory cycle is due to start, which should spur further growth. Companies have just finished lowering their inventories, and they will soon begin a new round of restocking, which should increase production, employment and salaries.
If the gross domestic product increases at least 3 percent between now and year's end, as I suspect it will, then the unemployment rate could be as low as 5 percent by early 1997. This might well trigger higher inflation.
Indeed, the Fed's beige book that just saw no inflationary pressure also reported that companies are competing aggressively for new workers. Some fast-food restaurants in St. Louis, for example, are even offering $250 signing bonuses.
There has long been a temptation to view wages as the laggard in the inflation cycle. Workers are thought to demand higher wages only when a sudden spike in inflation deflates their purchasing power.
But there is good reason to believe that this time wages -- which account for 70 percent of business expenses -- will be leading the inflation cycle.
A decade of stagnant wages, accompanied by a spectacular resurgence of corporate profits, suggests that workers have long been underpaid. As the country reaches full employment, a "worker backlash" could force wages ahead of price increases. There is already evidenceof just such a possibility. According to the Employment Cost Index, wages for workers in private industry just recorded their sharpest quarterly increase in five years.
The moment of truth is at hand for the Federal Reserve and the financial markets. The bond market is sending the central bank a clear message. Recent increases in market interest rates suggest that the financial markets are now assuming that the central bank will raise interest rates.
Investors are betting that Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, will do this and stay ahead of the inflation cycle. If the central bank disappoints the market by failing to slow growth, long-term rates will only continue to rise anyway.
Pro-growth politicians are putting predictable pressure on the Fed to lower rates. But it's time for the real Fed to stand up. Inflation is not dead.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains Against the Yen On Official's Remark in Japan

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rose yesterday after an influential Japanese finance official surprised the market by saying he did not believe Japan's strengthening economy justified a rise in interest rates and a higher yen.
The dollar also got help from remarks by Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin in a speech in Washington and a published interview with the German Bundesbank president, Hans Tietmeyer, traders said. 
 Mr. Rubin repeated his longstanding position that the United States wanted a strong dollar, and Mr. Tietmeyer's remarks suggested that the mark might have further room to weaken against the dollar.
"Today we had several comments to support the dollar," said Kosuke Hanao, head of foreign exchange trading at the Industrial Bank of Japan's New York branch. "Demand for the dollar is very good."
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 108.20 yen, up from 107.85 Wednesday. The dollar also traded at 1.5240 marks, up from 1.5210 Wednesday. The British pound cost $1.5380, down from $1.5435.
The catalyst for dollar buying came early in the day when Eisuke Sakakibara, director general of the International Finance Bureau of Japan's Finance Ministry, said recent evidence of a Japanese economic rebound did not mean Japan should change monetary policy. Interest rates, which have been at postwar lows since last year, have helped depress the yen's value.
Many traders sold dollars in advance of his broadcast interview in Japan yesterday, believing he would say Japanese interest rates should rise. But after he spoke, the dollar rebounded as traders scrambled to buy dollars and sell yen.
"That was the key surprise in today's market," said Hugh Walsh, vice president at ING Capital Inc. in New York. "You have Sakakibara commenting that the economy, although growing, is still not that strong. He doesn't see signs of inflation, and feels the dollar can go higher against the yen."
The dollar dipped briefly against the mark later in the day after the Bundesbank released May money supply growth data that suggested higher inflation in Germany.
But dollar buyers quickly emerged when the dollar touched 1.5200 marks, considered an important technical support level. The dollar rebound was aided by Mr. Tietmeyer, who was quoted as saying he did not foresee a weaker dollar.

HEADLINE: FILM REVIEW;
Sleepy Texas Town With an Epic Story

BYLINE: By JANET MASLIN 

 BODY:
THE great, stirring epic "Lone Star" stands as a peak in the career of John Sayles, who already has such admirably serious films to his credit. Long admired for the independence and quiet intelligence of his work, Mr. Sayles this time delivers a vibrant history lesson about a Texas border town.
Gratifyingly complex and beautifully told, this tale explores a huge array of cultural, racial, economic and familial tensions. In the process, it also sustains strong characters, deep emotions and clear dramatic force. Plain and forthright as it looks, "Lone Star" winds up with a scope and overview rarely attempted in American films today, which makes its success that much more exemplary. Every moment of the film, from the quiet foreshadowing of its first scene to a magnificently apt ending, is utterly right. 
 Sometimes decent but didactic in his earlier work (including "Matewan," "Eight Men Out," "Passion Fish" and "The Secret of Roan Inish"), Mr. Sayles this time displays nothing but soft-spoken grace. And he handles this film's dozens of significant characters and the many interwoven strands of its story line with ease. As writer, director and editor of "Lone Star" (the fluid editing is a particular asset, letting the story glide seamlessly between past and present), he assures the viewer that this film's many elements will converge in ways that are meaningful and moving. Indeed, "Lone Star" exists so far outside the province of slam-bang summer movies that it seems part of a different medium and a different world.
The place is Frontera, Tex., a sleepy little town on the Rio Grande. And the film's first sight is that of two Army officers cataloguing fauna in the nearby desert. ("You live in a place, you should know something about it," one of them says.) In the process, they unearth what are probably the remains of Charley Wade (Kris Kristofferson), who in 1957 was the town's bullying sheriff. In the present day, the crime will be investigated by Sheriff Sam Deeds (Chris Cooper), whose father, Buddy (Matthew McConaughey), was Charley Wade's deputy and is now the prime suspect in Charley's murder.
This crime story, while well told, serves "Lone Star" more as pretext than plot. Sending Sam Deeds off to explore the past, the film also examines Sam's troubled memories of life in his father's shadow and looks at the Frontera where Buddy once wielded great power, especially over its black and Hispanic citizens. Drawn into this exploration are whole families of other characters, and their pasts are tied to Buddy Deeds in ways that are made clear by the film's stunning denouement. In each of these stories, parents and children display stubborn, warring ways of looking at the past.
So Delmore (Joe Morton), the rigid black colonel newly put in charge of the local Army base, is estranged from Otis (Ron Canada), who runs the only local bar where black soldiers feel welcome. Del's attitude is not softened by the fact that Otis happens to be his father, nor is he able to behave less rigidly with Chet (Eddie Robinson), his own son.
As the film moves smoothly among dozens of characters, in a style Mr. Sayles also used somewhat more stiffly in "City of Hope," the viewer also meets Pilar (Elizabeth Pena), Chet's history teacher.
"What are we seeing here, Chet?" she asks sternly, finding her student more interested in drawing cartoons than in studying Texas' violent past. "Uh, everybody's killing everybody else," Chet answers hastily. Pilar can hardly accuse him of missing the point.
It happens that Pilar, as Mr. Sayles gradually lets the audience know, is Sam Deeds's first love, and that as teen-agers they were kept apart by both Buddy Deeds and Mercedes Cruz (Miriam Colon), Pilar's stern, prosperous mother. Shades of the past color the film's portrait of Mercedes as well as its long view of Sam and Pilar, who are able to rekindle their romance with surprising passion. It's worth mentioning that Mr. Sayles films a startlingly tender bedroom scene between these two without nudity or graphic sex and without failing to communicate that they are deeply in love.
In Sam and Pilar, "Lone Star" finds not only a romance, but also an embodiment for its central ideas: about crossing borders, challenging the past, escaping the burden of history. These themes echo everywhere in a film that eloquently weaves together the multi-faceted life of Frontera and grasps the importance of race or privilege or politics in every transaction.
From a parents' meeting at school to negotiations over the town's new jail to Charley Wade's ruthless bullying of local minorities, the film effortlessly incorporates a broad political awareness into its drama. One of its most subtly spellbinding scenes finds Del interrogating a young black private over her drug use, and finding his own view of the Army changed by a single conversation.
This long, spare, contemplatively paced film, scored with a wide range of musical styles and given a sun-baked clarity by Stuart Dryburgh's cinematography, is loaded with brief, meaningful encounters like that one. And it features a great deal of fine, thoughtful acting, which can always be counted on in a film by Mr. Sayles. Though none of the actors are given much screen time, a remarkable number of them create fully formed characters in only a few scenes.
Mr. Kristofferson does a superb, unflinching job as the film's personification of racist evil; Mr. Canada and Clifton James (as the mayor) capture the tensions between Frontera's black and white characters as well as a certain brotherhood under the skin. Mr. Morton and Ms. Colon both illustrate the high price of repressing one's true nature, though nobody here has the two-dimensional nature of a symbolic figure. All the film's characters are flesh and blood.
Mr. Cooper brings grit and dignity to the film's pivotal role, perfectly in keeping with the film's tacit style. The sultry Ms. Pena gives an especially vivid performance as the character who is most unsettled by shadows of the past. The film is greatly helped by the fact that neither of these two looks or acts like a movie star and that they blend effortlessly into the texture of small-town life. "Lone Star" does glimpse flashes of Hollywood magnetism in Mr. McConaughey, who makes a riveting impression even though he appears only briefly. Buddy Deeds is meant to be feared and imagined more than he is seen.
Also outstanding are Gabriel Casseus playing Otis as a proud young black man in 1957, when it was clearly dangerous to behave that way, and Frances McDormand as Sam's jumpy, over-medicated ex-wife. Tiny roles are also memorably etched, as in the brief appearance by Beatrice Winde as the widow of a principal in a murder case, an old lady busily playing Game Boy. Sam introduces himself politely, but she remembers Buddy too well to resist a wisecrack: "Sheriff Deeds is dead, honey. You just Sheriff Junior."
"Lone Star" is about watching a whole town, and perhaps a whole society, emerging from such long shadows.

 "Lone Star" is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). It includes mild profanity, racial insults, brief violence and one very discreet sexual situation.
 
LONE STAR

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Mugging Boutros-Ghali

BYLINE: By A.M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
The U.S. decision to veto the re-election of the Secretary General of the U.N. tells us a lot about the Clinton Administration -- all bad -- and nothing true about Boutros Boutros-Ghali, the talented and brave Egyptian diplomat Washington is trying to eliminate.
"Trying" -- this story is not over. President Clinton can use the veto to override the 14 other members of the U.N. Security Council. But the Council then has to agree on another candidate, which the veto-free 185-member General Assembly, overwhelmingly in favor of Mr. Boutros-Ghali, can either approve or throw back repeatedly. And, lest Washington forget: In 1950 the Assembly re-elected Trygve Lie despite Soviet vetoes, with the urging of the U.S. 
 U.S. economic pressure -- elect our choice or get no money from us -- may win out. But the sheer outrage of U.N. members could make the U.S. happy to avoid the Lie precedent and accept a half-term -- two and a half years. The Secretary General tells me he put the compromise forward to save U.S. face, and his country's pride, but was turned down.
The veto threat was not made because of international opinion but was dead against it. It was announced -- months early -- for weakling domestic political motives and with phony "reasons."
A Secretary General is chief of the U.N. staff and can bring peace-threatening problems to the U.N. But his strength depends on his background, and skills and the respect U.N. members hold for him. Those qualifications make Mr. Boutros-Ghali the only influential Secretary General aside from Dag Hammarskjold, killed in a Congo air crash in 1961.
He is the most respected professional diplomat to come out of the Arab Mideast. He stood with Anwar el-Sadat at Camp David to help bring Egyptian-Israeli peace. He subjected himself to the same hatreds that murdered President Sadat.
This man encompasses several civilizations -- Mideastern, Western, African. He draws understanding from the Islamic world in which he has lived, the Christianity in which he worships, and the Jewishness of his wife. He is urbane, unabashedly intellectual and numbers French among the languages he speaks perfectly, for all of which some Americans cannot forgive him.
In his five years in office, Mr. Boutros-Ghali has won the support of almost all nations in Europe, the Mideast, Africa, Latin America and Asia -- a great collection of colors, religions and interests. Without the veto threat, he would breeze through the election unopposed.
The Administration threatens veto for fear that the Republican onslaught against the U.N., with him as its Satan-figure, might win some know-nothing votes. Even as front-runner, Mr. Clinton was too flabby to resist the Republican attack.
The U.S. excuse: A new budget broom is needed. Come off it. Mr. Boutros-Ghali was as good an administrator when the U.S. voted for him as his five predecessors, which is not very. But Washington knows that in five years in office he made reforms and pared budgets more -- when allowed -- than all his predecessors put together did in 45 years.
The U.N. is broke because the U.S. chronically owes more than $1 billion. The Republican Congress reneges -- as did the Democratic Congress that Mr. Clinton was supposed to lead. And the whole U.N. membership keeps pushing the organization to bankruptcy with peacekeeping missions by the dozen, commissions and conferences, then orders the Secretary General to pay the bills.
Republicans and the U.S. delegation to the U.N. like to beat up on Mr. Boutros-Ghali because he did not and could not always snap to their demands for military rescue of the Bosnian Muslims -- which Mr. Clinton himself withheld until he caved. Once I read that Mr. Boutros-Ghali is anti-Israel. That comes as news to such strong supporters of Israel as Abraham Foxman of the Anti-Defamation League, who says it is totally false.
Americans have the right to oppose him, but not to insult him or his people. That is what Republicans do who ape former comics like David Letterman and mockingly drawl his name out -- "Booootros Booootros." The words mean Peter, son of Peter. Funny? Regular thigh-slapper -- like calling Yitzhak Rabin "Izzy" or yelling "hey Mario, whatsamadda," or sneering the honorific of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., and hurts as much. Now they know.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: In Congress, New York's G.O.P. Defends Turf

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Goldwater's Coattails" (editorial, June 14) attacks us as having done a poor job of defending New York State in Congress. To the contrary, we have been successful in protecting New York and the Northeast.
These victories include protecting our Medicaid dollars; reviving the low-income energy assistance program; beefing up transit operating funds; protecting Ryan White money for AIDS programs; protecting funds for the elderly; increasing Federal grants for teaching hospitals; working to keep regional veterans' offices and services intact; holding the line on Head Start money; saving the Summer Jobs program; protecting dairy and other agriculture programs, and increasing funds for the Violence Against Women Act and other grants to fight crime. 
 You also miss the bigger picture in ignoring the benefits that a balanced Federal budget would provide for New Yorkers.
Besides lower mortgages, smaller student loans and lower interest rates for car payments, unless we get Federal deficits under control, payments on our national debt will crowd out spending for all other Federal programs, the ones that benefit our region and others. In addition, lower interest payments that come with less Federal borrowing will mean a windfall for states and city governments that have floated bonds.
We cannot overemphasize how dire the straits our region, state and city would face were it not for New York's Republicans at the leadership table.
 
SUSAN MOLINARI
GERALD B. H. SOLOMON
Washington, June 18, 1996
 
The writers are members of Congress from New York's 13th and 22d Districts, respectively.

HEADLINE: Charles Kades, 90, Architect Of Japan's Postwar Charter

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
Charles L. Kades, a lawyer who supervised the drafting of Japan's postwar Constitution, died on Tuesday in a hospital in Greenfield, Mass. He was 90 and had lived in Heath, Mass., since his retirement from law practice in New York in 1976.
In a long and varied career, Mr. Kades, a native of Newburgh, N.Y., who graduated from Cornell and received his law degree from Harvard, tackled many complex problems. 
As a Government lawyer in Washington during the New Deal in the 1930's he worked as a counsel for the Public Works Administration, the Treasury and the Internal Revenue Service. In private practice in New York in the 1950's, 60's and 70's, he specialized in tax, bond, banking, corporate and estate matters; became a senior partner of the firm of Hawkins, Delafield and Wood, and advised Gov. Hugh L. Carey on the creation and operation of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, the agency that supervised New York City's recovery from financial crisis.
Yet none of the cases he worked on and none of the deals he made had the impact of one whirlwind, a 10-day effort in February 1946 when Mr. Kades supervised the transformation of Japan from a monarchy into a modern democracy with full guarantees of equality.
Under pressure from the occupying Allies, the Japanese Government had begun the process of revising the Meiji Constitution of 1881 late in 1945, but when details of the drafting committee's work leaked out on Feb. 1, 1946, and were seen to be no more than a light reworking of the old Constitution, there was an immediate outcry.
Although an American directive allowed him to order reforms "only as a last resort," with the first postwar general election just two months away and with an 11-nation commission due to take over the issue of a constitution, Gen. Douglas MacArthur, the Supreme Allied Commander, intervened.
He ordered his own 24-member Government Section staff to draft a constitution, and on Feb. 4, his aide, Brig. Gen. Courtney Whitney, convened a meeting and declared: "Ladies and gentlemen, this is a historic occasion. I now proclaim you a constitutional assembly."
Lieut. Col. Charles Kades, who had been in Japan since a week before Japan's formal surrender the previous summer after taking part in the invasion of France in 1944 and serving on the War Department's General Staff, was put in charge of the steering committee and told to produce a constitution by Feb. 12.
Colonel Kades, a gentle leader who resolved a myriad of debates, worked night and day to accomplish his mission.
The resulting document effectively stripped the Emperor of authority, established an elected government and guaranteed a range of civil rights, including full equality for women.
On March 4, Colonel Kades presided over the negotiations with Japanese authorities that led to the adoption of the American draft, including the famous renunciation of war that Colonel Kades had composed himself from General MacArthur's notes.
The Constitution took effect on May 3, 1947, and proved so popular and so effective in laying the groundwork for Japan's postwar re-emergence as an economic power that Mr. Kades, who was decorated by the Army for his work, also became a lionized figure in Japan.
Mr. Kades is survived by his third wife, Phyllis; a daughter from a previous marriage, Caroline Foster-Bunch of Avalon, Australia; three stepchilren, Jewelle Bickford and William C. Wooten, both of New York, and James H. Wooten of Orlando, Fla.; and nine grandchildren.
