HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Kept In Check

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Signs of economic strength and concerns over inflation and supply combined to restrain Treasury prices yesterday.
By the New York market close the 30-year Treasury bond was down 1/32 , to 8613/32 to yield 7.10 percent -- unchanged for a third day. 
 Bond prices were pressured after a regional survey by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia suggested that the economy was expanding at a fast enough pace that would accelerate inflation and compell the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates.
Economists polled by Reuters had expected the Philadelphia Fed would report that its general economic index, compiled from a survey of area manufacturers, was 16.3 in June, compared with 16 in May. Instead, the index rose to 25.6 in June, while the prices-paid component of the index rose to 15.5, from 10.2 in May -- an eight-month high.
The data appeared to contradict Wednesday's Federal Reserve survey of regional business conditions, known as the beige book, which indicated that that wages and prices remained largely in check even amid a pickup in the pace of growth.
"We continue to have mixed economic reports with the market fluctuating from statistic to statistic, and today the Philly Fed scared the market about inflation again, reversing the benign beige report yesterday," said Gerald A. Guild, senior vice president of the taxable fixed-income department at Advest Inc.
"We're now in our fifth month of bond market decline, which has been largely fueled by inflation expectation," Mr. Guild said. "And no doubt we'll look back on 1996 like we did 1994 and realize that inflation remained quite low."
Bonds were little changed by the initial unemployment claims for the week ended June 15, which showed 4,000 fewer Americans applying for unemployment last week.
"Despite the most recent downtick in the claims series, initial unemployment claims have established a trend in the 350,000 to 360,000 range," said Marilyn Schaja, an economist with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. That is "a clear departure from the mid-April through May range of 340,000 to 350,000," she said. The unemployment claims data portray a moderating labor market, she said.
The market received something of a boost when the Senate voted to confirm Alan Greenspan for a third term as chairman of the Federal Reserve. The vote was a resounding affirmation of his monetary policy, analysts said.
But market participants remained concerned about the amount of new supply coming to market following an announcement by the Treasury on Wednesday on the size of next week's sales of two-year and five-year notes.
Yesterday the Treasury auctioned $19.25 billion of a new one-year bills at an average rate of 5.56 percent, with decent investor demand. In when-issued trading late in the afternoon, the two-year note to be sold on Tuesday was offered at a price to yield 6.33 percent, while the five-year was offered at a price to yield 6.73 percent.
Adding to the market's concern about supply yesterday was the Lockheed Martin Corporation's $1.25 billion three-part debt offering, which is due to be priced today.
The company set a record on May 26 by pricing the largest-ever investment-grade corporate debt issue, when it sold $3.5 billion of its debt.
The new offering, through underwriters led by CS First Boston, includes $500 million in 2-year notes, $400 million in 8-year notes and $350 million in 12-year notes.
Following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of a new one-year bill:

HEADLINE: Senate Confirms Greenspan 91-7 for a Third Fed Term

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 20

 BODY:
The Senate overwhelmingly confirmed Alan Greenspan to a third term as chairman of the Federal Reserve today, brushing aside arguments from a few Democrats that he had held back economic growth by focusing too narrowly on fighting inflation.
The vote was 91 to 7. The "no" votes came from Democrats representing Midwestern states with strong populist histories of opposition to tight-money policies like those that have distinguished Mr. Greenspan's nearly nine-year tenure at the central bank. 
 The vote means Mr. Greenspan, who is 70, will remain in charge of monetary policy for another four-year term regardless of who wins the Presidency. A Republican, Mr. Greenspan was first named to his job by President Ronald Reagan and was renominated by President George Bush in 1992. With Mr. Greenspan having won the confidence of inflation-wary investors on Wall Street and enjoying support from both sides in Congress, President Clinton renominated him in February. The nomination had been held up since then by a small group of Democrats led by Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa.
The Senate also approved President Clinton's two other nominees to open Fed seats, but not without giving a scare to one of them, Alice M. Rivlin, who has been the Administration's budget chief.
Ms. Rivlin's nomination to be the Fed's vice chairman was approved by 57 to 41, with the surprisingly large opposition all coming from Republicans angry about what they considered dishonest tactics by the Administration in its budget negotiations with Congress.
Senator Christopher S. Bond, Republican of Missouri, had led the opposition to Ms. Rivlin, saying she should be accountable for the Administration's proposing long-term spending cuts but then telling the affected departments and agencies that the cuts could be revisited in future negotiations. Mr. Bond and several other senators said they were concerned that Ms. Rivlin had shown herself willing to put politics ahead of good policy.
The Senate voted 98 to 0 to approve the nomination of Laurence H. Meyer, a widely respected economic forecaster from St. Louis.
Neither Mr. Greenspan nor Ms. Rivlin made any comment after their confirmations. Mr. Meyer said he was "delighted that the long delay is over."
Although his previous term expired in March, Mr. Greenspan has continued to serve in an acting capacity. Mr. Meyer plans to be sworn in on Monday. Ms. Rivlin is expected to be sworn in later next week.
Mr. Greenspan, Ms. Rivlin and Mr. Meyer will then join the other four Fed governors and the presidents of the Federal Reserve Banks in participating in a two-day meeting starting July 2 at which the Fed will decide whether to raise interest rates to cool down a resurgent economy.
Ms. Rivlin and Mr. Meyer are judged by some economists to be slightly more sympathetic than Mr. Greenspan to arguments that inflation is a diminished threat. But neither of them is likely to push the Fed to diverge in any substantial way from Mr. Greenspan's strategy of attacking inflation early and making price stability the central bank's primary goal, economists said.
Mr. Harkin had held up a vote on Mr. Greenspan's confirmation until the Senate agreed to a full-scale debate, which finally began last week. Mr. Greenspan's critics argued that intense worldwide competition and a weakening of labor unions, among other factors, had made inflation much less of a threat than in the past. They said that Mr. Greenspan was keeping rates higher than needed, limiting the economy's ability to grow and create jobs.
"Raising the living standards and real wages of ordinary Americans is our No. 1 economic challenge," Mr. Harkin said before today's vote. "But time and time again, the policy of the Federal Reserve under Chairman Alan Greenspan has stood in the way. Under the Greenspan Fed, job growth and the living standards of average Americans have been sacrificed on the altar of high interest rates and slow-growth policies."
Senator Byron L. Dorgan, a Democrat from North Dakota, said Mr. Greenspan "and his friends at the Fed seem to view themselves as a set of human brake pads whose sole mission in life is to slow down the American economy."
But Mr. Greenspan won support from most other Democrats and from all Republicans who voted.
Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, the chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, praised Mr. Greenspan for keeping "a steady hand at the tiller instead of taking the politically expedient course" of giving in to calls for a looser monetary policy.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat, called Mr. Greenspan "a national treasure." Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut, the co-chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said rejecting Mr. Greenspan would be a "tragic mistake."

HEADLINE: 2 Startling Arrests Capture Growing Mood That New York Is Safer

BYLINE: By JANNY SCOTT 

 BODY:
From time to time, a single incident or series of events seems to leap out of the vast variousness of New York City life and come to symbolize some emerging shift in the public mood.
The Zodiac killings in the spring and summer of 1990 became an emblem, in that extraordinarily violent time, of a growing fear among many New Yorkers that the city was out of control. 
 And now, in a time of dropping crime rates, two startling arrests have seized the imagination of a public that had been tentatively toying with the possibility that it might have become a little more safe.
Twice in a week, a combination of old-fashioned police work and newfangled fingerprint-matching technology have led the New York City police to conclude that they have solved an unusually high-profile and baffling case.
In the first instance, the police used a fingerprint from a fare-beating arrest to link John J. Royster Jr. to the beating and attempted rape of a young piano teacher in Central Park, the killing of a Park Avenue dry cleaner and two other attacks.
In the second, the distinctive handwriting of a man who signed a confession in a Brooklyn shootout led a detective to compare -- and match -- the man's fingerprints with prints believed to belong to the Zodiac gunman.
And in a weird parallel, police in Greenburgh, N.Y. said yesterday that fingerprints had enabled them to solve a year-and-a-half-long series of robberies, bludgeonings and killings of elderly people in New York suburbs.
"A particular event is made more or less important by the mood of the city," said Tom Reppetto, president of the Citizens Crime Commission of New York City, a private watchdog group.
"Everybody is saying, 'Gee, they seem to be on a winning streak,' Mr. Reppetto said of the public response to the New York City arrests. "Which fits the mood that things are getting better in New York."
Not everyone agrees that the mood is justified -- or even that the city's spirits are really up. Some suggest the phenomenon is largely a creation of the media, the Mayor and police public relations.
"All this will be shot to hell if the next morning some poor jogger gets it in Central Park or Riverside Park," said Herbert J. Gans, a professor of sociology at Columbia University. "Meanwhile, the city's fundamental economic problems, particularly for the poorer people as the budget gets cut, they're still there."
It is not the first time that a incident in New York City -- often a crime -- has suddenly captivated public attention for what it seems to represent about a direction that the city is headed.
Like the 1990 Zodiac killings, the Son of Sam murders in 1976 and 1977 came amid a rising fear of crime and sense of chaos. The city was near bankruptcy, the subways decaying. When the power blacked out, looters took to the streets.
When Yusuf K. Hawkins, a black teen-ager, was killed during an attack by a gang of white youths in Bensonhurst in 1989, the incident came to symbolize a rising sense in an election year that the city had become polarized along racial lines.
Bernhard Goetz, the subway gunman, became the emblem of people's fears of subway violence. And the fatal stabbing of Kitty Genovese on a Queens street in 1964 while more than 30 neighbors ignored her cries for help came to embody public concerns about the depersonalizing effects of modern urban life.
Why a certain event takes on symbolic value at a certain moment in the city's history seems to depend often on a concatenation of factors including the cast of characters, the location, politics and the media.
Incidents involving New York City archetypes -- the aspiring artist, the immigrant, the tourist -- tend to make powerful symbols. So do incidents that occur in locations like the subway or Central Park.
Election-year politics can increase the likelihood that an event will come to seem to represent the zeitgeist, in part because it may get focused upon, interpreted, perhaps even simplified into a symbol.
Finally, the news media play a role. Some say the media create these events. Others say newspapers and television simply illuminate them, tapping into an already existing feeling.
"The media give it focus, the proper words, the pictures," said Thomas Kessner, a professor of history at CUNY Graduate School who specializes in the history of New York City.
"They dress it up in a certain way, so that people can simplify it into one of several easy perceptions: This place is strange, it's dangerous; or 'Great, we found the criminal.' "
The two arrests in New York City appear to meet many of those criteria.
Mr. Royster's arrest came in a case that involved, among others, an aspiring pianist brutally attacked in Central Park and a hard-working immigrant woman who was killed while opening her dry- cleaning business on the Upper East Side.
Even the attacker's technique -- smashing his victims' faces into the ground -- was symbolic, said Marshall Blonsky, who teaches semiotics, the interpretation of symbols, at The New School. His weapon was "New York itself -- the street."
So an arrest in such a case produces a kind of public catharsis. As Professor Blonsky put it: "When you get someone, it's a jubilee" -- not least of all for a Mayor facing re-election.
"I think that election politics certainly add yeast to this mix," Professor Kessner said of emblematic events in general. "People are looking for easy symbols and symbols they can sell in terms of their own position."
Another factor that can influence the symbolic power of an event is race, said Dennis M. Walcott, president of the New York Urban League, citing the arrest of Mr. Royster, who is black, in the attacks on four white women. "As a result of the location and the interracial dynamics involved, it receives more public attention," he said, comparing it to "equally horrific rapes and attacks that occur in poorer neighborhoods."
By contrast, Mr. Walcott said the media paid little attention to an incident that might well have taken on great significance of its own -- the shooting death of a suspected carjacker, who was black, by three white police officers in Brooklyn last week.
Since media attention focuses public attention and thus has the power to change public policy, Mr. Wallcott suggested that there is a need for "a more balanced coverage of horrific issues that impact on the fabric of life in the city, so it's not just relegated to the richer communities or the white communities."

HEADLINE: Morgan Stanley Expected to Buy Asset Manager

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
Morgan Stanley & Company, seeking to expand its asset management business, is expected to reach an agreement as early as this afternoon to buy Van Kampen American Capital Inc. from its controlling shareholder, Clayton Dubilier & Rice, for more than $700 million in cash, according to people familiar with the negotiations.
Van Kampen, which is based in Oakbrook, Ill., specializes in bonds and sells its mutual funds through brokers. It currently has more than $40 billion of mutual fund assets, or just over 1 percent of the mutual fund market, and earlier this year was ranked 20th in terms of mutual funds under management. 
 Philip N. Duff, Morgan's finance director, and Don Gogel, a senior Clayton officer, did not return telephone calls seeking comment late yesterday. A deal will probably not be announced until early next week.
The sale, which still could encounter roadblocks, would be but the latest step in Morgan Stanley's campaign to expand its asset management business, and would increase its assets under management to more than $150 billion. In the summer of 1995, Morgan Stanley bought Miller Anderson & Sherrerd L.L.P., a money manager based in Philadelphia, which then had $33 billion under management.
Like some other big financial companies, Morgan wants to build up asset management, which is generally perceived as a steady business that will provide predictable income in lean times. Managing money requires little capital and generates regular fee income.
Big banks and brokerage companies have eagerly been snapping up money managers. In December 1995, for example, Dresdner Bank of Germany agreed to pay $300 million to acquire RCM Capital Management.
Goldman, Sachs & Company, in a recent research report on the money management industry, predicted considerable consolidation in this industry, arguing that asset managers either have to be very large and benefit from economies of scale, or have to be niche players with particular specialties.
The sale of Van Kampen is expected to give a healthy profit to Clayton, a big investment firm, and its investors, who together control more than 80 percent of Van Kampen. Clayton originally acquired the Van Kampen Merritt Companies from Xerox Financial Services Inc. for about $400 million in 1992. In late 1994, Clayton agreed to acquire the American Capital Fund Group from the Travelers Group and later merged it with Van Kampen to create Van Kampen American Capital Inc.
Earlier this month, Van Kampen filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell $250 million of shares to the public. In recent days there have been reports that Morgan Stanley and the McGraw-Hill Companies were each discussing bids for Van Kampen.
For the first quarter, Van Kampen had net income of $15.2 million.

HEADLINE: To Infinity and Beyond: Is a Radio Deal Too Big?;
Westinghouse Would Own 32% of Top Markets

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

 BODY:
Don Imus doesn't have much use for the argument that radio is coming under the grip of a few powerful owners.
"There are 11,000 radio stations around the country," said Mr. Imus, the vinegary talk-show host who is based at WFAN-AM in New York. "I'm on 85 and Howard Stern is on 30. For there to be some kind of monolithic invasion, we'd have to be on thousands of stations." 
 But as yesterday's merger of Westinghouse Electric and Infinity Broadcasting demonstrates, numbers alone do not tell the whole story about power in radio. Consumer advocates and some Federal regulators said this deal -- the largest in the history of the medium -- would give one company unprecedented control over advertising revenue and programming in the nation's largest radio markets, including New York, Los Angeles and Chicago.
In New York alone, Westinghouse would own six stations, with a stable of personalities that range from Charles Osgood, the genteel morning commentator and poet manque on WCBS, to Mr. Imus and Mr. Stern, whose ribald commentary have made him the most famous and controversial individual in radio.
Such diversity has long been a hallmark of the radio industry. But as the Federal Government has loosened restrictions on the ownership of stations, companies like Westinghouse and Infinity have assembled powerful station groups. With the consolidation, critics say, has come generic and homogeneous programming.
"I feel sorry for the listeners," said Robert Unmacht, the editor of the M Street Journal, a radio industry newsletter. "Finding a creative and interesting radio station will be harder because the pressure is on to make them very much alike."
Mel Karmazin, the president and chief executive of Infinity, said yesterday that the $3.7 billion deal would not have happened without the Telecommunications Act of 1996, which relaxed station ownership limits further and set off an acquisition frenzy. Together, Westinghouse and Infinity would have 83 stations in 16 markets and total advertising revenue of $1 billion.
By leveraging its combined power in local markets, he said, Westinghouse could help radio capture a greater share of the ad dollars from newspapers and television.
Robert J. Coen, of the McCann-Erickson advertising agency, whose forecasts of advertising spending are closely watched, predicted that radio would account for $12 billion of the $172 billion in total 1996 spending.
"We think this is the kind of deal that was intended when the telecom bill was passed," Mr. Karmazin said.
Others are not so sure. More dangerous than its national reach, they said, is its potential dominance in local markets. In the top 10 markets, Westinghouse and Infinity commanded 32 percent of the total 1995 radio ad revenue, or $814 million, according to James Duncan Jr., the editor of Duncan's Radio Market Guide, a trade publication.
In New York, where Westinghouse and Infinity own three FM and three AM stations, the companies accounted for 37.7 percent of the ad market. Among their holdings are the city's two major all-news stations, WCBS-AM and WINS-AM; its only sports talk station, WFAN-AM; two FM rock stations, WNEW-FM and WXRK-FM; and a smaller station for Korean listeners, WZRC-AM.
In Boston, where the companies own five FM stations and one AM station, they had 43.6 percent of the radio advertising market. In Philadelphia, where they own three FM stations and three AM stations, Mr. Duncan estimated, the two earned 47.3 percent of the ad dollars.
"Forty percent would be quite a dominant position in a single market," said James H. Quello, a commissioner on the Federal Communications Commission, "We would have to take a hard look at that."
Even radio executives who champion consolidation expressed some trepidation about competing against Westinghouse.
"While you hate to have one company with that many stations, consolidation will make for a better industry," said Jeff Smulyan, the chairman of Emmis Broadcasting, which owns stations that would compete against Westinghouse in New York, Los Angeles and Chicago.
Consumer advocates said the Government should scrutinize the merger on antitrust grounds. "They clearly have excessive economic and political power in New York and Los Angeles," said Gene Kimmelman, the co-director of Consumers Union, a lobbying group in Washington.
The Justice Department is looking into another radio deal: the proposed acquisition of Citicasters Inc. by Jacor Communications. The deal would give those companies four FM and two AM stations in Cincinnati -- stations with more than 60 percent of Cincinnati's radio ad revenue. At issue is whether the Government should weigh Jacor's percentage of Cincinnati's total advertising market or just its radio ad market.
Mr. Karmazin and Michael H. Jordan, the chairman of Westinghouse, said they were confident their merger would not violate antitrust statutes. And several regulatory experts seemed to agree. But executives close to the companies acknowledged that the deal might have a tougher time clearing the F.C.C.
The agency still prohibits a company that owns a television station from owning more than one AM and one FM radio station in that market, though numerous exceptions have been made. Westinghouse and Infinity would exceed that limit in most of their markets. And a company can own no more than eight radio stations in a major market, and no more than five on either FM or AM band.
That means Westinghouse would have to divest itself of three FM stations in Dallas, where it would own nine FM's and one AM. The combined companies would also have to sell two stations in Chicago.
In passing the telecommunications act, Congress directed the F.C.C. to award liberal waivers to companies exceeding the cross-ownership rules. Westinghouse obtained several waivers after it acquired CBS Inc., because the network's television stations put it above the cross-ownership limit in a number of markets.
Noting that the holdings of the merged companies would greatly exceed the cross-ownership limits in markets like New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, one executive close to Westinghouse said, "The tricky putt will be getting this past the F.C.C."
Less prone to Government regulation but more important to listeners is the growing homogeneity of radio programming. Mr. Unmacht noted that Infinity has contributed mightily to an industry trend in which stations have shifted their programming -- often in lockstep -- for fear of losing listeners.
Since 1994, for example, five of New York's FM stations switched their format to modern rock. Infinity's WXRK, one of the last holdouts with its classic rock format, joined the crowd earlier this year.
Mr. Unmacht also noted that Mr. Karmazin's emphasis on lean budgets and high profits might clash with Westinghouse, which has spent more on its all-news stations.
In particular, he said, WCBS-FM, a highly rated New York station that plays oldies and has an expensive roster of disk jockeys, might have a rocky ride under Mr. Karmazin.
Other industry experts attribute the sameness of radio programming to a variety of factors other than consolidation: the splintering of music into more narrow niches; the increased reliance of market research; new technology; and even simple human nature.
"Once you have something that's proven, you go with it," said Tom Zarecki, the director of marketing services at Radio Computing Services, a computer software company that caters to the radio industry. "Programming doesn't get worse with group owners, it gets better, because programming concepts get tested more."
Like many others in radio, Mr. Zarecki said he felt a Westinghouse-Infinity merger would improve the industry by making it more profitable, more professional, and putting it on a better footing with newspapers and broadcast television.
Still, the mere success of a company like Mr. Zarecki's speaks to the industry's changes. Radio Computing Services developed the Selector, a computer-software program for radio stations that automatically picks and plays a sequence of songs.
One of his best clients is Infinity, which uses the Selector at WXRK in New York to play a pre-set schedule of modern rock songs.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Westinghouse to Acquire Infinity for $3.7 Billion
Westinghouse Electric will acquire Infinity Broadcasting for $3.7 billion, merging the nation's two largest radio broadcasters in a deal made possible by a new telecommunications law that lifted the limits of radio station ownership.
A merger of Westinghouse, a large industrial company that also owns the CBS radio and television networks, and Infinity, the nation's largest independent broadcaster, would create a radio giant particularly potent in the nation's largest markets. [Page A1.]
Mel Karmazin, widely regarded as the nation's most successful radio executive, has dodged the limelight. Until now. [D5.]
 
Green Light for Greenspan
The Senate overwhelmingly confirmed Alan Greenspan to a third term as chairman of the Federal Reserve, brushing aside arguments from a few Democrats that he had held back economic growth by focusing too narrowly on fighting inflation. [D2.]
 
Rising Oil Prices Push Trade Gap
The highest oil prices since the Persian Gulf war helped widen the American trade deficit as imports and exports climbed to record levels. So far this year, the trade deficit is running at an annual rate of $98.9 billion, only a slight improvement from the seven-year high of $105.06 billion set in 1995. [D3.]
 
Owens-Corning Asbestos Suit
Owens-Corning, the building-products manufacturer that has been chafing from decades of asbestos litigation, has sued three medical-testing laboratories, contending that they falsified tens of thousands of test results supporting claims against the company. [D3.]

Court Rules on Bargaining
The Supreme Court ruled that it is not an antitrust violation for companies within an industry to get together and impose new contract terms on their unionized employees after labor negotiations have broken down. The decision was a victory for National Football League team owners and has implications for all industries that conduct bargaining on a multi-employer basis. [A1.]
 
Accounting Rules for Derivatives
The Financial Accounting Standards Board has proposed bringing most of a company's derivatives activities onto its balance sheet for the first time. Until now, most derivative transactions have been disclosed to investors only in footnotes of financial statements. [D2.]
 
Executives Get More Shares
Major Wall Street firms have increased the proportion of stock in the compensation packages of their top executives, a new analysis shows. The stock payments now account for about 40 percent of top executive compensation, up from virtually nothing seven or eight years ago. [D2.]
 
China Moves on Currency
China announced a plan to make its currency, the yuan, more easily convertible, beginning with a move that would allow foreign companies to freely buy and sell foreign currency at designated banks. [D3.]
 
Some Support for Sallie Mae
The long reach of the Orange County, Calif., crisis is having some odd repercussions. One of them is a $100 million lawsuit filed by the county against the Student Loan Marketing Association, or Sallie Mae. But several analysts say holders of Sallie Mae shares have nothing to fear -- and should even consider buying more. Market Place. [D6.]
 
Finding Sport in 'Lunacy'
There's "Generation X" and "The X-Files," "Madame X" and X marks the spot. Now, ESPN hopes to add one more name to that list: the X Games, 35 1/2 hours of contests showcasing new extreme sports, like sky surfing and bungee jumping. They're being billed as "sheer unadulterated athletic lunacy" in a new campaign. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D6.]
 
Blue Chips Up, Technology Down
Blue-chip stocks were the beneficiaries of a retreat by technology issues, as the Dow Jones industrial average gained 11.08 points, to 5,659.43. The technology-laden Nasdaq composite fell 11.93 points, to 1,167.34, its sixth straight session of losses. [D6.]

HEADLINE: U.S. Trade Deficit Up 7.7% In April on High Oil Prices

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 20

 BODY:
The highest oil prices since the Persian Gulf war helped widen the American trade deficit as imports and exports climbed to record levels.
The Commerce Department reported today that the deficit in goods and services rose 7.7 percent in April to $8.63 billion, after a March imbalance of $8.01 billion. 
 The Clinton Administration, under heavy fire from Republican critics for an ever-widening trade deficit, played down the April increase in imports and stressed instead the growth in exports. It offers proof, spokesmen said, that President Clinton's emphasis on market-opening trade deals is paying off.
"Today's numbers are just one example of a broad spectrum of recently released data showing a healthy economy," Commerce Secretary Mickey Kantor told reporters. "The U.S. economy is continuing to expand and provide increasing opportunity for American workers."
Mr. Kantor noted that the April deficit was 20 percent lower than the same month in 1995. Private economists, however, were not as impressed. They said that while there was a narrowing of the deficit from horrendous levels in early 1995, the improvements have stalled recently.
"We are now stuck in a range of monthly deficits of between $8 billion and $9 billion, where we have been since last fall," said Lawrence Chimerine, chief economist at the Economic Strategy Institute in Washington. "Analysts who had been counting on additional declines in the deficit to spur U.S. economic growth this year are going to be disappointed."
So far this year, the trade deficit is running at an annual rate of $98.9 billion, only a slight improvement from the seven-year high of $105.06 billion imbalance of 1995.
But two other reports today did show some signs of strength in the economy. The Labor Department said new claims for unemployment benefits fell by 4,000 last week to 357,000, the first decline in four weeks, and a larger drop than economists expected. Still, the less volatile four-week moving average of new claims rose by 3,000, to 354,250.
And a survey of business conditions done by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia showed that economic activity rose significantly in June, with the lag between when goods are ordered and when they can be delivered rising sharply. The Philadelphia Fed said its general economic index, compiled from a survey of area manufacturers, rose to 25.6 for June from 16.0 in May.
Marilyn Schaja, an economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette in New York, said she believed this Fed survey was "one more reason to expect the Fed to tighten" when central bank policy makers meet on July 2-3.
The trade report showed that imports of goods and services rose 1.7 percent in April to a record high of $78.57 billion, reflecting the jump in oil prices and volume and higher shipments of foreign cars.
Petroleum imports soared 30 percent, to $5.85 billion, as the average price for a barrel of crude surged to $19.33, the most expensive since the start of the Persian Gulf war in January 1991. The price was $17.33 in March, but analysts noted that oil prices had already retreated from the peak as supplies increased.
U.S. exports of goods and services also set a record during the month, climbing 1 percent, to $69.94 billion, reflecting higher sales of commercial aircraft and consumer products.
In a separate report, the Commerce Department said today that the first-quarter deficit in the United States current account rose to $35.6 billion, a 16.9 percent increase from the fourth quarter of 1995. The current account is the broadest measure of United States trade because it includes not only the goods and services covered in the monthly reports but also investment flows and foreign aid payments.
The higher current account deficit for the January-to-March period reflected deficits in goods, investment flows and the category that includes foreign aid and a smaller surplus in services.

HEADLINE: A Park on the Hudson River

 BODY:
Few cities are blessed with as much waterfront property as New York. Few have made such abysmal use of it. Now the city and state seem to be coming together on a plan that will turn the depressing expanse of rotting piers along the Hudson into a park that will allow residents and tourists to appreciate what it means to live along the water.
The land between Battery Park and 59th Street in Manhattan has been in limbo since the Westway highway project was abandoned over a decade ago. Opposition from environmentalists doomed Westway. A less ambitious roadway is being constructed in its place. But the 550-acre strip between the new road and the Hudson is still in limbo. 
 The best possible plan for this precious asset would be one that rehabilitates the decaying piers, balances passive open space with ball fields and water-based recreation, and allows for small businesses, like restaurants and marinas, that would encourage the public to visit the waterfront.
Charles Gargano, the state's top economic development official, has endorsed a plan along these lines. But Gov. George Pataki has yet to speak. He must do more than express his approval. The project will not go far unless the state agrees to match the $100 million promised by the city.
The park's architects propose an esplanade along the length of the waterfront, and would convert 13 of the 37 decrepit piers into ball fields, playgrounds and public gardens. Of the 550 acres, which includes the piers, open land and the water between the piers, 49 would be set aside for commercial development. Restaurants and small shops would be permitted in only three areas. Two of them, Chelsea Piers and the maritime district around 42d Street, are already developed. The third, in Greenwich Village, is home to a parking garage. The revenue spun off by the businesses would be used to underwrite maintenance of the park.
Mr. Pataki's commitment is essential. Work on the new highway abutting the east side of the waterfront has already begun. Repair of the piers and construction of the park will be a less costly burden on the surrounding community if the two projects can be done in tandem.
A spokesman for Mr. Gargano said the Governor must be convinced that the park is "something the community wants" -- an allusion to threats of lawsuits if the plan goes into effect. The opponents generally favor a park without any commercial development, even if it amounts to little more than a bikeway and walkway. The fancier the park gets, they argue, the more expensive it will be to maintain, and the more pressure to permit additional business use to generate revenue.
But most of the real open space along the river is on the giant piers. The new plan -- the product of years of work and community consultation by the Hudson River Park Conservancy -- addresses the challenge of fixing the piers and making them useful. It is a good plan, and rejecting it might mean an end to any park for the foreseeable future.
Since the territory below 34th Street belongs to the state, there would be nothing to keep Mr. Gargano's authority from allowing commercial development there anyway, as it already did with the huge Chelsea Piers athletic complex. Chelsea Piers is a popular facility, but the last thing the waterfront needs is uncoordinated development that is not centered on the principle of public access.
Mr. Pataki may be able to get the state's $100 million share of the park's cost from his proposed environmental bond act. Once that critical commitment is in place, officials must still make sure the park plan includes protections that will convince even the most worried opponent that wide-scale commercialization of the riverfront is not on the agenda.

HEADLINE: In America;
Burning Their Bridges

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
If the racist firebugs in the South had any sense at all they would stop torching black churches. The fires are bad for the racism business. Each church that goes up in smoke generates sympathy for the very folks who have been so assiduously stereotyped and demonized over the last few decades.
The media spotlight is now focused on the fires, and the prevailing image of the black people involved (typically one-dimensional) is that of humble congregants standing in the humid night air with tears streaming down their faces as they watch their houses of worship crackle and burn. 
 There hasn't been such a counterproductive outburst of bigotry since 1963, when the police commissioner of Birmingham, Ala., T. Eugene (Bull) Connor, unleashed his dogs and turned the city's fire hoses on peaceful demonstrators.
A lot of whites looked at photos and film footage of Connor's cruelty and said that's enough. Something similar may be happening now.
Condemning the church fires, President Clinton said: "This tears at the very heart of what it means to be an American. This has got to stop."
His comments were an echo, more than three decades later, of President Kennedy, who said he was sickened by a newspaper photo of a black woman recoiling in fear from one of Connor's lunging dogs.
The arsonists are too dim-witted to get it, but there is hardly a better way to heighten the public's awareness of the true evil of racism than to keep burning down churches.
The fires have even smoked out the Christian right, a symbol of white intransigence on matters of race. "I would not deny," said Ralph Reed, director of the Christian Coalition, "that there was a time in our nation's history when the white evangelical church was not only on the sidelines, but on the wrong side of the most central struggle for social justice in this century. I think that was wrong; I think we paid a price for that."
Discussing the fires on "Meet the Press" last Sunday, Mr. Reed acknowledged that "there were white evangelicals in the South who justified Jim Crow and segregation, and invoked Scripture to do it." He said that his organization, which is raising money to rebuild some of the churches, must "make racial conciliation a major priority" if it is to have "a morally resonant voice" on other issues.
All of this is well and good. Expressions of outrage and repentance from whatever quarters are welcome. But it is important to keep in mind that we are not dealing here with spontaneous combustion. The fuel for these fires can be traced to a carefully crafted environment of bigotry and hatred that was developed over the past quarter-century. The aim of that effort, racist to its very core, was to roll back the gains of the civil rights era and keep blacks and other ethnic minorities socially and economically marginalized.
Expressions of outrage over the burning of churches is not enough to atone for that shameful effort.
As Roger Wilkins said in an interview this week: "I certainly welcome the President's personal concern and his directions to his subordinates to do all they can to solve these crimes. At the same time, I can't avert my eyes from the much larger tragedy of those millions of blacks who are effectively excluded from the economic life of this country, and those thousands and thousands of children whose lives are being consumed in the flames of poverty."
On Wednesday the President met with Southern governors and promises of additional assistance were made. At the same time, volunteers from around the country are working with the stricken congregations in biracial, bipartisan rebuilding efforts. This could be the beginning of a new era of mutual respect and cooperation.
But as Mr. Wilkins noted, there are more urgent problems facing blacks in America than the burning of churches. Black unemployment has been in double digits for more than two decades. The educational facilities available to desperately poor black and Latino children are a scandal. And the effort by those who are well off to set fire to the safety net for the poorest of America's poor continues.
While the nation responds to the burning of churches, the greater tragedies continue to be ignored.

HEADLINE: 9 in Former Javits Center Union Held in Fraud

BYLINE: By ADAM NOSSITER 

 BODY:
Nine members of a union that used to represent workers at the corruption-plagued Jacob K. Javits Convention Center were charged yesterday with illegally obtaining union health benefits, unemployment compensation and Social Security benefits, as well as with loan sharking.
The charges against members of the Exhibition Employees Union Local 829, including the local president and vice president, were the first connected to the Javits Center since Gov. George E. Pataki announced a major reorganization at the center last summer. The union no longer represents workers there, and the crimes the men are accused of occurred before the reorganization. 
 The Governor's action last year was prompted by longstanding allegations that the center and its unions were rife with corruption and influenced by organized crime. Exhibitors at the huge glass structure on the West Side of Manhattan regularly complained of featherbedding, inefficient workers and exorbitant costs for such simple activities as plugging in extension cords.
The charges announced yesterday by District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau are not directly related to those types of complaints. Indeed, in at least one of them, the loan-sharking charge, the principal victims were union members themselves. Nonetheless, officials depicted the activity as part of a general climate of corruption at the center.
"What we saw at the Javits Center prior to the new administration was an atmosphere of lawlessness on the floor," said Dan Castleman, Mr. Morgenthau's chief of investigations. "It was exactly this type of conduct: loan-sharking and gambling, no-show jobs, manufacturing of false identities to obtain benefits, staged accidents that led to workmen's compensation claims and lawsuits."
The local president, John V. McNamee Sr., and vice president, Paul Coscia, were charged in a scheme to obtain health benefits for a man whom prosecutors said was an associate of the Genovese crime family but not a union member. The two men, along with two rank-and-file members, James McCann Sr. and Thomas Donovan, were accused of submitting false claims totaling almost $50,000 to the health insurance providers, Empire Blue Cross/Blue Shield and Aetna Life and Casualty. Prosecutors said almost $30,000 had been paid.

NEW YORK
 
Math Scores Up at Schools
For the second year in a row, elementary school students in all 32 New York City school districts raised their scores in a standardized test of math skills, and continued a four-year trend of improving math performance citywide, officials announced. While students did not fare as well in reading, officials attributed the results to a more difficult reading test this year. [Page B1.]
 
Central Park Victim Gains
The woman who was severely beaten in Central Park two weeks ago has regained consciousness and begun to communicate with family and doctors, a change her physician described as an "absolutely crucial step" toward recovery. On Wednesday, the 32-year-old piano teacher demonstrated awareness for the first time since the attack by responding to simple questions with a nod or shake of the head and by mouthing her name, said her neurosurgeon. And yesterday, able to move her arms and legs, she sat up in a chair. [B1.]
 
In a time of dropping crime rates, two stunning arrests have seized the city's imagination. [B3.]

These are bad times for Peter Gatien, the fallen nightclub king of New York's under-25 world. He was indicted for conspiracy to distribute the drug Ecstasy at two of his clubs. The man, Richard Basile, 77, of Bensonhurst, was apparently not injured. As in the previous attacks, including a fatal explosion in 1982, the motive is unknown. [B4.]

A psychiatrist defended his treatment of a 17-year-old girl, Nancy Blumenthal, left, who committed suicide at the Westchester County Jail last month, saying that the girl did not want to take her antidepressant medication and he could not force her to do so. HEADLINE: Observer;
Going Nowhere Together

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER 

 BODY:
The good news from the Census Bureau is that the rich are getting richer faster than they used to get richer. The bad news, of course, is that the poor are still either getting poorer or not getting a bit richer.
This is the kind of situation that, if allowed to continue to its logical conclusion, ends with ill-clad soreheads cheering while the flower of the American boardroom goes to the guillotine. 
 Fortunately the logical conclusion is unlikely to be reached in our time. In other words, let future generations look out for themselves, and while you're up get me another Mercedes Benz.
In any event, the well-heeled of that pleasantly distant future will probably not have to face the guillotine. Americans may love capital punishment, but they like it in quiet good taste. When the logical conclusion overtakes those C.E.O.'s of the future, testy American paupers will doubtless prefer to spin them off by lethal injection.
But why dwell morbidly on a future further away than next quarter's earnings report? What matters now is keeping the unrich from becoming disgruntled about their measly lot. Keeping the unrich gruntled constantly occupies our two political parties.
How do they do it? With programs of gruntlement maintenance, or disgruntlement impedance, as for some strange reason it is not called in Washington, home office of mushmouth English.
Whatever you call it, the point is to keep the unrich from turning churlish and rising up against the conspiracy of lawyers and business that is the Federal Government. At present, for instance, the parties are conducting a political campaign distinguished by great heat and little of anything that has to do with the price of eggs, or the price of anything else, including labor, housing, transportation or corporate subsidies.
The goal of both parties is to keep the public's eye off the ball. This purpose is conveniently served at the moment by the Whitewater affair, which is a kind of political version of "Entertainment Tonight," rich in headlines and spicy with topics for gossipy back-fence argument.
It is said to be a vital subject because it goes to the "character" issue. Leaving aside the question of what "character" has to do with conducting tricky affairs of state, note how happily it diverts public attention from the widening split between the rich and the unrich.
Neither party has anything arresting to say about the "downsizing" of the work force, the collapse of union labor, the death of the cities, the decline of health care, the financing crisis in social programs, or much of anything else that truly competing parties might be debating just now.
Whitewater and the "character" issue give both parties something entertaining to snarl about on television. The Roman emperors knew it was vital to provide the crowd with bread and circus both. Democrats and Republicans now provide circus for the crowd while laying on the bread for the moneyed society that keeps them in power.
The value of the "character" issue is the excuse it gives them for ignoring most matters of consequence. This week's report from the Census Bureau illustrates how effective both parties have been at playing Tweedledum and Tweedledee with the public.
Census figures show that during the Clinton Administration the rich have gotten richer considerably faster than the usual rate, yet it doesn't seem to have made much difference with people making over $100,000 per year.
In the 1994 Congressional elections, a majority (55 percent) of them voted for Republican candidates. Among voters earning less than $15,000 per year, 62 percent voted for Democrats. You might conclude from this that while a majority of the rich didn't think Clinton had anything to do with their fattening bank accounts, a large majority of the poor didn't think so either, so felt no anger at him.
The probable truth, of course, is that neither group thought about it one way or the other, because both parties had distracted them with more entertaining matters. Ronald Reagan was the master of this technique. While keeping the crowd hot about "social issues," Reagan did very little about them, but steadily, quietly redistributed the wealth upward.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Strengthens Again On Outlook Abroad for Rates

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar strengthened yesterday for the third consecutive day in a rally powered by new signs that Japan's interest rates would remain low and that European rates would fall.
Some traders said the political shake-up in Russia had also helped strengthen the dollar and weaken the German mark, which is vulnerable to uncertainties in Russia because Germany is Russia's largest trading partner. 
 But the main force driving the dollar higher came from Japan, where the central bank took a step to persuade the market that it would not raise interest rates despite evidence that the Japanese economy was rebounding. Higher rates would increase the yen's value but could crimp economic recovery.
The Bank of Japan injected 400.2 billion yen into the banking system during a regular maintenance operation, an amount considered extraordinarily large. The move helped reduce overnight bank lending rates to slightly less than the official discount rate, which has been at a record low of five-tenths of a percent since September. Traders sold yen and bought dollars in response.
"The dollar basically went straight up today," said Seth Cohen, a director of foreign-exchange trading at Merrill Lynch. "I think the market is finally starting to believe the Japanese authorities when they say rates aren't going up anytime soon."
In New York, the dollar traded at 109.07 yen, up from 108.20 on Thursday and the highest level in a week. The dollar also traded at 1.5341 marks, up from 1.5240 on Thursday and the highest level since June 12. The British pound cost $1.5350, down from $1.5380.
The dollar was also helped indirectly in Europe by optimism that Italy's central bank was about to cut interest rates. The increased hopes came from new signs of milder inflation in Italy and Government approval of a more austere budget. Sweden's central bank cut rates earlier in the week.
Though it remains unclear whether Germany will still lower rates, traders said there was some optimism that it could happen when the central bank convenes at its regularly scheduled meeting next Thursday.
Some traders said the mark had come under pressure because of reports of turmoil in the Kremlin. President Boris N. Yeltsin forced out three high-ranking officials on Thursday. Mr. Yeltsin will face Gennadi A. Zyguvanov, the Communist challenger, in a runoff election for President on July 3.

HEADLINE: Treasury Securites Gain; Hedge-Fund Buying Seen

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities improved in light trading yesterday, as talk of hedge-fund buying and rumors of central bank activity in the short end of the market helped support prices.
Traders attributed the rumors in the market to subdued activity in trading coupled with the lack of key economic data ahead of the weekend. 
 Doug Burtnick, senior fixed-income analyst with Technical Data of Boston, said the market was never able to capitalize on gains earlier in the week, trading instead in a narrow range with an eye on next week's Treasury auctions.
"Most likely, the front end will soften up a little bit more to lure investors into Tuesday's and Wednesday's auctions," Mr. Burtnick said. With the end of the quarter approaching, he said, most investors and dealers will spend the next week cutting back their positions before the Federal Reserve meeting in early July.
The price of the 30-year bond rose 4/32 of a percentage point, to 86 17/32 ; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, slipped to 7.09 percent, from 7.10 percent on Thursday.
Bill Gamba, senior vice president and head of Government bond trading at Cowen & Company, does not believe market sentiment has been affected. "There was some hedge-fund buying in the five-year sector today, and we did hear of overnight buying in the two- and five-year sectors," he said. "Coupled with options expirations, the market managed to maintain its tone."
He added that "coming supply will weigh on market prices." Mr. Gamba also said that in a skittish market he would not be surprised to see bond prices drop ahead of next week's auctions.
Carroll J. Delaney of Stires, O'Donnell & Company, said most players were out the door for weekend getaways shortly after noon. "At the beginning of today's trading session, there was already the strong possibility that the day would be uneventful, as the only reports out were hardly the type of straws to even slightly stir the drink," he said.
Mr. Delaney added that investors should be concerned about the Treasury market. "Price-yield levels do appear to represent value, but aside from foreign central bank buying of shorter maturities and hedge fund and other leveraged players' purchases of intermediate and longer paper, real end users of the magnitude and duration needed to ignite a serious rally have not appeared," he said
Mr. Delaney said the current market profile was almost a mirror image of the situation six months ago, when Treasuries had significantly less value, but buyers kept marching in. "The lesson here," Mr. Delaney said, "is that because the market is oversold or overbought, doesn't mean that it can't become more so. So while we do see the prevailing yields as attractive, without the approbation of real money investors, they will become even more attractive, especially when confronted with next week's supply."
If the two-year and five-year bill auctions can be "successfully digested and distributed, the potential for a corrective rally is enhanced," Mr. Delaney said.
In when-issued trading late in the day, the two-year bill was being offered at a price to yield 6.32 percent and the five-year issue at a price to yield 6.71 percent.
Separately, the Lockheed Martin Corporation priced this week's largest deal, selling $1.5 billion of debt in three parts through CS First Boston.
The aerospace company, which sold $3.5 billion in debt securities less than two months ago, in the largest investment-grade debt offering ever, priced $500 million of 2-year notes yesterday to yield 6.63 percent, $550 million of 8-year notes to yield 7.48 percent and $450 million of 12-year notes to yield 7.703 percent.

HEADLINE: Rich Control More of U.S. Wealth, Study Says, as Debts Grow for Poor

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, June 21

 BODY:
Wealth became more concentrated in the United States from 1989 through late 1994 as affluent families profited from financial markets while many poorer families fell deeper into debt, new data from the University of Michigan show.
The most prosperous 10 percent of American households held 61.1 percent of the nation's wealth in 1989 and 66.8 percent in late 1994, the University of Michigan found. At the same time, the average family in the poorest 10 percent of the nation's population had debts exceeding assets by $7,075 in 1994, measured in 1996 dollars, compared with a negative net worth of $4,744 in 1989. 
 The new figures came just two days after the Census Bureau announced that the gap in annual income between the most affluent Americans and everybody else was wider than at any other time since World War II.
While the Census Bureau looked at families' salaries and other incomes, the University of Michigan, in Ann Arbor, focused on families' net worth -- assets like stocks, bonds, bank accounts, houses and cars, minus debts like mortgages, home equity lines and credit card balances.
The trend toward rising disparities between the rich and poor has been well documented. But the university's data also showed that the middle class in the United States was becoming more prosperous.
If all American families were ranked from richest to poorest, the family in the middle -- what statisticians call the median family -- had a net worth of $62,395 in 1994, up from $47,742 in 1989, after adjusting for inflation. Most of the middle class's net worth came from their homes.
But the latest figures also show fairly little social mobility. Half the families with more debts than assets in 1989 were in the same predicament in 1994, and often even more in debt, said Frank P. Stafford, the co-director of the Panel Study of Income Dynamics at the University of Michigan's Institute for Social Research.
With banks and other lenders becoming more aggressive in pursuing marginal credit applicants, Mr. Stafford said, "it's not too surprising that we see bankruptcies rising at a time of economic expansion."
In its study, the university used figures from its regular surveys of close to 7,000 families, some of which have been in the study since 1968. The university did not include the value of personal belongings like clothing and television sets. The data also do not include accrued pension and Social Security benefits, which are hard to measure reliably. The inclusion of Social Security would narrow the measured gap between rich and poor, but the effect of including pensions is unclear, Mr. Stafford said.
A few economists expressed skepticism when told about the University of Michigan's results. Arthur B. Kennickell, a Federal Reserve Board expert on consumer finances, said that it was inappropriate to use research based on a long-running study of households.
Very rich and very poor families tend to drop out of such studies over time, so that the remaining respondents are disproportionately middle class, Mr. Kennickell said. And too few of the households in the sample are very wealthy, making it hard to reach conclusions about how much money the rich have, he added.
Mr. Kennickell said that his own research at the Federal Reserve was more reliable because extra surveys were done to determine the net worth of rich families, which are often reluctant to tell pollsters about their money.
Mr. Stafford disagreed with Mr. Kennickell's criticisms, saying that the University of Michigan data were weighted to be nationally representative. Mr. Stafford also said that the Federal Reserve had very low response rates on its extra surveys of the rich, to which Mr. Kennickell responded that the Fed had weighted its results to compensate for a response rate that he said was 20 percent.
Timothy Smeeding, an expert on income and wealth distribution at Syracuse University, said that the University of Michigan data were probably not reliable for the wealthiest 1 percent of American families, but that they were a very good measure of the rest of the population. Mr. Stafford said he had decided not to release any figures specifically on the top 1 percent for precisely this reason, presenting data instead on groups of 5 to 20 percent of the population.
The university's Institute for Social Research is best known on Wall Street for its monthly figures on consumer confidence. But it also runs the Panel Study of Income Dynamics, a widely cited continuous survey of household finances in the United States.
The National Institute on Aging, a Federal agency, has bankrolled much of the panel's research since 1980 as part of an effort to determine whether Americans are saving enough money for retirement.
The Fed and the University of Michigan are the two best-known sources for detailed data on household assets.
Mr. Kennickell's figures and Mr. Stafford's data show few broad shifts during the 1980's in the overall concentration of income, with the exception that the Fed figures show the top 1 percent becoming considerably richer. But the Fed and University of Michigan analyses differ considerably on more recent trends.
Mr. Kennickell said there was little change from 1989 to 1992, the most recent available years in the Fed data. The super-rich lost ground to the merely affluent, but there was little change in the overall share of the nation's wealth held by the richest 10 percent of the population.
By contrast, Mr. Stafford at the University of Michigan found that between 1989 and 1994, the bottom 90 percent of the population lost part of their share of the nation's wealth to the top 10 percent.
Mr. Kennickell said that it was possible that wealth became more concentrated in 1993 and 1994, two years covered by the University of Michigan but not by the Fed. The stock market climbed during this period, but the bond market plunged in 1994.
Rich people tend to have much more of their money in stocks and bonds than the less well off do, with the most affluent 10 percent of households accounting for four-fifths of American holdings of stocks. Middle-class families have a much higher proportion of their money in their homes. So rising financial markets tend to produce wider inequality of wealth.
Mr. Stafford said that such an explanation was plausible for the University of Michigan's findings, while noting that it would be surprising for wealth to become more concentrated under a Democratic Administration that has at times favored policies to redistribute wealth.

HEADLINE: No Jail Time for Ex-Policeman Who Shot a Fellow Officer

BYLINE: By ADAM NOSSITER 

 BODY:
The defense, the judge and even the victim came together yesterday in a surprisingly gentle final act to the wrenching drama of a white police officer who mistakenly shot an undercover black policeman on a Manhattan subway platform. They all agreed that the defendant should be spared jail.
In a proceeding so devoid of the usual bile it hardly seemed like a sentencing, Peter Del-Debbio, who mistook his fellow officer for a criminal and shot him five times, was given five years' probation and 200 hours of community service for his conviction on assault charges. 
 Desmond Robinson, the man Mr. Del-Debbio gravely wounded in those moments of panic and confusion two years ago, pleaded for leniency for him yesterday. In Mr. Robinson's few moments on the witness stand in the crowded, quiet courtroom, he spoke of a kind of bond with his assailant. The two men, he said, were both forced out of a profession they loved by the shooting.
Almost from the moment Officer Del-Debbio's shots rang through the subway station at 53d Street and Lexington Avenue on Aug. 22, 1994, the case stirred controversy and anger.
Many black officers said the incident showed once again that their white colleagues were too quick to perceive blacks as criminals, leading them at times to fire by mistake at undercover black officers. Their anger increased when Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and William J. Bratton, then the Police Commissioner, seemed to defend Officer Del-Debbio's conduct.
The incident also led the Police Department to review its procedures for reducing the risk of so-called friendly-fire shootings.
As for the two principals, their lives have been shattered by the shooting and its aftermath.
Mr. Robinson is in constant pain, with one of Mr. Del-Debbio's bullets still lodged in his back. And he now faces serious legal problems of his own: he was charged with sexual assault after a night of drinking with a female officer in May. He is unemployed, spending much of his time in physical and mental therapy, and is suing Mr. Del-Debbio and the city for $50 million.
Mr. Del-Debbio was convicted of second-degree assault on March 26 and dismissed by the Police Department. He now works as a laborer, doing street construction.
The incident that linked the two men began when a youth dropped a shotgun on an F train stopped in the station, and it went off.
Officer Del-Debbio, who was off duty and happened to be at the scene, heard the shot and picked up the shotgun just as Officer Robinson and other transit officers approached.
What happened next was remembered differently by both men, fueling the racial tension that arose around the highly publicized case. Mr. Del-Debbio said he had seen an armed man -- Mr. Robinson, who was not displaying a badge -- running toward him, and he fired.
But Mr. Robinson recollected that he had been running alongside the car, not toward the other officer. Prosecutors said two or three of the five shots fired by Mr. Del-Debbio had hit Mr. Robinson in the back as he was falling, or lying on the ground.
Despite the concerns that were raised in the aftermath of the shooting, the trial focused not on race but on the question of whether Mr. Del-Debbio had used excessive force. In convicting him of second-degree assault, the jurors concluded that he had acted recklessly.
The defendant and the victim did not look at each other in court yesterday. But as Mr. Robinson slowly read from a statement, there was no evidence of lingering hostility. Mr. Robinson spoke at first of "confusion, anger, sadness, disappointment, bitterness, understanding."
That last word set the tone for what followed.
"I cannot help but feel a strong bond with all fellow police officers, regardless of whether they are black or white, male or female, active or retired," Mr. Robinson said.
Noting that Mr. Del-Debbio had lost his job because of the conviction, Mr. Robinson said: "Perhaps more than anyone, I can understand the pain and emptiness that Peter Del-Debbio must feel, having been forced to leave the job. I know, from my own experience, that the loss of being able to serve the people of this city as an active member of the N.Y.P.D. is a harsh punishment in itself."
He said that jail for Mr. Del-Debbio "would serve no purpose" and urged the judge to show mercy.
In a seemingly anticlimactic presentation, Mr. Del-Debbio's lawyers then offered lengthy arguments for why their client should not go to jail. "Peter Del-Debbio reacted as a police officer," said one lawyer, Richard Murray. "In that split second, he had to make a decision."
Even the prosecution conceded that Justice Bernard J. Fried's task yesterday was difficult. An assistant district attorney, Raymond Castello, suggested four months in jail, to be served on weekends.
Justice Fried referred to Mr. Robinson's statement, saying: "He believes jail time would serve no purpose. I should listen to him long and hard." He then imposed the sentence of probation and community service.
Mr. Del-Debbio declined to comment, though lawyers said they would appeal his conviction. But the president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, Lou Mattarazzo, said: "We're very happy with the sentence. I think the judge showed the milk of human kindness."
Still, the 100-odd officers in the courtroom were not jubilant, perhaps reflecting a feeling among many on the force that Mr. Del-Debbio should not have been prosecuted at all. "There never should have been a conviction," said Richard O'Neill, a P.B.A. official. "There never should have been a trial."
But Michael Greys, a vice president of the Guardians, a black police fraternal organization, assailed the judge for not sending Mr. Del-Debbio to jail. Saying Mr. Robinson did not speak for other black officers in seeking leniency, he added, "We are disgusted by this sentence."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

F.A.A. Says Kiwi Will Cut Operations
The Federal Aviation Administration said that Kiwi International Airlines had reduced its fleet and its number of flights because many of its pilots were improperly trained and it lacked the personnel to run all its planes. 
 The action against Kiwi came four days after the agency grounded another small airline, Valujet, over maintenance issues. Kiwi has been under scrutiny by the F.A.A. for some time and was effectively grounded for a time in December 1994 because of training problems. [Page 20.]
 
Manhattan Bagel Stock Plummets
Manhattan Bagel stock fell more than 35 percent after the chain said it would lower its first-quarter earnings because of accounting irregularities at its West Coast unit. The company estimated the total amount involved to be about $350,000 on a pretax basis. [32.]

Blue Chips Rise in Heavy Trading
Blue-chip stocks rose sharply in very heavy trading, buoyed by a rebound in the battered technology stocks and the quarterly "triple witching" expiration of option and futures contracts. The Dow industrial average ended 45.80 points higher at 5,705.23, its first close above 5,700 in nearly a month. [35.]
 
Hitachi Has Fastest Supercomputer
A study says that Hitachi of Japan is the maker of the fastest supercomputer in the world. The new machine is capable of reaching a speed of more than 220 billion mathematical operations a second. [32.]
 
Lloyd's Bid to Stay Afloat
Lloyd's of London, in a bid to remain solvent, advised money-losing investors about the size of their final bills and threatened to fight anybody who will not pay. It offered 3.1 billion, or $4.7 billion, to help investors hit hard by the insurance market's huge losses. [32.]
 
Britain to Resume Beef Exports
Leaders of the European Union's 15 member countries agreed today to a plan that would gradually allow the British to resume exporting beef certified to be free of contamination from the so-called mad cow disease, a fatal brain disease. In response, Britain ended a monthlong blockade of the body's decision-making procedures. [1.]
 
Clinton Less Popular in Silicon Valley Four years ago, Bill Clinton successfully won the support of Silicon Valley by soliciting executives' advice and by promising to make high-technology businesses more competitive globally. But their ardor for Mr. Clinton has cooled. And political donations from computer and software companies have dropped, according to Clinton fund raisers. [1.]
 
Copper Futures Plummet
Copper futures fell to a two-year low on fears that big traders would dump their stocks of the metal in the wake of the trading scandal at Sumitomo. Sugar futures surged to a 15-month high; soybean futures jumped because of flooding in the Midwest. [34.]
 
Treasury Prices Up Slightly
Treasury securities prices rose in light trading yesterday, as talk of hedge-fund buying and rumors of central bank activity in the short end of the market helped support prices. Traders attributed the rumors in the market to subdued activity in trading coupled with the lack of key economic reports. [41.]
 
Dollar Stronger Against Yen
The dollar strengthened for the third consecutive day in a rally powered by new signs that Japan's interest rates would remain low and that European rates would fall. [34.]
 
$467 Million Acquisition Set
Pharmaceutical Product Development Inc. said yesterday that it would buy Applied Bioscience International Inc. for stock worth as much as $467 million, creating one of the largest publicly traded pharmaceutical contract research organizations. [33.]
 
Battling Postal Rate Increase
Businesses that advertise through catalogues and mass mailings are trying to block the Postal Service from raising the cost of some types of bulk mail. [35.]

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE MONEY;
In Slap at President for Tort Veto, Silicon Valley Reduces Donations

BYLINE: By JANE FRITSCH 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 21

 BODY:
Four years ago, Bill Clinton set out to win the support of skeptical executives in Silicon Valley by holding private meetings to solicit their advice and by promising to make high-technology businesses more competitive in world markets. High technology became a frequent theme of Mr. Clinton's campaign to "get America growing again."
The strategy worked. Public endorsements of Mr. Clinton by executives of computer and software companies gave an early and important boost to his campaign against President George Bush. And donations from the executives helped to shore up Mr. Clinton's campaign fund. 
 But Silicon Valley's ardor for Bill Clinton the President has cooled, largely because he vetoed legislation intended to cut down on lawsuits by shareholders, legislation that high-tech companies desperately wanted.
And the Clinton campaign is now feeling the sting. Political donations from computer and software companies, which provided hundreds of thousands of dollars in 1992, have fallen by as much as half, Clinton fund-raisers say. The campaign has had no trouble raising money in other parts of the country, a fund-raiser said, but in Silicon Valley "we're really getting hammered."
As the Clinton campaign works to win back Silicon Valley, its executives are raising an arcane tax issue as a test of Mr. Clinton's commitment to high-technology industries. They have barraged the White House in recent months with demands that the master versions of their software be given the same favorable tax treatment that is given to the master recordings of records, tapes and movies that are exported for reproduction in other countries.
So far, Mr. Clinton and the Treasury Department have refused the requests to handle the matter administratively, saying that legislation to amend the tax code is needed.
"All we ever get from the Treasury Department and the White House is some legal gobbledygook," said Harris Miller, the president of the Information Technology Association of America, a computer-industry trade group that has more than 9,000 members. "Someone has his or her fingernails into this thing and won't let it go."
The President's refusal to intervene on the issue is baffling, Mr. Miller said, because there is no political opposition on the issue. Recently, he said, he was asked to solicit association members to attend the Democratic National Committee's Presidential fund-raising dinner honoring Mr. Clinton. Mr. Miller said he had made little success.
"It is very tough to get people interested or enthusiastic about Bill Clinton when you look at very high-visibility, bottom-line issues and he comes out on the wrong side or doesn't take action at all," he said.
The export tax would save the software industry an estimated $700 million over 10 years, a figure that industry officials argue is insignificant in trillion Federal budgets.
Some software industry officials are closely watching the tax-credit issue for a sign that Mr. Clinton wants to mend fences after his veto of the securities bill.
"His veto of securities litigation reform last December took a lot of high-tech companies by surprise and was a disappointment," said Bill Sample, director of domestic taxes for the Microsoft Corporation, the nation's largest producer of software. "Certainly he's had positives and negatives with Silicon Valley and the high-tech community. If he doesn't respond to what seems to be a clear-cut fairness issue, the judgment will be harsher."
The securities legislation was by far the more important issue to high-tech companies, and they had been pushing for it for years. Because the high-tech industry is particularly volatile, it has been a frequent target of lawsuits by shareholders who suspect that they were defrauded by inaccurate or or overly optimistic company reports. But Congress overrode Mr. Clinton's veto of the bill, which made it more difficult for shareholders to sue.
To be sure, Mr. Clinton has taken a number of actions on behalf of high technology. In particular, the Administration's high-profile crackdown on the Chinese pirating of software has pleased Silicon Valley, said Kenneth A. Wasch, the president of the Software Publishers Association, an industry trade group with about 1,200 member companies.
"In the first week of the Clinton Administration, we were called over to get a briefing on their economic plan," Mr. Wasch said. "We have had access to the highest levels. I never got a call over to the Bush White House or the Reagan White House."
At issue is legislation passed in 1971 that allows tax credits of about 15 percent for certain products manufactured in the United States for export to other countries. The law specifically names "films, tapes, records or similar reproductions for commercial or home use." Industry officials argue that Congress would have included software if it had existed at the time.
Treasury officials said they had no objection to applying the tax break to software, but they said the law gave them no authority to do so because software is essentially different from films, tapes and records. Unlike films, which are passively played back, software actively drives machines, the officials said.
The companies have been pushing hard for the Clinton Administration to make the change because of the difficulty in getting legislation through Congress. A bill to include software on the list for tax credits would not be particularly controversial, they say, but would inevitably get caught up in the gridlock and horse-trading on Capitol Hill. In fact, the California Congressional delegation has sent a letter to Mr. Clinton urging that he act to grant the credit.
