HEADLINE: The World;
A Few Good Reasons to Start Caring About Africa

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: BANGUI, Central African Republic

 BODY:
WHEN the United States and France mounted separate military operations this spring to extract their citizens from crisis-stricken African countries within one month of each other the question that underpinned much of the commentary on the news was: Why bother with a continent that never seems able to find its way?
From the perspective of the West, which is focused on crises elsewhere, Africa in the 1990's has virtually become a bad word, synonymous with Burundi, Rwanda, Liberia, Somalia -- horrible crises that defy solution by well-intentioned outsiders. 
 But for Africans who watched American Marines pull Westerners out of the chaos of Liberia, or Legionnaires do the same in this former French colony, the question to ask was rather different: Why, many wondered, after the West's lengthy, almost obsessive involvement with Africa, are so many voices suddenly calling for something that sounds like abandonment?
It was not so long ago, after all, that Europe and America were sinking billions into African countries, hoping to lock up mineral wealth and markets, and making bedfellows of some of the worst dictators of recent times in the name of battling Communism.
 
 
 
Groping, Yes. But Hopeful.
 Where the West sees a glass half-empty and draining fast, for Africans the rapid spread of competitive elections throughout the continent in this decade, the sweeping economic reforms that have brought renewed growth to most of the continent, and the triumphs of peace in places like South Africa, Mozambique and Ethiopia mean that the glass is half full and perhaps rising -- highly televised wars and famines or no.
This is not the only difference of perspective between a pessimistic West and an Africa still groping for solutions but remaining hopeful. Addressing Africa's chronic economic weakness and political instability requires a searching examination by all of how things got this way.
For their part, Africans have largely abandoned the old diatribes in which they would blame outsiders for every ill; instead, to a remarkable degree they have become brutally honest in examining their own failings in nearly four decades of independence.
Almost simultaneously, however, it has become a fashion in Western capitals to pretend that Africa's problems are uniquely the product of the continent's own failings. Suddenly the self-comforting myth of the White Man's Burden has given way to an even more ahistorical belief: that Europe left Africa in good shape at independence. To believe that is to ask the next question: What is wrong with these people if they can't make modernity work?
Jim Hoagland, the foreign affairs columnist at The Washington Post, wrote of an editorial meeting in which one participant suggested that "the way to deal with Africa was to build a fence around the continent and then peek in 100 years later to see if anything had improved." A recent column by William Pfaff, who writes for The Los Angeles Times, meanwhile, took the other extreme, saying that Africa must be placed under some new form of international trusteeship until its immense problems can be worked out.
Not that either approach would work, of course. For a host of reasons, from emigration to epidemics, ignoring Africa and its problems would almost certainly backfire. And there is a moral argument: Africa has contributed about 12 percent of the United States' present population, with deep influence on its economy and culture; such ties cannot go ignored. As for trusteeship, the suggestion fails to ask why, after over a century of miserably presiding over Africa's destiny, the West is any more qualified to do so again today. Nor does it ask how Africans themselves might feel.
In any event, in assuming that Africa was well prepared for independence, both views betray the fund of ignorance that surrounds Africa and prevents even the well-meaning from exploring realistic ways of engaging it. A clearer reading of history would go like this:
After centuries of the Atlantic slave trade, which depleted the continent of millions of its best sons and daughters, colonialism, begun in earnest only about 100 years ago, was an affair of forced labor and captive supplies and markets for Europe. Preparation for independence was so secondary it could barely be called an afterthought. Chad, which at independence in 1960 had two and a half times as much territory as its French colonial master, boasted only three secondary schools.
Europe's treatment of much of Africa in the independence period can hardly be called an improvement. Many of Africa's worst dictators (some still with us) were the creatures of outside powers more eager for malleable allies than for fathers of independence.
Americans, who never colonized Africa, will rightly wonder: Why is this our problem? Liberia, although its origins 150 years ago as a colony of freed American slaves are unique, is a good place to start. As much as United Fruit in Central America, the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company has dominated its economy and politics for much of the period since the 1920's. More recently, to secure intelligence and communications assets in the country, Washington poured in more than $500 million in aid in the 1980's, as Liberia was being destroyed by Samuel K. Doe, one of West Africa's bloodiest dictators.
The links of history don't go back nearly as far, but equally grim stories can be told of American involvement in long-troubled countries like Zaire and Angola.
 
 
 
Business Opportunities
 Rather than simply seeking to apportion blame, however, many advocates of a reassessment of American ties with Africa say Washington should be prospecting for mutually profitable ways of dealing with it.
If the French and British rarely stop to ask the question, "Does Africa matter?" it is because their business people have long known what the late Commerce Secretary, Ronald H. Brown, was preaching to American companies shortly before his death: If the risks of doing business are higher than in most places, the rewards, in the form of average corporate profit margins of 25 percent, are the highest in the world.
In a recent study, Salih Booker, Africa Fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations, found that for all the despair about Africa, southern Africa's $7 billion in trade with the United States in 1994 roughly equaled America's total trade with all of the former Soviet countries. North African trade surpassed all of this country's commerce with Eastern Europe, and West Africa trailed that amount by only a small margin.
Paradoxically, just when Africa presents the richest opportunities, Americans, who account for only about 7 percent of the world's trade with the continent, seem strongly deterred by the images that steadily stream from a handful of traumatized lands.
"The United States runs a trade deficit with the continent, while most of the European allies run a surplus," said Mr. Booker, who added that until this year, Africa was the only region of the world for which the United States had no official trade policy.
"The U.S. could have a much bigger share of African business if it worked at it," he said. "This would mean more development and stability for Africa, but it would also mean jobs here at home. Isn't that what foreign policy is about?"

HEADLINE: Why So Resilient?;
A President Who Can Absorb Body Blows

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKEBy WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
IT'S probably the most puzzling question in the 1996 Presidential campaign, and one that is no doubt confounding Bob Dole: Why is it that as more and more whiffs of scandal have swirled around President Clinton, he has invariably emerged unscathed in the polls?
No President in modern history has demonstrated such resiliency in the face of one ominous headline after another: A sexual harassment lawsuit by a former state employee in Arkansas; the suicide of Vincent Foster, the deputy White House counsel; the resignation of Mike Espy as Agriculture Secretary amid allegations of impropriety; the White House travel office debacle and, of course, the Whitewater land deal, which has dogged the First Family for years. 
 Lately, the swirl has more resembled a twister. Nine days ago, the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation denounced the White House for improperly obtaining F.B.I. files on more than 400 people, many of whom worked for the Bush Administration. Embarrassing hearings on the matter got under way last week on Capitol Hill. On Whitewater, Senate Republicans issued a blistering report accusing Hillary Rodham Clinton and White House aides of impeding their inquiry. To cap it off, Federal prosecutors described Bruce Lindsey, a close adviser to the President and one of his closest friends, as a conspirator in an illegal scheme involving Mr. Clinton's last re-election drive as Governor of Arkansas.
 
 
 
Keeps on Ticking
 But by the end of the week, the polls showed not the slightest erosion in Mr. Clinton's double-digit edge over Mr. Dole, the presumed Republican nominee. An ABC News-Washington Post poll conducted June 14-18 found that 55 percent of respondents would vote for Mr. Clinton, while 35 percent favored Mr. Dole. And new polls in three large states, Texas, Florida and California, found Mr. Clinton comfortably ahead.
If Ronald Reagan was the Teflon President, then Bill Clinton is the Timex President: He takes his lickings, keeps on ticking.
"To have withstood so many legitimate questions about one's conduct without the public appearing at this point to take notice is a puzzling phenomenon," said Stanley A. Renshon, a psychoanalyst and political scientist at the City University of New York. "He seems to be doing everything possible to test the limits of the public's patience."
Scandals aside, Mr. Clinton's popularity no doubt has been shored up by factors that have traditionally immunized incumbents past: a relatively robust economy and encouraging quality-of-life measures like the declining crime rate.
But ultimately, the cumulative effect of so many accusations and disclosures could become too much for voters to bear. And Republicans can take solace in that they have nearly five months to make the "character issue" stick to Mr. Clinton.
While the Summer Olympics in Atlanta may dominate news coverage before the August party conventions, ethics issues are not about to disappear: The House and Senate inquiries into the F.B.I. file transfers have only just begun; so has the second Whitewater trial in Little Rock, involving Mr. Lindsey; and the special prosecutor for Whitewater, Kenneth W. Starr, now has the F.B.I. file affair on his plate as well. The Republican Party is sure to keep the questions alive in other ways; already, it is running TV ads reminding voters of the sexual harassment suit against Mr. Clinton and portraying him as a draft dodger.
 
 
 
Tolerance
 But for now, the President is benefiting from an understanding, though hardly sympathetic, public and from a far more tolerant political climate than in 1988, when Senator Gary Hart of Colorado abandoned his Presidential campaign amid revelations of his extramarital involvement with a woman on the yacht "Monkey Business."
Last weekend, hoping that he had finally broken through, Mr. Dole touted a CNN-Time poll that found Mr. Clinton's lead had slipped to 6 points from 22 points a months earlier. But the poll-taker has since conceded that the survey probably caught Mr. Dole at an unusually good moment: the day after his emotional resignation from the Senate. On Friday, a new CNN poll found that Mr. Clinton held a 19-point lead, even though most people said Mr. Dole was more honest and trustworthy.
In fairness, there is not a trace of evidence that Mr. Clinton has stolen public money, carried on with women in the White House or ordered wiretaps of his enemies. A joke making the rounds on the House floor is that Mr. Clinton amassed the F.B.I. files not out of sinister motives but because he was so eager to win friends, he wanted to send state-dinner invitations to his opponents.
"It's a drip, drip, drip type of thing," said Senator John Breaux, a Louisiana Democrat. "But the Republicans still haven't produced anything. The old saying, 'Where's the beef?' I would say, 'Where's the crime?' "
Yet voters know they did not elect a saint in 1992. From his initial appearances before wide national audiences, when he spoke of his past marital discord and bobbed and weaved on the draft, Mr. Clinton sought to inoculate himself against the character issue. His mantra during the New Hampshire primary four years ago was: "If you want a perfect candidate, vote for somebody else."
So far, the tactic has seemed to work. Many voters do not particularly like, or trust, the President. But that does not mean they won't vote for him. Voters have become so disillusioned about their politicians that they have low expectations about them.
"The idealism of the electorate has suffered, and the Clinton popularity is an index of the acceptance of lower standards," said former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California, who was angrily rebuked by Mr. Clinton when, at a candidates' debate during the 1992 primaries, he raised questions about Mrs. Clinton's business dealings.
Representative Patricia Schroeder, a Colorado Democrat who coined the term "Teflon-coated Presidency," said: "People are just scandal-overloaded. They know that Bush was involved in the Iran-contra stuff. They know that Reagan was not really in charge. What people are saying is the last President who they really thought was a conscientious guy was Carter -- yet he wasn't at the time getting straight A's from people."
 
 
 
The Dole Contrast
 As the accusations pile up, the public remains unmoved. Even the guilty verdicts in the Whitewater trial against the Clintons' business partners did not bring character questions to the forefront. Seventy-seven percent of Americans polled by The New York Times and CBS said the verdict brought no change in their opinion of the President.
Mr. Clinton has also benefited by the contrast with Mr. Dole, who many voters believe has yet to formulate a compelling rationale for his candidacy. Another advantage for Mr. Clinton is that the longest controversy, Whitewater, is impenetrably complicated to most Americans -- and difficult to boil down into a 30-second ad.
Haley Barbour, the Republican national chairman, accuses the media of glossing over Mr. Clinton's troubles (the White House certainly disagrees) and warns that the Administration's efforts to play down the gravity of its troubles could backfire. "Do not underestimate the impact when people are told over and over, 'There is not much to this,' " Mr. Barbour said.
Mr. Clinton's political fortunes could change, of course, and they could change overnight if the small drips turn into bucketfuls of questions. If there is one more indictment, one more scandal, or -- in Watergate parlance -- a smoking gun with Bill or Hillary Clinton's fingerprints, Mr. Dole might finally find the key to victory in November: The character issue could become too big for voters to ignore.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Unholy Fires on Hallowed Ground

BYLINE: By GUSTAV NIEBUHR 

 BODY:
IN America, where people rank among the most religious in the industrialized world, to burn a church is to commit an act of a singular profanity.
Its violence lies in the attempt to disrupt a community of believers, desecrate their altars and smash the spiritual rhythm of their lives. The arsonist attacks not just planks and shingles but the space where life's most important transitions are marked, where babies are baptized, marriages celebrated and the dead eulogized. 
 It is this recognition that has caused the growing sense of horror and outrage of many Americans, as night fires have gutted an increasing number of church buildings belonging to predominately black congregations in the rural South and beyond. Early Thursday, a church in Portland, Ore., was damaged by arson.
Church burnings register on a "soul-deep level," where even the Constitutional guarantee of religious freedom seems imperiled, said the Rev. Joan Brown Campbell, general secretary of the National Council of Churches. "You begin to ask," she said, "can one not go to a church of one's choice and worship free of fear?"
The council, which represents 33 Protestant and Orthodox Christian churches, has lobbied the Clinton Administration to step up the Federal investigation of the fires. What makes these acts especially insidious, Dr. Campbell and other say, is that they have occurred in black churches.
Deval L. Patrick, the Assistant Attorney General for Civil Rights, who is co-chairman of the group investigating the fires, called the burnings "an epidemic of terror."
In the last six years, Federal authorities have investigated 216 fires and desecrations in houses of worship and solved about a third. Half of the 216 incidents, Mr. Patrick said, have occurred in the last 18 months -- about 70 percent of them in Southeastern black churches.
Most have happened since December; most of the people arrested have been white. The attacks have sometimes come in clusters. On Monday night, two churches in northeastern Mississippi, less than five miles apart, were destroyed within minutes of each other.
From the days of slavery through the civil rights movement, religious congregations have provided an important meeting ground for blacks, who could gather outside the gaze of whites. Black churches formed in the face of the bigotry of established churches, which either barred blacks from membership or limited their participation, often segregating them in balconies.
 
 
 
A Nerve Center
 Rosetta E. Ross, associate professor of ethics at Interdenominational Theological Center in Atlanta, who throughout her childhood worshipped at a small Methodist church in rural South Carolina, said such houses of worship provided "the only place that African-Americans could gather and be in safe space, that is, in space that African-Americans could govern."
The local church served as a nerve center, where people learned news of their community and the society around them, said Professor Ross. In rural areas, she said, "There's still a sense of the church being the place that helps to hold the community together."
Black churches have long nurtured political and economic leadership, as well as providing spiritual uplift. Martin Luther King Jr., Adam Clayton Powell Jr. and Jesse Jackson were all ordained ministers before they were seen as national figures.
"The church in the black community is the symbol of our advocacy," said the Rev. Joseph E. Lowery, president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference. "It is the cultural-spiritual-political matrix in the black community. It is the site of mass rallies and marches."
If someone wanted to send a vicious message to black Americans, Mr. Lowery said, "they would want to target the one symbol of black aims and aspirations."
During the civil rights years, churches were routinely chosen for nocturnal firebombing. Sometimes the violence proved lethal: In 1963 a dynamite bomb segregationists placed in the stairwell of the 16th Street Baptist Church in Montgomery killed four little girls preparing for Sunday school.
Senator Bob Dole, the likely Republican Presidential nominee, spoke out early against the church burnings. President Clinton denounced the incidents in his June 8 radio address, and a few days later visited a South Carolina congregation that was dedicating a new building to replace one destroyed by fire. On Wednesday, he met with a bipartisan delegation of Southern governors and law enforcement officials.
Last week, the House unanimously passed a bill that would make it easier to pursue cases of church arson. The Senate is expected to approve a similar bill.
The burnings have also had an effect, outside Government circles, unintended by those who hoped the arson would terrorize rural blacks.
Public desire to help the congregations affected has cut across sectarian lines. Rebuilding funds have been launched by Christian groups, black and white alike, and by local synagogues and national Jewish organizations.
On Tuesday, the Christian Coalition, a conservative political organization that has supported legislation often in conflict with the views of black religious leaders, said it would ask churches on its mailing list to take up a special collection to raise $1 million. Two days later, the National Council of Churches announced that eight foundations had contributed $2.7 million to the council's Burned Churches Fund, to be used partly for rebuilding, partly to develop programs to combat racism.
Dr. Campbell said the council has also received offers from people who want to send money, lift boards or hammer nails in the effort to rebuild.
But beyond the crimes and the generous public response, there lies the more elusive problem of why the violence is occurring.
Mr. Clinton, in his meeting with the Southern governors, said he did not believe a conspiracy was at work, but he said many of the incidents appeared to be racially motivated. His comments reflected a lack of evidence to link the suspects in the few cases in which arrests have been made.
Dr. Campbell and Mr. Lowery attributed the burnings to a broad racial hostility simmering throughout the country. Dr. Campbell, who has visited 11 of the arson sites, said several pastors of burned churches blamed "hate radio," racially charged broadcasts on the airwaves that attributed the bulk of social ills, from downsizing to crime, to blacks.
Religious people, she said, should work to "change the climate," by pushing the cause of toleration, civility and respect for one another.
Mr. Lowery, on the other hand, said he thought the burnings had a broader source, in an "attitude of hostility" toward legislative gains made by blacks. Such hostility, he said, found inspiration in such efforts by politicians as rolling back affirmative action programs.
Still, church burnings represented a special kind of rage. "There is a hatred there," he said, "there is a lunacy there, that thinks they can shake their fists at God without consequence."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1234 words

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By HUBERT B. HERRING

 BODY:

MEDIA
 
What's Hot? Radio!
 
With all the talk about "new media" -- zapping the brain with the latest in electronic fare -- plain-vanilla radio is doing just fine. Ad revenues are growing fast, perhaps because of today's car mania and mega-commutes: unless you tempt fate surfing the 'Net as you steer, you're stuck with radio. So Westinghouse's $3.7 billion plan to buy Infinity Broadcasting made perfect sense -- a deal that would create a radio giant with 83 stations nationwide, dominance of many big markets, and, yes, Howard Stern. The deal is a direct result of Congress's recent loosening of telecommunications law, but because of its sheer size it could still face antitrust scrutiny. Critics also wonder whether it will hasten the day when you flip through the dial and find nothing but pounding, rat-a-tat news and sports, pounding rock music or the verbal pounding of the "shock jocks." Mozart? Hmmm. Must pitch for the Mets.
 
AVIATION SAFETY
 
Perfectionism Aloft
 
Every day, hundreds of people die terrible, untimely deaths -- from cars, crime, AIDS, alcohol, cigarettes, you name it. With most killers, our Washington protectors try, with varying success, to whittle at the toll. But whittling isn't enough for the Federal Aviation Administration. It wants perfection: zero fatalities. That may seem optimistic, with airplane deaths only blips on that fatal radar, but they do come in headline-grabbing bunches. Reflecting its new craving for this safety paradise, the F.A.A. grounded Valujet last week, citing "serious deficiencies" -- the agency had clearly changed its mind since its upbeat appraisal after the May crash. And as a quick encore, it said it wanted to scrap a dual, conflict-prone mission: promoting aviation with its right hand, keeping it safe with the left. From now on, both hands are to be safely on the wheel.
 
STATISTICS
 
Clinton Millionaires
 
Here's a puzzle. Democrats love to point smugly at Reagan-era statistics, the ones showing the rich gobbling ever more of the pie. But guess what? The latest numbers show that in the Clinton years, not only is the gap still widening, but the rich are grabbing even more of the national wealth. The top 20 percent of households, the Census Bureau said last week, now devour 46.9 percent of the income, up from 40.5 percent in 1968. So is Bill Clinton really the greater villain? Maybe not. The numbers, naturally, come bearing footnotes, and one is worth noting: until March 1994, the Census Bureau didn't account for income above $300,000; now the limit is $1 million. Considering all the obscenely large salaries paid to mere mortals these days, that could certainly skew the averages.
 
INFLATION KILLER
 
The Mighty Greenspan
 
It's a rare and heartwarming sight to see New York's two Senators agree so enthusiastically, but there they were last week -- Alfonse M. D'Amato praising Alan Greenspan's "steady hand at the tiller" and Daniel Patrick Moynihan calling Mr. Greenspan "a national treasure." The occasion? Mr. Greenspan -- no surprise -- was overwhelmingly confirmed by the Senate for a third term as Fed chairman. The vote came a day after a Fed report that has become a familiar drumbeat: the economy's doing fine, and inflation -- that brute! -- has still not struggled to its feet since the central bank beat it to a pulp years ago. So the Senate vote had a clear message: steady as she goes, and keep your foot firmly on the brute's neck.
 
TRADE
 
Rogues and Super-Rogues
 
It's an imperfect world. Some countries will always do unpleasant things. Even, dare one say it, the United States on occasion. But never mind that -- we're talking about the other ones, the bad ones, the "rogue nations." Is it our business to police them? True, it often makes sense to withhold America's welcome wagon -- on, say, trade -- but is it a bit much to demand that other nations enforce our lofty principles? Washington is already trying to whip up the world to join its anti-Cuba frenzy, and last week the House voted harsh sanctions against foreign companies that invest in Iran. But the rest of the world is balking, so on this issue, at least, America may itself become the "rogue nation."
 
AUTO PRICES
 
Terror on the Car Lot
 
Round numbers can be scary -- as in turning 50 (though it didn't seem to bother Donald Trump recently). Or exhilarating: as in breaking three hours in a marathon. But they are always potent, as the Commerce Department discovered when it calculated, two years ago, that the average new-car price had broken $20,000. A sobering number indeed, saddling cars with an image that auto makers didn't like at all: that of a costly luxury. So Detroit protested, and sure enough the Commerce Department now says that the earlier figure was not really precise -- and as it happens, the average never did hit $20,000. In fact, the agency says, average prices have actually fallen in the last year or so, to about $18,000, as more people choose cheaper cars and prices rise less frequently. Feel better?
 
MOVIES
 
50.5 Dalmatians?
 
 
Blockbusters here, blockbusters there. No, it isn't your imagination: anyone with a day job could not hope to keep track of all the movies opening these days, much less actually see them. Good news, though: relief is in sight. Disney has for years been firmly in the more-is-better camp, turning out 35 to 40 films a year -- partly to fatten up its library. But last week it said it would slash that to about 20, focusing more on "family films" -- but also keeping an eye out for projects like "The Rock," its current hit. The cuts make sense to one studio head, who said there's no glut of movies, just a "glut of Disney movies" -- the endless sports or teen-age comedies that have done so dismally. Now, only the cuddly or the huge will survive.
 
THE OLYMPICS
 
Torch by Madison Avenue
 
If you can walk through Atlanta this summer without getting an overwhelming urge to drink a Coke or a Bud, buy a Swatch watch or a G.M. car -- well, you're sadly short of modern-day Olympic spirit. You probably have idealistic notions about excellence, triumph, sweat and world records. What a quaint idea. The most visible world records so far are being set by the Brobdingnagian advertising displays -- the six-story Coke bottle, the submarine-size Swatch. Even as you make your way along Atlanta's streets, you'll probably walk on "official Olympic pavement" with "the official Olympic sun" beating down. So have advertisers found paradise, a land without limits? Sadly, no. In Olympic Park and much of downtown, ads can be no more than 35 feet high.
 
DIPLOMACY
 
A U.S.-China Deal
 
China agreed last year to stop its piracy of American music, movies and software, but then, apparently, kept turning them out anyway. So it was back to the drawing boards, with the United States threatening $2 billion in trade sanctions. Last week, again, there was a much-trumpeted deal to crack down on this piracy, the air filled with upbeat talk of "engagement" and "working together constructively." And, yes, there are new enforcement tools. But if, say, a compact-disk factory is closed, can American officials verify that it stays closed? No, not part of the deal. And, yes, the Chinese police have made several raids on pirate factories lately. But will such vigilance last?

HEADLINE: June 16-22;
Haves Over Have-Nots, Again

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

 BODY:
The rich getting richer? That seemed to be a staple of the Reagan Administration. But as a new report from the Census Bureau points out it seems a staple of almost all administrations since 1968.
Last week the bureau said that the gap between rich and poor continued to grow, and may have accelerated, during the first two years of the Clinton Administration. At the end of 1994, the top 5 percent of households earned 21.2 percent of total national income -- the biggest share of the income pie since the end of World War II. 
 Part of the growth in household income inequality stems from new ways the bureau measures income disparities, which make the rich look richer than ever before. But the report also indicates that larger trends like the growth in the number of highly paid women who marry highly paid men have more to do with the growing disparity than any Washington policies.
A new University of Michigan study also showed wealth concentrating from 1989 through late 1994 as affluent families gained from financial markets while poorer families fell deeper into debt. STEVEN A. HOLMES

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Defusing the E-Bomb

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
President Clinton flies to France this week for the annual G-7 meeting. Here's the speech he won't be giving to the gathering of Japanese, Canadian and European leaders:
Gentlemen, as we gather here this year, it's clear that we have no agenda. The reason is obvious: We are moving in opposite directions on the economic front. In this election year, the U.S. is moving from what Richard Gephardt calls an era of "deficit politics," focused on reducing our huge government debt, to an era of "income politics," focused on lifting the wages and lowering the taxes of workers. At the same time, though, you Europeans and Japanese are moving from an era of income politics, during which you swaddled your workers in lavish pension, health-care and retirement benefits, to an era of deficit politics, in which you've discovered you can't afford all these entitlement programs anymore, are trying to cut back, but your workers won't let you. I saw those protests in Germany and France on CNN. 
 The fact that we are moving in opposite directions is going to be a serious problem for all of us, and it's what we really should be discussing. From the American point of view, we are deluding ourselves if we think we can go back to the Reagan era of income politics, where the Government ran up huge deficits as it cut taxes and refused to cut entitlements. Unfortunately, though, my opponent, Bob Dole, is already planning to unveil a massive, Reagan-like tax-cut plan, with no serious deficit reduction. And I'm just as guilty. I've been throwing out proposals for tax deductions for college tuition, assisting first-time home buyers and resisting any deep cuts in Social Security, Medicare or Medicaid.
If either of us carries through on such promises we will be headed back to the huge deficits of the 1980's. But as all of you know, the international financial environment that sustained the Reagan deficits of the 1980's, and made them relatively painless for the U.S. public to absorb, no longer exists. The dirty little secret of Reaganomics was that it worked, and was sustainable, because the Japanese, the Arabs and the Germans all had surplus savings that they were ready to use to buy our Treasury bills, and thereby finance our deficit, so that we wouldn't have to raise interest rates sky-high. But times have changed. You can't save us anymore. The Japanese have their own banking crisis and have to finance their own aging population; the Arabs are broke, and the Germans are busy trying to finance their own deficit, run up by the cost of unifying East and West Germany.
As Thomas Gallagher of Lehman Brothers Global Equity Research points out, the longer we wait to downsize our entitlement programs the costlier it will be. He says that if we Americans decided today that we wanted to put Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid on a firm financial footing that would take us well into the next century, it would require a 15 percent tax hike across the board. If we wait until the next century, it will require a tax hike triple that amount. We all know those are politically unsustainable numbers. Which means we have no choice but to cut entitlements.
So here's the situation: We're all desperately in need of entitlement reform, but we American politicians are running away from it and our people are following us over a cliff. You European and Japanese leaders are at least running in the right direction, but none of your people want to follow. This is going to be trouble, or as Robert Hormats of Goldman Sachs International recently said about the G-7, "Our common failure to reform dramatically expanding entitlement programs is the ticking time bomb underneath us all, and the longer we wait to defuse it, the bigger the explosion will be."
Which gets me back to this meeting. G-7 summits can't change the world, but they can give us each a bit more courage to face our common problems, and a bit more credibility with our own publics by making clear that we are all in the same boat. Let's make this the Entitlement Reform Summit -- the one where we all pledge to begin defusing the "E-bomb." Because if we don't, the result will be turmoil. We will have intercontinental conflict, as we each try to suck up the other's savings to finance our deficits, and intergenerational conflict, as our children discover they have to pay for our negligence.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Europe Attacks U.S. Bid to Bar Investments in Cuba and Iran

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: FLORENCE, June 22

 BODY:
Leaders of the 15 European Union countries, four of whom will meet next week with President Clinton in France, expressed strong criticism today of United States legislation that would impose economic penalties on foreign companies that invest in Cuba, Iran or Libya.
The European leaders registered "deep concern" about the Helms-Burton Act, which would restrict non-American foreign investment in Cuba, and similar legislation being sponsored by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, that would penalize foreign companies that made large investments in Libya or Iran. 
 The European Union, its leaders said today, threatened to retaliate against these or other American attempts to impose what they called an extraterritorial secondary boycott against the target countries. Europe, like most of the rest of the world, does not support the American economic embargo against Cuba, and maintains what it calls a "critical dialogue" with Iran despite continuing American pleas to stop trading with it.
President Clinton signed the Helms-Burton Act despite reservations about provisions that would threaten foreign companies with lawsuits and exclude their executives from American soil if they used any Cuban property that was ever confiscated from someone who is now a United States citizen.
Senator D'Amato recently wrote to the French oil company Total S.A., warning it that proceeding with a $600 million acquisition of two Iranian oilfields from Conoco could threaten Total's ability to conduct business in the United States.
American diplomats in Paris said earlier this week that they did not expect the new legislation to cause much trouble at the meeting of the leaders of the world's leading industrial democracies, which starts next Thursday in Lyons, France.
The leaders of four countries that will be represented in Lyons -- France, Italy, Germany and Britain -- were among those who unanimously approved today's statement in the name of the European Union. Another opponent of the legislation, Canada, will also be at the Lyons meeting.
European officials said that they expected the United States to draw its own conclusions about how it would apply the legislation, given their opposition.
But the European leaders aligned themselves closely today with United States positions on the Middle East and Russia, urging all parties in the Middle East to search for peace and expressing support for the consolidation of democracy in Russia with a successful completion of the presidential elections there.
Like the Clinton Administration, most European governments were surprised by the victory of Benjamin Netanyahu in the recent elections in Israel.
Their statement made clear that they hoped that Prime Minister Netanyahu would resume negotiations with Syria despite his previous insistence that, unlike his predecessors, Yitzhak Rabin and Shimon Peres, he would not consider giving up territory in the Golan Heights to reach a peace agreement with the Syrian President, Hafez al-Assad.
Meeting here in a conference center in a 16th-century fortress that was designed to protect the Medicis from their Florentine subjects, the European leaders earlier resolved a three-month political crisis over their worldwide ban on British beef exports because of the so-called mad cow disease.
Britain stopped blocking European decision-making procedures after the group's approval on Friday of a plan to permit the gradual resumption of British beef exports once experts certified them as free of the disease.
So it was "business as usual" today, as the British Chancellor of the Exchequer, Kenneth Clarke, put it.
Still, there was no progress on an outline of revised procedures and treaty provisions to allow the group to take in central European countries early in the next century. The Europeans now expect to hold a special informal meeting in Dublin this fall to speed things up.
The leaders also conceded today that the common European currency they want to put in place could be introduced no earlier than 1999, assuming that any country could meet strict budget-deficit limits by the end of next year.
They also issued another in a series of almost ritual statements pledging to fight unemployment, which has now risen to an average of 10 percent, but without approving any European funds for programs to reduce the jobless rate.
Mr. Clarke pointed out that in previous meetings of this kind, the leaders pledged $10 billion through the European Investment Bank to build a new high-speed European rail network, but that political and environmental opposition, not lack of funds, had delayed them.

HEADLINE: Iraqis, Hurt by Sanctions, Sell Priceless Antiquities

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

 BODY:
Browsing the antiques markets of London a few years ago, McGuire Gibson, an expert on Mesopotamian art and archeology at the University of Chicago, found some of his worst fears confirmed. In the stalls of Portobello Road and the shops of Bond Street, dealers offered him antiquities probably smuggled from Iraq, a modern nation in distress that sits astride the remains of several ancient civilizations.
Cylinder seals, which were once used on tablets of wet clay in something like an ancient version of notarization, were for sale by the bagful. There were clay tablets with cuneiform writing from as early as the Babylonian period and other objects of uncertain origin. 
 "For decades, the Iraqis kept a very tight lid on stuff, and there was very, very little getting out," said Mr. Gibson, a professor at the university's Oriental Institute and a leading archeologist who conducted digs in Iraq from 1964 until the 1991 Persian Gulf war.
"After the war, the selling started. Now stuff is just pouring out. They are selling everything. If this continues, there won't be an archeological site left that won't be damaged."
With stringent economic sanctions against Iraq in place since 1990 and little relief in sight, art experts and archeologists say precious artifacts from some of the world's oldest civilizations -- Sumerian, Assyrian and Babylonian among them -- are pouring into the international market mainly to raise cash in hard times.
Experts say they cannot estimate the total value of Iraqi antiquities reaching the market illegally, but given that even small individual pieces can be priced at $50,000 in some cases, and that there are so many objects involved, the figure probably runs into the millions of dollars. Mesopotamian antiquities exported legally from the 19th century until the 1960's have fetched high prices -- in one case $12 million paid for an ancient palace relief.
Experts at Sotheby's and Christie's, auction houses that are careful to authenticate objects and know their origins, say they have not encountered pieces from the new wave of illegal exports.
While some of the sellers of Mesopotamian antiquities are middle-class families parting with heirlooms and Iraqi traders unable to sustain themselves because of an embargo imposed after Iraq invaded Kuwait in August 1990, looters and grave robbers working with international smugglers are doing most of the damage, some experts say.
There have been reports of hundreds of looters swarming over archeological sites, perhaps with semiofficial complicity, and a truckload of cuneiform tablets intercepted on the way to Saudi Arabia. So successful is the largely illegal trade in Iraqi antiquities that a thriving business in Mesopotamian fakes is also growing.
 
So Many Artifacts So Easily Removed
Diplomats, collectors, dealers and university experts -- most of whom do not want to be identified, so their future work in the region will not be disrupted -- disagree on some details about the boom. Some believe that individuals, including Government employees, are taking the best pieces out overland through Jordan; others think that most of the smuggling is done by professional rings operating through the Kurdish areas of northern Iraq into Iran.
As might be expected, Nizar Hamdoon, Iraq's envoy to the United Nations and an architect by training, blames the Kurds, who are in a permanent state of rebellion against central authority. But he also says Iraq is unable to guard all its archeological sites, numbering in the hundreds of thousands, and some objects are so close to the surface that they are easily removed.
Mr. Hamdoon said that many pieces had disappeared from provincial Iraqi museums after the war. American scholars and collectors have varying opinions about the value of missing museum pieces. But several said they believed that the Iraq Museum in Baghdad, which they described as one of the world's finest, had survived with most of its collection intact.
Constance Lowenthal, executive director of the International Foundation for Art Research in New York, which with the independent Art Loss Register monitors stolen art and antiquities, said Iraq had been vigilant in watching over its major museums and helpful in compiling lists of missing objects.
But questions remain about how some objects, especially large pieces, get out of the country undetected. In the current issue of Ms. Lowenthal's newsletter, IFAR Reports, John M. Russell, an art historian and archeologist at Columbia University, reports that parts of three large reliefs from the throne room of the Sennacherib Palace in Nineveh that he photographed in 1990 are now on the international market.
Iraq has laws against exporting antiquities, and selling illegal imports is a crime in the United States. But this trade is new, and many items are small and easily concealed.
Bonnie Goldblatt, a senior agent of the United States Customs Service who specializes in art fraud in New York, said law enforcement officials had not yet seized any illegal Iraqi objects. She added that such items were often camouflaged as goods from another country.
A collector in New York described a lot of the early museum pieces pilfered during and just after the gulf war as "rubbish" but concurred that many very valuable objects began to appear later from other sources, including the private collections held by families who, Iraqi and American experts say, have also sold off their modern art, antique carpets, furniture and wooden doors to stay afloat financially.
Sympathy for these Iraqis seems widespread among collectors and archeologists in the United States, who are critical of continued sanctions against President Saddam Hussein's Government. They say the sanctions are hurting cultured families and intellectuals more than Iraq's leaders and soldiers, some of whom may be involved in trafficking in antiquities for profit.
American Government officials, who acknowledge that sanctions have caused Iraqis to sell off a lot of their private wealth, including art and antiquities, nevertheless say that President Hussein need only meet his promises to destroy his weapons of mass destruction to end the hardship. Officials also say the Iraqi leadership has shown its contempt for history by tampering with ancient sites.
"Saddam Hussein's regime has chosen consciously to build luxury palaces on significant archeological sites near the ruins of Babylon," said James P. Rubin, spokesman for the United States Mission to the United Nations.
"And by refusing to meet the demands of the international community," Mr. Rubin added, "he is forcing his own people to sell their artwork, compounding the economic and material hardships with psychological and cultural suffering."
 
Videos, Delivery, Service With a Smile
Experts agree that London, New York and Tokyo have become the prime centers of the Mesopotamian antiquities trade, with Asians often paying the highest prices.
Professor Gibson of the University of Chicago said that dealers were sometimes sent videos of objects from Middle Eastern sellers, with offers to bring pieces to a prospective buyer anywhere in the world for inspection.
With the slump in stocks, property and artworks in the 1980's, the market in antiquities was already on the rise when objects from Mesopotamia began to appear in larger numbers a few years ago. The exploding market for cylinder seals -- the Mesopotamian equivalent of Chinese chops or European signet rings or raised stamps to press into sealing wax -- has been the most extraordinary.
These seals from the Fertile Crescent are tiny columns of semiprecious stones, precious metals or occasionally clay, carved around the outside in concave relief and then rolled, not stamped, on clay tablets (or later, wax) to make identifying marks. They may have identified the tablets' owners and been buried with them, sometimes in large numbers, in tombs that date to 2500 B.C. or earlier.
 
Stealing History, For Beauty's Sake
"Cylinder seals are special because they are very small, and to carve them takes extraordinary skill," said Professor Gibson, who has edited a catalogue of objects presumed stolen from Iraq. "They are spectacularly beautiful things."
"Except for the Assyrian reliefs with battle scenes and ritual scenes carved into them, there is nothing as wonderfully narrative or varied as a cylinder seal," he said.
"Because they are so small and are often made of semiprecious stones -- really wonderful stones -- they have taken on a value way above most other artifacts. Unfortunately they are easily transportable, easy to carry around and get out of the country. The biggest one would be something like three inches high and, say, an inch and a half in diameter. Most of the seals are an inch long and half an inch in diameter."
Ancient amulets are also small and easy to steal and smuggle, a New York collector said. Many were also carved from semiprecious stones and worn on a string. Scholars believe that engravings on them indicate that they could have been intended to ward off illness or evil. Professor Gibson has seen one that says, in effect, "This is to scare away demons." They may also have been used to protect a household.
Ancient graves in Iraq, including the royal tombs at Ur, contain many other objects illustrating the daily life of succeeding civilizations. At Nippur, where Professor Gibson had been working, archeologists found 17 layers of cities built atop one another, tracing human settlements from around 5000 B.C. to 800 A.D.
"Mesopotamia is the first place in the world where what we call civilization does pop up," Mr. Gibson said. "This is the first place where you get monumental architecture on a really grand scale, the first place you get an organization of people along craft lines, the first place you get monumental art."
"By 3500 B.C. you have already laid in certain motifs that will stay there right through Mesopotamian civilization and beyond it," he added, stressing the region's importance to the study of subsequent ancient history.
"Here we see the relationship of rulers to gods, the relationship of people to the ruler and in certain ways the relationship of people to nature. That was a tremendously strong tradition, and some of it found its way through Alexander the Great into Greece, influencing both the Western and Eastern worlds."

HEADLINE: New York City Studies Bid For Olympics

BYLINE: By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is forming a task force of city officials and business leaders to look for ways to bring the lucrative Summer Olympics to New York City in 2008.
"The Mayor thinks that New York would be the perfect place to hold the Olympics," said the Mayor's press secretary, Colleen A. Roche. "The Mayor is assembling a team right now of city officials, key advisers and business leaders and they will be examining the feasibility of having New York host the Summer Olympics in the year 2008." 
 Holding the games in New York would create thousands of new jobs in the city. New arenas and stadiums would have to be built and the city's infrastructure would need to be improved. And once the games began, the tourist industry would reap the benefits of over a million visitors.
"The Olympics have a huge economic impact on the city that hosts them," said Daniel Doctoroff, an investor who has just completed a preliminary study of the advantages of bringing the Olympics to New York. "And they can really be a catalyst for getting things done. In Atlanta they built a new international arrivals wing at the airport, upgraded their mass transit and created the largest new urban park in America."
But the competition to hold the games is fierce, often rivaling the competition of athletes on the field.
Cities must demonstrate that they have funding commitments from both the public and private sectors, adequate ground and air transportation and enough stadiums, arenas, housing for athletes and hotel rooms for tourists. Cities must first persuade the United States Olympic Committee that they are ready for the games. Then they must compete with the rest of the world before the International Olympic Committee.
"New York would be a phenomenal city for the games, but it does have some serious issues to work out," said Marc Ganis, the president of Sportscorp, a sports consulting firm. "It is an international city, a media center, it would be a great backdrop to the games," he said. "But it has a lack of physical facilities for the games and would need to find places to house the athletes. And the ground transportation logistics become a very serious matter."
Past attempts to lure the Olympic Games to the city have failed. In 1984, a similar coalition of business leaders and elected officials, led by the businessman Richard Ravitch, tried to bring the games to the city but lost out to Los Angeles. And a 1992 effort by Donald Trump to attract the 2004 Olympic Games to the city had little effect.
But now the city is preparing to stage the 1998 Goodwill Games, the international sporting competition conceived by Ted Turner, the media executive.
If the Goodwill games go well, their success could whet the appetite of the United States Olympic Committee to make a bid to hold future Olympic games in New York.
"The main thing is facilities, facilities, facilities," said John Krimsky Jr., the deputy secretary general of the United States Olympic Committee. "And the core infrastructure to accommodate the visitors, to house and move the athletes and coaches."
This summer's Olympic games in Atlanta, which have a $1.7 billion budget, are expected to draw more than one million visitors, 10,000 athletes, 5,000 coaches and trainers and 8,000 journalists.
And the new Olympic stadium, which cost $216 million to build, will become the new home of the Atlanta Braves baseball team when the games leave.
Talk of the Olympics comes a few months after Mayor Giuliani proposed building a new stadium for the Yankees on the West Side of Manhattan. If the city decides to make a full court press for the Olympics, it could improve the chances for the new stadium to be built. Mr. Doctoroff said his group would study ways in which a baseball stadium could be incorporated in the Olympics.
One factor that could work against New York City as a host is that the United States has staged so many games in recent years. The games were held in Los Angeles in 1984, and will be held in Atlanta this summer and in Salt Lake City in the winter of 2002. "The International Olympic Committee does like to spread it around the world," Mr. Krimsky said.
But Mr. Doctoroff said that he thinks New York has a fighting chance. "It is a symbol of the Olympics," said Mr. Doctoroff, a partner of the Texas investor Robert Bass.
"New York is the world's second home," he said. "Twenty-eight percent of the city is foreign-born, 40 percent don't speak English at home. This is a place where the various ethnic communities actually mix."

HEADLINE: Transit Official, Casting Doubts on Metrocard, Suggests Keeping Tokens

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

 BODY:
A year away from the scheduled elimination of the transit token, the Transit Authority's budget director has questioned whether it makes sense to do away with the token, leaving the Metrocard as the only way to pay a fare.
The doubts raised by Harvey Spector, the authority's budget director, are the first signs of dissension about the plan within the agency's top ranks, after an intensive three-year campaign to promote the Metrocard and clear the way for the token to be phased out by July 1, 1997. Mr. Spector, who is regarded by his colleagues as a sober judge of finances, expressed those doubts to Lawrence G. Reuter, the president of the Transit Authority, in a May 1 memo that was mailed anonymously to The New York Times. 
 Yesterday, Mr. Reuter defended the plan to do away with the token and said the timetable would not be altered. He said the concerns raised in Mr. Spector's memo either were misplaced or were being addressed.
Mr. Reuter also said that the Transit Authority plans to begin, "fairly shortly," to sell $1.50 or $3 Metrocards, good for one fare or two. "We have developed it," he said. "We're testing it."
The lowest-priced card now available costs $5, which some critics say is out of reach of the poor or impractical for people who use the transit system only occasionally. After buying a Metrocard, a rider can have value added to it at some token booths. Metrocard was supposed to be a boon to riders, who were to get an array of discounts, and to the transit system, which was to use it to make money in a variety of ways. But as Mr. Spector noted in his memo, both sides of that equation have collapsed. And, referring to the trouble the system has had in getting subway and bus passengers to accept the card and businesses to sell it, Mr. Spector questioned whether it would even be possible to eliminate the token.
"It's a pretty breathtaking statement that Metrocard is a flop," Gene Russianoff, staff attorney for the Straphangers Campaign, said of Mr. Spector's memo. "And if Harvey Spector, who is a smart guy about these things, is worried, maybe we should be."
The memo is, in part, a frank admission of some of the problems that have plagued Metrocard since it became available in 1993 -- most notably, the lack of acceptance by the public. In April, it accounted for just 6 percent of all fares paid, though that figure was rising quickly, with riders spending three times as much on Metrocards in May as they did in December.
The card is accepted on all Transit Authority buses and at 200 of the 468 subway stations, with the rest due to accept it by early next year.
The price for the Metrocard system will exceed $700 million. Officials note that the biggest expense has been new turnstiles, which they say were badly needed and have helped cut fare-beating. Still, they have long fretted about the need to show some benefit from such a large investment.
As envisioned since the early 1980's, the Metrocard was supposed to entice riders with discounts like lower per-trip rates for spending more money on the cards, or flat-rate monthly or weekly passes. As recently as late 1994, the Transit Authority and its parent agency, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, promised such discounts.
Because of those incentives, Mr. Spector wrote, "Metrocard penetration rates were expected to soar, allowing for the orderly phase-out of the token (customers would have a real economic reason to move away from the token)."
But in early 1995, it became clear that declining city, state and Federal aid would cause the system financial trouble, and the discounts -- which would cost the M.T.A. money -- were shelved indefinitely. Since then, the M.T.A. has raised the transit fare to $1.50, just to keep up with cuts in Federal aid.
One incentive that appears to have survived is the elimination of two-fare zones, or areas where commuters commonly take a bus and a subway, paying two fares for one trip. The M.T.A. chairman, E. Virgil Conway, has promised to do away with two-fare zones by the middle of 1997, and an electronic fare card may be the only practical way to do that. Ending two-fare zones may be the only reason left for the card, Mr. Russianoff said.
Mr. Reuter argued that other discounts, like monthly passes, are merely dormant, not dead, and that Metrocard is essential to reviving them. "If you don't have the technology in place, you lose that flexibility long-term," he said.
Transit officials believe that for Metrocard to succeed, particularly among bus riders, it must be available at thousands of neighborhood businesses. So far, the cards can be bought at 1,600 shops and newsstands, but they are hard to find in many areas.
"If we don't have a robust out-of-system sales network, we won't be able to eliminate" the token, Mr. Spector wrote.
That worry, Mr. Reuter said, is misplaced. "We are putting into place a plan to develop an out-of-system sales network," he said, but he would not elaborate.
Some transit officials have argued that a one- or two-trip fare card would make the cards more attractive to riders and, therefore, to merchants.
For years, the M.T.A. devised plans to make money from Metrocard, primarily by marketing it as an all-purpose debit card that could be used at tens of thousands of businesses for small purchases like magazines or T-shirts.
But this year, three years after the M.T.A. concluded that it needed a partner with greater financial expertise, lengthy talks with Chase Manhattan Bank collapsed. Officials say it would take at least a year to put together a partnership with another company. In the meantime, other banks and telephone companies have jumped into the new debit card business, and some M.T.A. officials fear that they have missed their chance.
In his memo, Mr. Spector wrote: "Without a venture, token elimination is not essential."

HEADLINE: Medieval Fortress of Spirituality;
Cloaked in Mystery, Brooklyn Nuns Do Their Work: Prayer

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
The basketball sailed over the high stone wall along St. Johns Place in Brooklyn, just missing the statue of Mary and the baby Jesus that rises forlornly above a block of graffiti-scarred row houses.
The ball's 13-year-old owner walked cautiously to the black iron gates of the Monastery of Our Lady of Mount Carmel, pressed a button and retreated to the street, watching until the gates groaned and a slice of daylight showed. From within, an unseen hand rolled his ball back onto the sidewalks of Crown Heights. 
 "I've never seen anybody come out," said the boy, Terrence Daniel. "Who does live in there?"
It is a question Brooklynites have asked for nearly 90 years now when they pass the corner of St. Johns and Bedford Avenue, where the monastery of a remarkable group of cloistered Carmelite nuns sits like a medieval fortress.
But even for those who know who lives inside -- the priest who celebrates Mass for the sisters at dawn, the parishioners who bring them fish and fruit and speak with them occasionally -- there has always been almost as great a sense of mystery. Because unlike other cloistered orders, the Brooklyn nuns have remained perhaps America's last practitioners of the oldest way: a life of complete isolation rooted in the 16th century.
This means that even those who have visited the whitewashed Italianate monastery for decades have never once seen its inhabitants.
No one can say for certain how many nuns live in the cloister, with the guesses ranging from 9 to 17. Even the priest who visits them six mornings a week, Monsignor Guy J. Puglisi, is unsure of their number and has no idea of the range of their ages. "It's a good question, but I can't answer it," he said. They remain hidden to visitors, communicating only through a barrel-shaped revolving wooden cabinet called a turn, first used in the Middle Ages to pass goods into monasteries without violating the cloister. In the few other American cloisters that had them, turns disappeared as part of Vatican reforms in the 1960's.
"Brooklyn is in a class all by itself," said Sister Constance FitzGerald, a Carmelite in Baltimore and an authority on the order's history.
To enter the turn room on St. Johns Place is to step back in time. Parishioners bearing handwritten pleas for prayer or bags of groceries that the nuns depend on are buzzed through the gates, buzzed into an anteroom and buzzed again into a tiny parlor. They place items for the nuns inside a polished 4-by-2-foot oak barrel half submerged in the bricks, and, like a secret revolving bookcase in a mystery movie, the barrel is spun around so a sister on the other side can take the contents.
Usually, a soft, muffled voice offers thanks or asks a question through the wood and a conversation is struck up. But it is always brief. Above the turn is a hand-lettered sign: "In the House of God, talk of Him or do not talk of anything."
In an era when nuns have become increasingly active and are working hard to change their image as escapists or innocents -- using models like Sister Helen Prejean, the death-row counselor portrayed in the film "Dead Man Walking" -- the Brooklyn nuns work as hard to remain changeless. Only by shutting out the world, they believe, can they be devoted to their sole mission: prayer.
Their concessions to the centuries since St. Teresa of Avila reformed the order in the 1500's are few and grudging. They have elecricity, but appear to use little of it, Monsignor Puglisi said. Others who glean details of their hidden lives from letters or snippets of conversation say they recently abandoned wearing veils and using straw sack mattresses, switching to thin foam-rubber pads on flat boards because straw was too difficult to maintain.
Even as they ward off encroaching technology, they are eminently practical. Monsignor Puglisi recalled that he once asked a sister behind the turn if he could use a phone. The barrel whizzed around and inside was a cordless handset. "I was a little, like, 'Well!' " he said. "The mother superior explained to me that she used it so she could work while she took calls."
But the sisters still wear thick brown wool habits like their predecessors, who founded the monastery in 1907, and they always wear sandals. Although nearly all other cloistered convents have done away with turns and metal grilles -- Sacramentine nuns in Yonkers took their grille out with an electric saw in 1969 -- the Brooklyn nuns still talk with visitors, even priests and family, from behind the turn or an opaque screen in the chapel.
While other convents have posted home pages on the World Wide Web and have bought cars to attend conferences, the Brooklyn nuns have never had so much as a television or radio and they do not leave the grounds even for visits of the Pope, but only for medical emergencies. When they die, they are buried in a crypt beneath the altar or on the grounds, thick with sycamores and maples.
"I've known people who have been in and out of there for 60 years, and never saw a sister, just the voice," said Pete Brennan, a retired banker who is part of an association of former neighborhood residents who raise money for the monastery. "When you were a kid it was a little scary: you're talking to a barrel, not a person."
The monastery was founded by six young nuns who traveled to Brooklyn from a convent in Port Tobacco, Md., near Baltimore. Established in 1790, the Maryland cloister was the nation's first, and from the earliest days, the Carmelite order evinced the quiet, steely resolve inherited by the Brooklyn nuns of today. According to one story, Archbishop John Carroll of Baltimore, the first American bishop, badly needed teachers. Without consulting the sisters, he obtained the Vatican's permission for them to abandon seclusion and start a school. The sisters insisted on remaining cloistered. The bishop relented.
The Brooklyn cloister began in a ramshackle clapboard house improbably called the McCann Mansion at St. Johns and Bedford, in what was then a solidly Irish and Italian Catholic neighborhood. The current monastery, three stories tall, with a bell tower, a steeple and a block-long enclosed garden, was built in the late 1920's by Helen Morton, the daughter of Levi P. Morton, a governor of New York and a vice president under President Benjamin Harrison.
According to the official history, Miss Morton provided the money after her dying sister, Alice, had a vision of St. Teresa, who dropped a pink rose on her bed and asked, "Will you build my monastery?"
Time has not been kind to Our Lady of Mount Carmel. The stained-glass dome over the chapel cracked and had to be boarded over, and a section of wall tumbled onto Bedford Avenue last year. As the stark neighborhood's economy declined and crime rose over the past 30 years, security became an ever-present worry. Special Mass in the ornate chapel became rare after a mentally disturbed man barged in during one service and ran away with the monstrance.
The outer wall is topped in parts with glass shards and razor wire. The wall is also now covered with technicolor scribbles and words like TERROR and ESCAPE! "In the old days," said Mr. Brennan, 61, who was born on St. Johns, "we were all very intimidated by the place. God forbid you should even throw a ball against the wall."
Inside, the nuns appear to keep up their prayers unperturbed. They usually rise before 5:30 to say the morning portion of the Divine Office, which is intended to make the entire day holy, Monsignor Puglisi said. They attend Mass at 6:30 and receive communion through a small gold door in the chapel wall. Then they spend the rest of the day in nearly complete silence, responding to letters, doing chores, but mostly praying together or alone in their rooms, called cells. They pray for priests and nuns, for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and other elected officials, for disaster and crime victims and for hundreds each week who mail or deliver requests for sick relatives, barren couples or out-of-work friends.
They are bound by their vows never to ask for anything and so do not receive help from the Brooklyn-Queens Diocese. Instead, they depend on the kindness of the dwindling group of former and current parishioners of nearby churches. James Quitone, a nurse who began to visit them when his father fell ill 14 years ago, often loads his car with cases of orange juice and tomatoes and Italian bread and drives over from Sheepshead Bay. "For those few tomatoes I bring you would think I bring the world," he says. He once took a couple of kiwis and the sister at the turn asked, "What are these fuzzy things?"
"No matter how many times I ask them what they like to eat," he said, "they always tell me whatever I bring is strictly up to the intervention of the Holy Spirit. The only way I figure out is to watch and listen and see what they don't return." The sisters seem to enjoy sweets, perhaps following their patron, St. Teresa, who once said when criticized for eating a big meal that there is "a time for penitence, but there is also a time for partridges."
Among the 65 monasteries of fellow cloistered Carmelites around the country, the Brooklyn nuns are sometimes regarded as relics or worse because of their stubborn resistance to change. While reluctant to criticize on the record, several Carmelites interviewed recently said they believed such seclusion and self-denial is unhealthy and unnecessary to keep up a life of prayer. "Some of us say that this 20th century has enough of its own kinds of hairshirts," said Mother Joseph, prioress of a convent in Terre Haute, Ind., that has a fax and a station wagon.
But the nuns' supporters believe prayer is being forgotten in the Catholic Church, and the way to restore its importance and rejuvenate shrinking religious orders is to return to the old ways. "People give me arguments about this, say those nuns are in there wasting their time, but I say that they're in there working," Mr. Brennan said. "Prayer is hard work."
Echoing Monsignor Puglisi -- who is fond of saying, "People don't know how powerful a place that monastery is" -- a priest from nearby St. Teresa's Church wrote of the nuns in the summer of 1942: "That which saves society is not that which can be seen upon the surface of things. It is not the power of industry, of war, of genius, of letters or arts. It is what touches its depths in a silence called the silence of good things."
