HEADLINE: Andreas Papandreou Dies at 77; Fiery, Ambiguous Premier Dominated Greek Politics

BYLINE: By MARLISE SIMONS 

 BODY:
Andreas Papandreou, the former Prime Minister of Greece and a maverick who towered over Greek political life for more than two decades, died early today at his home in Athens. He was 77.
The cause was a heart attack, his doctors said in a statement. Mr. Papandreou had open-heart surgery in 1988, though that did not keep him from winning an election in 1993. 
 But during 1995, his failing health prevented him from performing his dutiesm leaving Greece flailing. Yet even as his fiery voice had thinned to a near whisper and he walked with great difficulty, Mr. Papandreou refused to step aside or name a deputy to run the Government.
Finally, in January, his Socialist Party named Costas Simitis Prime Minister, and Mr. Papandreou had not been seen in public since his release from a hospital on March 21.
Few other politicians in modern Greece have inspired as much love and loathing at home and as much bewilderment and irritation abroad. The tall figure with bushy eyebrows fascinated Greeks with his compelling oratory and his unpredictable and volatile ways, and he remained hard to fathom even for his friends.
He was successful at home because he appealed to Greece's thirst for change, and his nationalist polemics appealed to the Greeks' perennial feeling of being misunderstood and unappreciated.
Abroad, Greece's Western allies were regularly befuddled as the undoctrinaire Socialist took positions diametrically opposed to theirs on issues ranging from Serbian aggression in Bosnia to the role of NATO.
Above all, the United States loomed large in his life, for that was where he had served in the Navy, graduated from college, worked, married twice and had four children; it was his source of funds and the nation that he first admired and later railed against obsessively.
The core of his foreign policy was to end Greece's status as "a client state of the West." As a result, he refused to condemn the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan and variously threatened to pull out of NATO, the United Nations and the European Union, although he accepted the Union's generous funds.
He blocked European credits for Turkey, Greece's enemy. While others shunned Libya and Yugoslavia, he improved his ties there. In the Bosnian war he supported Serbia, a longtime ally, and opposed sanctions against Serbia. He was reluctant to condemn Serbian atrocities, even in the face of ample evidence.
Mr. Papandreou thrived on being contrary; he described this as "tightrope diplomacy." Until the collapse of the Soviet Union, he was especially skillful at extracting funds from fearful Western governments that wanted to protect Europe's southeastern flank in the Communist Balkans. But despite his polemics, he remained pro-Western.
Although he was always passionate about politics, his life was made up of very distinct parts.
The only son of Sophia and George Papandreou, Andreas George Papandreou was born on Feb. 5, 1919, on Chios, while his father served as governor general of the Aegean Islands. When Andreas was five, his parents divorced. But he stayed in touch with his father, who rose in politics and became a powerful and popular leader, eventually becoming Prime Minister.
In 1937, when Andreas entered Athens University Law School, Greece was ruled by a right-wing dictator, Gen. Ioannis Metaxas, and his father and other liberals were banished to the island of Andros. Andreas, by now a Trotskyist, joined a resistance group that distributed underground newspapers and pamphlets, for which he was arrested and tortured.
Shortly before Mussolini's troops entered Greece, Andreas Papandreou left for New York, where he arrived in May 1940 with $14 in his pocket. He enrolled at Columbia University and took odd jobs to support himself. He married a Greek-American, Christine Rassias, in 1941 and earned a doctorate in economics at Harvard University in 1943.
The marriage ended in divorce a decade later. Dr. Rassias, a psychiatrist, said she often felt bullied by her husband, that he was a "ruffian" and "lied all the time." She wrote an unpublished autobiography in which she described Mr. Papandreou as cruel and dishonest.
In an interview last year, Dr. Rassias was asked why the book had not been published. Speaking of Mr. Papandreou, she said: "He paid me $90,000 not to publish the book because he was running for office then. He was afraid it would damage his political chances." She accepted. "I needed the money," she said.
After becoming an American citizen, Mr. Papandreou joined the Navy for two years of wartime service, much of which he spent as a clerk in the Bethesda Naval Hospital. When World War II ended, he started his career as a lecturer in economics, first at Harvard, then at the University of Minnesota and Northwestern University. He eventually became a professor and the chairman of the department of economics at the University of California at Berkeley, until he resigned in 1963.
Meanwhile he had met Margaret Chant, of Elmhurst, Ill., a former journalism student. After both obtained divorces, they were married in Nevada in 1951. They settled down in Berkeley, raised three sons and a daughter and became actively involved in liberal American politics.
It was with the help of American funds that Mr. Papandreou returned to Greece. Supported by Guggenheim and Fulbright grants, he spent 1959 studying the Greek economy. He went to Athens again in 1961 to set up the Center for Economic Research, this time with financing from the Ford and Rockefeller Foundations.
He handed back his American citizenship in 1964 to run for Parliament under the auspices of his father, the Prime Minister. Later that year his father named him Deputy Minister of Economics.
But King Constantine, who distrusted both men, dismissed the Prime Minister and his Cabinet. The period of instability that followed led to a right-wing military coup in 1967, and both Papandreous were arrested. The younger man was kept in solitary confinement for eight months.
Again the United States loomed large. Pressure from influential Americans, including the economist John Kenneth Galbraith, led the military junta to release Andreas Papandreou and other political prisoners in 1967. But from his exile, first in Sweden, then in Canada, Mr. Papandreou organized a coalition of opposition groups and denounced the American Government for "complicity" in the military coup. He remained convinced that Washington quietly supported the 1968-74 military dictatorship.
In a 1972 article in The New York Times, he wrote that the United States approved prime ministers, interfered in elections and in military promotions and "controlled the Greek Intelligence Service."
In 1974, when Greece was traumatized by Turkey's invasion of Northern Cyprus, he and many others were convinced once again that Washington knew about the Turkish military plans and could have stopped them. The belief that in general Washington favored Turkey over Greece in their perennial squabbling fed more anti-Americanism.
The party he founded in 1974, the Panhellenic Socialist Movement, or Pasok, changed Greece's political landscape. It brought him -- and the left -- to power in 1981. Describing himself as a "non-dogmatic Marxist" he quickly introduced social reforms that benefited low-income groups, promoted workers' councils and farmers' cooperatives, abolished censorship and lowered the voting age to 18; prompted by his American wife, he brought legal equality for women.
As soon as he took office after the 1981 elections, Mr. Papandreou tweaked the West by opening a Greek Embassy in Cuba and granting diplomatic status to the Palestine Liberation Organization.
Behind his neutralist gestures, Mr. Papandreou's foreign policy was cautious, almost conservative. He kept Greece in NATO, but refused to take part in some exercises. He preserved Greece's membership in the European Union, thus obtaining important agricultural subsidies. But he also gave Washington what it had not been able to obtain from his right-wing predecessor: a five-year renewable agreement to retain four military bases and a number of smaller installations on Greek soil.
At home, many Greeks applauded him because he established civil marriage and legalized divorce and abortion. But his economic policy remained so full of contradictions that no one quite knew where he stood, and critics said that he squandered the power and the funds he had to modernize the country.
For all his calls for change and the generous funds from the European Union, Greece remains the Union's poorest nation. Of the $12 billion the Community lent Mr. Papandreou in the 1980's to modernize, diplomats in Brussels said, 80 percent was spent on consumption and salaries for political featherbedding.
As opposition leader and as Prime Minister, he lashed out against the corruption of his predecessors, but his own government unraveled in the late 80's in a series of scandals involving fraud and phone-tapping.
His prestige also suffered because he publicly flaunted his affair with Dimitra Liani, a flight attendant half his age, while he was still married to his wife of 38 years. After humiliating publicity, Margaret Papandreou, the mother of his four adult children, agreed to a divorce in 1989.
By late 1989, he could no longer withstand the cascade of scandals and he lost the elections. Parliament indicted Mr. Papandreou and ordered him and four of his former ministers to stand trial on charges including bribery and embezzlement. He repeatedly protested his innocence, saying that American agents were trying to "destabilize" Greece and that his political opponents were out to destroy him politically.
Mr. Papandreou was narrowly acquitted in 1992, but two of his ministers were convicted.
Yet on Oct. 10, 1993, Mr. Papandreou made an astonishing comeback. Even though he had had a heart operation; taken Ms. Liani, his mistress, as his third wife; built a mansion costing more than $1 million, and never quite shaken off corruption charges, he won election for the third time.
This was perhaps his most remarkable trait, the ability to change position and survive scandal and even indictment without loosing popularity.
"He was an amazing politician," said Nicholas Gage, author of several books on Greece and a former New York Times correspondent there. "He made ordinary people feel they mattered. Above all he was a master at tapping the mood of the moment and at adapting his views to that. Basically, he was politically amoral."
Behind his charm, there was also a man known for being autocratic and wanting total control.
Epiminondas Zafiropoulos, an opponent and member of the 1989 parliamentary investigation into Mr. Papandreou's conduct, said the leader was essentially "an insecure man" who "wanted to be the master of all the games."
During his 10 years in office, he modernized Greece, but not enough to pull it from the doldrums. Rather than cutting back the country's enormous and rigid bureaucracy, he bloated to capture votes. Although Mr. Papandreou inherited a patronage system where a politician is expected to provide a job for every supporter, many economists agree that he did little to change this; some say he expanded it.
Some of Mr. Papandreou's supporters believe that his successes and his strong leadership in balancing an unruly society have been unfairly overshadowed by his governments' financial scandals and by troubles involving his wives.
Although extra-marital affairs are common in Greek politics, Mr. Papandreou broke the rules by publicly displaying his liaison with Ms. Liani. Greek women, in particular, did not pardon this affront to his wife, a strong voice for social reform and women's rights.
In 1995, he was relentlessly criticized by supporters and opponents for naming his new wife director of his office and giving her much power over access to him. He caused further outcry by saying he would support her if she had political ambitions.
The fallout was intense. One result was that his longtime ally, George Kouris, publisher of the newspaper Avriani, staged a smear campaign and regularly published nude pictures of a young Ms. Liani, hoping to undermine the Prime Minister and to block Ms. Liani's political career.
Last year, friends said, even as his health was waning, Mr. Papandreou aspired to become President -- a largely ceremonial post -- when Constantine Karamanlis's term expired in May. But the struggle to succeed Mr. Papandreou as party and Government leader was so fierce that he reportedly feared a breakup of the party and renounced his aspiration.
Over the years, he published a number of articles and books on economic and political themes, including the succesful "Democracy at Gunpoint" and "Paternalistic Capitalism."
In addition to his wife, Ms. Liani, he is survived by his four children from his second marriage, to Margaret Chant: George, who is Greece's Minister of Education, Sophia, Nicholas and Andreas.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 52; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 3905 words

HEADLINE: Atlanta Is Burning

BYLINE: By Paul Goldberger; Paul Goldberger is the chief cultural correspondent for The Times. His most recent article for the Magazine, about Jerusalem, appeared in September.

 BODY:
The real question is whether Atlanta sold its Southern soul to get where it is, or whether it had one in the first place. Forget Tara. Atlanta is what you would have if Detroit got its act together.
The reality of Atlanta is that it has become the ultimate American city, born of a marriage of outsize boosterism and hard-nosed business. It may be in Georgia, but with every passing day it is less and less of Georgia. The Atlanta that is about to become the most watched city in the world, as 1.4 million athletes, spectators and journalists descend on it for the 1996 Olympic Games, is a place that has invented itself in what can only be called a stunning combination of civic determination and public relations hype. The city has trained for this moment in its history with as much focus, and as much tenacity, as any athlete has prepared for the Games. 
 Only one aspect of Atlanta is truly Southern, and that is its ability to sugarcoat its ambition: Atlanta has manners, unlike, say, Houston, which was the last American city to try to vault from regional city to international metropolis on the strength of its own ambition. But Atlanta is less brazen, and determined not to fall on its face the way Houston did when the oil economy collapsed. This city is not above trying to charm its way into the circle of major cities -- but builds a mass-transit system and one of the world's biggest airports, just in case. Atlantans see the Olympics much less as a chance to make money, as Los Angeles did in 1984, than as a sign from the rest of the world that their city has been accepted into the fraternity of big-time urbs.
"How did we get the Olympics? Confidence and salesmanship -- after all, it's not like we had great architecture and the Mediterranean," says Joel Babbit, an advertising agency head who once served as the city's chief of marketing -- a title that in itself says something about Atlanta's priorities -- under Mayor Maynard H. Jackson. "We have always marketed this city like a product. Atlanta's business is self-promotion. We have always sold first, then kept the promises afterward."
Assertiveness, of course, is only one quality of great international cities. It's a precondition, necessary but not sufficient. Truly great cities possess not only ambition and money but also a kind of energy that has nothing whatsoever to do with business. Every great city has an ineffable style, a sense of a physical presence that is very much its own, which joins with its cultural ambitions to make the place sizzle. The greatest cities in the world have the ability to create culture and not just consume it -- and if that makes daily life a little more difficult, well, the success of these cities is based on the belief that the trade-off is worth it. That's why Barcelona and Berlin and Los Angeles are greater cities than Frankfurt and Dallas and Denver, which for all their economic might are really just big business centers.
So far, for all its success, Atlanta is still firmly in the latter category -- a great place to do business rather than a great city of the world. Atlanta sprawls, and its downtown, for all its gleaming skyscrapers, seems less and less of an urban nexus than a kind of weak center surrounded by ring upon ring of suburban development. True, downtown has the Martin Luther King Center for Nonviolent Social Change, organized around King's tomb and nearby birthplace, and CNN Center, the Cable News Network's headquarters (tours offered daily). But the place that really seems to dazzle the tourists is World of Coca-Cola, a mini theme park in which visitors can spend $4.50 to explore what is really no more than a three-story commercial for Atlanta's richest corporate citizen: not exactly high culture.
The next decade will tell whether Atlanta, having successfully elbowed its way into the company of great marketplaces, can make it all the way into the club of great cities. It's hard not to think of the city as organized for convention-goers as much as for international travelers, as a business center whose best product is ease -- of access, of operation, of living. Nothing to laugh at, particularly given the quality of life in most American cities. But those qualities don't make a place into Barcelona, however well it sells itself.
Modern Atlanta has been shaped by corporate power since the 1920's, when Robert Woodruff of Coca-Cola first put together the coalition of businessmen and politicians that has governed the city ever since. Woodruff believed that a corporate agenda and a civic agenda were much the same thing, and that joining the two would somehow make it possible for Atlanta to preserve a sense of community that was felt to be Southern and to transcend the limitations of the South at the same time: Southern charm mixed with Northern aggressiveness, you might call it. It is a belief that Mayors like William B. Hartsfield, Ivan Allen Jr., Maynard H. Jackson and Andrew Young, each a powerful personality in his own right, have deferred to.
Middle-class Atlantans worship at different churches, but the Chamber of Commerce is sacred to all. This attitude has worked wonders in selling the city as a kind of middle-class dream, a place where the good life can be lived by anyone, white or black, who makes a decent living. It doesn't hurt, of course, that the city's climate and scenery are far above the norm: Atlanta is 1,050 feet above sea level, higher than any other major city besides Denver; it was once entirely forested and still has a dense green blanketing most of its neighborhoods, a color broken only by the white and pink blossoms of the dogwoods that make many of the city's residential streets look like botanic gardens for the long and early spring that follows each year's mild winter.
Downtown Atlanta, though it struggles for dominance with the growing clusters of office towers outside of town, has a stunning skyline, its pointy-topped skyscrapers as gleaming a sign of 80's prosperity as those of any city in the country. Most of it is second-rate post-modernism, to be sure, although there are a handful of first-class buildings, like Philip Johnson and John Burgee's I.B.M. Building, a sumptuous tower of granite that won the admiration of critics when it was finished in 1987 and then, in true Atlanta fashion, spawned several nearby imitations.
But it is the work of John Portman, the architect and developer whose Hyatt Regency Atlanta Hotel downtown was completed in 1967, that made Atlanta architecture -- and Portman -- famous around the world. The Hyatt revolutionized hotel construction with its atrium and glass elevators, and its success inspired Portman to go on to build Peachtree Center, a multi-tower grouping that brought tremendous activity to downtown, but all of it, unfortunately, indoors and off the city streets. Portman saw his mission as making the city safe and palatable for the middle class, and he did so almost too well, for he filled Atlanta with buildings that brought a kind of suburban mall mentality to the center of downtown.
It seems right that Atlanta was the birthplace of a whole generation of urban buildings that turn inward, as malls do. This is a city in which the suburban sensibility predominates, a city in which making daily life feel smooth is generally a first priority, and where people are most comfortable sticking with their own. Atlanta strives to provide modest doses of visual stimulation, cultural activity and urban energy but is careful not to let things get out of hand, as if it feared that too much culture and energy could turn the place into New York or Los Angeles, something few Atlantans could abide: these cities are harsh, something Atlanta never wants to be. When it comes to a choice between dogwoods outside the window or a good symphony downtown -- well, sophisticated Atlantans would like to have both, but if forced to choose, there would be no contest.
Historically, Atlanta never did have much to sell, other than itself: it didn't even have a normal reason for being, since it started not as a trading settlement or a harbor or a factory town but as the end point of the Western and Atlantic Railroad's new lines in 1837. (The city's original name was Terminus.) Its arbitrary location in the middle of the forests of northern Georgia seems oddly fitting now, in an age in which technology makes it possible to conduct almost any business from almost anywhere and location becomes a matter of choice. For as cities located the old-fashioned way, on rivers and in natural harbors or valleys, struggle to survive, the capriciously sited Atlanta booms.
Atlanta grew mighty as a transportation hub, a banking center and the headquarters of the corporation that grew up around the city's most potent invention, Coca-Cola, first served in an Atlanta drugstore in 1886. Yet today the city is at least as well known for being the headquarters of CNN. Since its founding in 1980, CNN has beamed the name Atlanta 24 hours a day onto television screens around the world, proving that a media center can be wherever someone -- in this case Ted Turner -- declares it to be. A generation ago it would have been unthinkable for a media venture as ambitious as CNN to have started outside New York or Los Angeles, if only for credibility. Today this hardly matters, and CNN, far from needing credibility from New York, confers it on Atlanta.
Atlantans are fond of comparing their city with Birmingham, Ala., just 135 miles west, and the comparison tells much. As late as World War II, the cities were roughly equal in size and economic strength. In the view of Atlantans, it is their pragmatism, their commitment to business and their willingness to open their city to outsiders that caused their economy to take off like a rocket, leaving Birmingham in a strife-filled dust. While Birmingham protected its insularity, Atlanta was trying to build the airport that eventually became the world's second-busiest and would turn the city into a transportation hub with few equals in the world. And while Birmingham was putting all of its resources into a violent fight against integration, Atlanta was putting together a coalition of business and civil rights leaders to oversee peaceful desegregation of its public accommodations.
"Atlanta always said, we will be different, we won't make the same mistakes as other cities," says Maynard H. Jackson, the city's first black Mayor. "When Birmingham had fire hoses and cattle prods in the street, Atlanta went to the bargaining table. We knew that cattle prods are bad for business."
In Atlanta, appearances have always counted for more than ideology -- which is why, for much of the city's business community, integration was less a moral issue than one of sheer pragmatism. Boycotts, riots and demonstrations meant lost business, cost money and made the city look ridiculous. Atlantans knew in the 1960's what the rest of the nation thought of places like Selma, Ala., and Birmingham, and even those with a private preference for segregation bit their tongues rather than see their city held up to national ridicule. The Atlanta way was to keep things quiet and trust in appearances.
Not that civil rights in Atlanta has been only a matter of appearances. The city's commitment to using business as a vehicle for social progress has made it something of a national showcase for affirmative action, an effort that began in the mid-1970's, when Mayor Jackson insisted that contractors building Hartsfield Atlanta International Airport take on minority partners. The Olympic procurement contracts, worth $387 million, have been viewed as Atlanta's biggest affirmative action opportunity of all: at the insistence of city leaders, 35 percent of the construction contracts have gone to minority companies, which have helped design and build virtually every Olympic structure.
And yet, while its political and commercial worlds have been gradually integrated over the last generation, Atlanta remains almost entirely segregated socially. Its neighborhoods are almost all either black or white; blacks meet whites at large public functions but only rarely in smaller, more intimate settings.
Neighborhoods like the Cascades, a tree-filled cluster of grandiose mock-Georgian villas and French Provincial chateaus on the South Side, are occupied almost entirely by prosperous blacks. While their haute-suburban luxe stands as a reminder of the economic opportunities Atlanta has afforded African-Americans, these neighborhoods underline the fact that Atlanta, for all its vaunted racial progress, remains a bastion of segregation. And the city's poorer neighborhoods, needless to say, are no more integrated. Residents of the Cascades do not have to look at the South Bronx or the South Side of Chicago to know how far they are from poverty; traveling a mile or so down Martin Luther King Jr. Drive will show them just as much urban despair.
Segregation has always been the rule in Atlanta. True, the city points with well-deserved pride at the size and strength of its black middle class, buttressed not only by a strong economy but also by Atlanta's position as the historical center of black higher education, with six colleges guaranteeing a continual flow of educated, middle-class blacks into the city's job pool. Yet white Atlantans historically were so determined to separate themselves from their black neighbors that most of the long north-south streets running through the city were given different names as they crossed the border from black to white areas, lest there be any confusion as to where they were. After all, it would never do for a white family to have an address on Moreland Avenue; it had to be Briarcliff Road.
Interstate 85, the main north-south route, was laid out to take a wide loop around the east side of downtown, a circuitous route that effectively separated the business district from the black neighborhood to the east. There were no black policemen in Atlanta until 1947, and even then, the first cadre of black officers were required to restrict their patrols to black neighborhoods and to change in the basement of the YMCA so as not to integrate the locker room of Police Headquarters. (The city's current Police Chief, Beverly Harvard, is a black woman.)
And blacks were no more welcome at public events in Atlanta than elsewhere in the South. One of the city's proudest celebrations, the premiere of "Gone With the Wind," in December 1939, attracted cast members like Clark Gable, Vivien Leigh and Olivia de Havilland -- but not Hattie McDaniel and Butterfly McQueen, who were emphatically not invited to the segregated event. As late as 1964, when Martin Luther King Jr. won the Nobel Peace Prize, the city was in a tizzy over a proposal that Atlanta pay him tribute at an interracial dinner in one of the city's major hotels; it was only after Robert Woodruff, the longtime chairman of Coca-Cola and the dean of the city's business community, sent word of his approval that tickets for the event began to sell.
Gary M. Pomerantz, a reporter for The Atlanta Journal-Constitution, summed up the situation in postwar Atlanta in his book "Where Peachtree Meets Sweet Auburn": "A fast tempo in business in Atlanta was considered a godsend. But in race relations, it was not."
Those days are long gone. Yet the Olympics, for all the success of affirmative action, have not brought Atlanta to an era of complete racial good will. Most events will be concentrated downtown, which ought to be a good antidote, symbolically at least, to the city's increasing sprawl, but the downtown focus has caused new tensions with the city's poorer residents. While Olympic planning has brought splendid cosmetic improvements to some of the residential neighborhoods, most of the improvements have been directed toward soothing the eyes of visitors -- making sure, for example, that as tourists walk from stops on Marta, the city's transit system, to the Olympic gyms and stadiums, they will see trees, new street lighting, small parks and elegantly paved sidewalks instead of decrepit streets and rubble-strewn vacant lots. To some critics, this amounts to little more than an attempt to hide the city's poverty from public view during the Olympic festivities.
Empty the Shelters, a local advocacy group for the homeless, has claimed that 1,676 families have been displaced from public housing around the city to make way for the Olympics. The group has tried in proper Atlanta fashion to make its case in the form of a catchy public relations campaign, built around a sour-faced cartoon character, Spoilsport, a female response to Izzy, the city's saccharine Olympic mascot. Spoilsport has written a short, dyspeptic guidebook to the city that is nothing if not a counterpoint to the rest of the city's relentless boosterism. "Atlanta, known as 'the city too busy to hate,' might more aptly be called 'the city too busy to care,' " snarls the guide. There is little evidence that anyone pays Spoilsport much attention.
Where have the displaced residents gone? Not to other housing in downtown Atlanta. While there has been much talk for years about building new housing downtown, relatively little of it has actually gone ahead, even with the Olympic boost; the 2,000 units in the Olympic Village, which have been built to house Olympic athletes, will become dorm space for Georgia State University after the Games, not housing for Atlanta residents. In April, Spoilsport's creators gave their Big Boot Award to Mayor Bill Campbell, calling him "the individual who has demonstrated outstanding performance in the field of displacing and removing Atlanta's poor residents, in an attempt to hide the face of poverty in our Olympic city."
People who can afford it, both white and black, have increasingly fled to the suburbs, pushing the borders of the booming Atlanta metropolitan region farther and farther out, and separating themselves not only more and more from the city's old downtown but also from any sense of responsibility for its future. Paradoxically, the area is full of people who eagerly describe themselves as coming from Atlanta when they are far from home; once back, however, they think of themselves as residents of Sandy Springs or Roswell, with barely more feeling of connection to Atlanta than to Savannah. The city's "urban fabric," such as it is, consists increasingly of new office buildings, shopping malls and hotels out on the interstate, miles and miles from the city center.
The problem of conflict between Atlanta and its surroundings is getting worse, not better: when the Georgia-Pacific Corporation, one of the first major corporations to ride the Atlanta boom, relocated its headquarters from Portland, Ore., in 1982, it built a huge granite skyscraper near Five Points, the historic center of Atlanta's downtown. But the biggest corporate move of the last few years was made by the United Parcel Service, which told the world it was giving up Greenwich, Conn., for Atlanta but actually set up shop on a huge, wooded campus 12 miles away in Perimeter Center. For all its fabled success, the city is now looking more and more like the hole in the center of a doughnut, facing the same battles with its surroundings that embitter other large metropolitan areas.
That's much more than an issue of black versus white, though, since as more and more blacks have achieved middle-class prosperity, they have chosen, like whites, to slip across the border. Living in the Cascades in the far southwest corner of town may be a shining example of black success, but huge numbers of Atlanta's prosperous blacks now live beyond the city limits altogether and have become a part of the suburban constituency. The city's historic black centers -- Auburn Avenue on the East Side (the "Sweet Auburn" of Atlanta lore) and Martin Luther King Jr. Drive near the black colleges on the West Side -- increasingly have the kind of relationship to the African-American community that Little Italy in New York has to prosperous Italian-Americans living on Long Island.
The disappearance of the center of the city will be the issue as Atlanta faces its future after the Olympics. There is now a proposal to build a second ring road, even farther out than I-285, the beltway that Atlantans call the perimeter but that increasingly feels like the center. "If that road gets built, Atlanta will sprawl all the way to Chattanooga in one direction and the Atlantic Ocean in the other," says Michael Lomax, a former chairman of the Fulton County board of commissioners whose hopes of becoming Mayor were dashed by Maynard H. Jackson's decision to attempt a return to office in 1989. "The region is pushing another perimeter road, which will make this place more like Southern California. Will we be willing to invest in more mass transit so we can be a well-planned city around a central core? Unlikely."
Lomax is black and hard-edged; Leon Eplan, who as Mayor Jackson's budget and planning commissioner oversaw much of the city's planning in the 1970's and returned to office as the city readied itself for the Olympics, is white, older and more connected to the city's old-style mentality. In his case, that translates into the belief that Atlanta can still turn itself, physically at least, into a viable urban center and moreover, that it is on the verge of doing so. His vision of urban greatness is not an Atlanta built on the model of Los Angeles but a cosmopolitan city, almost European in its character.
"The 20th-century automobile city isn't working, and I'm convinced that major transportation for the 21st century will be rail," Eplan says. "I'm convinced that all of north Georgia will converge back again on the central city. It is exciting to be here now -- it feels like Chicago must have felt in 1893, with the World's Fair laying the groundwork for a great city of the 20th century. Well, with the Olympics, we are doing it for the 21st."
Trish Deb, a spokeswoman for Empty the Shelters, says: "The problem with Atlanta is that the corporate agenda has replaced a civic agenda. Atlanta has turned over its power to a coalition of corporations." Deb misses the fact that this is how business has always been done here: indeed, it was Robert Woodruff's notion that a corporation's goal was to convince the city that its interests were the city's own. Community service of an old-fashioned sort is somewhere next to godliness here.
But can business leaders themselves make a world-class city? They have never done so anywhere else -- it takes the money and ambition of business people, combined with the vitality (and often the contrariness) of a potent cultural community. And while no one should underestimate the effect of CNN and a slew of universities on the cultural fabric of Atlanta, this is still in every way a community driven by business, not by culture: a city still mainly attuned to bringing the good life to suburban middle managers and convention-goers.
Livability is not to be sneezed at, but urban greatness often coexists more comfortably with friction. Atlanta's success at making life smooth for the middle class may, paradoxically, be something that holds it back from the top tier of cities, rather than pushes it forward. The problem of Atlanta may not be that it is too difficult but that it is too easy.

LENGTH: 2022 words

HEADLINE: An Anglo-French Corner of Quebec

BYLINE: By PATRICIA BEESON; PATRICIA BEESON is a writer who lives in Toronto.

 BODY:
ESTRIE, meaning kingdom of the east, is the official French-Canadian name bestowed in 1981 on the Eastern Townships region in southeastern Quebec. About the size of Massachusetts, it lies roughly, west and east, between the Richelieu and Chaudiere Rivers and, north and south, between the former seigneuries (feudal domains once owned by French nobles) along the St. Lawrence River, and the northernmost New England states.
Late last spring, my husband and I drove east from Toronto to North Hatley, our favorite village in Estrie. The land had emerged from the long Quebec winter with an almost audible sigh of relief. There were still a few patches of snow on the high hills, the most northerly outcrops of the Appalachians, and the winter winds had worn thin the paint on some of the clapboard farms. We looked forward to a long weekend sampling some of the places to stay in the region, including Manoir Hovey, a lakeside hotel with lovely gardens, and two bed and breakfasts -- the chic La Raveaudiere and the folksy Cedar Gables. 
As we approached La Raveaudiere, we drove through landscape that reminded us of Vermont, its wooded hills, lakes and meadows. Indeed, most of the area's earliest settlers were Americans loyal to the British crown who entered the Eastern Townships over the Vermont, Maine or New Hampshire borders after the Revolutionary War. They were followed, in the early 1800's, by a large wave of British, and a distinctive Anglophone region developed within the French-speaking province.
But around the 1850's, economic forces -- the overflowing farms of the seigneuries, the need for labor in the lumber industries and the construction of a railway from Montreal -- brought in French-Canadians, who today constitute 90 percent of the population in Estrie.
North Hatley, on Lake Massawippi about 30 miles north of the Canadian border, is still something of an English holdout. But it too is changing; Anglophones now represent only a little more than half of the community.
La Raveaudiere, an elegant bed-and-breakfast up the hill from the long and narrow lake, is owned by two French Canadians. Our room was one of three on the third (top) floor, with sloping ceilings, bathrooms and air-conditioning. Of the four bedrooms on the second floor, all with private bathrooms, one is air-conditioned and three have large handsome overhead fans. Our room, with its pale honey walls, green-painted floor and fresh flowery fabrics, looked out toward both golf course and garden.
In the living room we found glasses and bottles of port and sherry on a small table. Magazines were invitingly heaped on the floor next to big sofas set into a large bay of windows overlooking the garden. We gravitated into the bar, at one end of a long fir-green room, which was also the elegant kitchen when we last visited.
Since then a new kitchen has been built from the former laundry room, and the old kitchen has been transformed into a dining room where the owners, Serge Raveau and Simon Marcil, now serve northern Italian food to their guests. Friendly and chatty with guests inclined to talk, our hosts seemed pleased at our interest in their eclectic array of paintings.
At the back of the house is a brick-paved terrace, where breakfast is served in summer. The mornings were still cool when we were there, so we ate breakfast -- eggs, croissants and fresh fruit salad -- indoors.
There's a lot of cool weather in Estrie, which really has only three seasons: a long winter, a mere passing sigh of a spring as the land leapfrogs into summer, then, usually, a lovely and lingering fall. In late spring and summer, the Pilsen Restaurant and Pub in North Hatley is filled with a high-spirited crowd that spills out onto its long river-level veranda, a congenial gathering place with geranium-filled window boxes and red-and-white-striped umbrellas.
Set beside the bridge over the Massawippi River, which flows out the pointed north end of the lake, the restaurant, at street level, was jammed by 7 P.M., so we descended to the pub, where the young staff switched seamlessly from one language to the other, bustling to and fro with immense plates of breaded chicken or hamburgers nesting on mountains of chips. Upstairs the food has more pretensions, but was still good pub fare and very reasonable. The chef's special -- veal, walnuts and apples, assorted vegetables and french fries or rice, followed by chocolate cheesecake with raspberry coulis -- came to $38 for the two of us, coffee and a half-liter of wine included.
The Massawippi River, which we could see from our table, splits North Hatley into two. East of it are most of the village's few shops and behind them, some handsome 19th-century houses climb up the hill toward La Raveaudiere. To the west, hugging the lake, is the lion's share of the most affluent homes -- rambling clapboard or shingled residences. There, too, are its two distinguished hotels, Manoir Hovey and the Auberge Hatley (formerly called Hovey Manor and Hatley Inn till Quebec law ruled all signs must be in French).
From the veranda of the Auberge Hatley -- one of only four hotels in Quebec to be members of Relais and Chateaux -- we could just see the lake below the lawns and trees of the hotel's perfect garden and turquoise pool. We had dinner in the tranquil, split-level pink and green dining room overlooking the garden. We began with a little entree of goat cheese, shrimp and slivers of salmon, with a green sauce of arugula and watercress -- a visual delight, which delivered what it promised. This was followed by the tenderest slices of pork and spinach, with a little cake of potatoes served separately. For dessert, my husband enjoyed a glorious chocolate confection.
After coffee, we asked Vincent Chabert, the maitre d'hotel from Grenoble, France, to show us some of the 25 guest rooms. Still calm and attentive after a long day, he gave every appearance of pleasure in doing so. Each of the four rooms we saw was different, fresh with stylish fabrics and paintwork -- one in shades of terra cotta and tobacco, with glossy white woodwork and striped fabrics, another in a flowered deep blue and white. Liliane and Robert Gagnon, the owners, are largely responsible for the interiors, which along with the service and cuisine attract Canadians of both tongues, as well as guests from Europe and the United States.
Americans have summered in North Hatley for a very long time. After the Civil War and Reconstruction, wealthy Southern families, who had formerly escaped the heat in New England's resort areas, passed by the lands of their erstwhile adversaries and went farther north to Canada.
The first to "summer over" in North Hatley is reputed to have been a Dr. Powhatan Clarke, from Baltimore, who, traveling north with his family in 1886 on the new spur line from Newport, Vt., to Lennoxville, Quebec, fell in love with Lake Massawippi when he saw it out the window. Many of these wealthy summer visitors built imposing houses around the lake, some echoing the architecture of the South.
ONE of these, then known as the Birches, is now the Manoir Hovey. It was built in 1900 by Harry Atkinson, owner of Georgia Power in Atlanta, in imitation of Mount Vernon, on a handsome property bordering the lake. Manoir Hovey still feels like a substantial country home. The house, with its brimming flower beds, pool and pillared front, looks out onto the lake and the garden.
In addition to the rooms in the main building, the hotel has turned several of Atkinson's former outbuildings and staff quarters into appealing guest accommodations, creating a total of 35 rooms. Our room was on the second floor of one of these outbuildings, with latticed paper, white wrought iron beds and flowered fabrics. But, while the staff is obliging and diligent and the meals excellent, the country house decor in the main building, including the dining room and adjacent book-lined library, has a disappointingly tired air.
About half way between Manoir Hovey and the village center is Cedar Gables, a bed and breakfast overlooking the lake owned by Ann and Don Fleischer, longtime expatriates from Ohio. Ann spins, and Don's home-brewed beers and wines are much esteemed. The five rooms are clean but no effort had been made at color coordination, and the walls over our bed were filled with family photographs in a way that made us feel somewhat intrusive. But the good-heart edness of the Fleischers has enthusiastic fans, evident from their guest book, and our $68-a-night room price included a substantial breakfast, complete with home-baked muffins and jams.
About 25 miles south of North Hatley on the east shore of Lake Memphremagog is the delightful small village of Georgeville, where the Anglophone presence seems, to an outsider anyway, little diminished. A small old hillside graveyard is full of Murrays and Bullocks and Perkinses going back to the late 18th century. Down the steep hill past the pink and white Auberge Georgeville and the immaculate oxblood-red Murray Memorial Center is a grassy square flanked by houses straight out of Woodstock. And the jolly people lunching on Maison McGowan's informal little terrace were almost exclusively English-speaking.
A plain turn-of-the century fishermen's inn, Maison McGowan is set on the east shore of the 27-mile-long, narrow Lake Memphremagog, which extends south into Vermont. Immediately in front of the 12-room inn are the pier and boat slip, where we watched small boat launchings and the arrivals and departures of the local scuba diving center. Our simple lunch of chicken salad was good, as was the tempting selection of desserts, and the staff very agreeable and friendly. The crowd on the terrace was mainly older, with casual straw hats, assured tones and clothes of faded khaki and denim.
Outward appearances in Estrie may suggest New England. But this is not New England. It's certainly not Ontario either, the nearest Anglo province, nor even the Quebec beyond its boundaries. Trying to define it, the Quebec Government guide book describes it as being "a celebration of bicultural existence possessing a discreet Anglo-Saxon charm blended with 'quebecoise' joie de vivre."
 
If you go
 
Events
From early May to mid-October, the Auberge Hatley collaborates in Gourmet Golf with Manoir Hovey and Auberge Ripplecove, a hotel on the south end of Lake Massawippi with 26 rooms, suites and chalets built in 1945 and completely renovated in 1987. The program involves two nights at each inn and three rounds of golf from a choice of 12 courses in the area. The cost is $342 a person, calculated at 1.31 Canadian dollars to $1. In winter, the three inns offer Skiwippi, a six-night inn-to-inn cross-country ski program. A price has not been set yet; last year it was $572.50. Available year round is the Moveable Feast, with three six-course dinners (one at each inn) and three three-course dinners (again, one per inn). No price has been set yet; last year it was $381.70.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 41; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 824 words

HEADLINE: ARTS/ARTIFACTS;
A Neglected Corner Of Picasso's Legacy

BYLINE: By RITA REIF 

 BODY:
"TO MAKE A DOVE, YOU must first wring its neck," Pablo Picasso once said, explaining how he shaped clay into some of the most memorable ceramics of the 20th century.
Picasso produced several thousand pieces of pottery over the last four decades of his life. Among them were vases that look like fat owls or voluptuous women and pitchers, plates and tiles painted with fauns, radiating suns, bullfights and men's portraits. 
 Though Picasso's ceramics represent a rich artistic legacy, they are among the least known of his works, for a very simple reason: he kept most of them in his own collection. Vases and bowls were piled on the floors, around the fireplaces and on mantels and table tops in his home and studio in the South of France. Photographs from the 1950's show Picasso in a cavelike room surrounded by the great variety of ceramics he produced at the Madoura pottery workshop in Vallauris, near Antibes.
Picasso's ceramics are more complex in their forms and decoration than the thousands of reproductions that were made with his authorization by Madoura's potters and painters. There are other differences. The original ceramics are dated but not signed; the reproductions, in contrast, are sometimes numbered and always stamped with "Edition Picasso, Madoura," "d'apres Picasso, Madoura" or the like.
At his death at 91 in 1973, Picasso owned 3,222 pieces of pottery. For years, some of the artist's ceramics have been on view at the Picasso Museum in Antibes. But once his estate was dispersed, under the direction of the French Government, to museums and to heirs, the ceramics were exhibited beyond the Vallauris area. In 1980, 12 pieces were exhibited with his paintings and sculpture in "Pablo Picasso: A Retrospective" at the Museum of Modern Art. Larger selections were displayed at the Picasso Museum in Paris after it opened in 1985.
Now, some of the artist's favorite ceramics are on view in the first exhibition of his pottery in the United States, "Pablo Picasso -- Unique Ceramics," at the Hammer Galleries on 57th Street west of Fifth Avenue, through July 26. (It will be at the Nassau County Museum of Art, Roslyn Harbor, L.I., in November.)
The show consists of 45 ceramics made between 1948 and 1969. Etienne Sassi, an art dealer in Paris and Vallauris, bought most of the pieces in 1989 from the estate of Picasso's widow, Jacqueline Roque Picasso. He and his brother, Dominique, were childhood friends of Jacqueline's daughter, Catherine Hutin-Blay. "Her house was just two blocks from ours in Juan les Pins," Mr. Sassi said. Dominique Sassi, a master painter at Madoura in the 1950's and 60's who decorated the Picasso reproductions, also knew Jacqueline when she was a saleswoman at Madoura, before she married Picasso.
Mr. Sassi had the ceramics hung unconventionally in roughly carved picture frames in the Spanish style. The frames are included in the prices for the ceramics; two works on tile, for example, range from $38,000 for an image of a faun's head to $1.8 million for a still life of a vase of flowers.
The show includes examples of most of the themes -- animals, portraits, bullfights and still lifes -- that Picasso returned to again and again in his ceramics. He began working in clay in 1946 when he visited Madoura and took delight in creating clay figures of animals and people. When he returned a year later, he brought sketches of the pieces he wanted to make. As his friendship with Georges and Suzanne Ramie, the owners of Madoura, grew, Picasso continued to have his works fired there, even after he moved 20 miles away to Cannes in the late 1960's.
PICASSO SINGLEHANDEDLY revived the moribund ceramics industry in Vallauris, an activity that had been a mainstay of the local economy for 800 years. Defying all conventions of the craft, Picasso handled clay in ways professionals discouraged, twisting and pulling jugs and pitchers into anthropomorphic shapes and pinching the center of a vase to create the wasp waist of a woman. The fresh approaches he took brought new energy to the craft. And he encouraged other artists to work in pottery, which he viewed as a medium that combined sculpture and painting.
Some of the pieces on view display the wit for which Picasso was known. The image of a tall thin man in a bicorn hat astride a horse confronting a bull is painted on a shaving plate that is pierced with two holes. The work is probably a visual pun on the story of Don Quixote who hung a shaving plate around his neck to serve as the breastplate of his suit of armor.
Several other works are embellished with bullfight scenes that appear to have been sketched quickly by the artist. A more unusual study of an artist in his studio is boldly drawn in black on a white pitcher. On one side the artist is painting a nude model; on the other he is sculpturing her. Painter and sculptor depicted on pottery? Perhaps it's another of his self-portraits.

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Of Time and a Theater

 BODY:
IN JUNE 1956, JOSEPH PAPP MIXED FREE Shakespeare and a summer's night for the first time when he presented two plays at the East River Park Amphitheater near Grand Street and the F.D.R. Drive. The 2,000-seat concrete theater was built in 1941, part of an urban renewal project on the Lower East Side. Today, overgrown with vegetation and overrun with graffiti, it warns of time's passage and decay. A rich blend for the site-specific En Garde Arts troupe, which opens its 10th-anniversary production there on Thursday: "The Trojan Women -- a Love Story" by Charles L. Mee Jr., directed by Tina Landau.

HEADLINE: FILM VIEW;
Immigrants' Tales, in Subtle Shades of Gray

BYLINE: By Sanford J. Ungar; Sanford J. Ungar, dean of the School of Communication at American University in Washington, is the author of "Fresh Blood: The New American Immigrants."

 BODY:
SAM DEEDS, THE CRUSADING sheriff of Rio County, Texas, in the film "Lone Star," has crossed the border to investigate the death years ago of Eladio Cruz, a Mexican-American who used to smuggle friends into the United States by hiding them among the watermelons in his pickup truck.
In a sleazy town just inside Mexico, Sheriff Deeds encounters one Senor Montoya, "the tire king," a grizzly old cynic who lived north of the Rio Grande himself for 15 years. As they talk in the yard of his tire warehouse, Montoya takes a Coke bottle and draws a line in the gravel. He challenges Deeds to step across the line. 
 "A bird flying south, a rattlesnake," the tire king says to the earnest, somewhat tongue-tied sheriff, "you think he sees this line? You think halfway across that line they start thinking different? Why should a man?"
Deeds protests that the Mexican Government itself has often found the border to be a convenient device to define its authority. But Montoya is not impressed with the role of government on either side of the river. "I'm talking about people here!" he shouts. "Men!"
The confrontation becomes a galvanizing moment in "Lone Star," John Sayles's rich new border drama, which stars Chris Cooper as Sheriff Deeds, Elizabeth Pena, Kris Kristofferson, Matthew McConaughey and Frances McDormand. Trying to solve a complex mystery involving previous sheriffs, including his own father, Sam Deeds encounters the many forces that artificially divide people from one another.
In the film, which opened on Friday, we see old immigrants who express contempt for new immigrants, "Anglo" parents who resent a teacher's efforts to explain how the Texas settlers took land from the local Mexicans, politicians who prey on the public's fears to push construction of an unnecessary new county jail, and black people caught in the middle of it all. In this context, the border seems like just one more contrivance, albeit a uniquely symbolic one.
Mr. Sayles's latest movie is compelling for many reasons, but an important one is that it speaks honestly about immigration along our southern border. Until relatively recently, the Federal Government did not even count as immigrants the people who crossed that line -- or, for that matter, the northern one -- on foot. It was assumed there would be a continuous two-way flow, regulated by economic forces and the desire to unite families.
Even now, according to the Immigration and Naturalization Service's own estimates, fewer than half the illegal immigrants living in the United States crossed the Mexican border to get here. Most came by airplane on valid student or tourist visas and simply overstayed them. Yet the southern frontier is the primary theater of battle for the increasingly militarized struggle to control what has become known as the immigration "problem." It is the place Presidential candidates go to utter sound bites on the subject, the place the Government brandishes its new night-vision scopes and computers.
Thanks to Mr. Sayles and others, film has become one of the few places where one can
find reliable information about and meaningful insight into the immigrant experience. While politicians bash immigrants, film makers -- and novelists along with them -- tell us gripping immigrant stories, recording them before they disappear.
Immigration has long provided grist for movie makers, of course. During the silent era, humor was found in the antics of the awkward, newly arrived outsider. The 30's brought films like "Angels With Dirty Faces," about gangs of toughs, most of them Irish (who were themselves only emerging from pariah status). By 1961, a gang of Puerto Rican immigrants could be found duking it out with the home-grown variety in the movie "West Side Story."
Many films about Jewish families, including Barry Levinson's "Avalon" and Paul Mazursky's "Enemies: A Love Story," based on a novel by Isaac Bashevis Singer, have been grounded in immigrant memories and behavior. And Francis Ford Coppola's "Godfather" and its kin recorded the traditions of Italian family life even as they drew on the tribal rituals of the Mafia.
But in recent years the theme of immigration has been used in more explicit fashion and handled in a far more complex and subtle way. "Little Odessa," James Gray's 1995 film set in the Russian immigrant neighborhood of Brighton Beach in Brooklyn, dealt with a Russian mob hitman and his family relationships.
In Mira Nair's 1992 film "Mississippi Masala," immigrant motelkeepers from India struggled to come to terms not only with Southern white power structure but also with the local black culture. In her 1994 film, "The Perez Family," Ms. Nair took up the strains between the old-line Cuban immigrant establishment in Miami and the Marielitos, who arrived in the 1980's to disturb their peace and prosperity.
Another film that expanded the view of the American immigrant experience was Wayne Wang's "Joy Luck Club," based on Amy Tan's best seller about four Chinese immigrant women and their assimilated daughters. Even Tom Cruise was thrust into the immigrant action in Ron Howard's "Far and Away," a 1992 epic that portrayed new arrivals from Ireland joining the western land rush in the 19th century.
From abroad, evocative films have also emerged: Hanif Kureishi's "My Beautiful Laundrette," about Pakistani immigrants in London, or Mathieu Kassovitz's "La Haine," about strife and social dislocation in the housing projects of suburban Paris, or Gianni Amelio's "Lamerica," about Albanians who long to migrate to Italy. From north of the border, Canada, comes "Double Happiness," Mina Sum's 1995 film about a Chinese girl who rebels against her traditionalist immigrant parents.
The proliferation of immigration-related films may reflect the banality of much of their competition as well as the desire of immigrants and their children to tell their family stories. But it is a relief to discover heroes and villains in the barrios and the ethnic enclaves instead of just on horseback, in nuclear-powered submarines, or in the courtroom and the war room (not to mention the newsroom).
One of the best of the recent crop is last year's "Mi Familia," the tangled tale of three generations in a Mexican immigrant family in Los Angeles, directed by Gregory Nava and narrated by Edward James Olmos, who also has a starring role.
THE FILM OFFERS AN alternative, if not revisionist, view of certain aspects of American history and values in the 20th century. When young, pregnant Maria Sanchez -- a United States citizen -- is picked up on a Los Angeles street in 1933 and deported by train to central Mexico without so much as a chance to go home and tell her husband and children, it is not mere movie-making hyperbole. It is precisely what happened to thousands of people during the Depression in Southern California and some northern cities.
Two years later, Mrs. Sanchez and Chucho, the son she was carrying in her womb when she was deported, return to California on foot. It seems only fitting that Chucho should grow up to tell his parents, in a moment of crisis over his drug-dealing, that "money is all they respect in this country, and they don't care how you get it." And with children who run the gamut from radical ex-nun to petty thief to rich lawyer, the Sanchez family finally seems about as American as apple pie -- and fajitas and bagels and pizza and egg rolls.
The paradox here may be that even as the restrictionists in Congress vote to enlarge the Border Patrol and cut back the access of legal immigrants and new citizens to Federal programs, we go to the movies to observe how hard immigrants actually work. As has been the case at many previous moments of economic uncertainty in American history, there is widespread popular support today for new controls on immigration, yet immigrants are as much in demand as ever.
The diligence of the immigrant in the face of frustration is the theme of "Nueba Yol" (1996), directed by Angel Muniz, about a confused Dominican's economic hardships and absurd experiences in New York City. The film, which stars Luisita Marti, a popular Dominican comedian, has been seen primarily so far in the Dominican Republic (the source of New York's largest community of new immigrants today) but is beginning to be more broadly distributed here.
Although many of the recent immigrant movies are steeped in sentiment, they remind us of the courage and fortitude required of immigrants both on their journeys and after they arrive. The films elaborate their joys and hardships in a way the public dialogue does not.
Yet another case in point is "Someone Else's America," by the Yugoslav director Goran Paskaljevic. Any congressman or senator tempted to vote for the latest restrictive "immigration reform" bill pending on Capitol Hill should spend 96 minutes watching Mr. Paskaljevic's film, which swept through European film festivals last year but got little attention in this country.
The director tells the story of Alonso, a legal immigrant from Spain, and his trusty sidekick Bayo, an illegal immigrant from Montenegro -- an odd couple if ever there was one.
Alonso (played by Tom Conti, who happens to be the son of Italian immigrants to Scotland) owns a bar in Brooklyn, where Bayo is allowed to sleep in return for cleaning up. When Bayo's elderly mother arrives in the United States after much stress and duress, she finds that America is not the promised land she expected. "I don't know how to live here," she complains. "It's someone else's country."
But true to form and tradition, it is one of Bayo's sons, a churlish but ambitious fellow, who makes the country his own. He masters English, turns Alonso's fading bar into a booming ethnic restaurant and marries a young Chinese-American from the neighborhood who was born in the United States. Thus he gets his green card.
Not everyone lives happily ever after in this film, but these immigrants work hard and take care of one another. The distinctions between legal and illegal, so critical in the political debate over immigration, become almost laughable.
"Someone Else's America" also helps us understand that the frenzy over multiculturalism and the effort to enshrine English as an "official language" are mere distractions from the long-term project of making this country work as what it has always been -- an ever-changing mix of people from everywhere else.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: $72 Million Renovation of Former Bloomingdale's;
For UConn in Stamford, a New Home

 BODY:
In the fall of 1997 the Stamford branch of the University of Connecticut will move from smaller quarters in the north end of the city to a prime downtown location in a former Bloomingdale's department store.
"It's going to be a tremendous improvement in our ability to serve the area," said Mark Swanson, director of UConn-Stamford. "It has been made clear to us that Fairfield County wants UConn to have an increased presence here." 
 A $72 million transformation of Bloomingdale's is under way, almost tripling UConn's size, from the current 55,000 square feet to 155,000 square feet.
The growth will permit a doubling of the present student body of 900 undergraduate and 480 graduate students.
The renovation will provide new amenities such as a conference center, fitness center, student lounges, food court and extensive computer networking.
Perkins Eastman Architects of Manhattan has designed a building with expanses of glass that Aaron B. Schwarz, a principal with the firm, described as "focused on linking a state-of-the-art university with the city."
"The three-story, glass-walled concourse along Broad Street will be open to the public," Mr. Schwarz said. "Videos will occasionally be beamed out to the street, and glass spines that cut diagonally through the building from roof to ground will admit light to all of the areas that it passes through."
Anticipation of the purchasing power of more than 2,500 students has awakened interest in a 106,000-square-foot parcel of vacant land opposite the former Bloomingdale's site on Broad Street.
"We could build up to 250,000 square feet of retail and commercial space there," said Tom Rich, a second-generation member of the Rich family, which redeveloped downtown Stamford 20 years ago.

HEADLINE: Bread Lines

BYLINE: By Katrina vanden Heuvel; Katrina vanden Heuvel, the editor of The Nation, writes frequently on Russian affairs.

 BODY:

WAKING THE TEMPESTS
Ordinary Life in the New Russia.
By Eleanor Randolph.
431 pp. New York:
Simon & Schuster. $26.
WHAT Americans already think about Russia usually determines what they see there. Certainly this has been true of many American correspondents who have returned from their stays in Moscow to write books. 
 Eleanor Randolph is different. A former Moscow correspondent for The Washington Post and now a reporter for The Los Angeles Times, she has been careful not to judge the extraordinary changes she witnessed from 1991 to 1993 -- the dissolution of the Soviet Union, the introduction of economic shock therapy by President Boris Yeltsin -- through Western biases or cliches.
"Waking the Tempests" is a portrait of the ways in which ordinary Russians survived "as their government, economy and society changed virtually overnight." For two years Ms. Randolph traveled across Russia, from Moscow to the Arctic Circle, from the Far East to the southern farmlands, talking to people we don't usually hear from -- psychics and priests, ecologists and sexologists, mail-order brides, gay activists, pensioners, prosecutors, women entrepreneurs and preschool teachers. Through firsthand experiences, conversations and friendships, she captures the hopes, fears and general confusion of people who are being asked or compelled to enter a world of profound uncertainty. "Looking at the life rather than analyzing the system," Ms. Randolph believes, is "one of the few ways to gauge the enormity of what happened in Russia in the last few years."
She visits decaying hospitals and new sex clinics, old communal apartments and luxurious suburban developments, deteriorating public schools and plush private academies. She explains the workings of the mail-order bride business and the juvenile justice system. She examines who is giving business to faith healers, Mafia thugs and environmental activists. If there is a central theme running through this largely bleak picture of life in the new Russia, it is that of the age-old Russian conflict between order and freedom being waged at almost every level of life.
The most striking aspect of "Waking the Tempests" is Ms. Randolph's compassion for the losers in post-Soviet Russia's increasingly polarized society. Her book is free of the triumphalism and the ideological assumptions so often found in American accounts of Russia's so-called transition period. It is therefore a useful antidote to the many books and articles that depict Russia's development as a general, if erratic, success story. If the human costs of economic shock therapy were as fully and thoughtfully recounted in news reports as they are in Ms. Randolph's book, readers would have a better understanding of Russia's current political landscape. Only rarely do newspaper or television reports explain how Russia's fragile middle class, once the main constituency for political reform, has been ravaged by Mr. Yeltsin's program. Nearly a third of the country now lives below the poverty line, according to Government statistics. "Freedom is wonderful," an elderly and impoverished couple explain to Ms. Randolph, "but you can't eat words."
One of Ms. Randolph's most memorable encounters is with three formidable babushkas, or elderly women, in a bakery. Survivors of World War II, the women were confident that they would withstand the trauma of newfangled shock-therapy economics. Several months later, Ms. Randolph learned, "reform" had wiped out their life savings and turned them into despondent street peddlers.
Ms. Randolph's visits to disintegrating public hospitals expose other human costs of what the Yeltsin Government and its Western supporters call reform. Forty-two percent of the country's hospitals in 1993 had no hot water, 12 percent had no running water, and all suffer severe shortages of disposable syringes, vaccines and modern equipment. (In contrast, Ms. Randolph tours a well-equipped private hospital that is doing a brisk business catering to the new rich.) The long-term consequences of deteriorating health care are clear: an unparalleled and precipitous drop in life expectancy, especially for Russian men, who in 1991 lived, on average, to 65.5 years, but by 1994 lived only to 57.3. At the other end of life, infant mortality figures are up, and the birthrate is down. Just last month, a leading Russian newspaper ran the headline "Is Russia Dying?" over a roundup of the country's latest health statistics.
Although the elderly have borne the brunt of the economic turmoil, political and psychological changes have led Russians of all ages to new religions and faith healers. In sometimes darkly funny prose, Ms. Randolph describes the arrival of the Hare Krishnas on Moscow's streets. The Mormons, the evangelicals and the Bahais soon followed. Psychics fill stadiums with followers and broadcast weekly programs to millions of believers. When Ms. Randolph left Moscow in 1993, America's Christian right groups were beginning to find Russian converts.
Ms. Randolph also has some sobering things to say about the sexual revolution in Russia today, which is, as she rightly reports, less a liberating experience than a mixture of exploitative commercialism and degradation. Incidents of sexual violence and discrimination against women have soared, according to the Government's own inadequate statistics. And although sex education is practically nonexistent, just the proposal to introduce it into Russian schools has created a hotly contested political and moral battleground, one that would be familiar to Americans. Indeed, many of the social problems afflicting Russia -- juvenile delinquency, inadequate educational and health systems, alcohol abuse, growing inequality and poverty -- would be familiar to us.
Ms. Randolph has a keen eye for the details of Russian life, but she is an observer, not an interpreter. I finished this book having been moved, but wanting to know what went wrong in Russia after 1991 in the name of markets and democracy, and why. Two conflicting answers have emerged in Russia and in the West. One blames mainly the legacy of seven decades of Communist rule for the country's current woes. The other finds the fault primarily in unwise and rapacious policies pursued by Mr. Yeltsin's post-Communist Government. Ms. Randolph barely raises this crucial question. For answers to it, readers will have to look elsewhere.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Review

HEADLINE: Planting by Numbers

BYLINE: By John Lloyd; John Lloyd was the Moscow bureau chief of The Financial Times of London from 1991 to 1995. He is writing a book on the first five years of the new Russia.

 BODY:

Travels with a Hungry Bear
A Journey to the Russian Heartland.
By Mark Kramer.
320 pp. Boston:
A Richard Todd Book/
Houghton Mifflin Company. $24.95.
The manner in which Russians wrest food from their soil has been the despair of visiting and knowledgeable foreigners for centuries. Carl Augustus Koefoed, the Danish agriculturist who helped Prime Minister P. A. Stolypin make his agricultural reforms from 1907 onward, wrote of the practice of Russian farmers that "for them, it was enough that it was Russian, and therefore indisputable -- something holy." 
 In much the same spirit, Mark Kramer, touring collective farms almost a century later, hears the dean of a Soviet agriculture college lay down the orthodoxy to an aspiring private farmer who complains that he cannot cover his costs while he receives fixed low prices for his produce. The dean "was shouting, enunciating his words one by one: 'Listen to me, sir: the low price represents the voice of the people!' "
The dean was right: the people did like low prices (which people does not?). Successive general secretaries kept prices low for fear of popular rage -- and when they were allowed to go up at the beginning of 1992, the reaction swept away the Government that had raised them and helped revive a discredited Communist Party.
Mr. Kramer's is thus a very large subject, but "Travels With a Hungry Bear: A Journey to the Russian Heartland" is an often irritating book. The author, a professor in Boston University's journalism and American studies departments, philosophizes, strikes attitudes and gee-whizzes with amiable exasperation about the people he meets. He is not a man to miss a chance to push a reminiscence on you -- his eyes mist over with sentiment at times -- yet when he isn't being emotively correct, he is worth reading. He has worked on farms and written about farming for much of his life, and he knows that he cannot get his point across by writing a treatise. So he can be very interesting about, say, comparative milking methods.
In a series of travels during the late 1980's and early 1990's, he saw what ailed the self-enclosed continent that was Soviet agriculture. In large part, it was the infrastructure -- the fact that the state and the collective farms, no matter how much new (often foreign) equipment they managed to acquire, and no matter how efficient they became in this or that process, were caught in a system with slovenly work, terrible transportation, vastly wasteful storage, no signals of demand and a huge and overlapping bureaucracy that poked into everything and had to be placated and bribed at every level.
One of Lenin's most malign bequests to the Soviet economy in general and Soviet agriculture in particular was the utopian mind-set. Lenin believed -- at least until it was too late -- that the operation of an economy was merely a matter of adopting modern technology and setting it to work under party control in order to turn out socialism at the end of the production line. The successor versions of this mind-set saw Soviet officials grasp for a new technique -- and then introduce it everywhere, in the belief that it, and it alone, could change everything.
For example, Mr. Kramer talks to Fyodor Trofimovich Morgun, who introduced the "minimum tillage" system (which he had seen in Canada in the early 1970's). It is a way of plowing the earth that stirs the ground rather than flip it over and that can, under some conditions, be more efficient than other methods. As he tells it, Mr. Morgun fought for this system through layers of prejudice and conservatism, and finally had it adopted in the late 1970's. He saw it as a revolution. Mr. Kramer sees it for what it was. "It suggested something that party authorities . . . actually came to like: a mere technical fix could make the food problem go away." Such technical fixes were also the stuff of Mikhail Gorbachev's economic reforms -- though they did, accidentally, help Communism go away.
Soviet farming survives into the post-Soviet era substantially unreconstructed, with the private farmers still held at bay by people like the dean -- no longer for the sake of low prices, but for the preservation of bureaucrats' jobs. In addition, a peasantry that could rise to the challenge of private farming seems to have been effectively wiped out. Collective farming remains a "holy" matter: the walls of that temple will only slowly be breached.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Review

TITLE: TRAVELS WITH A HUNGRY BEAR (BOOK)
