HEADLINE: Across the Great Divide

BYLINE: By Glenn C. Loury 

 BODY:
Glenn C. Loury is a professor of economics at Boston University. His most recent book is "One by One From the Inside Out: Essays and Reviews on Race and Responsibility in America."

TRAGIC FAILURE
Racial Integration in America.
By Tom Wicker.
205 pp. New York:
William Morrow & Company. $25.
 
COMING THROUGH THE FIRE
Surviving Race and Place in America.
By C. Eric Lincoln.
157 pp. Durham, N.C.:
Duke University Press. $17.95.
The year was 1968. Reporting on the causes of the recent urban riots, the National Commission on Civil Disorders, popularly known as the Kerner Commission, concluded: "What white Americans have never fully understood -- but what the Negro can never forget -- is that white society is deeply implicated in the ghetto. White institutions created it, white institutions maintain it, and white society condones it." In his introduction to the widely read paperback edition of the report at the time, Tom Wicker praised it for making plain "that white, moderate, responsible America is where the trouble lies." So he believed then and so, as he makes clear in "Tragic Failure," he still believes today. And more: he still believes that it is white America where the solution lies. 
 In that same fateful year, Christopher Jencks and David Riesman published "The Academic Revolution," a survey of American higher education that included a chapter entitled "Negroes and Their Colleges." Liberals, yes, but as skilled sociologists, they had set themselves a task of description. Their candid conclusion, sympathetically stated, was that "Southern Negro colleges are, with a handful of hopeful exceptions . . . near the end of the academic procession in terms of student aptitudes, faculty competence and intellectual ferment." Furious black educators immediately cried racism; this being 1968, open discussion was at an end.
C. Eric Lincoln's memory burns hot even to this day. In "Coming Through the Fire" he declares: "Each generation produces a new spate of Jencks-and-Riesman scholars" who "climb out of the ivy to reassure us that . . . the gap between black performance and white achievement is still an ordinance of nature." This is an unfortunate slander, done all too casually, of good and decent men. But so steeped is Mr. Lincoln in the memory of racial affliction that he loses sight of certain useful distinctions -- for example, the one between a candid friend and an implacable foe.
In 1996, this is a distinction that is vitally important to maintain. The moral authority of the aggrieved black just ain't what it used to be. Collective memory of the brutality and inhumanity of racial caste in American history is fading. Passionate evocation of that "strange fruit" that used to swing from Southern trees leaves today's undergraduates as cold as the new American political majority is left by Mr. Wicker's calls for massive programs of social intervention to bring the inner-city poor into meaningful participation in the commonwealth.
These are two Southerners, both venerable warriors on behalf of racial justice, both now in their eighth decade. But this is not their time. As many decades separate us from the 1950's and the onset of the civil rights era as separated Thurgood Marshall's oral argument in Brown v. Board of Education and the founding of the N.A.A.C.P. If de jure segregation is dead, de facto segregation, by class as well as color, lives on, and we are at a loss about how to go forward.
C. Eric Lincoln, a distinguished African-American scholar of religion and culture at Duke University, has literally "come through the fire." The notebooks into which he had been pouring his observations and reflections on racial matters for some 50 years were destroyed, along with nearly all of his personal possessions, in a tragic blaze. So this slender volume -- often eloquent, sometimes moving and only occasionally sanctimonious -- is an effort to salvage for public consumption something from a lifetime of remembering.
At its best, "Coming Through the Fire" is a plaintive, elegantly rendered cry for transcending the irrational racial essentialism that has marred this republic for centuries. "The notion of race," Mr. Lincoln writes, "is the hydra-headed monster which stifles our most beautiful dreams before they are fairly dreamt, calling us away from the challenges of normative human interaction to a dissonance of suspicion and hatred in pursuit of a fantasy that never was."
Mr. Lincoln ends his book with a call for "no-fault reconciliation -- the recognition that we are all of a kind, with the same vulnerabilities, the same possibilities and the same needs for God and each other." This is precisely right. Sadly, this is not all he has to say. Fixation on racial injury leads him into a dangerous and unproductive sentimentality. When discussing inner-city violence, for example, he issues an all-too-familiar, and deeply problematic, refrain: "The high incidence of destruction of Blacks by Blacks reflects the low esteem in which black youth (taking their cues from society) hold themselves and each other. . . . Bang! Bang! You're dead. But you were born dead! And so was I." Writing of allegations that surfaced during the O. J. Simpson trial about the Los Angeles police detective Mark Fuhrman's "routine falsification of evidence," he says that "skewed statistics on black criminalization. . . originate at the point where the Fuhrmanization of law enforcement and the Fuhrmanization of justice come together in a synthesis of doom. Black doom. This is true victimization."
No, this is true nonsense, made no more palatable for having been stated by a gentleman of consummate civility. If indeed we are all created in the common image of God, then the problem of social pathology is at bottom a problem of sin, not of skin. These urban predators, like the violent racists who terrorized rural Alabama blacks in C. Eric Lincoln's childhood, have no excuse.
Still, it is a fair surmise that there might be fewer predators if there were more opportunity in the urban ghetto. Our inability to create this opportunity is the "tragic failure" that concerns Tom Wicker, a former political columnist for The New York Times and the author of nine novels and five books of nonfiction. He sees the failure as purely a political failure, and the key to success as obvious. It is jobs, and in his view only a newly invigorated left-wing politics can deliver the kind of job programs likely to make a difference to the most disadvantaged youths.
His radical proposal for how to engender such a movement is for blacks to abandon the Democrats en masse. This would destabilize the two-party system, and out of its ashes might then arise a new, ideologically liberal political party, "one truly committed, not just paying lip service, to economic opportunity and social justice for all." He elaborates: "The program of such a party . . . would promise opportunity to the poor, even to those presently lost souls in the inner city . . . to become useful, self-supporting and respected citizens with a stake in community and country."
Mr. Wicker writes with a reporter's eye for detail, using the words of his many interview subjects to tell much of his story. His dedication, "To my grandchildren -- may they live in a better world," reflects the dispirited tone of his essay; one finishes it seriously doubting that he believes a "better world" is likely to arrive any time soon. He never reveals why he thinks the new-party strategy could work, given the modest results of the Rev. Jesse Jackson's two recent Presidential candidacies. But it is a reflection of Mr. Wicker's frustration in the face of Republican electoral successes over the last two decades that he is driven to such a farfetched prescription.
Frustration and righteous anger do not a politics make. Mr. Wicker and Mr. Lincoln's central premise is flawed: the race problem in America today is no mere continuation of age-old sins. Rather, it is deeply connected to the problems of the underclass, and to the absence of a sense of shared purpose transcending racial and ethnic boundaries -- what Arthur Schlesinger Jr. called "the disuniting of America." There is a disturbing lack of black agency, outside of the political arena, in the visions of both men. That was an error in 1968, and it is an even greater error today. Americans should not forget the crimes of the past. But the act of remembering, and being outraged by memory, is no substitute for formulating an effective political and communal program.

HEADLINE: More Than Meets the Eye

BYLINE: By Larissa MacFarquhar; Larissa MacFarquhar is a contributing editor at New York magazine and Lingua Franca and an advisory editor at The Paris Review.

 BODY:

THE POWER OF BEAUTY
By Nancy Friday.
589 pp. New York:
HarperCollins Publishers. $27.50.
Was sex better in the 60's? There seems no other explanation for the charming and extraordinary Nancy Friday. Ms. Friday is a product of that peculiar decade of -- as she sees it, the wonderful, brief period after the pill was first marketed and before "matriarchal feminism" cast a pall on the sexual revolution. And for the past 20 years she has been promoting sex with a road-to-Damascus fervor that is often startling, but is enormously fun to read. 
 Ms. Friday is extremely successful as sex gurus go, probably because she combines salacious anecdotes with an innocent, therapeutic earnestness. Sexuality in a Nancy Friday book is something to be worked on, like self-esteem or a positive attitude in the office. She writes about the subject in a way that is both hopelessly 60's and quintessentially American: sex can make us happy, and because it makes us happy as individuals it can change society as a whole. She is a one-woman love cult who sincerely believes that if we could only learn to love our genitals, most of the world's problems would be solved. "It is a terrible waste of natural resources that we don't go out of our way, especially in these strained, difficult times, to educate more women to beam postorgasmically upon the world," she writes in her new book, "The Power of Beauty."
"The Power of Beauty," Ms. Friday's seventh book, is nominally about the effect that looks have on our lives, but that's not the half of it. It is also a hymn to genitalia, a j'accuse aimed at prissy mothers, a paean to the adorableness of men and a plea for the return of the codpiece. In addition, it's a catalogue of everything Ms. Friday believes has gone wrong with America because of feminism: Sperm banks. Breast envy. Strippers don't enjoy their work like they used to. And nobody is masturbating enough.
Ms. Friday's central point is that beauty matters. Face and body beauty, that is -- no "inner beauty" nonsense. "Beauty is a player," Ms. Friday cries in her inimitable fashion, "stalking the streets bare-breasted, stiletto heeled, fly unzipped." Ms. Friday likes the idea that beauty matters -- she can't stand feminists like Naomi Wolf who find beauty's power politically suspect -- but she wishes women would stop pretending that looks aren't important, and start competing openly. Ms. Friday is an emotional capitalist, and what she objects to about the way women deal with beauty and sex is, in effect, unfair trading practices: banding together in groups within which it is understood that no one woman shall have too much sex or be too beautiful. "The Power of Beauty" is her manifesto for a sexual antitrust movement.
Of course, the fact that beauty matters gives rise to various problems, Ms. Friday acknowledges, ranging from mundane adult envy all the way down to the roots of self-esteem. But, according to Ms. Friday, all of beauty's problems are traceable to mothers. Extrapolating from her own experience (as a daughter), she maintains that mothers think genitals are repulsive and dirty, and ingrain in all of us the feeling that we're ugly and sex is bad. The solution, therefore, is for fathers to participate equally in child-rearing. (Ms. Friday's father left her mother before she was born, and Ms. Friday ascribes most of her own life's problems, and thus life's problems in general, to this fact.)
It makes sense, of course, that such a change in parenting arrangements would have a profound effect of some sort. The same idea has been suggested by, among others, Dorothy Dinnerstein in her excellent 1976 book, "The Mermaid and the Minotaur." But Ms. Friday's reasoning depends on an idealization of men so extreme and so specific that it's not so much wrong as simply odd. For instance, she imagines that men's relationship to the important pre-Oedipal stuff like feces and genitals is vastly different from women's -- that while all women are revolted by these things, men unequivocally embrace them.
This bizarre idealism crops up throughout the book. Ms. Friday considers male rivalry, for instance, to be some kind of perpetual cricket game -- invariably concluded with handshakes all around. "Men's lips don't get mean and narrow, as ours do, from sucking in all the swallowed venom," she writes. And for rapists, Ms. Friday has sympathy. "When men . . . force us into sex, they are carrying out women's opinion of them," she declares. Women say no when they mean yes, men get confused -- and "meanwhile, the ugly penis, which is bigger than both of them, demands its reward, not unlike the troll that lived under the bridge."
"The Power of Beauty" is part cultural critique and part memoir, and the two are intertwined, to say the least. It's one of those "we" books, written in the first person plural -- a rhetorical device that neatly appropriates both the irrefutability of an eyewitness and the scope of a historian. Ms. Friday's mind works in a way that might be described as synecdochic-paranoid: everything is connected by a chain of associations and everything leads back to Nancy Friday herself. Beauty, sex, penises, clothes that Ms. Friday has worn, world history, more penises, all blur together. Fortunately, Ms. Friday is at her ebullient best when recounting the story of her life.
After growing up homely in South Carolina, she tells us, she moved to New York in the early 60's to find that she had suddenly become dazzlingly attractive. But her triumph came too late: inside she was still the plain girl from Charleston who didn't trust male attention. "When too many eyes focused on me in my sea-green Pucci dress, and offers of love reversed the rejections of adolescence, up from the unconscious swam infantile grandiosity," she confesses. "I was terrified that the telephone in my apartment would never stop ringing, would bring me so many suitors that I would soar too high. . . . Then, when all eyes were on me, I would be unable to handle the adoration and would spot my dress, humiliating myself."
Sex also was terrifying for Ms. Friday back then, since she suffered terrible cases of "post-sex enslavement" and lived in constant fear of getting pregnant -- imagining, as she memorably puts it, her "ravenous cervix, always hungry for the intrepid do-or-die sperm fighting their way upstream like crazed salmon." Since her marriage to Norman Pearlstine, now the editor in chief of Time Inc., her life seems to have calmed down somewhat, but she hasn't lost her signature sparkle. Anyone who deals with Mr. Pearlstine professionally will be delighted to discover that he and his wife have bought a pair of men's shoes with a large pink penis painted on each foot, to each of which is attached two large pompoms.
MS. Friday writes in a kind of what-fresh-hell-is-this stream of consciousness, as though she keeps her computer running all the time and types paragraphs into it whenever she thinks of something new and outrageous. She seems always to be writing about something she saw just the previous night or the week before. For the most part this style comes off as breezy and spontaneous, but every now and then it begins to border on lunacy. Take this passage, for instance, from a section on foot fetishism: "Just thinking about Bettelheim's image of Cinderella's tiny slipper as a virginal vagina . . . I am reminded that women today don't look or act like Cinderella, being neither in economic need of a prince, nor virginal, nor do women even require a prince's penis, given the local sperm bank. When you also factor in the ever-earlier onset of menstruation, meaning that adolescent girls are larger of body, it should be noted that they also walk on larger feet." There follow a number of other thoughts on the subject, and then, at the bottom of the page, we arrive at the denouement. "Sooner or later," Ms. Friday concludes darkly, "the shoe, the vagina and the penis are going to have to sit down together and have it out: What does it all mean?"
What does it all mean -- the nearly 600 pages of "The Power of Beauty," filled with recollections, speculations and eccentric apercus? Nothing so coherent as a theory of beauty, perhaps, but instead a kind of Dadaesque verbal collage, in which are visible the contours of the curious, exuberant and fascinating Nancy Friday herself.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Municipal Art Society Awards;
Honoring Those Who 'Inspire Others'

 BODY:
In a ceremony held in the Governors Island movie theater -- part of New York City's newest historic district -- the Municipal Art Society handed out its annual series of awards last Tuesday to New Yorkers and New York organizations that, according to its president, Brendan Sexton, "light creative sparks" and "inspire others."
Mr. Sexton presided over the group's annual meeting, at which the award recipients included former Mayor John V. Lindsay, honored for his lifetime support of cultural and environmental causes; William Aguado, head of the the Bronx Council of the Arts, and Robert Blackburn, who founded the Printmaking Workshop in 1948. 
 The Queens Borough Public Library, which for the last 10 years has had the highest circulation of any library system in the country, was also honored, for its outreach and its special collections in Spanish, Chinese, Korean, Arabic and the South Asian languages.
New York State's Chief Judge, Judith S. Kaye, accepted an award for the Midtown Community Court, a system of community service sentencing, counseling and job training handled in a renovated court building at 54th Street and Eighth Avenue.
The Women's Housing and Economic Development Corporation, which sponsored the "recapture" of the abandoned Morrisania Hospital in the Bronx, turning the 1920's hulk into 132 subsidized apartments, was honored, as was Brooklyn's West Indian American Day Carnival Parade on Eastern Parkway. The architect Hugh Hardy presented an award to the city's School Construction Authority for "consistently hiring quality architects and designers."
The Municipal Art Society held the meeting on Governors Island because the group is concerned about the island's future when the Coast Guard leaves. Whatever use the island is ultimately put to -- Mr. Sexton suggested veterans' housing, a marina, a military museum and a conference center as possibilities -- the society would like to see significant public access.

HEADLINE: A Massachusetts Farmer-Developer Sows Housing

BYLINE: By MICKY BACA 

DATELINE: GRAFTON, Mass.

 BODY:
FORTY years ago, says John Magill, he "fell into" the housing development business in this historic New England town 40 miles southwest of Boston after rebuilding the barns destroyed by fire on his family's dairy farm.
Hundreds of homes later, the farmer-turned-developer has set Grafton's close-knit neighborhoods of colonial homes abuzz with a plan to turn 350 acres of his family's 500-acre farm into a $20 million golf course and housing development. Despite some controversy over its traffic and environmental impact, his plan is expected to go forward. 
 Most residents here know Mr. Magill as a local boy who made good. Some even recall his plowing snow on early winter mornings when he could barely reach the pedals of his father's tractor. The 62-year-old Mr. Magill, who now lives in a sizable home on one of the town's more scenic hills, has done 99 percent of his housing construction in his hometown where, he says, "people got to know me and know I'll give them a fair price for their land."
Mr. Magill is proposing to build the 18-hole golf course surrounded by 160 single-family homes just minutes from the early 19th-century buildings and pristine white churches nestled around the community's shady village green. With no other such development in the area, Mr. Magill says he expects an eager market for the $250,000 to $400,000 colonial homes he plans to build.
Called High Fields of Grafton, the project is getting mixed reviews from residents, some of whom worry about the traffic it will bring to the winding roads that surround it. Others in the neighborhood have raised concerns about the cost of running town sewer lines out to the area to accommodate the Magill project and what impact the golf course will have on water quality and supply, according to Town Planner Megan DiPrete.
On the other hand, Ms. DiPrete said, there is a "sense of excitement" about the idea of a golf course coming to town and the hope that it will enhance this "steady, well-run and desirable" town of 13,000 10 miles southeast of Worcester.
"If something has to go in, at least a golf course will have open space," says Mildred Bean, chairman of the local Historical Commission and a neighbor to the proposed golf course. "As far as John is concerned, I'm glad it's a small-town boy making good. It could have been a developer from Boston."
But Mrs. Bean said that residents of her native town -- a quintessential New England community that served as the location for the filming of Eugene O'Neill's "Ah, Wilderness!" in 1935 -- would have ample opportunity to air their views on the project in perhaps a year and a half of public hearings and scrutiny by town and state officials.
The town's Planning Board is now conducting public hearings on whether to grant a special permit for the overall project and then consider the subdivision proposal. The local Conservation Commission will have its say on Mr. Magill's plan to disturb about one acre of wetlands and various state agencies will look at its environmental impact, said Ms.DiPrete.
Five other developments with a total of 184 houses are currently under construction in Grafton, Ms. DiPrete said, some that will take several years to complete. In fact, said Sean Padgett, the planning board's chairman, there is more development here than ever before, even during the boom years of the mid-80's.
"People were just discovering Grafton when the bottom fell out," he said, referring to the recession of the early 90's.
Now, Mr. Padgett says his town is on the edge of a development front moving out from the Worcester area as well as from the high technology complexes along Route 495 to the east.
WHAT'S more, the state's Department of Transportation is scheduled to build a commuter train station linking Grafton to Boston in the next few years. And, said Ms. DiPrete, the private, nonprofit Worcester Business Development Corporation, in conjunction with the town, will begin construction soon of a biotechnology park on 120 acres near the station site.
"Frankly, I'm a little nervous that it might bring too much development," Mr. Padgett says.
Mr. Magill, who owns and operates the Grafton Inn, which has been welcoming guests to a restaurant and rooms overlooking the Grafton Common since 1805, said the town could not stop the growth. "I'm for everything really, I like things to grow," said the former farmer.
Mr. Magill conceded that it would be a "sad day" to see the cows leave his family's Silver Spruce Acres farm. He said he hadn't decided whether to retain the remaining 150 acres not used for the golf course development as a dairy farm. If he does, he said, he would likely reduce the herd of 300 that he now maintains, he said.
Mr. Magill's father, Henry, who was a herdsman for a state hospital in Rutland, Mass., bought the farm and moved his family to Grafton in 1942 when John was 9. Back then, Mr. Magill said, there were some 30 farms in the town.
Founded in 1735, Grafton was a self-sufficient farming community for more than a century before it became known for its local industries of leather, bootmaking, textiles and clockmaking. These days the community, which was once a summer place for wealthly city dwellers, is more of a bedroom town for Worcester and Boston, though some industry thrives in its northern section, Ms. DiPrete said.
Currently there are only three remaining farms, Mr. Magill said. He has not lived on his farm in years, but his three employees live there and operate it, he said.
Mr. Magill said he discovered his building talents while restoring his father's fire-ravaged barns in 1955. Before long, the 22-year-old made the jump from building barns to putting up a single-family home here and there to building his first major project, a 25-lot subdivision on the town's Pigeon Hill.
From single-family homes, Mr. Magill branched into building condominium developments at the height of the market in the mid-80's. He built some 300 units, selling as many as 10 a month during the housing boom.
Mr. Magill said he had borrowed money to finance his first phase of condominiums, but had financed all subsequent developments on his own. He hopes to finance High Fields himself as well, he said.
Mr. Magill will not say how much money his company, Magill Associates, earns or how much he is worth personally.
While he owns two of the most historically significant buildings in town, the Inn and a bank building dating to 1840 that houses his offices, Mr. Magill said he was not a "historian." He bought the Inn in 1983, renovated it under the guidance of local historians and has his daughters run it, he said, because "I'm interested in making money."
Despite his millions, Mr. Magill still projects the image of a dairy farmer. Residents say he often does business with a simple handshake, finds the bureaucratic red tape of today's development world frustrating and has a formidable temper. He is more likely to be seen driving the company dump truck or backhoe than the family Mercedes.
"My family were working people;" Mr. Magill says, "we're still working people."

SECTION: Section 7; Page 32; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 865 words

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

BYLINE: By LAUREL GRAEBER 

 BODY:

JOE PAPP: An American Life
By Helen Epstein. Da Capo, $18.95.
Born Joseph Papirofsky, one of the great innovators of American theater emerges in this biography as scrappy and uncompromising, a loyal champion of causes who attracted enemies as well as friends. His "final portrait . . . might have been jointly painted by Goya, Whistler and Francis Bacon, so hard is it to categorize," Benedict Nightingale said here in 1994.
 
INDEPENDENCE DAY
By Richard Ford. Vintage Contemporaries, $13.
The recent winner of the Pulitzer Prize for fiction and selected as one of the best books of 1995 by the editors of the Book Review, this novel continues the story of Frank Bascombe, the hero of the author's 1986 novel, "The Sportswriter." Having abandoned journalism for the real estate business, Frank is beset with vague longings for his ex-wife and for a better life, though he often feels that his emotional detachment makes such quests impossible. "Frank Bascombe has earned himself a place beside Willy Loman and Harry Angstrom in our literary landscape, but he has done so with a wry wit and a fin de siecle wisdom that is very much his own," wrote our reviewer, Charles Johnson. Vintage Contemporaries has also restored to print two of Mr. Ford's earlier works. WILDLIFE ($11) is the story of a teen-age boy in Great Falls, Mont., witnessing the unraveling of his parents' marriage, as his father loses his job and his mother lapses into an affair. The novel "is shot through with nuance and minute observation," Sheila Ballantyne said in these pages in 1990. ROCK SPRINGS ($12), a collection of stories, also explores the themes of love and betrayal among a variety of men and their families. The finest of the tales "achieve luminous moments, moments with potential to change how the reader sees," John Edgar Wideman said in the Book Review in 1987.
 
RIVER OF TRAPS: A Village Life
By William deBuys and Alex Harris.
University of New Mexico, $24.95.
The village is El Valle in northern New Mexico, where Mr. deBuys, his wife, Anne, and Mr. Harris moved in the 1970's. But the book is less a portrait of a place than of a person, Jacobo Romero, an elderly Spanish sheepherder and erstwhile bootlegger who became his young neighbors' friend. "The poetry of the text is matched by Mr. Harris's photographs," Barbara Kingsolver said here in 1990.
 
THE SUMMER BEFORE THE SUMMER OF LOVE
By Marly Swick. Harper Perennial, $12.
Loss is the theme of many of these stories, whether it is the death of a child or a lover or the departure of a parent or a spouse. Portraying confused feelings rather than clear epiphanies, "Ms. Swick's clear and unobtrusive prose defines an intricate emotional landscape," our reviewer, Michael Gorra, wrote last year.
 
KIDDING OURSELVES: Breadwinning, Babies, and Bargaining Power
By Rhona Mahony. Basic Books, $15.
The author argues that women will never achieve economic equality with men as long as mothers continue to bear more responsibility for child rearing than their partners do. Offering suggestions for changing marital dynamics as well as the workplace, the author has written "a groundbreaking book," Susan Chira said in these pages in 1995. THE HITE REPORT ON THE FAMILY: Growing Up Under Patriarchy, by Shere Hite (Grove, $14), is based on a survey of more than 3,000 men, women and children. Like Ms. Hite's earlier works, the book draws conclusions -- in this case, surprisingly optimistic ones -- from personal testimonies. Many of her subjects "provide revealing and moving reflections," Susan Jacoby wrote in the Book Review last year. Patriarchy is not so much lamented as longed for in FATHERLESS AMERICA: Confronting Our Most Urgent Social Problem, by David Blankenhorn (Harper Perennial, $14). Maintaining that fathers are necessary, not optional, the author "makes a persuasive case," Ellis Cose said here in 1995.
 
THE BLACK BOOK
By Orhan Pamuk. Translated by Guneli Gun.
Harvest/Harcourt Brace, $15.
An Istanbul lawyer searches for his wife, who has suddenly disappeared. As he seeks her, he becomes enmeshed in the life of her half brother, a newspaper columnist who is also his cousin. The result is "something much beyond a mere mystery novel," Robert Houston wrote in these pages last year.
 
A GOOD WALK SPOILED: Days and Nights on the PGA Tour
By John Feinstein. Little, Brown, $13.95.
If a good walk is spoiled by golf, not much else is, the author concludes. Chronicling 15 months in 1993-94, he finds professional golfers remarkably drug- and ego-free. Last year our reviewer, Michael Bamberger, praised Mr. Feinstein as "a dependable, thorough and honest reporter." Some of the same terrain is explored fictionally in THE LEGEND OF BAGGER VANCE: A Novel of Golf and the Game of Life, by Steven Pressfield (Avon, $12). Bagger Vance, a caddy with a taste for the mystical, reveals the secret of the Authentic Swing to his disciple, a glum war hero playing in a tournament with Bobby Jones and Walter Hagen. "Mr. Pressfield's portrait of a Savannah seaside resort in 1931 is as bright as the life he brings" to certain characters, Dave Kindred said here last year. Laurel Graeber

HEADLINE: NEW URBANISM;
Helping to Shape The Inner City

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Herbert Muschamp's account of the recent Congress for the New Urbanism (C.N.U.) Conference in Charleston, S.C. ["Can New Urbanism Find Room for the Old?," June 2] begins with a powerful endorsement of our organization's mission and accomplishments to date, designating it "the most important phenomenon to emerge in American architecture in the post-cold-war era" and "the only nationwide movement of consequence initiated by baby-boom architects." 
 Although Mr. Muschamp mentions a recent "important enlargement of scope" in C.N.U.'s commitment to "saving America's aging inner cities," he devotes most of the article to rectifying a perceived slight by C.N.U.'s founders toward their modernist predecessors and to a "skirmish" over "esthetic" issues that punctuated the congress's closing session. In making his case, Mr. Muschamp cited the group's "limited grasp of the history of suburban culture."
Had Mr. Muschamp attended the organization's prior three congresses, he would have seen that those pastures have been well tilled both in theoretical and pragmatic terms (the New Urbanists have been ardent students of the suburbs, learning from both their failures and successes).
Unfortunately, Mr. Muschamp's reporting of the most recent congress failed to mention several significant inner-city initiatives that were advanced at the congress. One such initiative was the formation of an inner-city task force with Mayor John Norquist of Milwaukee and Ray Gindroz of UDA Architects in Pittsburgh as co-chairmen.
Mr. Muschamp also neglected to mention a keynote address delivered by Henry G. Cisneros, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. Mr. Cisneros's remarks included passages from C.N.U.'s newly adopted charter; he enthusiastically signed that document at the close of his talk, which mentioned sweeping new HUD programs designed to reconfigure troubled inner-city high-rise and superblock projects into more pedestrian-friendly, mixed-use neighborhoods connected with the larger urban context.
This appropriation of New Urbanism principles by a major shaper of American urban policy is surely worth noting. Its potential impact on the quality of inner-city life goes far beyond issues of esthetics.
 
PETER KATZ
San Francisco
 
The writer is the acting executive director of the Congress for the New Urbanism.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
How Istea Refreshes Some of the Island's Byways

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN 

 BODY:
WERE it not for a Federal highway law that authorized funds for the enhancement of local roads, many projects now in progress -- from the creation of bike and pedestrian trails to the restoration of historic buildings -- might never have been undertaken.
That is the consensus of Long Island and state officials on the so-called "transportation enhancement" program known as Istea (pronounced ice tea). Twenty-seven projects have just been awarded their third -- and possibly final -- round of financing. 
 "We all too often forget that bicycles and walking are among the best modes of transportation," said John B. Daly, the Commissioner of the state's Department of Transportation. "This enhancement program has focused attention on worthwhile projects that could otherwise be overlooked in the press for improving roads and bridges and getting more asphalt down."
Istea is the acronym for the Intermodal Surface Transportation Efficiency Act, a $151 billion transportation law signed into law in 1991. Under one of its provisions, states must set aside for enhancement work 10 percent of Federal funds ticketed for roads other than major highways.
In New York State, $92.3 million was set aside for the program, with $17.36 million apportioned to Long Island. The state used up its allotment for this year and 1997 for this year's awards, so this round could be the final one, unless Congress extends Istea when it expires on Sept. 30, 1997.
Local municipalities or state agencies must sponsor enhancement projects and must agree to pay for at least 20 percent of their cost. In-house services, bond issues, fund-raising and other methods are used to generate local contributions.
Liberal guidelines allow a wide leeway on how the money can be spent. Eligible proposals have included the restoration of historic buildings, revitalization of ponds and streams and the acquisition of scenic easements.
"What Istea has really helped facilitate is a sense of place for Long Island," said Robert B. MacKay, one of 21 members of the Long Island Transportation Enhancement Advisory Committee panel formed to select local projects. Mr. MacKay is also director of the Society for Long Island Antiquities, a preservation group.
"It's that sense of place that is going to be vital to our economic future if we are going to continue to be both a tourist destination and an attractive place to live, work and play," he said.
The 27 projects on Long Island that are among this year's award winners will receive a total of $8.53 million in Federal financing, to be augmented by about $1.8 million from local sources. Most of the projects selected over the last two years are already under way, said David Glass who coordinates the Long Island program for the state's Department of Transportation.
T HE 1996 awards, which Gov. George E. Pataki announced May 25, include funds for the restoration of a historic church in Cold Spring Harbor, for revitalizing the Freeport waterfront and for a walkway along Greenport's harbor that the village's mayor, David E. Kapell, said would be "the fulfillment of a dream that began 30 years ago."
The largest award, $1.293 million to Freeport, will permit the acquisition of a 3.75-acre waterfront parcel and the construction of a boardwalk. The village will contribute an additional $431,000 to the project's $1.724 million cost.
The parcel, at the foot of Miller and South Ocean Avenues, had once been approved for construction of a 40-unit condominium that was never built. Instead, it will become a park, with benches, walkways and a gazebo. The proposed boardwalk, which will stretch from Woodcleft Avenue west to the Miller Canal, will cross the property.
The village received two previous Istea awards for its so-called Nautical Mile, which extends down Woodcleft Avenue, a thoroughfare lined by boatyards and other marine-related uses, as well as by restaurants and shops. The Federal money, together with local funds, is being used for walkways and bicycle paths.
There has been an ongoing effort to turn the Nautical Mile into a major tourist destination, and the Istea funds will be vital in achieving that goal, said Eric Hemphill, executive director of the village's Community Development Agency.
In Greenport, a waterfront revitalization plan has been given a $503,000 Istea award this year. The village will contribute $126,000 to the $629,000 project to construct a 1,650-foot long bicycle and pedestrian path along the shoreline of Greenport Harbor. An international design competition will be used to select an architect.
"We view our harbor walk and the whole revitalization project as bringing the Greenport economy out of the doldrums," Mayor Kapell said.
Another waterfront project, this one in Stony Brook, will use a $144,000 grant to improve pedestrian access between the Museums at Stony Brook and Stony Brook Harbor.
The City of Glen Cove is planning to link its downtown area to its waterfront at Garvies Point with walkways and bicycle paths. The rejuvenation of a mill pond next to the firehouse is part of the $731,000 project made possible by a $570,000 Istea grant and $161,000 from the city.
"Some people don't even realize we are a waterfront community, and this will remind them that we are," said Patricia A. Bourne, executive director of the city's Community Development Agency.
And in Islip, which received two Federal grants totaling $415,00, streetscape improvements in downtown Bay Shore costing $287,000 will include opening up water vistas. The town will contribute $57,000 to the Bayshore project and $47,000 to the townwide sidewalk and bicycle-path improvements.
Historic preservation will also benefit from this year's awards.
I N Cold Spring Harbor, the former Methodist Church on Main Street will be restored with the help of a $115,000 Istea grant.
The Gothic-style building dating to 1842 will become the new headquarters of the Society for the Preservation of Long Island Antiquities, which will pay the balance of the more than $600,000 cost of acquisition and restoration.
The Town of Riverhead received two awards totaling $313,000 for historic preservation, which it will augment with a contribution of $78,000. One will be used for improvements on and around the 62-year-old Suffolk Theater on Main Street, now undergoing renovations as an arts center.
The other will further enhance the Hallockville Museum Farm on Sound Avenue. The plan is to move additional 18th-century buildings to the complex, and to create "something akin to a Sturbridge Village in Massachusetts," said Andrea H. Lohneiss, Riverhead's Community Development Agency director.
Other awards include one for an $867,000 project sponsored by the Nassau County Department of Parks and Recreation under which a $507,000 Istea grant would be used to help acquire the 92-year-old Jackson-Malcolm farmstead on Route 106 in Jericho.
The property, which includes a barn that the county already owns, adjoins the county's Jericho Preserve. It could be commercially developed, said John B. Kiernan, Nassau's parks commissioner. "Without Istea, I wouldn't know of any other funding source that would allow us to buy it," he said.
A historic building in Brookhaven, the Davis house in Coram, will be restored with a $330,000 grant. The pre-Revolutionary War structure was used as a meeting place for town trustees for almost 100 years.
But for many people, perhaps the most meaningful legacy of Istea will be the network of bicycle and pedestrian paths that is being created all over Long Island.
Brookhaven was the sponsor this year of a project that, using a $736,000 Federal grant, will construct 36 miles of new bikeways connecting parklands from the Atlantic Ocean to Long Island Sound. In the Town of Southold, $393,000 will be used to implement safety measures for cyclists and to create new trails through public and private lands. The Suffolk County Department of Parks, Recreation and Conservation, in conjunction with Nassau County's parks agency, will mark a historic trail along 25A from the Queens County line to Port Jefferson.
"I would like to see pedestrian and bike space included in every project done by the Department of Transportation," said Nancy Manfredonia, president of the Greenbelt Trail Conference, a group that creates and maintains hiking and biking trails. "There is now more understanding of that need because Istea has helped promote the idea that cyclists and pedestrians matter."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Eric Hemphill (left), executive director of Freeport Community Development Agency, at the site where boardwalk (rendering above) will be built with the help of Istea funds. (Spiegel, Peter and Liu) (Vic DeLucia/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
More Care-Free Living Choices for Empty-Nesters

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
OVER the last four years Mart and Sharon Vaarsi scoured northern New Jersey for a residential community that would offer them an easier way of life as they head into their empty-nester years. Recently, their search ended.
The couple, who have two grown sons, the youngest a junior in college, put down a deposit on a home in Darlington Village at Rio Vista, a complex of 62 single-family detached houses in the Bergen County community of Mahwah. All the outdoor maintenance -- from mowing the lawn to shoveling the snow -- will be done for the Vaarsis. 
 Their current house, a bilevel elsewhere in Bergen County, "does not suit our living arrangement as well anymore," said Mr. Vaarsi, a Manhattan lawyer. It was time, he said, "to have someone else take care of the maintenance."
Darlington Village is among a spate of projects being built by developers hoping to attract empty-nesters such as the Vaarsis, who want to cast off chores, but do not want to compromise on space.
A few of the projects involve detached single-family homes only. Most include large town houses, which have bounced back from their recessionary slump. Eighteen such projects, totaling over 1,800 units, are under way in the state's 14 north and central counties, according to the New Homes Division of Coldwell Banker, a brokerage based in Short Hills.
Yet with prices in excess of $250,000 for the town houses and more than $350,000 for the detached houses, the projects are designed to appeal mostly to prosperous empty-nesters. Developers say professesional couples and trade-up buyers are other markets they will tap.
As of the first quarter the median sales price for existing one-family homes in the state, including town houses, was $150,000, up from $146,100 the same time in 1995, according to the New Jersey Association of Realtors in Edison.
"Such projects fill a need in a niche market," said David J. Schoner, vice president of Coldwell Banker's New Homes Division. "These are people who live in large houses within a 10-mile radius of the new communities and buy because of the security and lifestyle they offer."
He said the market would grow as the wave of baby boomers came of age and entered their peak earning years after the turn of the century.
But the lack of suitably zoned land will temper the pace of construction of such projects, which usually require a higher-density zoning. (Indeed, many current projects are a result of a zoning change to help towns meet their obligations under the State Supreme Court's Mount Laurel doctrines to provide housing for low- and moderate-income people.)
And since buying is more a choice than a necessity for empty-nesters the market is limited to financially strong developers able to ride out the longer sales program.
That follows the downward trend in new residential construction in the state, which for 1995 showed 7 percent fewer housing permits than the previous year's total of 26,986. A Rutgers University report also showed that the number of permits was unlikely to top 30,000 for each of the next four years.
The dearth of new construction in the near term is helping projects for empty-nesters now under way. But to be successful they must provide features buyers want, such as two-car garages and large master-bedroom suites on the first floor, said Mr. Schoner. Most important, he said, they must be in upscale locations with records of appreciation.
That is the case in Cedar Grove, where K. Hovnanian Enterprises of Red Bank is is developing Reservoir Ridge, 80 detached homes offering a condominium form of ownership on 45 acres on Mountain Road. The site borders Upper Montclair..
"The focus groups we held identified that the maintenance-free lifestyle would be appealing to move-down buyers in the area," said Gabriel M. Pasquale, senior marketing adviser for Hovnanian's northeast region. "Not everyone wants to live in a traditional single-family home."
The houses have 1,860 to about 3,000 square feet of space and include, among other features, two-car garages. Base prices range from $330,000 to $370,000; the monthly maintenance fee is $175. In the 14 months since sales began over 60 percent of the homes have been sold, said Mr. Pasquale.
Darlington Village in Mahwah, where the Vaarsis intend to live, is also finding a demand among buyers because it offers "an alternative," said Joseph M. Minetto, a principal at Darlington Associates, which is developing the 40-acre site. It is at the core of the group's larger project on what was once part of the 1,110-acre Darlington estate of George Crocker, son of Charles Crocker, one of the four founders of the Central Pacific Railroad. Later it was used as a seminary by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Newark.
OF the 62 houses, contracts have been signed or are pending on 14 since sales started two months ago, said Mr. Minetto. The houses, averaging 3,000 square feet, are priced from $459,000 to $525,000; the monthly maintenance is $225.
In Bergen County, a town-house complex is expanding and a mixed-housing community is about to begin. By mid-July construction is to resume at the incomplete Bear's Nest project in Park Ridge, where former President Richard M. Nixon once lived. Building there halted two years ago after 76 of the original 182 units were sold.
Pinnacle Communities Ltd. of Short Hills, which took over the 46-acre project last year, will complete the last 106 units and add 14 more on adjacent land. The new units will have the same Tudor exteriors designed by Eleanor Petterson, a student of Frank Lloyd Wright. But they will be widened, creating 20 to 30 percent more space on the first and second levels for a total of 3,000 to 4,000 square feet. Some 2,000 more square feet will be in the basement and third levels.
Prices for the homes, with the master bedroom on the first floor in some models, are to start at $450,000 to $560,000.
Brian M. Stolar, a principal at Pinnacle, called northern Bergen County "ground zero location" for such housing.
"A high percentage of its population has lived in the area a long time, is well-off and is looking for something different," he said "They are buying a lifestyle."
At the Village of Old Tappan in Old Tappan, site work has begun on Orangeburg Road for a condominium project. As now envisioned, It will have 83 apartments 1,700 to 2,000 square feet of space in 23 buildings.
There will also be 7 detached homes with 2,900 to 3,500 square feet of space and 41 town homes, with 2,100 to 3,000 square feet of space. Nine Mount Mount Laurel units are planned, but the developer is negotiating with the town to have them developed offsite.
"We saw a need for bigger town homes," said Patrick Kalian, president of the Kalian Corporation of Red Bank, the developer.
"Empty-nesters want to stay in the area in a home requiring no maintenance," said Mark Bellin, the company's executive vice president, "but there is not much available and there appears to be a pent-up demand."
Prices of the apartments average $245,000 for the apartments; the town houses range in price from $334,950 to $449,950 and detached houses from $500,000 to $600,000. The monthly maintenance fee, not yet set, will be plus or minus $200 depending on the unit. Since sales began two weeks ago 32 deposits have been taken.
The entire project "is catering to more than one market" said Mr. Kalian.
IN Hunterdon County, Sterling Properties of Livingston is turning 12.5 acres on McCansmill Road in the historic Potterville's section of Tewksbury Township into a 26-unit town-house project, a first for the area.
The units at Lamington Falls will be in six free-standing buildings, designed to blend into the community. Twenty-two will have 2,400 to 3,000 square feet of space; four, custom designed by buyers, will be larger. A 2,100-square foot structure on the site will house three low- and moderate-income apartments, with income-based rents.
Prices on the for-sale housing start at $380,000 to $425,000, with the custom units costing more. The monthly maintenance is $175, said Joseph Forgione, a Sterling principal. Sales start today and reservations have been taken on three units, he said.

HEADLINE: COVER STORY;
Often Scarier Than 'Bambi': 'Nature'

BYLINE: By WILL JOYNER 

 BODY:
IT'S 8 o'clock Sunday night. Do you know where your children are?
 
 Even if they're teen-agers, there's a good chance they are at home with you, tired from weekend escapades and apprehensive about the next day's duties. And even though this is 1996, long past the era of the family viewing hour, there's a good chance everyone is indeed together in front of the television, trying to agree on a show - which is not easy.
 "The Simpsons" is an acquired taste, even for the hippest. "Murder, She Wrote" has always been proudly geriatric. "Lois and Clark" presents an awkward generation gap. The answer for many families, and for many other Sunday-evening viewers, is "Nature," the natural-history documentary program that has been a hit on PBS for 14 seasons.
 "Nature" is by no means the choice of least provocation. Its film makers are the best in the business and they travel to Earth's most picturesque reaches, so the photography is always gorgeous and innovative. But each episode of "Nature," which is produced by WNET, tells a story about animals or plants, and the story, being true, inevitably makes vivid the cruel and private facts of life as well as its splendors.
 "We don't script our films ahead of time," says Fred Kaufman, the executive producer of "Nature." "We go out and shoot, and what we get we edit into films. There are some people out there who turn on 'Nature' and they just want to see a sanitized world for an hour."
 "Nature" does not provide a sanitized world. In South Africa, spotted hyenas prey on zebras at night. In Tanzania, jackals stalk ailing wildebeests. In Scotland, the ruthless goshawk though the theme of a "Nature" episode is almost always a positive one - nurturing and survival, for instance - the characters sometimes do struggle violently and die. They also have sex.
 This month, "Nature" is repeating its six-part series "The Nature of Sex," which was first broadcast in 1994. The series spends time with crabs and walruses, but it also progresses, tastefully, to an open if never explicit protrayal of human relations. Before "The Nature of Sex" was first broadcast, Mr. Kaufman and George Page, the creator of "Nature" and its narrator and executive editor, were certain that the series was in no way exploitative, but they were anxious enough about its content to ask PBS to show it at 9 P.M. instead of 8. As it turned out, they were worrying needlessly.
 "I was astonished," Mr. Page said recently, sitting in his office at WNET in Manhattan with Mr. Kaufman. "The thing got huge ratings - a lot of people were watching - and I don't think we got a single letter saying someone was offended."
 The explanation for this has a lot to do with Mr. Page. His ruggedly handsome face and deep, soothing voice (equal parts Walter Cronkite, John Wayne and Walt Disney) give "Nature" much of its character as a serious but accessible science program. "It's sunrise on the Serengeti Plains of East Africa," says Mr. Page at the start of a typical "Natural" segment, "and a herd of Thomson's gazelles is already wide awake." In just a few words, information and drama are linked.
 Learning of nature's mysteries as Mr. Page speaks is a lot like sitting at the knee of a beloved granfather, and a great many people of all ages feel a personal bond to "Nature." the program has broader age, economic and ethnic demographics than any other prime-time program on PBS. Its ratings have always been strong. (In 1995, it was among the three highest-rated prime-time programs on PBS.) And in spite of greater competition in nature programming with the advent of the Discovery Channel, those ratings have actually gone up in the last couple of years.
 Nothing is ever certain in public television, but as they gather 14 or 15 new films for their 15th season, with solid financing from Canon and Ford, Mr. Kaufman and Mr. Page are confident of success. It was not always so. In the early 1980's, Mr. page wasn't sure what he would come up with when he was asked by his bosses at WNET to develop a new science program.
 "I looked at what was already being done on PBS," he says "It was the 'Nova' series, which would include an occasional natural history film, and it was the National Geographic specials, which shifted between PBS and commercial television. I also, witha cold eye, looked at the ratings when a natural history film was on PBS, and it was always a spike."
 Mr. Page decided that natural history was the way to go, and he went looking for enough good films to create a first season. He found them at the BBC natural-history unit, which he credits with inventing the genre about 30 years aog.
 "About two weeks before the series was to go on the air, " Mr. Page says, "some of our programming colleagues at PBS in Washington, after seeing the first three programs, called in a panic and said: 'These shows are not going to work. Nobody's going to watch. They're too slow.' Well, what those three programs were was 'The Flight of the Condor.' which is now regarded as a classic. The public loved it."
 Over the years, Mr. page and Mr. Kaufman, who took over from David Healy as executive producer in 1991 after being the program's series producer for nine years, have progressed from simply acquiring films and adding narration to participating in the films' planning and creation as co-producers. The cost of a single film has increased greatly, to as much as $700,000. One new area that they want to explore is the field of human-animal relationships.
 The constant is a rare breed of film maker: adventurer, naturalist and technician all in one.
 "I used to say you could count the world-class natural history film makers on one hand," says Mr. Page. "That's not true anymore, but it's still a very small, elite group."
 This group includes more Americans than it once did because of the influence of "Nature," Mr. Kaufman and Mr. Page believe. It still includes Hugh Miles of Scotland, a veteran whose three-part "Kingdom of the Ice Bear" involved 16 trips to the High Arctic over two years. In a "Nature" special on its film makers, Mr. Miles sums up his professional purpose in this way: "If I can transport the audience for one hour from their living rooms and make them have the impression at the end of it that they've actually experienced what I have experienced, then I've done my job. If they actually learn something about the animal, that's a bonus, and if they're entertained, better still."
 As a weekly presence in its viewers' lives, "Nature" has a comparable sense of purpose, and one aspect of this is to benefit the environment without preaching.
 "Sometimes it's tempting to do that because we do care about the environment, and we think it would be a good idea for the planet to survive," Mr. Page says. "But our philosophy is that our series is here for people to learn how the natural world works, and if they understand it, they are likely to care about it, and if they care about it, they are likely to want to protect it."

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Tottenville;
Way Down South on Staten Island

BYLINE: By JANICE FIORAVANTE 

 BODY:
TOTTENVILLE, the Staten Island community farthest from Manhattan and the southernmost point of New York State, escaped the frenzy of building after the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge opened in 1964.
It remained more rural than perhaps any other part of the borough, with old Victorian houses, wooded areas and its own Main Street. 
 But Tottenville was discovered a decade ago and now town houses, semi-attached and custom homes have given parts of Tottenville a suburban look. And with development have come suburban problems, among them school overcrowding.
The wave of development began in the mid-80's when a Tottenville builder put up six custom homes, causing other builders to move into the area.
"In the early 80's, builders could buy land for about $2 a square foot," said Thomas Maira, the owner of Maira Real Estate. "By the late 80's, land cost from $5 to $7 a square foot."
The coming of sewers helped, too. In 1990 and 1991 sewer lines connected Tottenville to a sewage-treatment plant in Eltingville. Thus septics were replaced, making the area more appealing.
Surfside Village, begun in 1986 and one of the community's earliest town-house developments, won approvals because it included its own sewage-treatment plant. The complex, on Raritan Bay between Loretto Street and Sprague Avenue, now has 296 town houses with an additional 60 still to be built.
Eighty percent of the new construction has taken place between Hylan Boulevard and Raritan Bay, what Mr. Maira calls "below the Boulevard."
"Fifty percent of that property consisted of small bungalows improved to be year-round homes," he said. "Of the other half, about 36 percent are custom homes, costing in the $400,000 range. The rest are semi-attached, not in rows, but scattered, two here, another two down the street."
He described the custom homes as predominantly center-hall colonials with two-car garages and one-bedroom apartments above the garage.
One-family, semi-attached homes are priced from $179,000 to $199,000 and semi-attached, two-family homes from $189,000 to $219,000. Among older homes, mostly two-story Victorians and colonials, prices range from $170,000 to $220,000. Prices of two-families range from $180,000 to $230,000.
While many newcomers feel that the rash of construction means progress, others feel the community has been overbuilt. "Tottenville, like almost all areas on the South Shore, has been town-housed to death," said Lydia Ragucci, owner of Ragucci Realty and a member of the land use committee of Community Board 3.
NEW zoning laws are being phased in and are helping to change the picture. "Over the past three years," Ms. Ragucci said, "most of the area has been rezoned to allow only detached one-family homes on a minimum of 35- by 100-foot lots." Jean Timberlake, community liaison for the Staten Island office of the Department of City Planning, said the last of the zoning changes were being implemented.
Priscilla Raccuglia-Carollo, president of the Tottenville Civic Association, called the building of town houses and semi-attached homes "overdensifying," resulting in classroom overcrowding in the public schools.
(The overcrowding is a result of a 41 percent surge in population in Tottenville from 6,486 in 1980 to an estimated 11,000 today. A third of the increase is in residents under the age of 18, according to the Staten Island Office of Economic Development.)
"Now P.S. 1 is so overcrowded, the third-grade classes are being bused to a building on the grounds of Mount Loretto," a nearby property owned by the Archdiocese of New York, Ms. Raccuglia-Carrollo said. "The school lost its computer room, library and gym to make more classrooms."
Bernard Campbell, principal of Public School 1, said that despite the problem, more than 70 percent of its 753 pupils read at grade level or better. "When the school board leased the old school on Mount Loretto," he said, "we got back our gym, library and two science labs," which had been used as classrooms. But, he added, they had to be used as classrooms again as more building of new homes meant a further increase in pupils.
Our Lady Help of Christians, a Roman Catholic school with 250 students from pre-kindergarten to grade 8, is building two new classrooms to house the 25 percent increase in enrollment in the last three years, according to the principal, Nancy Lucas.
The community's 1,100-student I.S. 34 is ranked No. 1 in reading scores among New York City intermediate schools, said Frank Moschella, the principal. He credited the supportive community and education-oriented parents.
One such parent is Diane Silverman. Three of her four children (the youngest is 2-year-old Bree) attend Tottenville's public schools. "Every aspect of the education in Tottenville public schools is great, except for class sizes," she said. Page is 7 and in second grade at P.S. 1; Jena, 12, is in seventh grade at I.S. 34 and Rian, 14, will enter Tottenville High School's Science Institute this fall.
Tottenville High School, a few communities northeast in Huguenot, has about 3,400 students, of which 87 percent go on to higher education. Its Science and Humanities Institutes offers Latin and college-credit courses. Earlier this month, the school's Tottenville Pirates baseball team won its second straight Public School Athletic League championship, at Yankee Stadium.
The bungalows below the boulevard tell the story of Tottenville as a summer getaway and fishing enclave. In 1886, 300 to 400 of the community's 2,800 population made its living in oystering and fishing. This attracted shipwrights who built sailing vessels. Shipyards and oystering were among the area's most profitable industries.
The community adopted the name Tottenville in 1869 for Gilbert Totten, an 18th-century settler. He and his descendants were instrumental in building the Bethel United Methodist Church, completed in 1841. It was the community's first house of worship.
The neighborhood had been called Bentley Manor, named by Capt. Christopher Billopp for his ship, the Bentley, after he was granted land on Staten Island in 1668 by the Duke of York.
Billopp built a two-story stone house beginning in about 1680, which came to be known as the Billopp House. A conference held there on Sept. 11, 1776 after the Battle of Long Island, in which Continental Congress representatives rejected a call for surrender, gave it a new name. The Conference House is now a national and New York City historic landmark.
A ferry run by the Staten Island Railroad from Tottenville to Perth Amboy, N.J., began operation in 1867 and ended in 1963. But proximity to New Jersey still lures shoppers from Tottenville, as does that state's lower sales tax. Malls, discount, chain and warehouse stores there and in Staten Island have posed problems for Tottenville merchants.
A consultant, Joannene Coppinger-Borock, helped establish a local development corporation with Paul Kidder, president of the Tottenville Merchants Association, who is now president of the development group. The development corporation, supported by grants from private industry, is working to strengthen Tottenville's three commercial strips, Main Street, Amboy Road and Page Avenue.
The 123d Police Precinct station house is found on Main Street, along with the Post Office and the Richmond Country Savings Bank. Amboy Road, with its art gallery, bakery and ice cream parlor, is also the site of the Tottenville library, dedicated in 1904 and the first to be built on Staten Island. Among Page Avenue's stores are a pizzeria, bagel bakery and a florist.
Mr. Kidder said the organization would work with landlords to help a variety of businesses come into Tottenville.
The corporation sponsored a parade and fair on June 9 called Heritage Day. This event, which drew about 3,000 people, presented line dancers in cowboy hats and boots and demonstrated that the country is not far away.
A 110-acre undeveloped area and wildlife sanctuary called Long Pond that is in the final stages of becoming a park, Mrs. Timberlake of City Planning said. Guy V. Molinari, the borough president, called it an ideal addition to "strengthen the small-town qualities of Tottenville."

CONFERENCE HOUSE PARK: The 227 acres along Raritan Bay now known as Conference House Park has been attracting people to its shores since prerecorded history. "It's quite clear that this was a summer spot for Native Americans from up and down the East Coast because we have found cross-cultural artifacts," said Joanne Jackson, a consultant working for the Department of Parks and Recreation who is writing a landscape architectural report. The park contains 72 burials, 50 reported pits with hearth materials and pots, as well as arrowheads. The report will recommend making this an archeological preservation zone to discourage amateur archeologists from disturbing the burials. "We want to increase awareness that this is an archeological site," said Ms. Jackson. "But when I see evidence of recent beach parties, I can't help but smile -- they've been going on here for a good, long time."

HEADLINE: FARM LIFE -- Protecting the crop.;
Farmer Makes a Choice on the Use of Pesticides for His Fruit

BYLINE: By JANE JULIANELLI

 BODY:
AT first it looked like a vintage flying machine, two huge aluminum booms swinging out from a center carrier, attached with vinyl curtains to deflect the wind.
A sprayer for crop protectants, designed and built by John Halsey at a cost of $5,000, funny looking as it appeared, did the trick. By putting the chemicals directly on the leaves and branches of the tree, rather than blowing it up through the tree, Mr. Halsey said, he could use 30 percent less chemicals than by using a conventional sprayer. 
 Mr. Halsey will be spraying his 20 acres of apple trees in Bridgehampton from April into early September, like most farmers in Suffolk County. Such spraying continues to run into opposition from those who object to anything other than natural forces to control the destiny of the crops.
As farmers educated in the latest methods of pesticide use and in fastidious record-keeping, the Halseys, a 12-generation Long Island farm family, feel strongly that controlled use of pesticides is essential to protect their crops and their livelihood.
"To produce the quanity and quality of food that our citizens in America demand and deserve, we as growers are going to have to use crop protectants," Mr. Halsey said, "and we'll use the most appropriate amount of the most efficient product."
This translates into making applications against funguses from April into early September, depending on humidity and temperature, and against insects, depending on temperature, between May and June. Mr. Halsey changes products with weather changes, using 10 or more products to mix up the cycles so that one insect won't become resistant to one product. He follows the label recommendations, which tell how much he can put on per acre and how often it can be applied.
"Then we balance that against the need," Mr. Halsey said, "and not always put on as much as the label says."
Some of the controversy over agricultural pesticides is being played out in Albany, where farming advocates and legislators often clash.
For instance, the Long Island Farm Bureau in Riverhead, which represents the interests of farmers, believes there has been no scientific evidence to substantiate the fear that pesticide use by farmers is a cause of breast or prostate cancer on Long Island.
"I disagree with the statement that there is no evidence," said Assemblyman Steven Englebright, a Democrat of Setauket, who is a sponsor of the Pesticide Use and Registry bill. The bill would require private and commercial pesticide applicators to file an annual report with the Department of Environmental Conservation in Stony Brook.
"There's a great deal of evidence that suggests that pesticides do affect the human immune system and the human sexual hormone system," said Mr. Englebright.
"There is a library of information documenting the ill-health effects. And a recent study suggests that pesticides in combination with one another can have a dramatic effect, as much as 1,000 times more powerful than an individual pesticide."
Assemblyman Englebright, who is vice chairman of the Legislative Commission on Toxic and Hazardous Substances and who grew up on a farm in Evansville, Ind., said the Pesticide Use and Registry bill was an effort to develop a data base that will enable health researchers for breast cancer and other afflictions that may be linked to the use of pesticides, to keep a record to determine if there is a cause and effect relationship.
William Sanok, county agent for the Cornell Cooperative Extension of Suffolk County, said that the public's perception of pesticides was in many cases not based in fact.
"My No. 1 gripe is when people start making laws that are based on emotion rather than the facts," he said. "I'm involved with the breast cancer task force at Cornell. A lot of the people that are anti-pesticides say that breast cancer is highest on Long Island. No. 1, it's not highest on Long Island. No. 2, it's less prevalent on eastern Long Island than it is in the rest of Suffolk County."
Mr. Sanok, calling himself the Mr. Kimble of "Green Acres," added: "I've been in this business for 30 years and I've seen some tremendous changes in the evolution of use of pesticides. For example, we used to use DDT (Dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane) for almost everything, and found out it didn't work on everything. And because it had such a long residual effect on the environment we stopped using it."
Mr. Sanok said that of the 600 farmers in Suffolk County, many were preparing a new generation that is better educated, like Jennifer and Amy Halsey, who go to school to learn integrated pest management and potential alternatives to pesticides.
This generation will work with new products that have to go through a great deal of testing before they're approved, he said. "The major changes have been away from the long residual, broad-ranged type of pest chemicals such as DDT and Chlordane," Mr. Sanok said. "We're using things like Bt (Bacillus thuriengensis), which is a naturally occurring bacteria manufactured into a commercial product."
Dave Rosenberger, associate professor of plant pathology at Cornell University and the New York State Agricultural Experiment Station in Ulster County, who covers most of eastern New York, called the new pesticides less persistent.
"Those persistent pesticides were phased out in the 1960's and early 1970's." he said. "And the products registered now are all very short-lived in terms of having any persistent effect on the environment. The new products are different from DDT and Chlordane in that they are metabolized or broken down into harmless compounds relatively quickly.
"'So Mancozeb fungicide and other fungicides and insecticides we use generally disappear within two to three weeks after application at the most, and some of them a lot quicker than that. What made DDT dangerous was its persistence."
Assemblyman Englebright disagreed. "I cannot have a universal agreement with that perspective and I would only point to the incidence of Temek," he said. "Temek was applied broadly in the farming regions of eastern Long Island just a very few years ago. It was supposed to break down based upon tests that were done in other states and not be persistent within the ground water and the environment.
"As a result it did not break down in Long Island well water. It contaminated over 2,000 wells on the East End and was an economic calamity. It is still in the ground water in a large part of the South Fork and North Fork as a significant contaminant."
On an optimistic note Assemblyman Englebright said that many of the farmers he had met, with whom he empathized, were reasonable and thoughtful and were struggling to find ways through this issue.
Back at the Halsey farmstead in Bridgehampton, John Halsey was standing in the barn by his sprayer, wearing a hat to protect him from mischievous barn swallows nested in the rafters. Jennifer Halsey was home for the summer from the Cornell School of Agriculture and Life Science to run the Integrated Pest Management program on the farm.
The program is considered by all sides of the pesticide issue to be gaining broader acceptance and reducing significantly some of the past problems in terms of broadcast spraying and the impact upon non-target organisms and the general environment.
"IPM is all about scouting for insects, which reduces the use of crop protectants and pesticide sprays," Ms. Halsey said. "People, when they associate the word pesticide, they associate it with a bad thing and it's really not.
"What it's doing is protecting the crop from an insect, from a fungus. There's several different insects, such as European lead mite, leaf minor and leaf hoppers that will chew on the leaves. Because leaves are green, they are photosynthesizing and you need that for the apples to grow. So you want to reduce that.
"But there is a threshold point where it can be too much or too little," she continued. "And once you meet that point you have to come out and treat the trees. So what I do is I come out and find whether the trees are at that threshold point or not and then I come back and I tell Dad whether he has to spray or not."
She continued: "What he used with his father was, when they went out in the potato field and saw a couple of potato bugs, that was it. They went out and sprayed.But now that there's such a reduction in spraying I wait until the threshold point."
One basic difference between John Halsey's approach and Jennifer's approach, Mr. Halsey, said was "I'm impatient but Jen will count the bugs."
"She's been trained and I give her the time to go out and look at enough leaves on enough trees and count the insects that she's looking for," he said. "The research publications have indicated how many insects of a particular kind can be on the trees before they'll do economic damage. She will do the counting to determine that threshold level."
Ms. Halsey showed her father a piece of paper on which was what appeared to be eight minuscule fragments of steel wool. They were bugs.
"It's all based on the design on the wing. Also, the apple maggot has a white speck on its back," said Ms. Halsey, describing what was undetectable to the untrained eye. "There's also a cherry fruit fly in here. But what we are really concerned with is the three apple maggots, as well as some other fruit-feeding insects."
Mr. Halsey said: "The rest of them she questions. Because Jen is studying carefully the differences in the insects, she identified three that were harmful and five that were not. I would have identified eight that were harmful and gone out and protected the crop against them needlessly because there's not enough there."
Mr. Halsey hung 18 traps, looking like red apples, covered with a plastic bag smeared with glue. These go around the perimeter of the orchard where apple-maggots over-winter.
"During the height of the season," Mr. Halsey said, "July and early August, Jen will go twice a week and count them and in that period of time if she finds -- what's the number Jen?"
Ms. Halsey referred to her textbook: "If a total of five apple maggots are caught, then you should apply a crop protectant." Mr. Halsey described their spreadsheet graph, carefully listing every trap, and the date Ms. Halsey looked at them.
"Just take for example, trap No. 1," Mr. Halsey said. "She didn't find any for a month. So we wait on that."
As for more natural ways to control pests, Mr. Halsey said: "Our Integrated Pest Management program is taking into account any predatory insect of the damaging insect. Ladybugs are a major part of our pest control program in the orchard. The new products are being developed so that we don't kill the ladybugs when we kill the problem insects. Last year we had very good control of aphids by ladybugs."
Mr. Halsey said that in addition, they consider organic farming every day they operate. Organic farming, Mr. Halsey said, is "the growth of a food crop with a product that is safe for the environment and safe for humans."
"Most of the organic fruit is being grown in Washington State which is an entirely different growing climate than ours," he said. "I'm working with some people who are trying to develop organic-type products for this area but so far the fungus is a big problem."
So as the humidity of the maritime climate sets in this summer over eastern Long Island, the controversy over pesticides goes on. Will there come a time when it becomes virtually impossible for the farmer to make a living because of the restrictions and costs?
"Boy, I sure hope not," Assemblyman Englebright said, "and I don't think so because we're all working together. The best soils in the world are in eastern Long Island. And with the long growing season, it's essentially a state and national treasure."
