HEADLINE: Back to Vietnam: Past Meets Present

BYLINE: By KATE STONE LOMBARDI

DATELINE: THORNWOOD

 BODY:
THAO THACH missed her graduation ceremony from New York Medical College in Valhalla last month. Instead, she was visiting clinics in the rural provinces of Vietnam, bringing medical supplies to the country she fled by boat in the dark of night 15 years ago.
To return to Vietnam was not easy. Dr. Thach was 16 when she left Danang with her father and sister, setting out on a perilous journey during which she and her family spent 12 days being buffeted on the ocean. Their small boat ran out of gas, and there were days when she fainted from hunger. At one point, a boat from China stopped to give the stranded party water before moving on. Another paused long enough to steal their jewelry but gave them rice. Finally, a third boat towed them to Hong Kong. 
 The journey that took her back to Vietnam was longer still. After a year in a refugee camp in Hong Kong, the family moved to California. She mastered English, at the same time holding jobs in a department store and at a supermarket. Dr. Thach attended high school in San Jose, junior college also in California and, eventually, transferred to the University of California at Davis, where she earned a B.S. in biochemistry. This spring, she earned her medical degree in Westchester.
Throughout the years, and despite the horrors she saw during the fall of Danang -- an experience she said she still could not discuss -- she longed to return home.
"The minute I left Vietnam, when I was on the boat, I promised myself I would come back," Dr. Thach said. "I just felt it was a sad thing to leave a country, and I had so much resentment. I wanted to come back, and I wanted to help people."
She found that opportunity through an organization called Project: Hearts and Minds, a nonprofit agency, which seeks to foster reconciliation between citizens of the United States and Vietnam by providing medical aid to Vietnam. The agency, whose New York chapter is based in Thornwood, organizes two relief missions a year, in which groups take medical supplies to Vietnamese hospitals and clinics.
The project was begun in 1991 by two Vietnam veterans from California. Groups traveling to Vietnam have included veterans who sometimes visit the areas in which they served in combat. Tom Conlin, the group's president, who lives in Thornwood, said the experience has provided psychological healing to veterans who are able to return to the country peaceably offering aid.
Not all members of the group are Vietnam veterans. Mr. Conlin was a conscientious objector during the war. Participants run the gamut of the political spectrum and include those who enlisted, those who were drafted and those who supported the war.
Dr. Thach's visit represented two milestones for Project: Hearts and Minds. First, she was the first Vietnamese refugee to return to her country with the organization. Second, Dr. Thach, who is now an American citizen, was one of six women who traveled to Vietnam this spring as part of the first all-female group.
The women delivered medical supplies to four sites: Chu Lai Hospital, Son Tin/My Lai Hospital, My Tho Women's and Children's Hospital and Go Cong Tay Hospital. They also visited the Ha Tan District Hospital to see if it was suitable for future support. The group brought syringes, antibiotics, dressings, latex gloves, needles, rehydration kits and intravenous equipment.
"In terms of their needs, it's everything from the smallest stuff -- like having enough soap and water -- to the bigger and more expensive items, like ultrasound machines, anesthesia machines, dental equipment and CAT scans," said Gail Moroso, a group member and nurse who coordinates a perinatal H.I.V. transmission study at Women/Infants Health Care at SUNY Health Science Center in Brooklyn.
She added that second-hand equipment, which had been donated in the past, was breaking down and that replacement parts were nearly impossible to get.
Ms. Moroso was stationed in Nha Trang, Ban Me Thuot and Long An from 1968 through 1970, working for the United States Agency for International Development, which was part of the State Department. She worked as a nurse adviser in Vietnamese civilian hospitals, where her assignment was to help the Vietnamese upgrade their medical nursing care. But conditions were very different from what agency planners envisioned, Ms. Moroso said.
"Our program wanted us to do some very sophisticated things in terms of changing their nursing care," Ms. Moroso said, "but we were busy trying to get the chickens out of the ward and stopping the patients from cooking under the beds and get them to get running water in their recovery room and get the toilets working, so it ended up being a lot of very practical stuff."
Returning to Vietnam for the first time in more than 25 years, Ms. Moroso said that while some things were considerably changed, the primitiveness of the medical care was surprisingly the same.
"Unfortunately, the hospitals did not look that much different from how I remembered them and that was sad," Ms. Moroso said. "Of course, the big difference was that there was no war going on. There was no shelling, no military trucks and no tanks. At first I kept trying to figure out what else was missing, and then I realized it was the sandbags."
Vietnam remains one of the poorest countries in the world, and the group described a lack of the most basic medical equipment. Latex gloves and syringes -- both meant to be disposable -- are routinely washed and reused. Dispensary cabinets are rusted and broken, mold grows on surfaces in the operating rooms and water is not distilled.
At the clinic at Chou Lai, a metal-frame bed is provided, but patients provide their own mats and bring their own pajamas. In general, hospitals will provide food for a fee; otherwise, families bring their own. Families also do much of the basic patient care like washing, turning, walking and feeding the patient.
"It's a combination of economic and cultural forces," said Dr. Cathey E. Falvo, chairwoman of the board of Project: Hearts and Minds and part of the group which visited this spring. "Nurses do specific things like give you medicines, but you don't let strangers bathe you. Hospitals can't afford to provide what amounts to nurse's aid care."
Dr. Falvo, also director of International and General Public Health at the Graduate School of Health Sciences at New York Medical College, said that Vietnam also faces severe problems with malnutrition, malaria and dengue fever (a virus transmitted by mosquitoes). Cholera and typhoid have also been rampant.
She said that Vietnam was particularly strong in public health education and observed that posters urging H.I.V. prevention, encouraging breast feeding and good diet and promoting population control were graphically presented and widely distributed.
Members of the group said they were struck by the beauty of the country and the graciousness of the Vietnamese people. For Dr. Falvo, a high point came after the group trudged eight kilometers through rain and mud to reach an outlying clinic and were met with iced bottled water, delicious fruit and, in the midst of great poverty, overwhelming hospitality.
Ms. Moroso rode on a small pole boat on a tributary of the Mekong River and reflected that when she had last been in Vietnam the area had been overrun with the Vietcong. Twenty-six years later, she spent an afternoon singing songs and exchanging addresses with Vietnamese students.
For Dr. Thach, the memories were more painful. She said that she could not describe how Danang had changed since she left because she has suppressed most of her memories.
"I didn't have the courage to go back to my house in daylight," Dr. Thach said. "I saw it in the dark. It's too upsetting. It was my parents' dream. They worked really hard to build that house. It is painful to me how much a human can endure."
Project: Hearts and Minds is planning another relief mission in October. Medical supplies are donated by medical-supply companies and hospitals. Continental Airlines donates transportation for mission participants as well as shipment of supplies and equipment in and out of Manila. Each person traveling can take 140 pounds of medical equipment. Those interested in the project or in donating medical supplies should call 747-2176.

HEADLINE: Connecticut Q&A: Elaine Zimmerman;
Looking Out for the Needs of the Children

BYLINE: By NANCY POLK

 BODY:
ELAINE ZIMMERMAN, executive director of the Connecticut Commission on Children, combines a missionary's zeal with a mother's determination in her work representing the interests of children. She must look after their needs from prenatal to age 21. To spread scarce money as efficiently as possible Ms. Zimmerman has emphasized the importance of prevention and the needs of the youngest Connecticut citizens.
"In the last five years there were significant budget cuts," she said. "Children's needs were increasing in terms of learning, safety and health. It became clear that with limited dollars and increased needs it was wise to invest in prevention." 
 She said that she is often frustrated. "The truth is that children are off the political agenda," she said. "What children's policies there are, are secondary to other agendas, such as welfare reform ." She said that she worries about the implications of this shift in social policy.
"Right now the country is very confused about the role of mothers," she said. "We want poor women in the work force and middle-class women home. We blame different classes of women for different ills in society."
Recently Ms. Zimmerman discussed a few of the issues and programs administered by her department. Following are exerpts from that conversation:
Q. What is the state of children in the State of Connecticut?
A. They are not doing very well. We are seeing children increasingly fearful of not having anyone to take care of them while parents work or job-train. Not just poor children.
Many children are doing well, many are not doing well. Often this breaks out by class and race. In many instances the gaps in public policy that are facing children are not just segregated by class, for example, in child care. In Connecticut two-thirds of moms are working but our supply of child care is both short and not quality. Parents are unable to afford a care-giving environment so they are forced to rely on neighbors or patchwork arrangements.
We're seeing children in up to seven arrangements in one day. One thing this does for a child is it never allows enough backdrop of safety and certainty to begin to play or explore. It hurts the developing psyche and it hinders the imagination.
In the health arena, around 10 percent of our children -- 70,000 -- don't have health insurance. They are the ones who end up in hospital rooms. They are the ones who end up missing school. Of the children who are not school-ready in our state, one out of seven is in poor health.
Q. Is poverty the reason for these serious problems?
A. We have a significant number of poor children located in pockets of Connecticut. We have higher numbers in our urban areas and significant poverty in our rural areas. For children in poverty the dropout rate is twice as high. The lead poisoning rate is three to four times greater. Teen pregnancy is five to seven times more likely.
We have 110,000 children in poverty. These children are on A.F.D.C.
What we need to do particularly with welfare reform is to make sure that these children have quality environments to go to when their parents are in job training or working. Parents worry if their children aren't in safe environments. The parents have trouble concentrating and they worry that their children aren't getting their fair share. They won't benefit the same as children in "Cadillac" programs. They are right because we now know that the quality of care giving influences language, social skills and learning.
Q. What is the commission's current priority?
A. Prevention, beginning with the earliest years. The core focuses of the commission are prevention with interest in early intervention, capacity building to help people work substantively on issues both on the state and local level and service integration so we are not cutting the baby into 20 pieces.
Q. What is service integration? Why is it so important?
A. Because of marginal funding we have a host of programs that address children's needs but they aren't integrated. So one program deals with health, another with child care, and another with after school. Current policies encourage the fragmentation of service delivery which isn't how children thrive. I think with the increasing budget cuts that we are going to see, the day of service integration is about the hit us.
Q. How serious a problem is teen pregnancy in Connecticut?
A. There is a significant correlation between teen pregnancy, school failure, welfare dependency and unemployment. Teen moms lose their ladder to career and opportunity. Often the child of a teen mother is at risk because of low birth weight and poverty. The baby doesn't get parental guidance and nurturing. Two generations end up being hurt.
We have the highest rate of teen pregnancy of any Western industrialized country. In Connecticut we have one of the highest rates of teen births. At 23 percent the rate of teen births in Hartford in 1993 was more than double that of New York City. We have the highest incidence of teen pregnancy in Hartford, Windham, New London and Bridgeport.
Q. Are teen mothers responsible for the majority of social problems afflicting the state's children?
A. Teen moms are not the cause of our nation's ills; rather, it is the opposite. It is emblematic of our society's abandonment of children. People blame teen parents for many of the social ills in the United States. That's overdone. Our teen pregnancy rate has actually gone down. In 1990 there were 4,026 teen births. By 1993 it had declined to 3,655.
We are seeing repetition of the pattern with teen parents giving birth to children who become teen parents. There are multiple causes. One is a sense of no future. The severity of violence and the sense that one won't live for many years is increasing the number of urban children who feel one way to have a sense of future is to have a child. There is a higher incidence of teen pregnancy among families in poverty.
We are in terrible shape in this state in terms of statutory rape with 66 percent of the fathers being over 21. We are doing nothing. We recommended to the Governor that we seriously enforce statutory rape laws and that we target Hartford because it has the highest incidence.
Q. How serious a problem is lead paint in Connecticut?
A. Lead levels are high. People don't know that high lead levels affect I.Q., hearing and growth. Lead paint is found both in urban and rural areas because Connecticut has an old housing stock. If you have an old house you should pay attention. Be careful to avoid children's exposure to paint chips and paint dust. People need to get advice from their local health department before beginning renovations.
Q. Where do you stand on the issue of family values?
A. We do need a return to family values but I think that actually means a return to the social contract. Mass Mutual did a study of what the public meant by "family values." It was not about abortion or not abortion. It wasn't about the structure of the family -- two wage-earning family or single parent. It was about the social contract.
It was about whether or not you give to me and I give to you when we're in trouble. It was about whether or not you pick me up and I pick you up when we each fall. The public is concerned that there has been a decline in the social contract. We are simply not teaching good citizenship in a deep way, what someone else might call religious values.
What we really need to do is get back to caring about one another and caring for community. Parents want to make sure this is happening and fear it is not. We also hear from people that work in the state systems that they fear parents are not paying enough attention to this. This is crucial. When we see kids thrown out of windows of housing projects because they will not steal candy, something is very wrong.
The decline in the social contract has nothing to do with class. On the wealth end we have people just absolutely forgetting their family responsibilities, not being home, having au pairs. The number of children not being held and missing out on the routine, daily music of parents, is very high in this state. We're not getting back to basic values and basic caring.
Q. How can you get parents more involved in the fate of children?
A. We launched a Parent Leadership Institute. They had lots of good ideas but invariably they would say, "Who are we? We're just parents."
Parents are the untapped jewelry box in this state in terms of a key constituency to determine what needs to happen. They don't feel they have the right to be involved and they don't have the skills of democracy to know how to influence and effect change in government for children. The institute is in its fourth year and we have waiting lists because parents are so eager to participate.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Elaine Zimmerman of the state's Commission on Children. (George Ruhe for The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Legislators Pass Bill Assessing Property

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE

 BODY:
A BILL to have Westchester reassess all its property and establish a system that shifts the burden of taxation away from homeowners has cleared what may be its last major hurdle.
The bill, advocated by a bipartisan coalition of county and state Legislators as well as County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke, was approved last week by the Democratic-controlled New York State Assembly. Earlier in the month, it was approved by the Republican-controlled State Senate and was endorsed by the County Board of Legislators. 
 If signed into law, as is expected, by Gov. George E. Pataki, the bill will be subject to approval by the County Board a second time. In the vote earlier in the month, the board was divided 10-7.
"This has been a long time in coming, and is still many years off from being implemented," said Philippe M. Gille, senior executive assistant to Mr. O'Rourke. "But at least at some point property taxes in this county will make sense."
Property in Westchester County is currently assessed by towns and cities, with assessors using different methods and assessing at different percentages of full value.
Proponents of the revaluation, who often call it "reval," say that many parcels have not been reassessed for years and that there are large disparities in taxes paid by owners of nearly identical parcels. The inequity of the tax-assessing system has led many owners of large commercial parcels as well as those of small residential ones to appeal successfully to officials or the courts for a tax reduction. This has led to an eroding of the tax base of the county as well as its local governments and school districts.
Westchester County annually pays out about $12 million in tax refunds; the local governments and school districts have had to make proportionately similar refunds.
Opponents of the revaluation fear the shift of the tax burden that the approved legislation will cause. The Builders Institute of Westchester and the County Chamber of Commerce were among a number of businesses that unsuccessfully lobbied the County Board against the plan, contending primarily that it allows businesses to be taxed at a higher rate than homeowners.
"If adopted and implemented, we believe it will seriously impact the county's economic growth potential and further erode the county's existing employer base," said Harold E. Vogt, president of the Chamber, in a letter to the Board.
Others expressed concern that the proposal did not adequately protect owners of cooperatives and condominiums.
Asked about these concerns, Mr. Gille said: "To the extent business says it is an attempt to shift the burden away from homeowners, that's true. But the Westchester business community has got to realize that if we continue to tax homeowners out of Westchester County there will be no one here to work for them or to buy their products." He called the suggestion that condominium and cooperative owners were not protected a "scare tactic."
The proposal calls for the following:
*All property in the county would be reassessed at full value during a three-year period. The estimated cost of this reassessment, $12 million to $25 million, will be paid for by the county. No changes in assessment rolls will be made until the entire county is reassessed.
*Once the assessments are completed, the information will be delivered to each taxing jurisdiction. This includes the county, towns and school districts that do not fall in one community. These taxing districts have the option of establishing a classification system for taxation. Under classification, homeowners, including owners of condominiums and cooperatives, can be charged a lower tax rate than businesses. Commercial property owners can see their taxes go up 25 percent, while homeowners can come down 25 percent, Mr. Gille said.
*Tax increases due to reassessment will be phased in over five years.
*For the purpose of setting taxes, all homeowners are given a 30 percent reduction on their property value (up to $35,000 in value) to offset any tax shift.
*Eligibility for tax exemptions for the elderly are expanded by allowing Westchester to use a higher income threshold for qualification.
The bill in the Assembly was sponsored by Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, Democrat of Greenburgh. Mr. Brodsky last year opposed a similar proposal but supported the plan this year after he amended it to protect homeowners further.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST HARLEM;
Pathmark Delayed as New $1 Million Loan Is Sought

BYLINE: By JANET ALLON

 BODY:
A year ago the Pathmark supermarket proposed for 125th Street and Lexington Avenue was debated not just in East Harlem but all over the city, and the subsidies, including grants and low-interest loans, that the project would receive were a focus of opponents' anger.
Now, groundbreaking, originally set for this summer, has been delayed at least until fall and possibly next spring, while the developers, a consortium of nonprofit groups called the East Harlem Abyssinian Triangle, await approval on an additional $1 million low-interest loan from an Empire State Development Corporation fund to finance job-creating public and private partnerships in economically distressed areas. State officials say approval is expected. The project's developers say they need the money to cover construction costs. 
 The request for more money has refueled some bitterness that local supermarket owners harbor toward the project. It is part of a $12 million financing package, about half of which includes government and private grants, a $1.5 million city loan at 1 percent interest, and promised tax breaks.
"Why are they getting additional money?" asked Richard Lipsky, who represented independent store owners in their unsuccessful fight to block city approval of the Pathmark. "We want the state to come up with a low-interest fund to encourage local entrepreneurship and to refinance all supermarket debt at 3 percent."
Luis Salcedo, the owner of the Bravo supermarket at 126th Street and Fifth Avenue, asked, "Why subsidize a big company when big companies abandoned this neighborhood?"
"There is so much that we could do with $12 million," Mr. Salcedo said. "Everyone talks about how we need a supermarket. What about education and housing? The taxpayers subsidized this project. I don't blame Pathmark, I blame the government. What we want is a level playing field."
A year ago, Community Board 11 passed a resolution that any project it approved had to guarantee that 25 percent of jobs would be filled by people from the neighborhood, where unemployment is 16 percent. Pathmark has promised that its project will go further, bringing 75 percent of the 200 post-construction jobs to East Harlem.
But owners of small neighborhood supermarkets and bodegas point out that since at least some, if not many, of their businesses will be forced to close in the face of Pathmark's competitive advantage, the loss of jobs could cancel out that benefit. "If it opens up, we will be out of business," Mr. Salcedo said.
One of East Harlem's major supermarket owners, Alfredo Rodriguez, sold the larger of his two Associated Supermarkets, at 122d Street at Third Avenue, immediately after the Pathmark deal was approved because he feared the store would lose value once Pathmark opened. The market is still open, under a new owner, and in the wake of the Pathmark delay, Mr. Rodriguez is holding on to his other store at 116th and Lexington. "I'm hanging in there to see if it gets built," he said. JANET ALLON

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MIDTOWN;
Coliseum 'Shrinks' to Gasps

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
The scene was like "Gulliver's Travels" meets "The Fountainhead." A giant architect looms over Manhattan and plucks the Coliseum, a legal, political and economic sore spot for nearly a decade, from Columbus Circle. He substitutes a sleeker and larger building complex.
In reality, the giant was a lanky architect, William Donohoe, working for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which owns the Coliseum. Last week, with the help of a three-dimensional cardboard model, Mr. Donohoe described the authority's latest guidelines for development of the Coliseum site. 
 The goal is to sell the building while avoiding the wrath of neighborhood advocates from the Upper West Side, Clinton and midtown, who had argued that earlier proposals cut off light and air and increased traffic congestion in Columbus Circle and surrounding blocks.
To Mr. Donohoe and other M.T.A. officials, the cardboard model represented how far the agency had come. But to the skeptical advocates, whose protracted lawsuit had helped to scuttle earlier development plans, the model was a map of how much farther the agency has to go.
When Mr. Donohoe removed the model of the million-square-foot Coliseum and inserted a mock-up of the first proposed replacement, a 925-foot-tall, 2.7-million-square-foot complex, the audience of community groups and others gasped at its size. They also shook their heads at what appeared to be only slightly smaller versions -- an 850-foot-tall complex and one at 752 feet. All three proposals, by Mortimer Zuckerman's Boston Properties, foundered in 1994, when Mr. Zuckerman and the city could not agree on a sales price.
The M.T.A's latest guidelines call for a complex no taller than 750 feet and no larger than 2.1 million square feet. And there are requirements intended to assuage community groups. Trucks, for example, would be unloaded away from Columbus Circle, to avoid slowing already sluggish traffic.
But Olive Freud, a neighborhood leader who was active in the 1989 lawsuit to stop the Coliseum project, was not satisfied. The complex, she said, would still be too tall and too big. "You think you've taught these people a lesson and they keep coming back," she said later. But she acknowledged that more litigation might be difficult to mount. "People get tired," she said.
Ross Graham, the head of a committee to review the Coliseum project for three community boards, said she has to "see how far the Mayor is supportive" of the M.T.A. proposal. As for the complex that could be built under the guidelines, "It's still awfully tall." ANTHONY RAMIREZ

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: JAMAICA;
Expectantly, York Awaits New Leader

BYLINE: By JANE H. LII

 BODY:
After a trying 14 months that saw the departures of one president and two acting presidents at York College, a student confrontation with the police and a significant budget cut, students and faculty members spoke optimistically last week about the impending arrival of their new president, Dr. Charles C. Kidd Sr.
"The morale is low on campus," said Andrea Jones, a sophomore majoring in social work at York, which is part of the City University. "We need someone to come in and give us a booster shot. He's done some creative things. You need somebody who can not only bring changes but also bring money." 
 Dr. Kidd, an environmental scientist, was most recently vice president of Florida A & M University. His academic specialty is a strong part of York's curriculum, and he has experience in community development. In a telephone interview from his home in Tallahassee, Fla., Dr. Kidd, 59, said he had accepted the presidency of York despite his knowledge of past troubles.
"We need to move beyond these problems very quickly," he said.
He said his priorities were to tap public funds for proposed expansion projects, to review plans for a joint program with the Food and Drug Administration and to improve communication between students, faculty and the administration.
Hubert Keen, the provost, said the college had suffered because of the lack of continuity during the transition. "We have suffered in gaining funds for planning," he said.
York College's troubles began in February 1995, when its president, Josephine D. Davis, was forced to resign amid allegations of financial improprieties. Last December, the acting president, Thomas K. Minter, resigned one month after a standoff between students, the police and college administrators over allowing Khalid Abdul Muhammad, a former aide to Louis Farrakhan, to deliver an address. The college gave in to the wishes of black and Hispanic students, who make up 65 percent of the student body, and he spoke.
Dr. Minter's successor, Marcia V. Keizs, worked to improve relations with students and to help finalize a master development plan, but she alienated a part of the faculty with her retrenchment plans.
Dr. Kidd "was the first choice among the finalists we were presented with," said Dr. Alan Cooper, a professor of English who is the faculty caucus leader and one of three faculty representatives who served on the search committee.
Carlisle Towery, executive director of the Greater Jamaica Redevelopment Corporation, said Dr. Kidd's impact would extend beyond York into neighborhood redevelopment.
Despite severe budget cuts that have already whittled the full-time faculty from 167 members to 159 in the last five years and removed $2.1 million from the operating budget of $24 million in 1995, Dr. Kidd will have to implement an ambitious master development plan that calls for enrollment to increase to as much as 10,000 from 6,500 by the year 2002. The plan also provides for business development of the college's boundaries on Guy R. Brewer Boulevard, a student center, expansion of the library and more parking.
"We have a number of strong departments and programs," he said. "We need to take advantage of the existing strengths and meet occupational needs obvious in urban areas such as Queens." JANE H. LII

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY & CO.
HEADLINE>Small Group in Hamilton Keeps a Mega-Store Out of Town

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH

DATELINE: HAMILTON

 BODY:
Until recently, the people of this sprawling suburb of Trenton had no reason to recognize Connie Silakoski. Then Mrs. Silakoski, a homemaker and mother of three, waged a battle against the nation's largest discount chain. These days, she is known as the woman who fought off Wal-Mart.
When Mrs. Silakoski, who lives on a cul-de-sac partly sheltered by woods and fields, learned that the retail giant was planning to build a store a half-mile from her house, she spun into action. In May, with the help of some neighbors, she circulated petitions and organized a rally that drew several hundred residents. On the eve of the local Memorial Day parade, she posted anti-Wal-Mart signs along the route. 
 "We were looking at the possibility of 90,000 cars a week passing through our residential neighborhood, where our children play," Mrs. Silakoski said, based on the results of a traffic study done by the town.. "It was too close to home for me to just sit back and let it happen."
Her efforts paid off: 10 days ago, the town planning board unanimously voted against rezoning two pieces of land on Yardville-Hamilton Square Road, just off Interstate 195, for commercial use. And Hamilton, population 87,000, became the latest of several towns that have fought Wal-Mart's efforts to establish a foothold in Central and North Jersey. Betsy Reithemeyer, a Wal-Mart spokeswoman, said the company still planned to build a store somewhere in the vicinity.
"There are many cases where someone is going to be opposed," Ms. Reithemeyer said. "But the majority is usually tickled. They want the additional tax revenue."
Wal-Mart has 14 stores in New Jersey, almost all are in the southern counties, where land is more available and less expensive. The northernmost stores are both on busy Route 1, in North Brunswick and Princeton. Although developers have tried to bring other Wal-Marts to North Jersey in recent years, the proposals keep falling through. Increasingly, the problem is opposition from homeowners like Mrs. Silakoski, who say a mega-store in their backyard would destroy their peace of mind, not to mention their property values.
In Raritan Township, Hunterdon County, plans for a Wal-Mart are on hold because of a disagreement between two property owners, said Robert Kren, the town planner. Meanwhile, a number of residents have expressed concern about the proposal, he said. In 1992, Paramus rejected plans for a Sam's Club warehouse store, part of a separate chain owned by Wal-Mart, because of local opposition.
"A lot of the suburban towns are going to be worried about traffic, congestion, perceived quality of life," said James W. Hughes, dean of the Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University. "Wal-Mart is going to have the most luck in towns that are desperately seeking ratables."
New Jersey is not the only Northeastern state Wal-Mart has set its sights on; it has focused on the entire region in recent years after several decades of expansion in the South and Midwest. (The company has more than 2,800 stores altogether, with annual sales of $93 billion last year.) It has opened 53 stores in Pennsylvania, 51 in New York and 6 in Connecticut, said a spokesman at the company's headquarters in Bentonville, Ark. While the stores have brought jobs and shoppers, they have also threatened the livelihood of small, local businesses, a factor that has brought citizens and business owners out in protest.
Resistance to Wal-Mart comes at a time when discount retailers are still thriving in New Jersey. Richard Brunelli, who owns a retail-leasing firm in Old Bridge, said the demand for "big box" retail stores, which take up more than 100,000 square feet, was stronger than ever. The financial struggles of smaller discount chains, like Jamesway and Caldor, have made room for more mega-stores, he said. But Wal-Mart cannot just take over the sites where these stores have closed, he said, because its stores are so much bigger. In most cases, he said, Wal-Mart would have to build from the ground up.
"Wal-Mart's success in North Jersey depends on its interest in dealing with very difficult planning boards and expensive real estate," Mr. Brunelli said. "They might not have the patience or the stomach to keep fighting it out."
In Hamilton, where only 18 percent of local tax revenues come from businesses, the Wal-Mart proposal was part of a larger plan to attract more retailers. (Developers had hoped to build a Home Depot down the street from the proposed Wal-Mart, but that plan was rejected, too.) The remaining 82 percent comes from residential property taxes, and municipal officials have warned that taxes will keep rising if the town does not attract more businesses.
John Bencivengo, executive director of the Hamilton Partnership, a nonprofit economic development group, said retailers had been "knocking down our door," and among other things, the town is considering a plan at the intersection of I-195 and Sloane Road for a 5,000-seat, 24-screen movie theater than could bring in $500,000 in ratables each year. The prospect of retail development still looms, since the town is rezoning two tracts of land along Route 130 (several miles from Mrs. Silakoski's house) from research-and-development to commercial use.
"Our town has been a bedroom community for years, and that has kept it clean and beautiful," Mr. Bencivengo said. "But if we don't bring in more businesses, the tax burden is going to make homeowners very unhappy."

HEADLINE: Old Guard;
Even in Slow-Motion, It's a Russian Revolution

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
WHEN the Soviet Union collapsed five years ago, many people not just Americans -- assumed that tomorrow had finally come to Russia. Just as Marxists view the withering of the state as a natural process of history, reformers regarded the end of Communist rule here as the final turn to the West.
They were wrong, of course, just as all those from Peter the Great on who would see Russia Westernized have always been wrong. But they weren't that wrong. Last week, despite fears of civil unrest, voter fraud and worse, 75 million citizens cast their ballots in independent Russia's first popular presidential election, which even fringe opposition groups acknowledge was free and fair. And on Thursday, under the kind of shadowy circumstances that have made the Kremlin an unparalleled touchstone of intrigue for hundreds of years, President Boris N. Yeltsin fired half of his top advisers at the insistence of the other half. 
 Only in Russia could a palace purge like that have democrats cheering in the streets.
 
 
 
Give It Time
 Watching the protracted and painful rebirth of this vast land is difficult for everybody. The place just doesn't fit any of the good-government notions of what a new democracy is supposed to look like. The media were totally rigged to support Mr. Yeltsin. It was nearly impossible to find on any wall in Moscow a poster of the Communist leader, Gennadi A. Zyuganov. Television was shameless in its endless attacks on the Communist past. But 20 years ago ward heelers from New York to Chicago got paid good money to keep the faces of rival candidates out of view, too.
So Russia is not a textbook democracy yet. It won't be one next year either. It may never happen. But there is still a revolution going on here right now; it's just not the type that happens in a week or a year. You can't even televise it, because this revolution will last at least a generation some people feel the future course of the nation won't begin to be clear until the people born after 1991 are old enough to run it.
"When the Berlin Wall fell down and then the Soviet Union disappeared, we all felt that the world was changed forever in every possible way," said Anatoly I. Antonov, head of the department of family sociology at Moscow State University. "Then we caught our breath. What we saw was the theoretical opportunity to take advantage of great change. But for most people there was no real way to do it. Humans can't move that fast. It may sound cruel, but the old generation will have to die before we can look at what is before us. This country is going to be divided for quite a while."
That was apparent from the first round of presidential voting last week. Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Zyuganov came in practically tied, and will face each other in a runoff on July 3.
Old people, scared of change, disgusted by their new poverty and yearning for a return to stability, voted in huge numbers for Mr. Zyuganov, who promised that the past would carry his supporters to the future. In one of history's strange ironies, the very rural communities that once battled with mutinous fury to prevent the Bolsheviks from confiscating their private land have become the last redoubts of Communism.
In the past, the cities, with their mighty industries and large proletariats, were the primary focus of Communist ideology and organization. Cities offered a prospect of well-being and privilege that the countryside never could. It was on farms, throughout the country, where peasants starved to death in the fields during much of the forced transition to Communism earlier this century.
But cities voted heavily for Mr. Yeltsin this time around, an outcome brought about in part by new population shifts from farms to cities, now that people are allowed to move about freely. To this small but growing group of new migrants, Mr. Yeltsin has held out more hope than any leader in Russian history.
It may seem obvious, but it is worth noting that young people don't want much to do with the Communists. Three quarters of all people under the age of 35 (and a greater percentage in the cities) voted for one of the three main non-Communist candidates -- Mr. Yeltsin; former Gen. Aleksandr I. Lebed, the law-and-order candidate, or the economic reformer Grigory Yavlinsky. Most experts here assume that in the second round Mr. Yeltsin will win by attracting supporters of the other two, especially those of Mr. Lebed, the strong third-place finisher who after the voting threw his support to Mr. Yeltsin in return for the top national-security post in Mr. Yeltsin's Government.
 
 
 
The Actuarial Factor
 It may seem odd to write the Communists out of the future just after their standard-bearer received 32 percent of the vote, particularly when the first-place finisher, Mr. Yeltsin, received only 35 percent. But Russia is a country where old people are dying off rapidly. The average life expectancy here for men, 57, is the worst in the industrial world; for women it is 70 -- better, but still no match for the West. Twenty years from now, almost half of the people who voted for Mr. Zyuganov last week (and who will undoubtedly vote for him again in the second round of voting) will be dead.
 That means the future probably belongs to somebody other than the Communists.
But it does not necessarily belong to democrats.
 First of all, Mr. Yeltsin is still detested widely here -- and he has not exactly been a fabulous advertisement for democracy. Even those liberal and young people who opposed Mr. Zyuganov frequently embraced some parts of his program. Most people here are suspicious of private property, wonder what was so bad about a system that supplied health care at low cost from birth to death, and hope that prices are once again reined in by the government. Those are ideas of social democrats, and if Mr. Zyuganov had emphasized them instead of spending so much time explaining all of Stalin's achievements he would likely have fared better in the first round of voting.
"We all know the old Communists are going to be gone in 20 years," said Roman Artemiev, the political editor of Daily Kommersant, which has become here something like what The Wall Street Journal is in the United States: essential reading for aspiring entrepreneurs, youthful tycoons and savvy managers. "What we don't know is what will come after them," Mr. Artemiev added. "Although that is not overtly the point of this election, it is the bottom line. If the Communists do manage to win they can create something new for themselves. If they lose, the numbers say they will lose forever. Then we will just have to find a future for ourselves."

SECTION: Section D; Page 7; Column 4; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1010 words

HEADLINE: All News, Almost All Profit, All the Time

BYLINE: By ROBIN D. SCHATZ 

 BODY:
Every morning, Edmond Garesche awakens in his Manhattan apartment to WCBS-AM, one of the city's three all-news radio stations, and listens for about two hours, as he lies in bed half-awake and then as he gets dressed for his job producing World Wide Web sites.
Mr. Garesche, 29, could surf the Internet to get the news he needs. He could turn to local news cable stations like New York 1 or national services like the Cable News Network and Headline News. Or, he could read a newspaper. 
 But Mr. Garesche, like millions of other Americans, remains a loyal listener of all-news radio, a staple of the nation's news diet since the 1960's.
Nothing satisfies the need for news as efficiently as an all-news radio station, said Mitchell Stephens, a New York University journalism professor, who has written about the history of broadcasting. "The radio niche is safe. As the baby boom ages and gets a little bored with hearing the same songs over and over again, these information formats become, for a while, even more attractive."
Fewer than four dozen stations in the country describe themselves as all-news, 11 of them owned by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, according to Arbitron, which provides ratings of radio broadcasters.
That is lower than in the 1970's and 80's; many stations have switched to what is known as a news-and-talk format, providing blocks of news in the morning and evening "drive times," with talk shows in the afternoon, evening and overnight.
While successful all-news stations thrive in virtually every major market, only a handful of cities support more than one. Washington once had three; now it has only WTOP-AM, owned by the Evergreen Media Corporation, and is struggling, ranking 15th in the market in the latest Arbitron ratings.
For many radio operators, the costs of all-news programming are just too high. Where a talk show pays its hosts and a music station its disk jockeys, a station providing 24 hours of news a day needs a team of journalists, a fleet of vehicles, a substantial amount of portable equipment and subscriptions to wire services.
Yet the all-news format remains attractive because it commands premium advertising rates, drawing a demographically attractive audience. Advertisers believe that listeners pay more attention to the content than they do to music stations, and all-news stations carry more advertising than music stations.
Generally, those who listen to all-news take that news in fairly small doses -- not surprising, given the repetitive nature of the format. Yet these stations have strong cumulative audiences, which Arbitron defines as the numbers of people who in the course of a week listen to a station for at least five minutes.
"This is the most stable and profitable format in radio," said Walter Sabo, a consultant in Manhattan.
In New York City, WINS-AM, which finished sixth in the latest ratings (WCBS-AM was seventh), reported advertising revenue last year of $29.3 million, making it the second-highest-grossing station in New York after the sports station WFAN-AM, and the third-highest-grossing station in the country, according to Duncan's Radio Market Guide. (The top-ranked station nationally is WGN-AM in Chicago.)
WINS abandoned rock-and-roll and switched to all-news in April 1965, and in November of that year made its mark as an important source of news when the Northeast was blacked out. Two years later, WCBS-AM converted to all-news.
Since last August, the two stations have been owned by Westinghouse, which paid $5.4 billion to acquire CBS Inc. (Last week, Westinghouse vastly increased its radio holdings, agreeing to pay $3.9 billion for Infinity Broadcasting, which has virtually no all-news programming.)
Westinghouse executives maintain that the merger with CBS has had no effect on program decisions at the all-news stations, which have competed vigorously for decades.
"Having two all-news stations in a market enables listeners to make choices," said Dan Mason, the CBS radio division president, "and that's the hallmark of local radio. We provide two types of services, similar to CNN and Headline News, if you will, and our audiences tell us there's room for and interest in both." Headline News reports the top news every 30 minutes; CNN adds in-depth coverage, features and commentary.
The CBS deal also left Westinghouse with the two major all-news stations in Los Angeles, KNX-AM and KFWB-AM. Roger Nadel, now vice president and general manager of KFWB, remembers the days when the station fought it out with CBS's KNX, which he ran from 1976 to 1989.
"With the change in ownership, I don't feel like that's who we're competing with anymore," he said. "My mission is to create new listeners, not compete for the same news listeners we've always had.
"If a million people are listening to KFWB and a million to KNX, that means nine million people aren't. My mission is to get those other nine million who aren't using news on the radio to understand the benefits of it."
In the New York metropolitan area, WINS is stronger in the five boroughs, nearby parts of New Jersey and Nassau County, where its signal is clearest, the general manager, Scott Herman, said; WCBS-AM does better in the rest of the area.
A third news station was established in New York three years ago, when Bloomberg L.P., which compiles business data and offers various news services, bought an AM station, renaming it WBBR.
The station has never done well in the ratings, and recently began cutting back on its stock market reports, increasing traffic and weather coverage. In the most recent Arbitron report, WBBR ranked 35th, with 342,000 listeners a week, compared with 2.4 million at WINS and 2 million at WCBS-AM.
Mr. Herman said he was not worried about Bloomberg as a competitor and had no plans to change a formula that has served well against WCBS for decades.
"We're quicker in our approach and very thematically consistent," he said. "We do the same thing every 20 minutes, 24 hours a day, seven days a week."

HEADLINE: Tool Orders Lower in May

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: MCLEAN, Va., June 23

 BODY:
Orders for industrial tools made in the United States dropped 11 percent in May from the previous month, even as demand from abroad soared, the Association for Manufacturing Technology said today. Machine tool orders declined to $381.25 million in May after dipping to $428.55 million in April. Last month's orders, though tepid compared with the earlier months of 1996, were still seven-tenths of 1 percent higher than those in May 1995.

HEADLINE: Andreas Papandreou, Greek Leftist Who Admired and Annoyed U.S., Dies at 77

BYLINE: By MARLISE SIMONS 

 BODY:
Andreas Papandreou, the former Prime Minister of Greece and a maverick who towered over Greek political life for more than two decades, died yesterday in Athens. He was 77.
His symptoms "were compatible with a heart attack, which finally caused his death at 2:30 A.M.," his doctors said in a statement. 
 Open heart surgery in 1988 had left Mr. Papandreou weakened, although it did not stop him from entering and winning elections for the third time in 1993.
But during 1995, his failing health prevented him from performing the normal duties of Government, leaving Greece flailing. He worked at home for just a few hours a day and rarely appeared in public. Yet even as his fiery voice, which could mesmerize the nation, had thinned to a near whisper and he walked with great difficulty, Mr. Papandreou refused to step aside or name a deputy to run the Government.
Finally, in January, his Socialist Party named Costas Simitis as Prime Minister, and Mr. Papandreou had not been seen in public since his release from a hospital on March 21 after a four-month stay.
Few other politicians in modern Greece have inspired as much love and loathing at home and as much bewilderment and irritation abroad. The tall figure with bushy eyebrows fascinated Greeks with his compelling oratory and his unpredictable and volatile ways, and even though he became as familiar as a close relative, he remained hard to fathom even for his friends.
He was successful at home because he appealed to Greece's thirst for change, and his nationalist polemics appealed to the Greeks' perennial feeling of being misunderstood and unappreciated.

Maverick Stances Angered His Allies
Abroad, Greece's Western allies were befuddled or exasperated as the undoctrinaire Socialist took positions diametrically opposed to theirs, on issues ranging from Serbian aggression in Bosnia to the role of NATO in the Mediterranean.
Above all, the United States loomed large in his life, for that was the country where he had served in the Navy, graduated from college, worked, married twice and had four children; it was his source of financing and the nation that he first admired and later railed against.
The core of his foreign policy was to end Greece's status as "a client state of the West." As a result, he refused to condemn the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan, campaigned against American military bases in Greece and variously threatened to pull out of NATO, the United Nations and the European Union, although he accepted the Union's generous funds.
He blocked European credits for Turkey, Greece's enemy. While others shunned Libya and Yugoslavia, he improved his ties there. In the Bosnian war he supported Serbia, a neighbor and longtime ally, and opposed international sanctions against Serbia. He was reluctant to condemn Serbian atrocities, even in the face of ample evidence.
Mr. Papandreou thrived on being contrary. He described this as "tightrope diplomacy." Until the collapse of the Soviet Union, he was especially skillful at profiting and extracting funds from fearful Western governments that wanted to strengthen Greece's capitalist system and protect Europe's southeastern flank in the Communist Balkans. Despite his polemics, he remained pro-Western.

A Family Tradition Of Populist Politics
The only son of Sophia and George Papandreou, Andreas George Papandreou was born on Feb. 5, 1919, on Chios, while his father served at the time as governor general of the Aegean Islands.
When Andreas was 5, his parents were divorced, and he and his mother moved to Athens. But he stayed in touch with his father, who rose in politics and became a powerful and popular leader, eventually becoming Prime Minister.
In 1937, when Andreas entered Athens University Law School, Greece was ruled by a right-wing dictator, Gen. Ioannis Metaxas, and his father and other liberals were banished to the island of Andros. Andreas, by then a Trotskyite, joined a resistance group that distributed underground newspapers and pamphlets, for which he was arrested and tortured.
Shortly before Mussolini's troops entered Greece, Andreas Papandreou left for New York, where he arrived in May 1940 with $14 in his pocket. He enrolled at Columbia University and took odd jobs to support himself. He married a Greek-American, Christine Rassias, in 1941 and earned a doctorate in economics at Harvard University in 1943. The marriage ended in divorce a decade later.
After becoming an American citizen, Mr. Papandreou joined the Navy for two years of wartime service, much of which he spent as a clerk in the Bethesda Naval Hospital. When World War II ended, he started his career as a lecturer in economics, first at Harvard then at the University of Minnesota and Northwestern University. He eventually became a professor and the chairman of the department of economics at the University of California at Berkeley, until he resigned in 1963.
Meanwhile he had met Margaret Chant, of Elmhurst, Ill., a former journalism student. After both obtained divorces, they were married in Nevada in 1951. They settled down in Berkeley, raised three sons and a daughter and became actively involved in liberal American politics.
It was with the help of American funds that Mr. Papandreou returned to Greece. Supported by Guggenheim and Fulbright grants, he spent 1959 studying the Greek economy. He went to Athens again in 1961 to set up the new Center for Economic Research, this time with financing from the Ford and Rockefeller Foundations. He handed back his American citizenship in 1964 to run for Parliament under the auspices of his father, the Prime Minister. Later that year his father named him Deputy Minister of Economics.
But King Constantine, who distrusted both Papandreous, dismissed the Prime Minister and his Cabinet. The period of instability that followed led to a right-wing military coup in 1967, and both Papandreous were arrested. The younger Papandreou was kept in solitary confinement for eight months.
Again the United States loomed large. Pressure from influential Americans, including the economist John Kenneth Galbraith, led the military junta to release Andreas Papandreou and other political prisoners in 1967. But from exile, first in Sweden, then in Canada, Mr. Papandreou organized a coalition of opposition groups and denounced the American Government for "complicity" in the coup. He remained convinced that Washington quietly supported the 1968-74 military dictatorship.
In a 1972 article in The New York Times, he wrote that the United States approved prime ministers, interfered in elections and in military promotions and "controlled the Greek Intelligence Service."
In 1974, when Greece was traumatized by Turkey's invasion of northern Cyprus, he and many others were convinced once again that Washington knew about the Turkish military plans and could have stopped them. The belief that in general Washington favored Turkey over Greece in their perennial squabbling fed more anti-Americanism.

Party Transformed Greece's Landscape
The party he founded in 1974, the Panhellenic Socialist Movement, or Pasok, changed Greece's political landscape. It brought him -- and the left -- to power in 1981. Describing himself as a "nondogmatic Marxist" he quickly introduced social reforms that benefited low-income groups, promoted workers' councils and farmers' cooperatives, abolished censorship, lowered the voting age to 18; prompted by his American wife, he brought legal equality for women.
As soon as he took office after the 1981 elections, Mr. Papandreou tweaked the West by opening a Greek Embassy in Cuba and granting diplomatic status to the Palestine Liberation Organization.
Behind his neutralist gestures, Mr. Papandreou's foreign policy was cautious, almost conservative. He kept Greece in NATO, but refused to take part in some exercises. He preserved Greece's membership in the European Union, thus obtaining important agricultural subsidies that helped ensure his re-election in 1985. He also gave Washington what it had not been able to obtain from his right-wing predecessor: a five-year renewable agreement to retain four military bases and a number of smaller installations on Greek soil.
At home, many Greeks applauded him because he established civil marriage and legalized divorce and abortion. But his economic policy remained full of contradictions, and critics said that he squandered power, opportunities and money.
For all his calls for change and generous financial support of the European Union, Greece remains the Union's poorest nation. Of the $12 billion the Community lent Mr. Papandreou in the 1980's to modernize, diplomats in Brussels said 80 percent was spent on consumption and salaries for political featherbedding.
As opposition leader and as Prime Minister, he lashed out against the corruption of his predecessors, but his own government unraveled in the late 1980's in a series of scandals involving fraud and telephone-tapping.
His prestige also suffered because he publicly flaunted his affair with Dimitra Liani, a flight attendant half his age, while he was still married to his wife of 38 years. After humiliating publicity, Margaret Papandreou, the mother of his four adult children, agreed to a divorce in 1989.
By late 1989, he could no longer withstand the cascade of scandals and he lost the elections. Parliament indicted Mr. Papandreou and ordered him and four of his former ministers to stand trial on charges including bribery and embezzlement. He repeatedly protested his innocence, saying that American agents were trying to "destabilize" Greece and that his opponents were out to destroy him politically.
Mr. Papandreou was narrowly acquitted in 1992, but two of his ministers were convicted.
Yet on Oct. 10, 1993, Mr. Papandreou made an astonishing comeback. Though he had recently had a heart operation, taken Ms. Liani as his third wife, built a mansion costing more than $1 million and never quite shaken off corruption charges, he won election for the third time.
This was perhaps his most remarkable trait, the ability to change position and survive scandal and indictment without losing popularity.
"He was an amazing politician," said Nicholas Gage, author of several books on Greece and a former New York Times correspondent there. "He made ordinary people feel they mattered. Above all he was a master at tapping the mood of the moment and at adapting his views to that."

Progress Overtaken By Host of Scandals
During his 10 years in office, he modernized Greece, but not enough to pull it from the doldrums. Rather than cutting back the country's enormous and rigid bureaucracy, he bloated it further to capture votes. Although Mr. Papandreou inherited a patronage system where a politician is expected to provide a job for every supporter, many economists agree that he did little to change this; some say he expanded it.
Some of Mr. Papandreou's supporters believe that his successes and his strong leadership in balancing an unruly society have been unfairly overshadowed by his governments' financial scandals and by troubles involving his wives.
Although extramarital affairs are common in Greek politics, Mr. Papandreou broke the rules by publicly displaying his liaison with Ms. Liani. Greek women, in particular, did not pardon this affront to his wife, a strong voice for social reform and women's rights.
In 1995, he was criticized by supporters and opponents for naming his new wife director of his office and giving her much power over access to him. He caused further outcry by saying he would support her if she had political ambitions.
The fallout was intense. One result was that his longtime ally, George Kouris, publisher of the newspaper Avriani, regularly published nude pictures of a young Ms. Liani, hoping to undermine the Prime Minister and to block her political career.
Last year, friends said, even as his health was waning, Mr. Papandreou aspired to become President -- a largely ceremonial post -- when Constantine Karamanlis's term expired in May. But the struggle to succeed Mr. Papandreou as party and Government leader was so fierce that he reportedly feared a breakup of the party and renounced his aspiration.
Over the years, he published a number of articles and books on economic and political themes, including the successful "Democracy at Gunpoint" and "Paternalistic Capitalism."
In addition to his wife, Ms. Liani, he is survived by his four children from his second marriage, to Margaret Chant: George, who is Greece's Minister of Education, Sophia, Nicholas and Andreas.

HEADLINE: Media: PRESS;
In Canada, concerns about consolidation.

BYLINE: By Clyde H. Farnsworth 

DATELINE: TORONTO

 BODY:
IN his 1993 memoir "A Life in Progress," the publisher Conrad M. Black describes his efforts to clean up a local lake when he was the co-proprietor of his first weekly newspaper east of Montreal.
"Like Orson Welles in 'Citizen Kane' saying, 'People will think what I tell them to think,' " he wrote, "I launched a violent campaign against the 'mismanagers of the dying lake.' " The lake was cleaned up. 
 A quarter-century later, Mr. Black, 51, who now controls 58 of Canada's 104 daily newspapers and 40 percent of the nationwide circulation, insists that Charles Foster Kane is no longer his role model.
"The only way to build and maintain a great newspaper franchise is to earn and maintain a reputation for fairness, liveliness and insight," he said in a brief interview after the annual meeting of Hollinger Inc., his publishing group, earlier this month.
Hollinger has grown into the western world's third-largest newspaper chain after the Gannett Company and Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, and with its latest deal to acquire the Southam chain's 20 Canadian dailies, Mr. Black has been pointedly criticized by some Canadians for his domination of the newspaper industry and his shedding of jobs.
 Although Canada's antitrust watchdogs have given Mr. Black a green light, some public officials and union officers express worry.
"There's absolutely no printed voice in my region that doesn't track back to Conrad Black," said John Bryden, a Liberal Member of Parliament from the southern Ontario district of Hamilton-Wentworth, where Hollinger owns the daily and four weeklies.
Tom Kent, a former federal official who headed a royal commission on newspapers in 1981, says, "What we're going to get, I'm afraid, is editors all in the image of how Conrad Black sees how the newspaper business should be."
Mr. Black is a man of strong, conservative views, about, for example, the benefits of free enterprise and the dangers of big government, and is not at all bashful about expressing them. For many in a country that is traditionally more interventionist in economic and social policy than the United States, his views cut the wrong way.
As The Globe and Mail, a Toronto paper owned by the Thomson Corporation, noted editorially, "Much of the gnashing of teeth and rending of garments has, of course, not been about concentration at all: it has been about Conrad Black proper."
At the Hollinger annual meeting, Mr. Black denounced what he called a "cabal" of the old guard management at Southam.
"It has been our impression that Southam management long accepted inadequate returns for the shareholders, published generally undistinguished products for readers and received exaggerated laudations from the working press for the lack of financial and editorial rigor," he said.
In almost the same breath he chastised journalists, saying they "could stand a good solid elementary course in reporting, fairness, objectivity, giving people the benefit of the doubt, occasionally emphasizing the positive, not exciting the endemic Canadian spirit of envy."
Yet Mr. Black insists that he's the best friend of Canadian journalists. "In nearly 30 years of newspaper ownership, we have rarely sold and never closed a daily newspaper." No one else, he notes, is buying newspapers in Canada.
But some journalists are wary nonetheless. They fear that to pay for his takeovers he will "slash and burn the operations of these papers to get a quick profit," Peter Murdoch, a representative of the Communications, Energy and Paperworkers Union, said at the Hollinger meeting.
Mr. Black responded that he had no plans to cut more staff. "There is pressure to get an adequate return, and an adequate return can be achieved chiefly by improving the quality of the product."
In addition to his Canadian holdings, Mr. Black controls The Chicago Sun-Times, 109 other American dailies, the Telegraph group in London, The Jerusalem Post and The Sydney Morning Herald in Australia, as well as the leading papers in Vancouver, Edmonton, Ottawa and Calgary, and all the dailies in Saskatchewan, Prince Edward Island and Newfoundland.
The Government has said it sees no threat to business competition in the newspaper industry, because, as Industry Minister John Manley told the House of Commons, Canadians are "surrounded by newspapers and other media and means of exchanging information."
Concentration is in part blamed on 1965 income tax legislation that bars Canadian advertisers from getting tax deductions from ads in foreign-owned publications. Foreign ownership is defined in the law as anything more than 25 percent, so the legislation has had the effect of keeping Canadian media in Canadian hands.
"That's something that the Government would want to take into account once we've had an adequate opportunity to look at whether that would in fact create additional sources of news and information," Mr. Manley said.
After the Hollinger annual meeting, Mr. Black asked, "If we're the only people buying, where am I a menace to the public interest?"

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Superstores Set Stage For the Political Sell

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
New Yorkers want it all when it comes to shopping, says the Manhattan Borough President, Ruth W. Messinger. They want superstores with big selections and low prices, but they also want the cozy shops that give neighborhoods texture. They want all the possible economic blessings from New York City's plan to allow giant superstores into underused manufacturing zones, but none of the pinch if smaller stores get hurt by the competition.
And they should have it, according to a report to be issued today by Ms. Messinger's office. That, she says, means something of the rezoning plan should change. 
 But with officials in the administration of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani united behind the rezoning plan, which is scheduled to come up for a vote before the Planning Commission this fall, Ms. Messinger's critique -- however minimal -- was creating a tempest in a shopping cart even before its official release.
Administration officials said that Ms. Messinger, like the shoppers she describes, is trying to have it all -- trying to increase her popularity in preparation for a mayoral run by hopping on the megastore bandwagon, and at the same time trying to pretend that she and Mr. Giuliani are not both moderates on the issue.
Fran Reiter, the Deputy Mayor for economic development and planning, even mentioned having seen Ms. Messinger at the Fairway Market in Harlem, a mega-grocery store that serves as a symbol for both sides of the rezoning debate.
"I do find it a little ironic that Ruth likes to shop at Fairway," Ms. Reiter said. "She loves to shop at Fairway and I have run into her there. I would suggest that she may be making an issue where there isn't an issue."
Ms. Messinger, who maintains that big new supermarkets are not the kind of stores she has a problem with, says her report pinpoints real flaws in the rezoning plan.
"What's wrong is to stage this as the Oklahoma land rush," Ms. Messinger said. "The Mayor is devoting all his policy effort to make it possible for superstores to locate all over the city with no guidance -- as of right," she added. "We need to encourage superstore development, but not where it will hurt existing uses."
Ms. Messinger's report, based on a survey of shoppers and stores, concludes something that would be hard to dispute: that many smaller retailers feel threatened by the prospect of big store competition and that poorer New Yorkers are more dependent on those smaller stores.
It also says that the rezoning plan -- or the next Mayor of New York if it turns out to be her -- must shore up and protect that important base of small-store assets. The report offers many proposals for protecting smaller retailers but premises the need for that help on the storeowners' fears.
Ms. Reiter said that, while she has not seen the report, basing conclusions on what people believe or fear might happen because of rezoning is flawed methodology.
She said the studies by the administration had shown that despite small merchant's fears, there is evidence to the contrary -- that retailing expansion creates new opportunities for all sorts of companies. And she rejected the land-rush analogy, saying the Mayor's rezoning plan is moderate and targeted, limited only to certain kinds of manufacturing areas.
One of the central open questions of rezoning is whether more superstores would level the playing field between New York City and the suburbs or simply cannibalize the existing urban market.
Ms. Messinger's report concludes that small merchants believe that city superstores would directly compete with other city retailers, but it also concedes that perceptions by merchants in New York are a bit fuzzy when it comes to identifying their own problems.
For instance, of the retailers surveyed in Manhattan, for example, 62 percent said they believed they would lose business to stores in the suburbs. But only 37 percent of their customers say they actually ever go to the suburbs to shop. In Brooklyn, by contrast, only 27 percent of the retailers said the suburban stores were a threat, but 50 percent of their customers say they go beyond the city to shop.
"This is not drawing sides with the administration," Ms. Messinger said. "But we ought to focus on all the kinds of shopping that exist here, not just the kind that could have some potential for expansion -- customers say we need both."
