LENGTH: 1256 words

HEADLINE: POLITICS: CAMPAIGN FINANCE;
Senate to Debate Bill to Ban 'Soft Money' From Elections

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 23

 BODY:
While President Clinton and Bob Dole shake the corporate and union trees for campaign money in New York on Monday, the Senate will begin debating legislation that would ban the practice and create voluntary limits on Congressional campaign spending.
For more than 70 years, corporations and unions have been barred from contributing to Federal elections -- at least in theory. But in recent years those entities, along with rich individuals, have gotten around the restrictions by giving vast sums to the political parties, which spend it for purposes other than winning Federal elections -- at least in theory. 
 Eliminating this kind of campaign cash, known as "soft money," is a major objective of the bill sponsored by Senators John McCain, a Republican of Arizona, and Russell Feingold, a Democrat of Wisconsin. The Republican National Committee strongly opposes this provision.
Mr. Feingold said last week that the soft-money provision was among the more popular in the bill and provoked a strong spirit of compromise. Other provisions, like the spending limits and the free broadcast time awarded by several networks to candidates who abide by them, are likely to meet opposition.
The Senate will debate the bill on Monday, and then vote on blocking a threatened filibuster on Tuesday. Senator Mitch McConnell, a Republican of Kentucky who leads the opposition, says the measure is an unconstitutional abrogation of the public's right to "participate in the political process." He said he was confident the move to end debate would fail and the bill would die. Mr. Feingold disagreed, contending "we've got a chance" to get the 60 votes required, and Mr. McCain said their odds were improving.
House action is even less certain, with no debate scheduled before mid-July, which could move the debate into a time perilously close Election Day for such an intensely political measure.
In the meantime, both Mr. Clinton, who has endorsed the McCain-Feingold bill, and Mr. Dole, who has taken no position, are raising soft money as if reform were only a day away.
Each hopes to raise as much as $3 million on Monday, sums that could then be spent on vaguely defined party-building activities, which range from administrative costs at headquarters to registration drives.
Such soft-money contributions are skyrocketing, up by 103 percent from our years ago.
The corporate donors describe their motivations simply. Peggy Carter, director of legal, regulatory and science issues for RJR Nabisco, said, "Contributions are an ageless part of the democratic process in this country."
RJR Nabisco, the tobacco and food products conglomerate, gave $831,053 to the two parties in the 15 months ending March 31, 84 percent of it to Republicans. Ms. Carter refuted what she called a public "assumption all of a sudden someone is for sale" when corporations give such large sums to the parties. She contended that contributions "allow us to get our toe in the door" and "present our side of the issue."
At first, the post-Watergate election law of 1974 seemed to halt this kind of giving. Under that law, reporting requirements for donors, parties and candidates became stricter. Corporations and unions created political action committees that could accept no more than $5,000 from each donor.
But in 1988 Robert Farmer, treasurer of the Dukakis presidential campaign, figured out that there was no prohibition on raising money for "party-building." Using that logic, the Democrats were the first to raise "soft money," most of which was funneled to states that did not prohibit accepting union or corporate money.
When Republicans saw what Mr. Farmer was doing, they quickly followed suit, and the theoretical ban on corporate and union money began to fade away. Soft money clearly "comes from sources that the law sought to foreclose," said Anthony Corrado, a professor of political science at Colby College.
"This is the purest form of corruption," said Fred Wertheimer, the longtime advocate of campaign law change and former president of Common Cause. Pointing to Mr. Clinton and Mr. Dole, as well as House Speaker Newt Gingrich and Vice President Gore, he said, "The most powerful players are out raising Watergate-size and Watergate-style contributions."
The McCain-Feingold bill would prohibit the national parties from touching contributions in excess of the Federal limits, meaning no corporate or union money whatsoever and no more than $20,000 from an individual.
In this election season, donations are up. Philip Morris Companies have contributed $1,687,478 to political parties during the 15 months ending March 31.
George Knox, a vice president at Philip Morris, said the conglomerate had given so much because "we hope to get good government out of participating in the process."
Mr. Knox said that while he could not say whether the threat of Food and Drug Administration action against cigarettes had influenced the size of the political contributions, Philip Morris did seek to "encourage those who are in general philosophical agreement with us, to sort of keep them going."
Mr. Knox said that 88 percent of its party money went to Republicans because "the Republican Party is generally more oriented toward business."
Arco, the oil, gas and chemical company, has given the parties $653,175 in the 15-month period, with 62 percent of it going to Republicans. Albert Greenstein, its director of media relations, said the donations helped Arco directly "in several ways. They let individuals know that Arco has an ongoing interest in the political process, a desire to participate and be consulted in major issues."
He said the donations gave Arco access to politicians "the same way that all contributors can get access." He said, "We're a very politically active committee. We're quite proud of that."
Alone as a bipartisan donor among the biggest givers is AT&T, which gave only 53 percent of its $705,684 to Republican party groups. Mike Brown, vice president for Federal legislation, said the company contributed in part because it wanted to sell long-distance service and computers to the parties.
"We're very ecumenical," he said. "We like to be seen as a good corporate citizen. We fund a great deal of activities, whether it's the Olympics or county fairs in Bergen, N.J."
Mr. Brown said the contributions were not a device to advance the company's interests in legislation. "I'm the chief legislative officer," he said, and "we have not to my knowledge been talking legislative issues with officers of the parties."
One of the few heavy donors to give more money to Democrats is Joseph E. Seagram & Sons. The liquor, beer and wine company gave 62 percent of its $460,000 in party gifts to Democrats. Amy Goldberger, media relations director for the company, refused to discuss contributions.
But even some critics of the system doubt the bill is the best solution. Professor Corrado, for example, said that he believed corporate campaign donations could never be suppressed. If it cannot, he said, "I'd rather see it all coming in to Washington" where it could be regulated.
Senator McConnell said that if the contribution limits were raised and then indexed to inflation, he might be able to support a soft-money ban. The current limits have been unchanged since 1974, even though inflation has reduced their value by at least two-thirds. Senator McConnell said he would insist that any limit on how much parties may spend to help candidates be eliminated by this bill.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: A Factory Is Losing Its Name. Workers Ask What's Left.

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
The New York Yankees never talked about the Boston Red Sox with the same venom that the 700 workers at the Farberware factory -- another Bronx fixture -- reserve for a Boston-based entrepreneur named Leonard Florence.
"He's an exterminator," said Jorge Rodriguez, a packaging worker who fears that the cookware plant, the borough's largest factory, will soon close forever. "He doesn't care about the people here. He just cares about money." 
 "He is a liquidator," added Ben Camadeco, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters' local representing Farberware workers. "He is the worst individual I have ever come across."
This vitriol is aimed at the rags-to-riches entrepreneur who Farberware workers say has all but signed their factory's death warrant. Mr. Florence, who purchased Farberware's name and assets in April, says he is stunned and wounded by all the nastiness emanating from the Bronx.
After all, he has grown accustomed to acclaim, not disdain, as his reputation grows as a Boston philanthropist. Tufts University has named a lecture hall after him, he runs an annual fund raiser for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston, and Pope John Paul II has named him a Knight of St. Gregory for his fund-raising for Catholic institutions.
To Mr. Florence, the Farberware situation is a horrible misunderstanding. Eager to save his reputation, he insists he is the workers' friend and sincere about cooperating with them to keep the plant open.
"I've spent years building my reputation -- someone didn't give it to me on a silver spoon," said Mr. Florence, chairman of the Syratech Corporation, which manufactures and markets silver goods. "And now I've really been beaten up."
Many workers say he deserves the thrashing because his decision to license the Farberware name to another cookware company means that the Bronx plant, the country's only Farberware factory, has scant chance of survival. They may still have the expertise and equipment to make pots and pans, but stripped of the Farberware name, they are convinced that stores will not stock their wares, shoppers will not buy them, and Mr. Florence will ultimately close the plant.
Many workers have a hard time holding back tears when they discuss their uncertain future. Carlos Rivera, a worker on the polishing line, talks of the factory as a "second home" and "second family." Khaleel Desaque, who has worked at Farberware for half his 48 years, fears he will no longer be able to afford college for his son if he loses his $25,000-a-year job. And Michael Filippou, a mechanic, is alarmed that he might lose his medical insurance before his wife gives birth this fall.
There is another potential victim, the South Bronx. Losing the squat, brick factory on Bruckner Boulevard and its $30 million annual payroll would be a stinging setback to a neighborhood that is beginning to climb back from the bottom.
When Syratech acquired Farberware's name and machinery, many workers looked to Mr. Florence as a savior for the struggling factory. At meetings with state, city and union officials, he proposed transforming the factory into an employee-owned plant that would supply Syratech with cookware to market.
"We were very upbeat," said George Miranda, a teamsters' official. "He said all the right things."
New York State tapped a financial expert, Eugene Keilin, to flesh out an employee-ownership plan that proposed ways to cut the plant's costs by more than $5 million each year to make it solidly profitable.
But when government and union officials met with Mr. Florence on May 31 to discuss the plan, he dropped the bombshell. He announced that Syratech had licensed the Farberware name for 200 years to another cookware company. He declined to disclose details, but word around the industry is he licensed the name to a Hong Kong manufacturer for a large profit.
The workers felt betrayed, that their company's soul had been sold. Many view his talk of making the factory employee-owned -- a plan he still stands behind -- as a hollow offer now that the cookware is shorn of its Farberware name.
"If he had said, 'I'm going to buy Farberware and do with it whatever I want to make the most money,' we wouldn't have been happy but we would have understood somewhat," said Harry Kokkinis, an economic adviser to the teamsters. "But, no, he approached us and said, 'Let's investigate this employee-ownership idea.' He carried on a cruel charade. He lied to us."
Mr. Florence's licensing move largely severs Farberware's ties to the city where an immigrant Russian peddler, Simon Farber, founded the company 99 years ago.
"If the poor man came back from his grave, he'd be ashamed about what's happening," said Pierre Zimmerli, who runs the factory's welding operations. "Someone could make good money with this factory, but without the Farberware name, we're kaput."
Government and union officials say that if the plant's previous owner, U.S. Industries, had only contacted them before selling Farberware's assets to Syratech, they could have come up with the money to buy the plant and guarantee its future.
"The message that everybody should take from this is, 'Please come to talk to us before these things happen,' " said Charles Millard, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation. "There is a lot the city can do. It's a lot easier for us to do them before things reach the precipice."
City officials fear the workers' vituperative words will make Mr. Florence less willing to work with them to keep the plant alive. Indeed, he said in an interview, "If they continue to beat me up, I'll just take my machinery and go away."
An affable man known for his marketing expertise, he insists the workers can still make a go of it if they persuade a celebrity like Martha Stewart to put her name on the factory's cookware.
Mr. Florence loves to talk about how he started out shining shoes at age 12. A businessman was so impressed on meeting him that he paid his way through college and hired him afterward to turn around an ailing silver goods company. When he did, his boss awarded him with a half-stake in the company. By age 29, Mr. Florence was a millionaire.
He expanded that silver company by merging it with Towle, a silversmith dating from 1690. But in 1985, Towle stumbled badly, and he was fired as chairman. The next year, Mr. Florence founded Syratech, building it up to a $170 million company with 40 percent of the nation's silverware market. In 1990, he got his revenge against Towle by acquiring it for $20 million.
Mr. Florence said his decision to license the Farberware name was a smarter move for Syratech shareholders "than egotistically betting the company's entire Farberware investment on the self-confident assumption" that it could run the factory at a strong profit when previous owners were unable to.
As evidence that he is sincere about helping the workers, Mr. Florence points to his offer to lease the factory's machinery to them for three years rent-free so they can continue production. He says Syratech is willing to market the cookware, under whatever name.
The workers are perplexed by his assertions that they can salvage the plant when he had bad-mouthed it as a money-loser with uncompetitive costs. He said the factory's $15,000-a-week security bill and $12,000-a-week trash removal costs were exorbitant, and New York's electricity rates triple those of many other communities. Another problem was the lack of a warehouse nearby.
"The problem is they have not been competitive, nor have they been making money," he said.
Last year the factory barely broke even, although it sold a record $100 million worth of cookware. But Mr. Keilin said the plant can become profitable through his cost-cutting proposals, which include cutting the cost of trash removal by 40 percent, electricity by 25 percent, labor by 20 percent and security by 15 percent.
City, state and Federal officials have proposed another way to bolster profits by $1 million yearly. The Federal empowerment zone that covers parts of Manhattan and the Bronx could be redrawn to include the factory, a move that would provide a $4,000 yearly tax credit for each employee living in the zone.
"The big picture is you can operate this plant profitably," Mr. Keilin said. "Why weren't costs reduced in the past? It's because no one asked."
"New York will never be the manufacturing center it was in the first half of this century," he continued. "But there are a lot of things we can do here. We make up in skills, market access and transportation what we give up in costs."
City and state leaders are beseeching celebrities to lend their names to the factory's cookware and asking department stores to hire it to produce their cookware lines. So far, they have had only a few nibbles of interest.
"We're trying everything possible to keep it going," said Charles A. Gargano, the state's top economic development official. "We've made an appeal to the business community to look into investing here. We're asking celebrities to step up to the plate. It is a dire situation. There are 700 good jobs on the line."

HEADLINE: An Ad Accuses Companies Of Overcharging for Drugs

BYLINE: By MARGARET ISA 

 BODY:
The wealthy Omaha industrialist Phil Sokolof, whose full-page newspaper advertisements in 1988 accused food marketers of poisoning Americans with saturated fats, is at it again. In a fresh round of ads that he said cost him more than $550,000, Mr. Sokolof is accusing Merck & Company of charging too much for cholesterol-lowering medications.
The new advertisement, with the headline "The Gouging of America," appears today in The New York Times on page A16, and is scheduled to appear in about 40 other major newspapers, including The Wall Street Journal, USA Today and The Los Angeles Times, Mr. Sokolof said. 
 The advertisement chides Merck, whose cholesterol-lowering drugs Zocor and Mevacor generated $3.2 billion in sales in 1995, for raising prices again this year. "Merck, how greedy can you get?" the ad says.
The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company, also mentioned in the ad, makes the drug Pravachol. Telephone calls to the company seeking comment were not returned.
Mr. Sokolof, 73, said he has put more than $8 million into the National Heart Savers Association, which he founded in 1985, to wage a fight against cholesterol, after a 10-year Government study linked high cholesterol to heart attacks in 1984.
A spokesman for Merck, John Doorley, characterized Mr. Sokolof's latest campaign as "silly." He said the daily cost for an average dose of Zocor was about $2.50.
Mr. Doorley said his company wants more people to benefit from its medicines but prefers to attract customers through more conventional publicity. In response to Mr. Sokolof's ad, the company's written statement said that it takes a lot of time and money to develop medications and said Merck works with insurance programs to maximize patient access to its drugs.
"In 1990 Merck committed to hold price increases on our entire product line to within the overall rate of inflation. We have maintained that commitment," the company's written statement said.
Mr. Sokolof's earlier ads, about he health risks of high cholesterol, led some food makers to reduce the saturated fats in their products, analysts said, but they predicted that the new campaign was unlikely to lead to lower drug prices.
"I don't think anyone's going to lower the price," said Hemant K. Shah, an independent health care analyst. Mr. Shah said the market for cholesterol-lowering drugs was already very competitive.

HEADLINE: Can Xerox Auction Off Hot Air?

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: PALO ALTO, Calif., June 23

 BODY:
A software-based system that holds digital mini-auctions to distribute hot and cold air throughout a laboratory has been developed by scientists at the Xerox Corporation, marrying the laws of markets with those of electronics.
The system, which has lowered energy costs in the building by more than 10 percent, is based on software "agents" that represent individual room temperature controllers that bid to buy or sell cool or warm air. An agent that loses an auction might suffer a brief reduction in heating, which would encourage it to increase its bid in the next auction to be more certain of winning. The system holds about 1,500 auctions a day, more than one a minute. 
 The system uses a powerful computer that acquires sensor data and distributes control information over a network throughout the building.
The researchers believe the auction system has wide application wherever scarce resources need to be allocated efficiently, and is an example of growing interest in using market mechanisms for managing and selling network resources.
A recent project by researchers at Sun Microsystems Inc. and Agorics Inc. explored the use of software auctions to manage digital traffic jams in a computer network designed to carry video data.
The idea of building automated market-based systems for control purposes is not new. But only in the last two years have scientists been able to build systems based on modern computer networks.
"Originally people thought this was science fiction," said Bernardo Huberman, a Xerox physicist and a pioneer in the emerging field of computational ecology. "However, it has turned out that using the market mechanism for controlling systems is a wonderful tool."
The auction-based approach is a useful tool for controlling large systems because it can operate without a hierarchical authority.
"Centralized approaches toward managing networks are doomed to failure," said Michael Rothschild, president of the Bionomics Institute, an economics research organization in San Francisco.
The Xerox researchers believe that decentralization becomes increasingly attractive as systems that require the interaction of large networks of computers grow in size.
"Systems that are based on market mechanisms scale up very gracefully," Mr. Huberman said. "Their real advantage comes as they increase in size."
During the 1970's the Xerox laboratory created the first practical office networks and scientists as the laboratory began experimenting with ways to harness the power of multiple computers in a network. In the late 1980's Mr. Huberman began research on using auction systems to share more efficiently a network's computer time. The research project, known as Spawn, was an early attempt to organize a computer network without a centralized control facility.
Mr. Huberman developed the thermal auction system with Scott Clearwater and several other researchers at Xerox's Palo Alto Research Center. During the day, as the sun shines on various sides of the building, the double-blind auctions take place electronically, a system in which neither buyer nor seller knows the amount of any bid except its own. As software buyers purchase warm and cool air, air control vents in each office in the system are adjusted accordingly.
The researchers designed the system with several notable differences from conventional auction systems. For example, they dealt with the tendency of the network to permit a single agent to accumulate large sums of "money" -- if, say, one office was on a shady side of the building and needed less air conditioning -- by simply erasing excess amounts from the agent's accounts.
While the auction-based thermal cooling system does not use real money, the researchers believe the technology can provide significant energy savings. They are holding discussions with companies including Honeywell about licensing the system for commercial use.
Many executives predict that the Internet will become an ideal media for automating commercial transactions. A number of entrepreneurs and industry researchers share the vision of creating software agents that will "shop" on behalf of computer users, keeping an eye out for particular items or bargains in Internet shopping malls.
"Markets like this are likely," said Hal Varian, an economist who is dean of the School of Information Management and Systems at the University of California at Berkeley. "The barrier is consumer acceptance."
Indeed, Xerox executives believe that the auction technology may have a commercial application that falls much closer to the heart of Xerox's business: printing services.
Mr. Huberman has designed a system called Docubid that would permit companies to choose a printing company by placing the job up for bid on a national network that Xerox would run. Once a buyer and seller were matched, the job would be submitted electronically and then shipped to the customer upon completion.
Yet the system could present Xerox with some problems, its executives acknowledge: some of its best customers for printing equipment are not interested in seeing more open markets.
And there are other barriers.
"The main thing that has been slowing up the larger-scale electronic commerce is the emergence of electronic money or a simple credit card scheme," said Mark Manasse, a researcher at the Digital Equipment Corporation. "There are a lot of regulatory and social issues that still need to be solved."
Another significant problem is the absence of workable systems that permit small-scale financial transactions -- as small as a nickel or a dime, or even a fraction of a penny in the future.
Mr. Manasse has designed an electronic money system known as Millicent to support financial systems that require large numbers of small transactions. Such a system might conceivably work well with an auction-based system, or one in which writers might desire to sell their work at a lower cost than is required by the current paper-based publishing economy in order to do multiple transactions quickly and benefit from the volume.

GRAPHIC: Diagram: "Bidding for Degrees"
Xerox has developed a computer system that not only monitors the temperature in the rooms of an office building, but also allows "agents" to bid for the warmer or cooler air depending on what is needed to keep the room comfortable. The value of the Xerox auction system is that it does a better job of distributing cool and warm air equally among a large number of offices. The air flowing through cannot simply be moved like blocks to the place where it is needed, so this system allows for the continual auctioning of air in the ducts. (Source: Xerox)

HEADLINE: Santa Fe Journal;
Texas Sashays Into Santa Fe -- and Pays Its Way

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

DATELINE: SANTA FE, N.M., June 23

 BODY:
It was as if the Texas border had taken a sudden, 152-mile bend to the northwest, across mesas, arroyos and barbed-wire fences, to enfold a patch of what most maps still call New Mexico.
At a ranch just south of here on Saturday night, with country and western bands blaring, barbecued ribs smoking and flaring, a towering party tent practically visible from adjoining states and an auction offering livestock including ostriches and a baby llama, was a genuine, $600-a-ticket, sorry-we-sold-out-months-ago Texas charity ball. 
 "That's all it is, a transplanted Cattle Baron's Ball," said Mike Schmidt, a Dallas lawyer and Santa Fe homeowner, referring to annual revels where Dallasites practice living up to their stereotype. In cowboy boots, tails, wing collar and bolo tie, Mr. Schmidt stood on the dusty, crowded main road through a movie set that had turned part of the ranch into a frontier town.
The Buckaroo Ball, in its third year, has institutionalized the foreign presence. It is the grandest effort yet to teach New Mexicans how to behave more like wealthy Texans.
In this city's high-stakes social rivalry, the ball also represents a challenge to the formal dinners and premieres of the Santa Fe Opera. There, benefactors must make do without beaded, fringed and feathered leather gowns, staged gunfights or steel guitars. "It's just dinner; that's it," said Jane Smith, chairwoman of the first Buckaroo Ball two years ago, speaking of one of the opera's main fund-raisers. "But," she said with slow emphasis, "they're an older crowd."
Not every Santa Fe-an wants to learn how to be part of the Texas crowd. Many here blame outsiders in general, Texans in particular, for chronic water shortages, cultural erosion and soaring housing costs that have only recently leveled off. Among some of them, Texas is known as Baja Oklahoma.
Gazing across a wide income gap between most New Mexicans and their Texan visitors, Gloria Mendoza, a fourth-generation native, does not like the view. "They move into a traditional neighborhood with rutted dirt roads and build $500,000 homes with 10-foot walls," she said. "Then they get bored and look around the neighborhood. They don't like the way their neighbors pile wood out front, or the old refrigerator, or a little old car. They don't want to assimilate with the people here."
For years, Ms. Mendoza has failed to win passage of a state law taxing all real estate transfers of more than $250,000. But she plans other counter-measures, like remedial classes in Santa Fe-ness. "When people move to Santa Fe they should go through a workshop that educates them on our way of life and how they can fit into our community," she said.
The Texans, however, have two things going for them. First, they give hundreds of thousands of Buckaroo Bucks each year to charities, especially for children, in a city where causes other than the opera and the art museums, the ball's organizers say, have attracted scant support. "Because of you, there is a brand new children's intensive care unit at St. Vincent Hospital," a master of ceremonies told the cheering, whistling crowd.
Connie Trujillo, executive director of the Esperanza Shelter for Battered Families, recalled last week how $75,000 from an earlier ball allowed her to buy two vans and hire a children's therapist. "If any non-profit in Santa Fe gets money, you're looking at three or five thousand. Not 75," she said. "The Buckaroos were the first people who produced that much money, and my hat goes off to them."
Second, the Texans are not Californians -- later, flashier arrivals. Natives, especially shopowners, know who their real friends are, said Stanley Marcus, the fabled Dallas retailer and Santa Fe homeowner who has been taking vacations here since the 1930's. "Texans bought and the Californians just look," he said.
Texans, fleeing their Saharan summers to enjoy nature's own air conditioning at 7,000 feet, have been heading in this direction since the 1840's. Then, in the days of the Texas Republic, a ragged band of Texas Rangers trying to capture Santa Fe from the Mexicans met the first local resistance.
Although both states have roots in Spanish colonial and Mexican culture, Hispanics and Native Americans remain far more influential here than in Texas. Some quarrel with the latest invaders, saying that schools and other public services remain poor despite tourism and charity. Feuds over race, real estate development and the future of a city whose economy has faltered have helped a citizens' group circulating petitions to force an August vote on replacing the mayor and City Council with a new form of government.
The Texan impulse to lend a hand and kick up the heels of their hand-made Lucchese boots converged a few years ago. Elizabeth Smith, one of the founders in 1974 of the Dallas Cattle Baron's Balls, persuaded friends including Jane Smith (no relation) to plan the same sort of frolic here in 1994. Wondering whether they could clear even $100,000, after expenses, they raised $300,000. Last year, they took in more than $400,000, and this year they appear likely to shoot past $600,000.
Although a few tickets cost $200 -- "We're not trying to be elitist," one of the organizers said -- 75 percent of the thousand or so tickets are priced at $600 or more. These tickets include a Friday night cocktail party, Saturday tours of local homes, gardens and artists' studios and a Sunday brunch. For $250 more, golfers can enter a tournament at a gated community financed by Texas investors.
The Buckaroo upstarts have won polite admiration from the opera's backers. "Certainly there is competition," said Abe Silver Jr., a Santa Fe Opera Foundation board member and treasurer of the Santa Fe Boys & Girls Club, a recipient of Buckaroo donations. "Those ladies have done a tremendous job of creating new sources of funding."
Depending on whom you ask, the Santa Fe Opera backers still raise more than the Buckaroos. "They've been around for 20 years," said Jane Smith, her eyes narrowing in determination. "But we're catching up."

LENGTH: 1051 words

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE REPUBLICANS;
Chaotic Message to Dole Over the Abortion Issue

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: SAN ANTONIO, June 23

 BODY:
Out of the screaming and hissing that echoed through the Alamodome, the Texas Republican Party delivered an unmistakable message to Bob Dole this weekend: taming rebellious factions within his party may be far trickier than even he imagined.
The clashes over abortion that dominated the state party's convention demonstrated that divisions among Republicans are no longer as stark as traditional economic conservatives on one side and religious and social conservatives on the other. But the politics have become far more complicated as the bickering goes on among Republicans who are steadfast in opposing abortion but who disagree about whether to press their position at all costs or choose for a more pragmatic approach. 
 The convention underscored something that Democrats and moderate Republicans tend to forget. Religious conservatives are by no means a monolith. While the state party is controlled by religious conservatives, the delegates in a close vote put down a move to deny Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison a seat at the national convention.
While the ferment here pitted Texan against Texan, it offered a preview of what could unfold at the national convention in San Diego in August and what the Dole campaign wants to avoid on the national level at all costs: a bitter floor fight over abortion; adoption of a tougher anti-abortion platform than even the Christian Coalition proposed, and high-profile roles for conservatives who are considered too fervent by many party leaders.
Bill Price, the executive director of Texans United for Life, who whipped up the Texas Republicans in the almost successful drive to keep Senator Hutchison off the national convention delegation because of her abortion-rights stance, warned that he and other anti-abortion leaders were not about to be squelched.
"There's a rogue elephant on the way from Texas that means business," declared Mr. Price, who was elected a delegate.
As a measure of the new conflicts roiling the Republican Party, consider how the battle lines have changed since this state's party convention two years ago. In 1994, the issue was over how Tom Pauken, who was backed by the Christian Coalition, wrested control of the party from mainstream Republicans.
But this past weekend, Mr. Pauken emerged as a figure of relative moderation as he sought to keep Mr. Price and his allies from overshadowing the proceedings. And Fred Meyer, the longtime party chairman whom Mr. Pauken had replaced, has become such a political relic that he lost his bid to go to the San Diego convention as a Dole delegate.
Mrs. Hutchison's ability to stave off defeat was mainly a victory for Mr. Dole, who is close to the Senator. But the all-but-assured Republican nominee had little else to cheer. Dozens of other Dole supporters, including Representative Henry Bonilla, were scorned in their bids to join the state's delegation to the national convention. And most of those who won spots on the delegation signed pledges vowing to vote against Mr. Dole's choice of a running mate if he or she does not oppose abortion.
Anti-abortion advocates at the convention hardly represent the Republican Party as a whole. But at the convention, there were more stickers here for Alan Keyes, who ran for President on a strict anti-abortion agenda, than for Mr. Dole. And Mr. Keyes and Patrick J. Buchanan drew far more cheers than Gov. George W. Bush and Senator Phil Gramm, two leading Texas Republicans who oppose abortion but who have warned the party against being preoccupied over the issue.
Though they may be a vociferous minority, these abortion opponents made clear this weekend that they are a force to be reckoned with. Mrs. Hutchison, for one, had dismissed Mr. Price and others who moved against her as a small minority on a "kamikaze mission." But nearly half of the 16,000 delegates here shouted "No!" on the question of whether Mrs. Hutchison and other proposed members of the Dole delegation should be sent to the convention.
Ralph Reed, executive director of the Christian Coalition, sought to navigate through these factions within the anti-abortion camp. He believes that the pragmatic course for anti-abortion groups is to align with Mr. Dole, even if is not as conservative as some would like. In that vein, Mr. Reed pressed behind the scenes for Mrs. Hutchison to win a slot at the convention. Yet, not wanting to offend the anti-abortion advocates that are vital to his coalition, Mr. Reed refused to condemn the effort to defeat dozens of Dole delegates to the national convention.
Mr. Dole has an even more complicated dilemma. In addition to trying to satisfy the anti-abortion factions, he also needs to assure the abortion-rights elements of his party that there is, indeed, a big tent. The risks are significant: he could lose the support of anti-abortion forces, who are among the most active members of the party, or the more moderate voters that he would also need to defeat President Clinton.
Trying to calm all sides of this fragile coalition, Mr. Dole is seeking to find a compromise for the party's anti-abortion plank that would call for a "declaration of tolerance."
But it was clear at the convention here that foes of abortion would probably not abide any weakening of the platform. The platform adopted by the convention here takes an even harder line on abortion than the Texas party did two years ago: delegates removed an exception that permitted abortion to save the mother's life. That language is at odds not only with Mrs. Hutchison, but also with Governor Bush and Senator Gramm.
Becky Farrar, 60, a delegate from Hico in central Texas, said she opposed abortion but voted to send Mrs. Hutchison to the convention because she believed that the party ought to show at least a smidgen of diversity.
"Part of the delegation wanted to elect all delegates who were visibly pro life; the rest of the delegations wanted a more diverse slate," she said. The question was never whether the delegates would be mostly against abortion, but whether anti-abortion forces get "the entire pie or three-quarters of the pie."
 Thus, as the feuding over abortion moves on to San Diego, it is clear that no matter how Bob Dole divides up the pie, some part of the Republican coalition will be left hungry.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Bill Price, the executive director of Texans United for Life, which sought to keep moderates on abortion from going to the Republican convention. (F. Carter Smith for The New York Times)

LENGTH: 1479 words

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE HOUSE;
Defying Odds in Mississippi, Black Carries G.O.P. Torch

BYLINE: By RICK BRAGG 

DATELINE: JACKSON, Miss., June 21

 BODY:
The poverty runs longer and deeper through Mississippi's Second Congressional District than anywhere else in America. From the three-room shanties of Jackson to the skinny blacktop of the Delta, this is a postcard of failed dreams. Women still tote water in plastic buckets to bathe their babies, and the first of the month remains a time of great expectation because so many people exist on welfare, food stamps and Government peanut butter.
The Republican Party -- the party of Newt Gingrich, Patrick J. Buchanan, welfare reform and the Contract with America -- wants their votes. 
 Danny Covington, a 40-year-old black man seeking office for the first time, could deliver this desperately poor district to the Republicans, if he can persuade 12 to 15 percent of black voters to join with the overwhelming white support he is expected to get to unseat Bennie Thompson, the liberal black incumbent.
The obvious question: Why would that ever happen? To many black people in this traditionally Democratic district, voting for a Republican, even if that Republican is a black man, would be like a possum snuggling up to a speeding car.
"African-Americans and minorities in general are conservative in nature, and we believe in the family," reasoned Mr. Covington, a former parole officer and civil servant from Vicksburg who served in the 1980's as a Congressional aide to another Mississippi Republican, Webb Franklin.
"We don't have to have a constitutional amendment to support prayer. We believe that a 4-year-old child should not be in a position to raise Momma and Daddy," he said, referring to Aid for Dependent Children checks, on which whole families subsist. "We also believe that life is good, life is precious, and life begins at conception."
Mr. Covington is one of 24 black Republicans who are running for Congress, in addition to 2 who are already serving in the House. He is one of few of them given a realistic chance of winning. Although black Republicans, especially in the South, remain an oddity -- just 2 percent of the party -- their numbers are climbing as blacks grow increasingly dissatisfied with their place in the Democratic Party. Charles Barkley, the Phoenix Suns basketball star from Auburn University who earned the nickname The Round Mound of Rebound in college because of his pudginess, has said he would like to run for Governor of Alabama as a Republican.
"Republicans are making some effort to be more inclusive, and some African-Americans are feeling comfortable inside the party," said Stephen Schaffer, a professor of political science at Mississippi State University. "Probably, on moral issues, African-Americans are more conservative, but it's a problem in general on economic issues."
But Mr. Covington believes otherwise. He said he was not trying to take milk from babies or food from old people, "but some guy who can bench-press 300 pounds, has all 10 fingers and can see real good, he should work," Mr. Covington said. "And if he commits a crime, we'll build more prisons" and put him in jail.
What was once unthinkable is shaping up in Mississippi as, at least, a real contest, political experts and Republican Party officials say. Some black voters laughed out loud when asked if they would vote for a Republican, of any color, but others said they would consider it. The reason: Years of Democratic leadership has done little to lift the weight of poverty here.
The district includes the whole Delta, an area where outhouses are still a common sight in back of ragged houses that lean between vast fields.
"I'm a lifelong Democrat, but I'm beginning to wonder," said 73-year-old Bennie Evans, who came to hear Mr. Covington speak at the Mount Zion Youth Center outside Jackson. "We want somebody who can change things."
But Democratic leaders said that as bad as life in the Delta and other poverty-stricken districts might be, it could get worse if the Republican proposals on welfare and other social programs were passed.
Mr. Thompson, in Congress since 1993, sees it as just one more case of political opportunism, and betrayal.
"It just appears to be a shortcut to what they think is the head of the line," said the 50-year-old Congressman, who lives in tiny Bolton, near Jackson. A former alderman, he has been a politician all his adult life, an uncompromising proponent of government programs for the poor.
"For any self-respecting African-American to run on an anti-affirmative-action plank, wanting to cut Medicare and Medicaid, reduce educational funding, is suicide. You can't represent a district like mine and not make sure that basic services are available to the people," he said.
But that, Mr. Covington said, is the whole reason why he believes he can unseat the incumbent: He said the district was stagnating, as Mr. Evans said, held fast in never-ending poverty and dependence on welfare.
Mr. Covington said Mr. Thompson could stay in power only if his district remained poor, remained chained to welfare checks.
"He wants people to be downtrodden," Mr. Covington said. "That's his platform. It's like he feasts on poverty."
Mr. Covington lives in a house in the country with a Jacuzzi in the back and campaigns in perfectly fitting suits and ties that did not come from Kmart. But he was born in rural Mississippi, in Columbus, to a woman who had three sons by three different men, who each abandoned her.
She made their living by taking in ironing and washing, and working as a maid. They lived in a two-room house. Mr. Covington took his first indoor shower at the University of Mississippi, where he went on a band scholarship. He played the tuba.
If his mother could survive without welfare, he said, so can others. If he could climb out of poverty, so can they.
While others look at the Delta and see only hopelessness, he said, he sees people who are struggling to make house and car payments and raise their children properly, but also many people who do not try at all. Mr. Thompson told them he would take care of them, Mr. Covington said, so there is no reason to find a job. "He's a poverty pimp," he said of Mr. Thompson.
Mr. Thompson responded: "I know almost 900 African-American elected officials in Mississippi, and I don't know one that's had to run on the Republican ticket to win. We need to have that kind of representation rather than the Republicans' finding somebody at the last minute to run for office."
It is not expected to be a gentlemanly campaign.
Mr. Covington, a tall, thin, ebullient, rapid-walking man who worked in several campaigns, including those for Mississippi's stridently conservative Gov. Kirk Fordice and Senators Trent Lott and Thad Cochran, has not tried to pass himself off as a toned-down conservative who would be palatable to black voters. He does not try to justify his place in a party that many blacks view as threatening. He simply denies the threat.
"I don't think there's a Republican anywhere in America who wants to see people starve, see people homeless, see people go without medical treatment," he said.
When pressed, he conceded that, yes, there are some Republicans who would drastically cut social welfare programs without apology. But while he is loyal to his party, he said he would be his own man.
Mr. Thompson has been here before. He defended his seat against Bill Jordan, a black Republican, in 1994. Mr. Jordan, whom some Republicans criticized for failing to run a hard race, still won 41 percent of the vote in a district that is 63 percent black, but where the voting-age population is just 58 percent.
Mr. Covington disdains any comparison between this race and that one. He ignored his Republican opponents, whom he easily defeated in a primary, and focused on Mr. Thompson. He drives hundreds of miles every day, stopping at community centers, churches, stores.
He works the crowd at the Church's Fried Chicken and the barber shop at the Edison Walthall Hotel in Jackson. On Wednesday, he crisscrossed the Delta with his campaign manager, Linda Brombach, putting 500 miles on his car.
"Covington is doing a different sort of campaign: going out and meeting people," said Mr. Schaffer, the political science professor.
"It'll be an uphill race for Covington," he said, "but he does have lots of political experience."
What he must do, some voters here said, is convince them that he is not a lap dog for Mr. Gingrich and other Republican leaders. Mr. Covington, who has been in the party since he joined the Young Republicans Club at Ole Miss 20 years ago, said he could better represent people here because "I can take things to the table" and deal with Mr. Gingrich, Mr. Lott and others.
But there is little disagreement among them. He is against abortion, even in cases of rape or incest. He supports Republican tax cuts and opposes gun control.
"I'm a conservative," he said.

LENGTH: 928 words

HEADLINE: In Slow-Paced Vermont, the Dirt Road Reigns

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER 

DATELINE: FAIRFIELD, Vt., June 19

 BODY:
You would think that everyone would want a better road. But in Vermont people fight to keep roads that freeze in winter, that turn into muddy sinkholes in spring, that kick up clouds of dust in summer, that gobble up shocks, mufflers and the occasional whole car.
When the state proposed paving a scant half-mile stretch of road in bucolic Brookfield some years back, there was a citizens' uprising. Jackie Wilder, a retired teacher, threatened to lie down in front of the bulldozers with her grandchildren. "And I had two grandchildren then," Mrs. Wilder recalled, adding that she would take the same stand today with her five grandchildren. 
 The road was not paved.
"It was a great victory," said Ed Koren, the cartoonist, who relocated to his dirt road in Brookfield (population 1,080) from the Upper West Side of Manhattan (population about 250,000), where all the roads are paved and many are potholed.
Vermont has about 8,000 miles of unpaved roads -- just 6,000 miles are paved -- and only 600,000 people. When small-town Vermonters give directions to their homes, there is always this part: "And then the pavement ends."
To a lot of Vermonters, an unpaved road is a better road. People go more slowly on a dirt road. In rural Vermont, slower is better.
Francis Howrigan, a 79-year-old dairy farmer, was meandering along the dirt roads of Fairfield the other afternoon, admiring the fields of buttercups and the views of the Green Mountains. He slowed down for birds. At one bend in the road, he stopped his car. Mr. Howrigan, a big man in work boots, got out, walked over to the side of the road and picked a bunch of wild pink roses, thorns and all.
"Nothing smells like wild roses," he said.
There is no rush hour on a dirt road. There is not much traffic, period. "Paved roads are for cars, not people," said Naomi Flanders, a performance artist who lives on a dirt road in Calais, where the residents rallied last year against a suggestion that eight-tenths of County Road be paved. "Dirt roads are for people."
Dirt roads go nicely with that other Vermont symbol, the covered bridge. Tourists love them, though they don't seem to come around much during mud season.
Dirt roads are a lot more interesting than highways. On summer evenings, Gregory Sanford, the state archivist, likes to walk barefoot with his two small daughters down their dirt road.
"We look at different colored rocks," Mr. Sanford said. "When we come back, I have 30 or 40 rocks du jour in my pockets. We're re-creating our dirt road in our house."
One reason the state still has so many dirt roads is the famous thriftiness of Vermonters. In addition to their pastoral charms, dirt roads are a lot cheaper to maintain than pavement. "It's economics," Mr. Koren said. "No one has the money to pave the damn thing."
Among New York City apartment dwellers, the building superintendent is all powerful. The Vermont equivalent is the local road commissioner, who maintains the town roads by grading, sanding and plowing. The road commissioner decides whose road is plowed first.
New Yorkers bestow Christmas tips upon their supers. The grateful residents of Brookfield rewarded their Road Commissioner, John Sprague, and his crew with a standing ovation at town meeting a year ago.
Oxford has its Rhodes Scholars. Vermont is proud of its Roads Scholars -- graduates of a 10-day workshop, sponsored by the Vermont transportation agency, that covers things like road drainage, signing and winter maintenance.
Braintree's Road Commissioner, Loren Bent, was recently named a Roads Scholar and given a $50 cash award by the town selectmen.
"One thing they did teach us," Mr. Bent said. "When somebody starts complaining, you say, 'I didn't make these roads, I inherited them.' "
There are 251 towns in Vermont, and most of the small ones have an appointed road commissioner.
Mr. Howrigan has being doing the job for 50 years in Fairfield. He is paid $150 a year. The town honored him by putting his picture on the cover of the annual town report one year.
The job can be demanding.
"A fellow moved to town one year and came to the selectmen's meeting," said Mr. Howrigan, who is also chairman of the Board of Selectmen. "He said, 'I'm so and so, I work in Burlington, and I want my road plowed first.' "
The man worked at I.B.M. and lived on the outskirts of town, Mr. Howrigan recalled: "I looked him right in the eye. I said, 'No way are you going to be first.' "
Many of the more-traveled dirt roads are actually dirt and gravel. One secret to a good dirt road is the gravel, Mr. Howrigan said. Ever frugal, he said he could buy a truckload for $9.
Plenty of Vermonters want their roads paved. Paving -- to pave, or not to pave -- is always controversial in small-town Vermont. In Brookfield, Mrs. Wilder, the retired teacher, said one woman who favored paving had not spoken to her since her side lost, 10 years ago.
While there are no statistics available, the pavement is slowly encroaching. Joe Sherman, a Vermont writer and the author of a book called "Fast Lane on a Dirt Road" (Countrymen Press, 1991), a contemporary history of Vermont, said many of the urban dwellers who moved to the state's back roads 20 and 30 years ago were now fighting to have their roads paved.
"Dirt roads are the quintessential paradox of our time," Mr. Sherman said. "Everybody wants to live in the wild and yet be ultra-civilized. It's kind of like backpacking with your espresso machine, or wanting to be on the fast lane on the dirt road. You can't do both."

HEADLINE: BEYOND THE BOARDWALK -- A special report.;
With Cash Rolling In, Atlantic City Raises Stakes

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY

 BODY:
Many people have written epitaphs for this storied old town. The version a few years ago went like this: Atlantic City was about to be surrounded with state-licensed casinos that would open in Pennsylvania and Connecticut and probably in New York. Losing its exclusivity as the center of East Coast gambling, the city would rapidly sink, dragged down by problems of urban decay and poverty that would never be solved.
That was a very bad bet. 
 Today Atlantic City is beginning its biggest expansion since gambling was legalized in 1978. Casino revenues have soared, hotel occupancy is up and the competition that seemed so threatening has retreated, leaving the field open. The city that wrote the book on resort development when Orlando was still a swamp and Las Vegas an unmarked spot in the desert has begun a new chapter.
All together, more than $4 billion in new casino and hotel projects have been announced or are now under construction, including four new casinos on property owned by Mirage Resorts, and a fifth to be built or bought by MGM Grand, which is shopping for a site. In the entire first 17 years of the city's gambling era, developers spent only $5.6 billion.
"We're bursting at the seams," said Donald Trump, who owns four of the city's 13 casinos and who this month announced another $75 million expansion, including the creation of what he said would be the world's largest gambling yacht.
The construction has also reached out into long-neglected areas of the city beyond the boardwalk. A $254 million convention center will open early next year with a single-level exhibition space bigger than any other on the East Coast, including the Jacob Javits Center in New York, to compete for the trade-show business that has been a Las Vegas windfall.
The convention center will be connected to a 500-room hotel, the largest non-casino hotel project here in at least half a century, anchoring a nine-square-block revitalization.
Much of the development is different from the past as well. The growth in overnight visitors and the anticipation of an expanded convention business are pushing casinos to look for new temptations -- stores, restaurants and theaters -- to keep people in town and spending. The Hard Rock Cafe and Planet Hollywood have arrived. Harrah's has said it will spend $7 million building just one new restaurant. Mr. Trump, never to be outdone, announced that he would spend $20 million each on two new restaurants.
"It won't be the old Atlantic City," said Mark Juliano, the president and chief operating officer of Caesars, which is expanding by 624 rooms and acting as development partner for the convention center hotel. "Life has a more hectic pace now and that will be true here. But I definitely see a wider variety of product being offered."
Casino officials and industry analysts say that while the reduced threat of out-of-state competition may have sparked Atlantic City's sudden surge, various related forces have compounded and channeled it.
*The state of New Jersey got friendlier. Under Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, gambling regulations were significantly eased last year, allowing casinos to market and advertise more aggressively, cut their labor costs by reducing some previously mandated functions, and offer new games. That increased profits and sent casino stocks soaring. Atlantic City casinos earned a record $3.7 billion in gross revenues last year, edging out the Las Vegas strip, which earned $3.6 billion.
*The state also changed strategy. Money from a 1.25 percent casino gross revenue tax that had been used exclusively to build low- and moderate-income housing was partly shifted to economic development, with a specific goal of creating jobs for local residents. The Atlantic City airport was refurbished and doubled in size. A $120 million project to beautify the entrance to the city, with park space and a laser-shooting lighthouse, was begun.
*Stephen A. Wynn came to town. Mr. Wynn, the chief executive of Mirage Resorts, which has been credited by many industry officials with helping to change Las Vegas's image from gambling city to entertainment resort with a mix of spectacle and family-style fun, said he would do the same here. That hastened the scramble to build and expand and improve properties.
But this new Atlantic City is also a place of new strains. Some residents say they fear that, just as many of the earlier casino jobs went to people from nearby towns and suburbs, the economic opportunities from the new restaurants and retail jobs may prove just as illusive to the city's mostly poor and minority inhabitants, who could see only the downside of growth.
Traffic, already bad, flirts with gridlock from the construction obstacles. Housing shortages and higher rents are expected.
And there are new political pressures. Mr. Wynn has said his development group, which includes Circus Circus Enterprises and Boyd Gaming, will not come unless the state builds a $330 million road and tunnel project to his property, which is several miles from the Boardwalk. Mr. Trump, currently the largest casino operator, has complained that the tunnel would be an unfair giveaway by the state that would favor one part of Atlantic City over another.
Mrs. Whitman has been left in the middle and has said she will issue a decision on the road project by the end of the month. So her words now move markets. When gambling industry analysts from around the nation gathered here recently, they sat rapt with their cell phones ready on their tables as she opened their conference. She smiled and stayed firmly noncommittal.
Pinky Kravitz, a local booster and radio personality who broadcasts his show every afternoon from a lounge at the Trump Plaza, said that all the new attention has its own effect: renewed confidence. "For the first time I feel optimism," he said. "That light at the end of the tunnel is what we were promised when the casinos came in."
Mr. Kravitz, who has lived 62 of his 68 years here, is a repository of his city's small and large humiliations. He remembers the low-tide moments -- the mid-1960's, when one of the once-elegant old hotels began giving paper towels to its guests for their showers, and the early 1970's, when casino legalization looked politically impossible.
Now the talk centers on who will win, who will lose, and whether the small downtown merchants will survive the years of disrupted parking and traffic during construction.
 
The New Success
How It Happened; What It Means
Former Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. of Connecticut figures prominently in the new success of Atlantic City, believe it or not. And so do Connecticut's Mashantucket Pequot Indians, owners of Foxwoods Casino, and Gov. Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania. All of them influenced the growth of gambling in the region in various ways, and the result, casino industry officials and analysts say, was the solidification of Atlantic City's position as the gambling capital of the east.
Mr. Wynn had originally wanted to build a Mirage Resort in Bridgeport. He promised to create 20,000 new jobs, and his accountants calculated that such a mammoth resort just 60 minutes from midtown Manhattan would swallow up in one gulp 30 percent of Atlantic City's business.
It was not to be.
Mr. Weicker, who opposed the expansion of casino gambling in his state, made a pact with the Pequots in 1993, giving them exclusive rights to gambling in exchange for 25 percent of slot-machine profits. Mr. Wynn spent more than $10 million trying to get the law changed before giving up. His next stop, somewhat reluctantly, was Atlantic City.
"In the short run, it would have been better in Bridgeport," said Richard D. Bronson, Mirage's head of development. "It would have been a killer." But in the long run, because of tourist concentrations, "we'll probably be better off in Atlantic City."
Meanwhile, Mr. Ridge of Pennsylvania, who was elected in 1994, announced that he would oppose new gambling casinos unless approved by voters in a referendum. Mrs. Whitman at the same time was taking the opposite tack, saying that New Jersey was open for business and that gambling was an important part of the mix.
A third force was a change in perspective that is as simple as it is profound: visitors who stay longer, especially overnight, spend more money in the casinos, and more people are staying overnight. The 6,345 hotel rooms in the city in 1986, for example, were empty about 20 percent of the time. Last year, the city had a 92 percent occupancy rate with more than 9,400 rooms.
But getting people to stay longer means, paradoxically, giving them more things to do that are not about gambling. That is where the state has exerted its leverage. New Jersey created a $100 million fund -- with a proposed expansion to $170 million now before the legislature -- to encourage non-casino hotel growth, all financed by the tax on casinos' gross revenues. At Caesars, for example, the new rooms to be set aside for use by conventiongoers will net the casino as much as a $20 million to $25 million rebate on the taxes it paid.
The idea, Governor Whitman said, is partly to change psychology and get the casinos to think beyond their own front doors. The old Atlantic City economy, in the days of vaudeville and straw hats for men, had always looked outward, treating commerce as a carnival. The casinos in their first phase faced in, drawing customers to a windowless world where a view or the smell of salt air was treated as a distraction from the business at hand.
Giving the casinos an interest in the success of the convention center is one part of the strategy. Another more subtle and symbolic but perhaps equally far-reaching effort -- the creation of a new park-lined boulevard leading from the convention center toward the Boardwalk -- is aimed essentially at getting the casinos to think of the city as their front door, not simply a parking lot.
"The gaming part is important and it's big and and it's going to continue to expand, but what we really need to do if we're going to get this place back to a sound footing is to get it back to being a vacation land," Mrs. Whitman said. "All the casinos are beginning to recognize that they need to be more than just slot machines for gamblers."
 
Plus Ca Change . . .
Revision And Consolidation
The walls of the Greater Exodus Baptist Church shake with a deep, sonorous rumbling from the earthmovers pawing the ground outside. It is the sound of condemnation and rebirth, of destruction and deliverance all in one. The church, a converted bingo hall, is to be leveled to make way for the new grand entry to the city, and the state's compensation package, financed by parking taxes, is making possible a brand new $3.5 million structure nearby: Greater Exodus's first permanent home.
"Monetarily, we have been blessed," said the founder and pastor, Bishop-elect Sherman R. Mosley. "We feel blessed that we have to leave."
Change and changelessness sit side by side in Atlantic City these days. On the Boardwalk, where french fries and sea rot still form the signature aroma, new places like the Warner Brothers Studio Store and Ripley's Believe It or Not Museum sit hard by the pizza joints and T-shirt shops that developers say are marked for extinction.
The question on everyone's mind is how it will fit together in the end, and who will be left. The casinos themselves are consolidating. Hilton Hotels bought Bally earlier this month, and the running joke at an industry conference a short time later was that next year there would be one casino left and one chief executive talking to a roomful of listeners. Each C.E.O. repeating the joke vowed to be the one left standing.
Some local business people say they fear that the same kind of consolidation could happen to them. The city has lost about 200 restaurants over the last 17 years of casino gambling, city officials say. Many that are left, like Dock's Oyster House, which has been serving up sea food dinners since 1897, are watching with trepidation as glitzy new places like the California Pizza Kitchen and the Rainforest Cafe open on the Boardwalk.
Joseph R. Dougherty, the third generation of Doughertys to run Dock's, said that while the convention center is likely to help his business, almost all of the big new restaurants have a relationship with a casino or are under a casino's roof.
"The casinos give free food, free drinks," he said. "It's tough to compete. But there'll always be people who want to get out of the casinos," he added. "At least a little."
 
In Abeyance
Waiting for Steve And the Roadway
Mr. Wynn of the Mirage is unquestionably the biggest businessman not in Atlantic City. His company, associated with dolphins, exploding volcanos and pirate-ship battles -- and especially with Las Vegas's dramatic resurgence -- hangs over all, making his every move or perceived change of posture the question of every development conversation. The scale of his proposal dwarfs any previous Atlantic City project: as many as 7,000 hotel rooms, four new casinos and more than $2.5 billion in new investment.
His spokesmen are adamant that the roadway to the Mirage site, a 168-acre former landfill that was given to Mr. Wynn by the city last year, is the quid pro quo. Without a way to bypass the narrow, congested local streets, Mirage officials say, the project is unworkable. Mr. Trump -- the biggest business man in Atlantic City -- thunders, meanwhile, that building a $330 million funnel to one business's door at taxpayer expense would be unconscionable.
Their public debate pushes all of Atlantic City's hot buttons: the role of the state, the threat of transportation paralysis, the fallout from heightened competition, the future of the Boardwalk. But it just as starkly illustrates the fever-pitch pace of change: Real life is charging ahead, shifting both Mr. Trump's and Mr. Wynn's positions even as they holler.
After Mirage said last year that it would seek a place at the Atlantic City table, announcements about casino expansions came like a string of firecrackers -- a fact for which Mirage takes credit. Mr. Bronson, the Mirage development official, said that several casino executives told him privately they were grateful for the Mirage news because it pushed their boards or parent companies to move ahead on expansion plans that had been stalled for months and in some cases years.
But every new expansion also fuels Mr. Trump's argument that the Atlantic City market is so hot that state subsidies and property improvements are not needed.
For Mr. Wynn, the new activity, and the transportation concerns it has set off as construction scaffolds rise, support his argument that Atlantic City's street system is near capacity. At the same time, the growth in gambling revenues and the new convention center make the city more attractive for his investment, and presumably increases the incentive for him to compromise.
Most analysts seem convinced that Mr. Wynn will come because, on the East Coast at least, there really is no place else for him to go, and that some kind of roadway will be built because the property is worthless without it and because the potential economic payoff for the state in jobs and taxes is huge. The compromise is expected in the fine print of the financing.
All this leaves Governor Whitman, who has been central to Atlantic City's economic first act, equally central to its political second act. She said in an interview that the new strength of the market meant that the marina site would unquestionably be developed, whether by Mr. Wynn or someone else; that the state's priorities were to improve transportation within the city and balance the competing interests, and that she would not be bullied.
"I don't accept any ultimatums," Mrs. Whitman said. "We're trying to look at what makes the most sense for Atlantic City as a whole."
Atlantic City's Mayor, James Whelan, said he, too, must juggle the various pieces of a city very much in motion, making sure that residents benefit from the growth but also that developers are not thwarted by stubborn property owners who will not sell out. He said that the motion itself is the measure of health, and that the singular lesson of his city's history is that it is better in the midst of change, more confident of its place and its roots. Resort rhythms are in the blood, Mr. Whelan added.
"We invented this stuff," he said.

 CORRECTION:
A picture caption on June 24 about plans to tear down Greater Exodus Baptist Church in Atlantic City to make room for a road project misstated the financing plan for a replacement. The church is to be built with donations from parishioners and money raised by New Jersey through parking taxes. It is not being built solely with state money.

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW;
Teen-Agers Scavenging For a Vestige of Hope

BYLINE: By JOHN J. O'CONNOR 

 BODY:
This is the relatively slow time of year when prime time makes room among its overwhelmingly middle-class images to slip in a glimpse of the nation's poor and often troubled youth, the kind who do not fit easily into television's preferred happy endings.
Two such documentaries are being broadcast tonight. On PBS, the "P.O.V." series, an indispensable forum for independent nonfiction films, offers "a k a Don Bonus," a video diary compiled by an 18-year-old Cambodian youth completing his senior year in a San Francisco high school. On CBS, "One Last Chance," part of a sporadic series called "Before Your Eyes," shows what a CBS News crew recorded over a year and a half while following Juan Carlos Castro, a juvenile delinquent in Tampa, Fla. 
 Don Bonus is the American name assumed by Sokly Ny, who fled from the Khmer Rouge with his family at age 3 in 1979 to find a better life in the United States. The American dream turned out to be pocked with nightmares.
Still, at a community center for at-risk teen-agers, he met a film maker, Spencer Nakasako, who was teaching a class on video techniques. With Mr. Nakasako's encouragement and assistance, he began keeping a video diary, which with his family's reticence was not easy. "We're from Cambodia and we're pretty traditional," he notes. "Talking about issues, about family secrets, to the public, we don't do that."
The soft-spoken Don plunges in with persistent nerve and candor. The family is seen initially in a miserable housing project where it is dangerous to look out the barred windows because of gun violence on the street. In one burglary, a family is wiped out as the thieves, Don observes wryly, take even the soy sauce. At school Don is sinking into D's and F's, and graduation will depend on his passing a reading proficiency exam.
Don is most troubled by the disintegration of his family. His mother is living with a man whom the children dislike; his older brother, Chandara, who had replaced the father left behind in Cambodia, is now caring for his own family and is busy advancing economically. Taping his brother from a distance at a party, Don suddenly begins crying.
In the end Don gets his diploma but the family is not able to witness the ceremony. They are at a court hearing for Don's younger brother who, arrested for attempted murder at school, is being packed off to reform school. Everything is far from fine, obviously, but the completion of this diary is an optimistic signpost on the way to Don's future.
In CBS News's more polished production, including narration by the actor Laurence Fishburne and a music track by Digable Planets, the story of Tampa's Juan Carlos Castro is far less encouraging. We meet Juan as he is arrested for a series of car thefts. At 14 he is already a father, with a second child on the way. His mother, a former prostitute, is a crack addict; his father, who lives in Newark, is just out of prison and on parole for drug dealing. Juan has been in 35 foster homes. With a record of three felonies already, he is given one last chance by Detective Carlos Sommellan, who enrolls the youth in an experimental program that closely tracks teen-age offenders.
At Manatee County Boot Camp in Tampa, Juan encounters a kind of "tough love" in the rigorous discipline administered by the commander, Lee Vallier. Juan thrives in the militarylike atmosphere, learning to read at college level and eventually being chosen as graduation speaker. When he is taken in by the family of Bill Clyburn, a sociologist who is an expert on dysfunctional teens, Juan seems like a poster boy for the rehabilitation program. But his transformation is short-lived.
Within weeks he is having trouble in school and sneaking off at night from the Clyburn home. The Clyburn family takes him to visit his father in Newark, but his yearning for a reunion with his own family ("They gotta accept me, I'm their blood") is cruelly snuffed. Mr. Clyburn finally decides he has had enough when Juan takes a family car for a joy ride. Formal charges are pressed, and Juan faces trial in adult court and the possibility of five years in state prison. Detective Sommellan pleads for parole and community service. Juan's future is left looking grim.
The documentary can be annoyingly sketchy. Near the end, it is mentioned that Mr. Vallier had to resign his boot camp post because of charges of abuse. But instead of details, we get only Mr. Vallier's response: "It was not abuse, it was discipline." The portrait of Juan needs all the clarity it can muster. As it stands, the hopelessness it discovers is shattering.

HEADLINE: Pulp Mill Legislation Raises No Conflict

 BODY:
To the Editor:
A June 18 news article on my bill to extend an Alaskan pulp mill's contract for cutting timber from Tongass National Forest confuses representing one's constituents with the mystical "appearance" of a conflict of interest.
My legislation would extend for 15 years a contract to the sole surviving pulp mill in southeast Alaska so the mill could have some assurance of wood to justify the investment to keep operating. Extending the contract is intended only to keep some 4,000 Alaskans working; it will have no impact on the environment. 
 A contract extension also will permit the pulp mill to pioneer a chlorine-free production process. And the mill has no other source of timber since there is no state or private timber in the region.
The contract extension is not coming at the the forest's expense. More than 60 percent of the forest's old-growth has been protected from harvest, leaving only 10 percent potentially open to timber development.
I have owned stock in two Alaska banks since it was given to me when my father died in 1952. I have declared those investments publicly since I have been in the Senate. I held the stock when I voted in 1990 for the Tongass Timber Reform Act, which took a million additional acres out of the timber base and ended a $40 million subsidy to the timber industry. If there was a conflict of interest, it existed then.
From the standpoint of personal gain, I could have invested my holdings outside Alaska and generated higher appreciation in blue-chip stocks, but I believe that one of the best ways to represent my constituents is to participate in my state's economy.
There is no conflict of interest here since by this legislation I am trying to save the third-largest element of southeast Alaska's economy.
 
FRANK H. MURKOWSKI
U.S. Senator from Alaska
Washington, June 20, 1996

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter
