HEADLINE: Jacob's Pillow Is Opening, but a Trauma Lingers

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

DATELINE: BECKET, Mass.

 BODY:
Visitors returning to the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in the Berkshires this summer won't notice the change. The white clapboard houses and weathered barns nestled in the overgrown remnants of an 18th-century farm are still home to myriad flora, fauna and lithe young bodies in leotards. The season, which officially begins June 25, will again mix the familiar and the exotic, everything from the Mark Morris Dance Group to Malavika Sarukkai performing Bharata Natyam, the classic dance of South India.
But something is very different: Jacob's Pillow narrowly escaped bankruptcy and foreclosure last winter, when it was unable to meet interest payments on $4.8 million borrowed in the early 1990's to renovate a deteriorating facility. And while the 64-year-old institution survived, its near-death experience is a sign of just how much the economics of dance have deteriorated in the last decade and how dependent dance has become on the kindness of its relatively few friends. 
 The Pillow, as it is called, is not the only icon of the dance world to have a brush with financial disaster in recent years. In 1992, American Ballet Theater required a multimillion-dollar infusion from private donors to pay off its accumulated debt. Last year the Joffrey Ballet slashed expenses and moved to Chicago to stay afloat. "All the operating assumptions of the 1970's and 1980's are out the window," concludes Robert Crane, executive director of the Joyce Mertz-Gilmore Foundation, which rescued the festival with a loan last December.
Jacob's Pillow has come a long way since 1931, when Ted Shawn, the modern dance pioneer, bought the worn-out farm as a retreat for his all-male company and staged "lecture-tea demonstrations" to pay the kerosene bills. Mr. Shawn opened a dance school in 1940 and with help from benefactors, a 500-seat theater in 1942 to anchor an annual summer dance festival.
It grew modestly with the tourism economy of the Berkshires through the 1950's and 60's. By Mr. Shawn's death in 1972, it had evolved into a summer refuge for dozens of dance companies, a place to develop and showcase new work. "The Pillow had become a core institution in the dance world," said Sali Ann Kriegsman, former head of dance at the National Endowment for the Arts, who was appointed executive director of the festival in May 1995.
But by the standard of, say, Tanglewood, the facilities were primitive. The parking lot, which abutted the theater, spoiled the bucolic ambiance; the restrooms would have seemed more in place in a World War II Army barracks. And by the 1980's, deferred maintenance had taken a serious toll. "Dance groups were telling us that it used to be romantic to come, but now it's not safe to use the stage," recalled Sam Miller, a former director of Jacob's Pillow.
The Massachusetts Industrial Finance Agency offered to help find a lender to underwrite a major facelift. Two issues totaling $4.8 million were sold in 1989 and 1991 to the Fidelity Massachusetts Tax-Free Fund, one of dozens of mutual funds run by the giant Boston-based Fidelity group. "The idea was to complete the renovation quickly and then pay off the debt from our capital funding campaign," Mr. Miller explained.
By all signs, the festival spent the money wisely. The parking lot was moved and expanded in time for the 1993 season, leaving space for a cafe on a handsome, tree-shaded lawn. The original Shawn theater was brought up to snuff, and a smaller studio theater was opened for avant-garde productions. Unglamorous projects -- roof repairs, sewerage and the like -- were also completed.
The catch was that the debt to Fidelity carried a $432,000 annual interest charge, one-fifth of the Pillow's annual budget. Mr. Miller hoped to cover half from operating surpluses and the rest from Government grants and private donations. But his timing could hardly have been worse, coming just as Congressional Republicans were gearing up to slash Federal money for the arts, and almost all nonprofit arts groups were feeling the pinch from the 1990-91 recession.
Donations stagnated, and the Pillow failed to meet its semiannual interest payments in December 1994 and June 1995. Fidelity responded by requiring the festival to commission a business review from a management consultant and by reminding the stunned board that the bonds were backed by a mortgage on the festival's land and buildings.
The consultant reportedly offered no insights into how the Pillow could dig its way out of the financial hole. Operations were already lean. And asking donors to cough up more cash to feather the nests of mutual fund shareholders was not appealing.
There was an ace in the hole, though: the Pillow was effectively judgment-proof. Foreclosure was a hollow threat, as The resale value of the property was only about $600,000, and Fidelity would have been legally obliged to pay off the festival's $250,000 credit line from the First National Bank of the Berkshires before it could realize a penny. After protracted negotiations with Neil Chrisman, a former banker at Morgan Guaranty who had become board chairman in January 1995, Paul Engler, the Pillow's new managing director, and Ms. Kriegsman, Fidelity agreed to settle for $1.25 million, provided the check was written by Dec. 31, 1995.
In fact, Jacob's Pillow was obliged to raise $1.5 million in a matter of six weeks because the bank had to be paid off before Fidelity. A chunk came as emergency grants from board members and an anonymous donor. But the bulk came from the Joyce Mertz-Gilmore Foundation, which lent the Pillow $1.25 million from its $50 million endowment. "It's rare when you have the opportunity to make such a difference in an institution this important," explained Mr. Crane, the foundation's director.
Looking on the bright side, Jacob's Pillow has, however inadvertently, been able to finance needed maintenance and worthy capital improvements for roughly two bits on the dollar. But lenders lacking effective means of enforcing their claims don't come along every day. And like almost every other institution connected to dance, the Pillow now faces an economic future in which it must run ever faster just to stay in place.
Revenues from ticket sales are expected to reach $953,000 this year, up slightly from 1995 but barely enough to cover 39 percent of the Pillow's operating budget. Raising ticket prices would be no panacea: with seats already running $27 to $43 for performances in the main theater. Nor would a strategy of filling more seats with aggressive marketing: the current budget already assumes the theaters will run at 93 percent of capacity.
Sales of T-shirts, chardonnay and melon with prosciutto should generate about $260,000 this summer. But the offsetting cost of running the shop, cafe and canteen will leave a profit of just a few thousand dollars.
Cutting expenses significantly also seems like a nonstarter. The marketing, fund-raising and administrative overhead are modest for an organization of this size and ambition. It might be possible to pare fees paid to dance groups, but the Pillow is not eager to impoverish hard-pressed artists, most of whom already accept less than their going rates as concessions to the festival.
That implies the festival must raise $1.1 million from individuals, corporations, foundations and government agencies simply to break even in 1996. And starting next year, it must find new revenues to pay the 6 percent interest on its debt to the Joyce Mertz-Gilmore Foundation, not to mention new money to begin paying off the $1.25 million principal.
Mr. Engler, a former business consultant to nonprofit groups, thinks the Pillow can earn a bit more on food and is exploring higher prices for the very best seats for the most popular performances. But he thinks the best hope for a firmer financial footing lies in increasing corporate giving and expanding the ranks of individual donors.
Trouble is, so does everyone raising money for nonprofit groups who, in a pinch, used to be able to turn to a favorite foundation, a particularly devoted angel or the nice folks in Washington. The question now, suggests Neil Chrisman, is, "How do you find water in a desert?"

HEADLINE: Let's Add 4 To the G-7

BYLINE: By Zbigniew Brzezinski; Zbigniew Brzezinski was national security adviser in the Carter Administration.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The Group of Seven industrial nations has to be reformed, or its annual summit meeting should be scrapped.
The meetings, like the one that begins on Thursday in Lyons, France, were originally intended as get-togethers of the leaders of the principal democracies, the largest free-market economies and the most advanced societies. But today the group's membership is no longer representative of power or of principle, and it needs to be expanded. Russia, admitted as the Soviet Union in 1991 on a limited basis, cannot now be excluded. For that reason alone, China, India and Brazil are as entitled to participation as Russia, and in some respects much more so. 
 A timely initiative in 1974, the summit meeting was an outgrowth of Western Europe's and Japan's postwar recovery. The gathering responded to the need for greater global coordination among the main economic centers. It also enhanced American-European dialogue at a time when Western Europe was becoming more serious about political unity and when the United States was trying to recover its moorings after the Vietnam War. And Japan, growing in economic importance, was engaged in a wider political relationship.
After bickering about who should be included, the seven states were effectively self-selected: the United States, Canada, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Japan. The discrepancies in gross domestic product and population were as marked then as today. Nonetheless, the seven met the membership requirements.
But 22 years later, the annual meeting no longer upholds them. Leaving aside that the informal get-together has turned into a circus dominated by pomp and circumstance and is attended by hundreds of officials, the very concept of the Group of Seven not only has become compromised but distorts global realities.
The first breach of principle was the admission of the Soviet Union in 1991. Mikhail Gorbachev, the nonelected President and head of the ruling Communist Party, was invited to take part only in the talks about Western aid for his ailing economy. As a sop to his pride, he was promised he would be invited to the 1992 meeting in Munich. But a political coup forced him from office and the Soviet Union was dissolved.
Boris Yeltsin took his place in the years since, also participating on a limited basis. (He won't attend this week's meeting because of the runoff election in Russia.) The Group of Seven calculated that including him would bolster his political position at home and thus enhance the chances of democratic reform.
For the Russians, President Yeltsin's presence satisfies their craving for continued status as a world power, and Moscow officials have begun calling the meeting the "P-8" -- for Political Eight.
But this ambiguity, to which the other leaders have acquiesced in their eagerness to help Mr. Yeltsin, poses several problems. First, a Government that has killed more than 40,000 people in Chechnya who wanted to secede does not quite meet democratic standards. When Mr. Gorbachev was admitted, the Soviet Union could not even pretend to be a democracy. The membership criterion of democracy yielded to political expediency. But now such elasticity should apply to other countries as well.
Second, Russia is not even in the forefront of free-market economies or of any other type of economy. It is a developing country, though armed with nuclear weapons. If its military status justifies its inclusion, what about other states with nuclear ambitions?
Lest the annual meeting become totally meaningless, however, only four new members, including Russia, should be added. Though the criterion of democracy has been compromised, it should be retained, though redefined to mean that some progress toward significant political or economic pluralism is required. The size of the country's economy and existence of significant free-market sectors should be taken into account.
China is a genuine economic success and a major military power. It galls Chinese leaders to be excluded while Russia's leaders boast of their role in the "P-8."
India is the world's largest democracy, with yet another successful election under its belt. Although India is weaker economically than China, its economy is growing rapidly. Without India, the Group of Seven cannot pretend to be inclusively democratic. Brazil's successful democratic presidential election last year, as well as its effective financial and economic reforms -- not to speak of its size and population -- similarly justify membership.
Perhaps in five years or so, South Korea and Mexico might be considered, too. For now, only when the Group of Seven becomes the Group of 11 can the world's central political and economic problems be properly addressed.

HEADLINE: Iraq Agrees to Ease Way for U.N. Monitors

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, June 24

 BODY:
In a move that officials here regard as a significant concession by President Saddam Hussein, Iraq has signed an agreement with the United Nations that is intended to speed the process of eliminating all Iraqi weapons of mass destruction so that economic sanctions can finally be lifted.
Weapons monitors believe that arms or components are still being concealed by Iraq nearly six years after its invasion of Kuwait and the imposition of economic sanctions that have crippled the Iraqi economy. The monitors will soon test the accord with an inspection that may involve politically sensitive sites. 
 In a separate agreement with the United Nations, Iraq agreed on May 20 to supervised oil sales to raise up to $2 billion in six months to pay for urgent civilian needs. But details are still being negotiated, and a Security Council sanctions committee has not yet approved a final plan.
The new agreement was signed on Saturday by Deputy Prime Minister Tariq Aziz of Iraq and Rolf Ekeus, the Swedish diplomat who is chairman of the commission charged with monitoring Iraqi compliance. The agreement includes an unequivocal pledge by Iraq to allow United Nations inspectors "immediate, unconditional and unrestricted access" to all suspect sites.
It sets up a regular system of meetings between Mr. Ekeus and Mr. Aziz to review the process, and it establishes a schedule for turning over long-requested Iraqi documentation by the end of this month.
The accord was made public today by Mr. Ekeus, who went to Iraq last week armed with Security Council demands for cooperation that stopped short of the American desire to include a threat of force. His visit followed Iraqi refusals the week before to allow an inspection team to enter buildings controlled by President Hussein's Republican Guard.
American diplomats here, who have taken the strongest position against the lifting of sanctions, said today that they were pleased that Mr. Ekeus had achieved a pledge of unconditional access. But given their experience with Iraq, they said, they would wait to see what happened next. One American official said that it was likely to be a long time before any relaxation of sanctions could be up for discussion.
Mr. Ekeus said at a news conference today that a decision made by the Iraqi leadership to open even sensitive sites controlled by the same forces that protect the President and his innermost circle was important.
"I don't underestimate the concessions Iraq has made," said Mr. Ekeus, who in the past has heard promises of Iraqi compliance that were not fulfilled. He said his request for written agreement produced some "heartburn" in Iraq.
"I told them a 'no' to this would mean serious repercussions for Iraq," Mr. Ekeus said. In return, the United Nations gave a vague pledge to respect Iraqi sovereignty and territorial integrity.
One underlying message in this pledge is that given access to very sensitive sites, inspectors will not poke around in material they may find that does not relate to weapons. Mr. Ekeus said that access to computers has been a delicate issue for this reason, even though inspectors have been instructed to search for terms relevant only to their task.
Mr. Ekeus reiterated today, however, that there is still much to be accomplished in Iraq because the Government continues to conceal what he called "some important components of weapons and telltale documents."
He said that Iraq insists it has destroyed some arms or equipment that the inspectors of the United Nations Special Commission, as it is formally called, want to account for. But the Iraqis have not produced the necessary documentary proof. Iraq also uses a range of concealment techniques, Mr. Ekeus said.
"Iraq is not concealing things only by static means," he said. "We are also concerned about moving things on trucks or other forms of transportation. They have highly dynamic methods of storing things."
Mr. Ekeus, whom Iraqi newspapers had called a "liar" and a "cowboy" before his arrival in Baghdad last week, said his discussions with the Iraqis were somber but more cordial than the Government's public posturing. He said that on Friday, after a series of meetings on Wednesday and Thursday, the United Nations delegation handed Mr. Aziz a draft agreement. On Saturday morning Mr. Ekeus was informed that the Iraqi leadership had accepted the document, which was signed later in the day.
Inspectors from the Special Commission are responsible for finding and destroying biological and chemical weapons and missiles deemed offensive rather than defensive. Another team, from the International Atomic Energy Commission, looks for evidence of nuclear weapons or programs to produce them.
The new agreement with Iraq covers both monitoring processes. In addition to destroying its weapons, Iraq must account for missing prisoners of war and return property stolen from Kuwait.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
As Summit Talks Near, A Defense

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

 BODY:
A few days before a meeting of top leaders of the Group of Seven industrial nations, a senior United States Treasury official defended their stewardship of the world economy yesterday, saying they had corrected exchange-rate misalignments, reduced currency volatility and promoted fiscal discipline, while strengthening the international monetary system against shocks.
Deputy Secretary of the Treasury Lawrence H. Summers, addressing the Emerging Market Traders Association in New York, said that by seeking a consensus on prudent domestic policies rather than by direct intervention in the markets, the major economic nations had carried out an "orderly reversal" of exchange-rate movements. They called for such a shift in April 1995, when the dollar was considered undervalued. 
 Mr. Summers said that policies by the Group of Seven -- which will convene starting Thursday in Lyons, France -- had reduced currency volatility to the lowest level in a decade. At the same time, he said, a concentration on sound domestic policies had brought average inflation down to the lowest rates in a generation. Mr. Summers also cited progress in reducing budget deficits and in narrowing trade imbalances, with Japan's current account surplus falling from 3.5 percent of output three years ago to less than 2 percent now.
But he disagreed with those who want the Group of Seven to translate the notion of more stable currencies into fixed exchange rates. Not only does the size of today's globalized capital market rule this out, he said, but such a system could have undesirable consequences if it forced leaders to use domestic policy to achieve an exchange-rate objectives.
"Would it have made sense, for example, to have forced the Fed to ease in late 1994 to contain the dollar's rise, despite the inflation risks still evident then?" he asked with regard to American interest rates.
He said the Group of Seven had strengthened the international monetary system against the risk of another currency crisis like Mexico's. The group, he noted, had created a financial safety net, tightened surveillance over suspect economies by the International Monetary Fund, and encouraged countries to publish timely economic data.
Mr. Summers said the leaders would lend some impetus to efforts to lighten the debt burdens of the poorest countries. Officials confirmed yesterday that prospects for a debt-relief plan remained uncertain, with three members of the Group of Seven -- Germany, Japan and Italy -- still resisting pressure from the four others -- the United States, Britain, France and Canada -- to order the I.M.F. to sell gold to finance it.
Mr. Summers said the seven national leaders would endorse a review of the World Bank and of regional development banks. Against a backdrop of declines in conventional foreign aid and increasingly global capital markets, he said, those agencies would be urged to help developing nations attract foreign investment by promoting healthy and educated work forces and protecting investors against political risks.
The Group of Seven, underscoring its interest in strengthening the development institutions, has for the first time invited to the talks the United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, the World Bank president, James D. Wolfensohn; the head of the International Monetary Fund, Michel Camdessus, and Renato Ruggiero, who directs the World Trade Organization.
Mr. Summers's defense of Group of Seven policies came as the imminence of the summit meeting, and the attendant hullabaloo, was causing some to renew questions about the usefulness of such exercises.
The latest skeptics are C. Fred Bergsten, a former Assistant Treasury Secretary, who runs the Institute for International Economics in Washington, and C. Randall Henning, a visiting fellow there.
In a book published this month titled "Global Economic Leadership and the Group of Seven," they say the economic powers are becoming increasingly ineffective and are failing to counter low growth, with the members practicing a "nonaggression pact" in which they refrain from criticizing each other's policies.

HEADLINE: ATLANTA 1996 -- BADMINTON IN INDONESIA;
This Is No Picnic: In Southeast Asia, Respect Rides on a Shuttlecock

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER CLAREY 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia

 BODY:
Nobody knows precisely how many Indonesians were lining the streets of this massive, sprawling city when Susi Susanti and Alan Budi Kusuma came home in August 1992. Some estimates put the crowd at 500,000; others at more than a million.
But this much is certain. As Susanti and Budi Kusuma stood in an open car with leis and Olympic gold medals around their necks and inched toward the national monument in Merdeka square, they had a new appreciation for the power of the very subtle game of badminton. 
 "On Sudirman, our main street, we could hardly move; it was jammed with people all shouting congratulations," Budi Kusuma said. "For five or six hours, we just kept going and going. It was like in Europe for the soccer championship or Brazil for the World Cup."
Indonesia, the world's fourth most populous nation with an estimated 190 million inhabitants, does not produce renowned athletes in major professional sports like soccer and basketball or in glamorous Olympic sports like gymnastics or track and field. But badminton, known here as "bulutangkis," is a very different matter. And when all of the players on its national team are swatting shuttlecocks at the country's training facility, it is the greatest collection of badminton talent under one roof on the planet.
There is Susanti, the intensely competitive 25-year-old considered one of the finest female players in history. She has the muscular legs of a beach volleyball star and the flexibility of a ballerina (she lunges for drop shots by doing splits). There are Ricky Subagja and Rexy Mainaky, the reigning men's doubles world champions and Olympic favorites this summer. There are also Budi Kusuma, who happens to be Susanti's fiance, and Hariyanto Arbi, the baby-faced powerhouse who won the last men's world title, and three other men ranked in the top 10 in the world.
Nearly four years after Budi Kusuma and Susanti won the first Olympic medals in the 50-year history of Indonesia, the throngs of people were missing on a trip to the training center in the southern Jakarta suburb of Cipayung. Instead, stray chickens and stray garbage lined the narrow unpaved streets that led into a large, landscaped compound with barbed wire on its high walls.
"You would never know this was here unless you were looking for it," Budi Kusuma said.
The Indonesians chose this unlikely spot for the training center in November 1992 because they wanted more space and privacy than was available in congested central Jakarta.
"The players are better here," said Indra Gunawan, the head coach of the Indonesian badminton team. "Before, they go to the movies or go out and maybe not concentrate. When it's far from the city, they do nothing but badminton."
 
Training Is Life; Life Is Training
Sunday, even in a largely Muslim nation, is the only day of rest for the approximately 80 elite players and 18 coaches who are based here. When they are not competing in tournaments, the players train six days a week for as much as eight hours a day in an enormous hall that resembles a converted airplane hangar. They sleep in two air-conditioned dormitories -- one for women and one for men -- behind the training hall and eat in a cafeteria equipped with video games, giant-screen satellite television and a pool table.
It is, in essence, a gilded cage. Players must train here if they wish to compete internationally for Indonesia and only a few players, normally those who are married, are permitted to live outside the compound.
"This is our home," said Susanti, who comes from a small town in West Java and is one of the rare players not required to share her dorm room. "I go back to see my parents only twice a year."
She does not express doubts about this arrangement, however.
"Badminton is the only sport right now that can bring Indonesia's name to the world," Susanti said. "When Alan and I got gold medals in singles in Barcelona, the world knew Indonesia better. I am very proud about that."
Still, much of the world took virtually no notice. Badminton is a major sport throughout southeast and east Asia. But, outside of Denmark, the rest of the west has yet to wake up to it.
The sport has not always been so disconnected. The modern version of badminton is based on the Indian game poona, refined and codified in England in the late 19th century. The sport got its name because it was a popular activity at the Duke of Beaufort's country seat: Badminton House.
It soon became fashionable in the United States and in the 1950's and 1960's, Americans made a habit of winning world titles. Joe Alston was considered an intriguing enough player for a new magazine called Sports Illustrated to put him on its cover in March 1955. But with the rise of network television and the major team sports, badminton receded far into the shadows, and by 1995 the United States had only about 3,000 registered players. Susanti, like others in her sport, is optimistic that badminton's inclusion in the Olympics in 1992 will ultimately broaden its reach.
"After Atlanta, maybe America will know badminton better," Susanti said.
But for America to know badminton better, it will have to get the opportunity to watch it on television, and that is certainly not part of NBC's master plan this summer. What viewers will miss is a remarkably fast and often spectacular indoor game that has little to do with the summer variant lazily played in backyards and loosely associated with straw boaters and unmuscular men.
"I always maintain that top-level badminton makes top tennis players look pretty wimpish," said the International Badminton Federation's executive director David Shaw.
The Indonesians' rigorous training regimen includes an exercise called "shadow badminton" in which they go through the motions of their sport in a sand pit. "Our bodies are not as big as the Europeans," Budi Kusuma said, "so we have to be faster and stronger."
 
The Search for Talent Is an Unending Pursuit
The Indonesians' advantage is that their omnipresent national federation, known by its Indonesian abbreviation of PBSI, covers all their expenses and, with help from corporate sponsors, operates 37 regional training centers in this far-flung archipelago. Talented youths are identified early by scouts, and the most promising end up in Cipayung in their late teens, although some, like Susanti and the latest female phenom, Mia Audina, arrive as early as age 15. Rich and powerful clubs like Jaya Raya in Jakarta also recruit young players and pay stars like Susanti handsomely to represent them.
Despite Indonesia's regional emphasis, elite badminton is almost exclusively played in Java, which, with 110 million people, is easily the most populous of the country's 13,677 islands. The top players, including Susanti and Budi Kusuma, are almost all ethnic Chinese, a minority group that has often faced discrimination in Indonesia but has considerable economic clout.
"If you ask me why, I'd say it's because badminton is a sport that not every family can afford to play," said Rudy Hartono, the greatest men's player in Indonesian history. "Playing outdoors costs little, but indoors can be expensive."
Resentment occasionally surfaces. But the players are quick to play down the significance of their ethnic origins and point to Joko Suprianto, a male player of Javan descent currently ranked No. 1 in the world, as evidence that the sport's base is broadening.
Badminton arrived here in the 1930's while Indonesia was still a Dutch colony, supposedly after Chinese traders brought the game to the island of Sumatra. But the sport did not really take flight until 13 years after independence in 1958, when Ferry Sonneville and Tan Joe Hock led Indonesia to victory in the Thomas Cup, badminton's version of the Davis Cup. It was the first major international sporting success for the new nation.
Indonesia would go on to produce many top players, the best being Hartono, who would win the prestigious All-England singles title a record eight times before retiring as a national hero in 1982. After a long slump, during which the Chinese were dominant, the Indonesians came roaring back in the early 1990's under the energetic leadership of Gen. Try Sutrisno, the former PBSI president. Sutrisno, with his powerful connections in a country dominated by the military, proved particularly adept at encouraging sponsorship. He is now vice president of Indonesia, which certainly should not hurt sponsorship in the future.
 
Success and Prosperity Heighten Expectations
Susanti and Budi Kusuma, a longtime couple who plan to be married in a Catholic ceremony next February, are among those who have benefited most. They each reportedly received more than $500,000 from sponsors and government sources for their Barcelona victories: a huge payday in a nation where the average income is less than $1,000. The players' parking lot at Cipayung is filled with new Toyotas, Hondas and Opels. But Indonesia's best still cannot approach the earnings of other top international athletes. Arbi, ranked No. 1 in the world in 1995, probably earned no more than $200,000 from all sources last year. That is less than tennis stars Andre Agassi and Boris Becker can make in a week.
Will it remain so in the future? Or will Asia's burgeoning affluence do for badminton in the 21st century what the West's affluence did for tennis in the 20th?
There are signs of movement. In June 1994, the International Badminton Federation signed a 10-year deal with Star Television, the Asian satellite broadcaster, which guarantees increased exposure and prize money. The Indonesian players are excited, but they know, too, that greater rewards mean greater competition. The South Koreans, Danes and, in particular, the Chinese are very strong, and even Susanti is hardly a sure bet to defend her title in Atlanta.
Even so, the Indonesian people are already anticipating another celebration and, above all, another opportunity to remind the world that their huge, oft-ignored nation exists.
"Badminton is getting tougher and tougher," Budi Kusuma said, "but my country has become used to gold."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices End Day Flat

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended little changed yesterday as market participants braced for new supply this week and a meeting of Federal Reserve policy makers next week.
With virtually no data to give direction, trading was sluggish yesterday, with volume for the day among the lowest of the year. 
 The highlight of the session was the Government's regular weekly bill auction, in which bill rates were mixed. Retail interest was just a little short of expectations, but over all, the auction results met expectations. The rates for the three-months averaged 5.10 percent, up from 5.08 percent last week, and the rates for the six-month bill averaged 5.23 percent, down from 5.27 percent. The price of the 30-year bond gained 5/32, to 86 22/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, slipped to 7.08 percent, from 7.09 percent on Friday.
Prices of intermediate-term issues are expected to come under pressure over the next few days as dealers and investors sell some holdings to make room for today's sale of new two-year notes and tomorrow's sale of new five-year notes.
In when-issued trading yesterday, the two-year note being sold today was offered at price to yield 6.30 percent, while the five-year note was being offered at 6.71 percent.
Economic reports his week are not expected to provide clues on the next Federal Reserve move. The Fed's policy making group, the Federal Open Market Committee, starts a two-day meeting next Tuesday.
Some analysts say they do not expect the Fed to raise short-term interest rates until it sees evidence that inflation is accelerating.
"The latest beige book, prepared for the July 2 and 3 F.O.M.C. meeting, characterized the U.S. economy as growing at a moderate pace," said Bruce Steinberg, an economist with Merrill Lynch & Company, referring to the Fed's survey of regional conditions, known as the beige book.
Even if the Fed holds steady on interest rates at the July meeting, Mr. Steinberg said, many analysts will then expect the Fed to raise rates at the Aug. 20 meeting.
Still, many participants are convinced that the Fed will soon raise rates amid signs that the economy is growing faster than expected.
But Sung Won Sohn, chief economist of the Norwest Corportion, argues that a strong second quarter has already been factored into stock and bond prices.

HEADLINE: G.M.'s Labor Costs for Parts Exceed Rivals', Study Says

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: TROY, Mich., June 24

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation's labor costs for auto parts are $440 higher a vehicle than the Ford Motor Company's costs and $600 higher a vehicle than the Chrysler Corporation's because G.M. buys fewer parts from low-cost outside suppliers, according to a study issued here today.
The study, by an independent consulting firm in this northern suburb of Detroit, bolsters G.M.'s position in this summer's labor negotiations with the United Automobile Workers union. G.M. has been seeking extra concessions this year from the U.A.W. to offset the disadvantage the company has from manufacturing so many of its own parts using highly paid union workers. 
 Stephen P. Yokich, the president of the U.A.W., sharply criticized the study. He said Harbour & Associates, the consulting firm that produced the study, had looked only at labor costs and had not included the lower quality and lower productivity at many outside suppliers.
"This study adds nothing to the ongoing efforts of the U.A.W. or the companies to balance the requirements of high-quality, efficient production with the need to sustain the good jobs that drive our economy," he said.
But Linda Cook, a spokeswoman for G.M., saw some merit in the study. "It does point out, right now, a cost advantage" for G.M.'s domestic rivals, she said.
The figures, which do not include Japanese-owned factories in the United States and elsewhere, underline the enormous changes that have taken place over the last three decades in the way auto companies are organized. During the 1950's and 1960's, G.M.'s vast empire of parts factories was widely viewed as one of the company's biggest competitive advantages, providing enormous savings from the large-scale production of everything from car seats to brakes.
But a combination of underinvestment, poor management and numerous wage and benefit concessions to the U.A.W has turned the parts factories into a liability for G.M. The company estimates its hourly cost of labor at $43, including benefits for retirees, while suppliers' costs are half as much for some parts.
Jim Harbour, the founder of Harbour & Associates, said G.M.'s labor costs were too high for it to continue producing labor-intensive parts like seat covers. "Anything that's labor intensive, you're not going to compete in at $43 an hour," Mr. Harbour said.
To the irritation of the U.A.W., G.M. has said that it is looking for ways to make its parts operations more competitive and is in the process of selling or merging five parts factories.
Mr. Harbour said his firm had prepared today's report in response to numerous questions from various news organizations, and the report was not paid for by any auto maker.
Daniel Luria, a former U.A.W. economist who is now an analyst at the Industrial Technology Institute, a research group in Ann Arbor, Mich., said that the Harbour figures might overstate G.M.'s cost disadvantage. Up to $12 an hour of G.M.'s hourly labor costs comes from pension benefits, retiree health care and other expenses that G.M. would have to continue paying even if it transfers work to outside suppliers, he said.
Mr. Harbour said that only $7 or $8 an hour of G.M.'s costs reflected retirement benefits that would have to be paid in any case. G.M. pays its U.A.W. workers an average wage of $19.27 an hour and does not give a detailed breakdown of its other labor costs. Overtime pay and taxes like employer-paid Social Security premiums make up the rest of the $43 an hour.
General Motors produces its own car lighting systems, brakes and hardware like seat tracks, while Chrysler and Ford do not produce any. But while G.M. generally produces the most parts itself, the world's largest auto maker does not make its own car and truck windows, while Ford makes all of its windows and Chrysler manufactures 65 percent of its windows, Mr. Harbour said.
The common wisdom in Detroit is that General Motors makes 70 percent of its own parts, Ford makes 50 percent and Chrysler 30 percent. But Mr. Harbour said that parts production at G.M. accounted for less than half of its total costs.
Mr. Luria has estimated that the work done in General Motors factories accounts for only 45 percent of the cost of one of its cars. For Ford, the percentage is 38 percent and for Chrysler it is 34 percent, he calculates.
Chrysler, which has the highest profits for a vehicle of any auto maker in the world and is trying to persuade the U.A.W. not to insist on too large a share of those profits this year, said that having the lowest auto parts costs of any American auto maker was not enough.
"G.M. is not the benchmark, the Japanese producers are," Nicole Solomon, a Chrysler spokeswoman, said.

HEADLINE: Morgan Stanley And Merrill Set To Add Money Managers

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
The money management industry continued its rapid consolidation yesterday as Morgan Stanley confirmed it would pay $745 million to acquire Van Kampen American Capital Inc., a mutual fund company, and Merrill Lynch & Company agreed to pay $200 million to acquire Hotchkis & Wiley, an institutional money manager in Los Angeles.
A third deal may be in the works. CNBC, a business-news cable channel, and several news services reported yesterday that Franklin Resources Inc., a mutual fund company based in San Mateo, Calif., was close to buying Mutual Series Inc., a mutual fund group, for more than $500 million. 
 Lisa Gallegos, a spokeswoman for Franklin, declined to comment on the reports.
Mutual Series, whose flagship fund is Mutual Shares, has $17 billion in assets. The group is managed by Michael Price, a well-known portfolio manager who also runs Heine Securities. An assistant at Mr. Price's office in Short Hills, N.J., declined to comment yesterday.
Big Wall Street firms, like Morgan Stanley and Merrill Lynch, are aggressively building their money management businesses, believing them to be a good source of fee income. The acquisition of Van Kampen, which has $57 billion under management and is predominantly a retail business, also gives Morgan Stanley the equivalent of a big retail brokerage, a useful consumer for many of its financial products, and an entree into the retail business.
Clayton Dubilier & Rice, the investment firm that is selling its controlling 80 percent stake in Van Kampen to Morgan Stanley, stands to make a handsome profit from the transaction. Clayton invested a total of $272 million in Van Kampen, but is now selling the company for an aggregate value of $1.175 billion. That is because Morgan Stanley agreed to buy Van Kampen for $720 million in cash, and $25 million of exchangeable preferred securities and will assume about $430 million of Van Kampen's long-term debt.
But Morgan Stanley said in a statement that it had agreed that "in no circumstances will the sum of the equity purchase price and the remaining long-term debt exceed $1.175 billion." The parties expect to complete the purchase by Nov. 30, the end of Morgan Stanley's fiscal year.
"I think it's a very good transaction," said Joan S. Solotar, a vice president at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, commenting on the Morgan Stanley purchase. "It augments Morgan Stanley's growth in the asset management sector, particularly as it relates to retail distribution. It also gives them added bulk and economies of scale."
And, she added, at a purchase price that is equivalent to 14.1 times Van Kampen's earnings, Morgan Stanley "has not paid an absurd price." Nevertheless, she added, "because good will is significant, Morgan Stanley's return on equity will likely decline some."
Morgan Stanley officials told securities analysts yesterday that the prospective internal rate of return from the investment in Van Kampen was 18 to 20 percent, and therefore offered better prospective returns than those offered by Morgan Stanley's own stock, Ms. Solotar said. Morgan Stanley has recently used its resources to buy back its stock.
Analysts see the pattern of acquisition and consolidation among asset managers as inevitable.
"It seems to be the thing to do," said L. Hunter Hallowell, an analyst at Dresdner Securities (USA). "You've got to have that distribution, distribution, distribution." Morgan Stanley's acquisition of Van Kampen, he noted, effectively gives Morgan Stanley a big retail distribution network for its many financial products. It also swells Morgan Stanley's funds under management to close to $160 billion from about $100 billion.
"They have often claimed that if you don't have $100 billion or more" under management, Mr. Hallowell said, "you're not a serious player."
Van Kampen, which employs 1,200 people, was formed by the 1994 merger of Van Kampen Merritt in Chicago and American Capital Management and Research, based in Houston. It is the fourth-largest mutual fund company in the United States, with more than $57 billion under management.
With more than two million investors, Van Kampen represents a departure for Morgan Stanley, which has until now concentrated on selling its asset management services to institutions.
The Wall Street firm is clearly seeking to increase its ability to sell investment products that it currently sells to institutions. "This acquisition is consistent with our stated goal of accumulating assets and gives Morgan Stanley a strong U.S. distribution capability through which we can offer to individual investors some products traditionally sold primarily to major institutions," Richard B. Fisher, chairman, and John J. Mack, president, said in a joint statement.
Morgan Stanley believes that it is following an important trend by improving its access to retail investors. "Individual investors control a growing percentage of the world's capital," said Barton M. Biggs, chairman of Morgan Stanley Asset Management, "Van Kampen American Capital is an important strategic acquisition that will enhance Morgan Stanley's ability to benefit from this long term trend."
Hotchkis & Wiley, which will be acquired by Merrill Lynch, has more than $10 billion under management.
Hotchkis, founded in 1980, will remain in Los Angeles and retain its name as it becomes a unit of Merrill Lynch Capital Management Group. That Merrill Lynch unit currently manages about $23 billion of client assets, including $10.6 billion in institutional mutual funds. Altogether, Merrill has more than $730 billion of client assets.

HEADLINE: Daytona Beach Journal;
'Birthplace of Speed' Has Adversary: Yes, a Turtle

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.

 BODY:
In this city famous for fast cars and wide beaches, driving on the hard-packed sand is about as old as the automobile itself. The allure is not just the convenience, swimsuit-clad drivers explain, but also the tradition -- of slow cruising along miles of surf, of tailgate parties by the dunes, of sunbathing in the back of a pickup truck.
Auto racing, already a fixture here on Volusia County beaches in the early 1900's, may have since moved to the speedway, but beach parking and driving, even if only at the legal limit of 10 miles an hour, remain a cultural icon and tourist attraction. 
 "Parking, having access to the beach, you can't take that away," said Alan Rosecrans, a 51-year-old retiree from Orlando. "You'd take away my childhood, what I've done since I was a kid."
But now the home of the Daytona 500 is caught up in a dispute over cars, and the reason is the loggerhead turtle, a lumbering visitor to "the birthplace of speed."
The loggerhead, a large sea turtle, is on the Federal threatened-species list, and its nesting season runs from May to October, corresponding to a season when 26 miles of the county's Atlantic coastline, in Daytona Beach, New Smyrna Beach and Ormond Beach, are crowded with people and wheels.
Local environmentalists sued the county last year under the Endangered Species Act, arguing that cars all too often ran over turtle nests, in the dunes, and that turtle hatchlings were hit by cars, got stuck in tire ruts or became disoriented by headlights and lights from beachfront property as they tried to cross from their nests to the ocean at night. The plaintiffs seek a ban on beach driving during the nesting months.
That prospect enrages many beachgoers, who threaten to stay home if beach driving is outlawed -- no small worry for an area where beach-related businesses account for about half the economy. As many as five million vehicles use the beach each year, Volusia County officials say, bringing about $3 million annually in beach access fees alone.
Only a few beaches in the entire country still allow driving, and none of the others are so well known as those here. On a recent weekend, vehicles ranging from trucks to golf carts stretched as far as the eye could see along the shoreline, either parked by the dunes or rolling slowly on two marked lanes. More people were sitting in open car trunks next to their coolers than lying on towels near the water.
The beach can be up to 500 feet wide at low tide, and the footing is solid. It is big enough, and sufficiently hard-packed, that not only stock car racing but even plane rides were once found there.
But it is also one of the places where the 300-pound adult female loggerheads -- and to a lesser extent green turtles, on the Government's endangered-species list -- crawl ashore at night, looking for the soft sand of the dunes to lay their eggs.
Once the eggs are laid, the adults depart. Then, on a night two months later, the hatchlings emerge from the eggs, and their survival depends largely on escaping predators like raccoons by making it quickly to the ocean, which they find by orienting themselves with the water's reflection of the nighttime sky. Because of the dangers that cars and artificial lights add to those from predators, the survival rate among the hatchlings can be as low as 1 in 10,000, experts say.
Only about 3 percent of all the loggerhead's annual nesting activity in Florida, the species' primary nesting area in the United States, occurs along the 49 miles of Volusia County beaches, county officials say. And the number of nests reported along the 26 miles where driving is allowed totals only a few hundred, out of thousands in the county as a whole.
But those suing the county say all nesting beaches are crucial to preservation of a threatened species. They also say their efforts would have a beneficial side effect, helping to prevent the occasional accident in which a beachgoer is run over by a stray car.
"In 1968, when my husband and I moved here, you didn't see 500 cars a day on the beach," said one plaintiff, Shirley Reynolds, a 59-year-old resident of New Smyrna Beach. "Now there are millions a season. It's a zoo."
Last summer a Federal court where the suit had been filed issued an order that forced the county to prohibit beach driving at night and to erect markers to keep cars from parking over nests. Now, in an effort to avert a trial that could lead to a total ban on beach driving from the beginning of May through October, the county has proposed to close nine miles of the most sensitive beach to vehicles while keeping the rest open with restrictions.
"We think we have come up with a good balance," said Joe Wooden, deputy chief of beach operations for the Volusia County Beach Department.
But losing any stretch of the beach to a few turtles offends some, especially those whose livelihoods are at stake. Concessionaries say they lose as much as 85 percent of their business on days when, under another curb imposed by last year's court order, the beach opens to cars late -- or not at all -- to protect the turtle conservation zone at high tide.
"Who's more important, us or the turtles?" said Richard Mason, who sells food and rents chairs in New Smyrna Beach.
And many drivers do not want to give up the convenience of not having to carry chairs and coolers any distance, of people-watching at cruising speed, of experiencing nature from the comfort of their machines.
"You take driving away, and Daytona will go down," said Jeff Wagner, 22, a landscaper from Orlando.
Others, meanwhile, seem to have caught on to the environmental concern. Indeed, the battle over the loggerhead has prompted an interest among county officials in using the turtles to attract ecotourists.
Still, turtle-cheering is one thing, car-bashing another. Were beach driving banned, said Adam Lovell, an 18-year-old lifeguard, "you'd probably have a riot."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Driving on the beaches of Volusia County, Fla., is a custom as old as the automobile itself. But it will be a thing of the past, at least from May through October, if a Federal court fight over the loggerhead turtle, a threatened species, is resolved in the favor of environmentalists. (Jack Mitchell for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In Times Square, Keepers of the Glitz;
3 Women Overseeing Block's Rebirth Promise to Return Its Splendor

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER 

 BODY:
Not long ago, Gretchen Dykstra took a phone call from a merchant looking for business space. The merchant was no Michael Eisner or Richard Branson; he represented a small, very small, business. But Ms. Dykstra, the president of the Times Square Business Improvement District, was enthusiastic about his proposal.
"This is a guy who has a 20-foot long, 10-foot-high fiberglass hot dog from which he sells hot dogs," Ms. Dykstra said. "It's called 'Between the Buns.' I said to him: 'You know, that's a name that might work in Times Square.' " 
 Listening to her recount this story recently, Rebecca Robertson and Cora Cahan reacted with delight, for they share Ms. Dykstra's enthusiasm for what she calls "the gestalt of Times Square" and which she defines as "eclectic, vital, colorful and sort of in your face, a certain esthetic chaos."
Together, they also happen to be in charge of it.
"The three witches of Times Square," Ms. Dykstra said.
"The three good witches," said Ms. Cahan, the president of the New 42d Street, a nonprofit organization responsible for restoring use to eight once-grand but outmoded theaters on the block. (The first, the New Victory, reopened as the city's first children's theater in December.)
"Oh, please," said Ms. Robertson, the president of the 42d Street Development Project, the state agency in charge of the transformation of 42d Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, and which, among other things, established the New 42d Street.
There are, of course, dozens if not hundreds of people who have been involved in the plans to reconfigure and reinvigorate Times Square, but by now the three women, admiring acquaintances if not friends, collegial and cooperative if not officially allied, have become the primary overseers of the rebirth of perhaps the world's most famous neighborhood.
Avowed fans of the neon, overwrought commercialism that made Times Square a notorious cavern of garishness and excess, they promise that as time goes on, it will be the same only more so, though without the squalor and danger that, in the late 1980's and early 1990's, seemed to swallow whatever glamour the area once possessed.
"We used to have what we called the D-word era," Ms. Robertson said. "Whenever there was an article about us, there were all these D-words: dead, desolate, dismal, dreary."
"And S-words," Ms. Dykstra said. "Seamy, seedy, slimy, scuzzy. It's extraordinary how hard it is to change the mindset of the public and the press."
Ms. Cahan noted that, in contrast, recent articles about the refurbishing and moving of the Empire Theater to have it serve as an entrance to a 26-screen movie complex, were lacking in disparagement altogether, and filled, instead, with wonder.
"This is a place that has good bones," Ms. Robertson said. "One of the things we did was look at what made people love this street, the legendary place with fables and stories. And one of the things we all want to do is make sure the magic continues."
 
Defining the Soul Of a Fabled Block
 On their watch, crime in the neighborhood is down, rents are up. It is a noticeably cleaner place. Bertelsman, Disney, the Virgin Megastore, Live Entertainment of Toronto, A.M.C. Entertainment Inc., Conde Nast and Madame Tussaud's have all arrived on Times Square or committed to it; where once there were dozens of adult bookstores and peep shows, under new zoning laws supported by the three women and scheduled to take effect in November, there may be as few as six.
All of which puts them, of course, at the fulcrum of the debate over the soul of the place. Is a giant hot dog suitable for Times Square? Is that part of the magic? There are differing opinions, though certainly among those with an economic interest in Times Square, the three women have created a substantial fan base. In the cajoling, lobbying, negotiating and marketing involved in the high-powered real estate world generally ruled by men, being women probably has not hurt.
"Women are more direct, I think," Ms. Robertson said. "Probably more gossipy, but really more direct."
Douglas Durst, the developer who is to build an office tower on the northwest corner of 42d Street and Broadway, agreed, sort of. "It makes a difference, women versus men," he said, "though now I'm trying to think of how."
Jeffrey Gural, the president of Newmark & Company, which manages three of the most famous buildings in the area -- 1501 Broadway, which once housed the Paramount Theater, 1560 Broadway (a k a the Actors Equity building) and the old McGraw-Hill building at 330 West 42d Street -- was among many Times Square business executives who were unstinting in their praise. "They've all done a terrific job, frankly," he said.
 
Managing Egos In an Artful Way
 Since 1992, with the establishment of the Times Square Business Improvement District, the alliance of businesses and property owners in the area stretching from 40th Street to 53d Street and from just west of the Avenue of the Americas to just west of Eighth Avenue, plus Restaurant Row on 46th Street between Eighth and Ninth, Ms. Dykstra, 47, has used the B.I.D.'s $6 million in annual assessments on local merchants to make the neighborhood cleaner and safer, and to market it to attract new tenants.
"Gretchen is the Mayor of Times Square," said Jeffrey Katz, the president of Sherwood Equities, which owns the buildings at 1 and 2 Times Square. "She's at the vortex of a very powerful, very big, very dynamic community with lots of money, lots of political clout and lots of egos and she manages it in an astoundingly artful way. I know I couldn't do that job."
Ms. Robertson, 45, a former city planner, joined the 42d Street project in 1987; since then, she has survived a political shift in both City Hall and Albany, which many read as a testament to the progress she has made on 42d Street. Among other things, she has overseen the state's takeover of 13 acres on the block and the relocation of some 280 occupants.
Since 1992, after plans to develop office towers on the four corners of Times Square were scotched because the real estate market had soured, she led the development of a replacement plan, now being put into effect, that would put an indefinite hold on office development (most likely until the developers decide the market has turned) and focus instead on supplementing the tourist attractions and entertainment venues with retailers and restaurants.
The next wave of these will open this summer; it began yesterday with Hansen's Times Square Brewery Restaurant.
"With Rebecca, it depends whether you're on her side or the other side," said Mr. Durst, who opposed Ms. Robertson for years when his competitors were given tax breaks to develop office buildings on Times Square but who is now taking advantage of those breaks to build an office tower of his own. "I much prefer being on her side. We litigated against her for a good many years, and it was a difficult time. But now working with her, it's terrific."
Ms. Cahan ("I'm older than they are," she said.) is a former dancer who for 16 years was the executive director of Feld Ballets/NY. She shares with Ms. Dykstra and Ms. Robertson an articulate outspokenness, though in demeanor she is a bit more high-strung.
Charged with making The New 42d Street self-supporting, through tenant rent, by the year 2000, she is now awaiting Disney's renovation of the New Amsterdam, which is scheduled to open in 1997, and concluding contract negotiations with Livent, which plans to combine the Lyric and the Apollo into one musical house. Madame Tussaud's and A.M.C. -- which are together to occupy the old Empire, Harris and Liberty Theaters -- will be her tenants as well; so, perhaps, will Jujamcyn Theaters, the Broadway theater owners, who have expressed interest in the Selwyn Theater, the only venue not yet spoken for.
"Cora will never, never, never give up," said Carl Weisbrod, the president of the lower Manhattan BID, who was also Ms. Robertson's predecessor -- the two of them recruited Ms. Cahan for the organization they created in 1990. "There are few people who could've done what she has already done with these theaters."
Indeed, you do not hear anybody arguing that well enough should have been left alone. The blighted Times Square of the 1980's -- the porn shops and prostitutes, the odors of garbage and urine, the criminal element and general atmosphere of threat -- renders few people nostalgic. But is the emerging Times Square -- with two new musical theaters, a wax museum, movie complexes, chain retailers and a huge new tourist hotel -- going to salvage any of the trashy, glitzy raffishness, the Runyonesque quality, that characterizes the memories of those who cherish it? Or will it turn into a sanitized place for the mass consumer, a glorified theme park or mall?
According to a recent survey conducted at the behest of the BID by Clark, Martire & Bartolmeo, a New Jersey market research firm, 20 percent of property owners, merchants and community leaders in Times Square, believe that as conditions have improved, something of the old flavor of the place has been lost.
And some outside critics are less reserved.
"They're apparatchiks carving up one of the prime locuses of New York City culture," said Bill Dobbs, a lawyer and a founder of the advocate group, New Yorkers for Free Expression, referring to the three women. "There's got to be both glamour and sleaze in a world-class city, and those three people are intent on cutting out the underbelly of New York City. If you do that, you will kill what makes New York so wonderful and turn it into suburbia."
 
No Theme Parks In Their Blueprint
Little irritates the three women more than this kind of criticism.
"That's so easy," Ms. Cahan said. "You cannot find a mall with stores cheek by jowl with theaters like this."
On the one hand, Ms. Dykstra said, what's being eliminated will not be missed.
"This is just romanticizing the gutter, and it makes me nuts," she said. And on the other hand, Ms. Robertson added, what is being erected is nothing like a mall; a mall, she said, is a place where one developer enforces his vision on a whole venue.
"When we're done, we'll have 60 different tenants on 42d Street, arguing, fighting for product and advertising space," she said. "There are going to be conflicts and people who like each other or don't. The idea is not to make it themelike, but make it a place of stories, which comes from all that crass commercialism."
Commercialism is also at the heart of a yet-to-be-resolved legal issue, namely whether the new zoning laws that would restrict the number of adult businesses in Times Square are constitutional or merely economically convenient.
Lawsuits have, in fact, been filed on behalf of adult bookstore owners and their customers, arguing that the new laws -- scheduled to take effect on Nov. 1 -- would force owners out of business and would also restrict the customers' access to those businesses and thus violate their right to free expression. A decision is not yet pending because whether the case will be heard in Federal or state court is still in dispute.
"There is no doubt that if the neighborhood had struck a not-in-my-backyard posture, you never would've seen the porn proposals passed," Ms. Dykstra said. "But in fact, Times Square will keep 6 to 10 porn shops, different levels of them, from the 25-cent peep shows to upscale bars. The question is: When do you tip the scale? It seems to me that in 32 square blocks, 10 porn shops is the right number. People who want to use them will be able to find them."
Norman Siegel, the executive director of the New York Civil Liberties Union, said, however, that restricting businesses on the basis of their merchandise is against the law, and that the case against the porn shops is based on a smoke screen, that the concentration of porn shops in the area created secondary effects like increased crime and a decrease in property values.
The problem, he said, is that a study that the city made of this in 1994, is inconclusive.
"In our opinion, it does not meet the burden of proof," said Mr. Siegel, whose office is on West 43d Street, near Times Square.
"I'm not denying there were problems in the neighborhood," Mr. Siegel said. "And I don't condone illegal activity. But the rhetoric of the people who are handling all this gives you the impression that there is a certain kind of person that is O.K. on 42d Street, and a certain climate that can be controlled. That troubles me."
Baloney, say the three witches of Times Square.
"I'm not sure you'll ever get people from Fifth Avenue penthouses on 42d Street," Ms. Robertson said. "It's always been a place for the masses, and I think it should stay that way."
But Ms. Cahan did not agree.
"Times Square belongs to everybody," she said. "That's the whole point."

HEADLINE: Speaker Insists on Hearings On Bill to Lift Insurance Rules

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 24

 BODY:
The Speaker of the Democratic-controlled State Assembly, Sheldon Silver, said today that he would block passage of a bill advocated by the life insurance industry that would change a decades-old consumer-protection statute.
Patricia Lynch, a spokeswoman for Mr. Silver, said he wanted time to examine the legislation and hold hearings so supporters and opponents could air their views. Consumer advocates had criticized the Legislature for considering the bill late in its session without giving them a chance to comment on it. 
 The bill would have lifted many of the regulations that restrict how much life insurance companies can pay in commissions to their agents, particularly commissions in the first year of a policy.
The rules are intended to discourage an illegal practice called churning, under which life insurance agents pressure customers to replace their policies with new ones so the agents can repeatedly reap high first-year commissions.
The industry wrote the bill with Gov. George E. Pataki's Insurance Superintendent, Edward J. Muhl. Mr. Pataki supported it.
John Calagna, a spokesman for Mr. Muhl, said the department would like to take part in the hearings. "The Superintendent felt that the bill was ready to go," Mr. Calagna said. "In our opinion, it should be passed, but if they need more time, we will be more than willing to participate."
Earlier this month, the State Senate and Assembly were preparing to vote on the bill without hearings. But after The New York Times asked why there were no hearings, the Assembly said it might hold them.
Today, Assemblyman Alexander B. Grannis, a Manhattan Democrat who is chairman of the Assembly Insurance Committee, said he had scheduled a hearing on the bill for Oct. 10 in New York City.
Even some consumer advocates said the statute was outdated and should be changed. But they said the process should be more open. Mr. Silver now agrees, Ms. Lynch said.
"We need time to digest it," she said. "It's very technical."
The Republican-led State Senate has not said whether it will approve the legislation, but there are only two weeks left in this session, so that seems increasingly unlikely. The Senate has not said whether it will hold hearings.
Peter J. Flanagan, president of the Life Insurance Council of New York, said he was not disappointed.
"We saw this as a very strong possibility, since we were late in getting the bill in," Mr. Flanagan said. "We are looking forward to presenting our views on why this bill is good for consumers, for the insurance companies and for the economic vitality of the State of New York."
