HEADLINE: Is the U.S. Souring on Free Trade?

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

 BODY:
Ian W. Delaney, chairman of the Sherritt International Corporation, a Canadian metals company with mining interests in Cuba, has just been warned by the State Department that he, his wife and his children may never be allowed to enter the United States again.
At the same time, Congress is rattling sabers in Europe's direction, vowing -- with President Clinton's support -- that Total S.A., the big French oil concern, and other European companies that supply Iran's oil industry may not be able to get American bank loans or export their goods to the United States. 
 What's going on here?
Just two years ago, more than 100 nations completed the Uruguay Round of global trade talks. After seven arduous years, they thought they had established the basis for a freer, stronger and less discriminatory system under a powerful new World Trade Organization that would keep international commerce expanding rapidly for decades.
But now, further trade liberalization -- this time in services -- has run into a wall. With skirmishes breaking out all over, the giddiness that followed the Uruguay Round has largely been replaced by the kind of reality that experts say explains why the world has never enjoyed truly unfettered trade.
"We have sunlight, but we have shadows, too," said Renato Ruggiero, the former Italian trade minister who now heads the World Trade Organization, in a recent interview.
The United States is blamed by many for casting some of the bigger shadows -- a surprising state of affairs for the Clinton Administration, which came into office championing free trade and the opportunities it offered to American exporters. But Washington now shows scant enthusiasm for a new round of global talks.
It is taking on foreign companies, like Mr. Delaney's, that it suspects of "trafficking" in private property expropriated by the Government of Fidel Castro, and is poised to impose broad sanctions against companies investing in Iran and Libya.
It has also been battling with China over copyright piracy, a fight it settled last week, and with Japan over barriers to the sale of Kodak film. That dispute is going to the Geneva-based World Trade Organization, where the United States has 12 other complaints pending and is itself the target of complaints filed by Costa Rica, India and the European Union, among others, which accuse Washington of failing to play by the rules it champions.
At the same time, Britain has been jousting with its partners in the European Union over sanctions against its beef; Canada has floated the possibility of enacting its own legislation in response to the American law penalizing Cuba trade, and European ministers over the weekend threatened to retaliate against any American moves against Cuba's, Iran's or Libya's trading partners.
President Clinton is expected to hear about all this over the weekend at the annual meeting of government chiefs of the Group of Seven leading industrial nations in Lyons, France.
The reasons for the fractiousness, the experts say, are both temporary and systemic. In the short term, they range from election-year jitters, which tends to make American politicians more truculent, to the bad luck of mad cow disease in Britain.
Deeper down, the tensions reflect the hard work that still needs to be done to accommodate different business practices among countries whose approaches to environmental protection and restrictions on child labor, say, are sharply at odds.
Beyond that, not every developing country sees itself as a winner that will benefit by opening its borders, and its fledgling service industries, to an onslaught of foreign bankers and other service providers.
Finally, there is the mixed blessing in regional trading blocs, like the North American Free Trade Agreement and the European Union, which pave the way for their own trade but also act as barriers to outsiders.
The prospects for global free trade looked promising not so long ago. After wrapping up the Uruguay Round, the Clinton Administration pushed the North American trade pact through a skeptical Congress, talked of a hemispheric free trade agreement in the next century, set 2020 as the target for Pacific-wide free trade under the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation agreement and showed interest in a trans-Atlantic trade area linking Nafta and the Europeans.
What followed seemed spectacular. As Charlene Barshefsky, the acting United States trade representative, told the House Appropriations Committee last month, American merchandise exports have grown 31 percent since Mr. Clinton took office, expanding faster than imports in 1995 and creating a million jobs.
What isn't clear is whether the Administration's new, harder line on trade mainly reflects fears and passions unleashed by the Presidential campaign or a permanent shift in emphasis stemming from the end of the cold war.
To be sure, the United States is spreading some light. Last week it agreed, in a case brought against it in the World Trade Organization by Venezuela and Brazil, to change the way it applies environmental regulations to imported gasoline. Washington's reaction was closely watched since the case was the first to go before the trade group.
The shadows are coming from the United States' inability or unwillingness to meet the deadlines set under the Uruguay Round for new accords liberalizing trade in financial services, telecommunications and maritime transport.
In the first two areas, it walked away from limited accords, saying the offers by its partners were inadequate and did not match its own. In maritime transport, it declined to make an offer after seeing what other nations had put on the table.
Ms. Barshefsky says American negotiators must demand full reciprocity these days or see Congress throw up insuperable roadblocks to liberalized trade. "With the cold war over," she said, "trade agreements must stand or fall on their merits. They no longer have a security component. If we do not get reciprocity, we will not get freer trade."
But while American banks and phone companies may desire better access to fast-growing Asian and Latin American markets, many of those nations see little gain for themselves in such deals as long as they lack financial and telecommunications industries that can compete.
This is why European banks, brokers and insurance companies accepted the limited financial-services agreement that Washington rejected, arguing that something is better than nothing and that as developing countries grow they will see the advantages of more openness.
"American trade policy is driven by an unhealthy obsession with reciprocity," said Jagdish Bhagwati, a Columbia University economics professor. "It becomes its own enemy."
Sylvia Ostry, former chief economist at the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development in Paris who is now at the University of Toronto, added: "The conventional wisdom is that America is just suffering election jitters. But I think there has been a secular trend toward regionalism and reciprocity."
Some argue that single-area negotiations, like those on financial services, are inherently risky because trade-offs are more limited than in a global negotiation when other issues are on the table -- making the power of protectionist lobbies greater.
But Jeffrey M. Lang, the chief deputy trade representative, disagrees, arguing that "we couldn't even do services during the Uruguay Round, when everything was on the table."
Yet the telecommunications talks collapsed after a lobbying campaign led by Motorola forced the Administration to reverse an offer to open the American satellite telephone market to foreign competition.
Another big shadow now is being cast by the growth of free trade areas throughout the world. More than 100 regional agreements have been registered with the W.T.O., covering about 60 percent of international trade.
The regional arrangements have proved particularly attractive to the Clinton Administration because they allow it to win concessions, especially on environmental issues and labor standards, that it might not obtain so easily in a global negotiation.
But a growing number of trade officials want to set a target date for merging all the regional blocs to create a global free trade zone with common regulations administered by the World Trade Organization. The chief European negotiator, Sir Leon Brittan, has called for members of the W.T.O. to consider steps toward such a merger at a ministerial meeting in Singapore in December.
"Unless we agree to act," Mr. Ruggiero warned, "the world will become divided in 20 years into two or three intercontinental blocs, each with its own rules and internal free trade, but with external barriers against the world."
Ms. Barshefsky and Mr. Lang, though, appear reluctant to embrace ambitious new goals and grand designs, preferring to concentrate on limited aims, including completing the stalled talks on services.
"We don't need rhetorical goals; we need practical results," Mr. Lang said, adding, "If we call for ambitious new negotiations, countries may take back what they are offering for the final grand bargain, and we will all be worse off."
For that reason, he said, the Administration preferred a more modest agenda for the Singapore talks. He hopes for an agreement with the European Union on freeing trade in information technology, and also that the world organization will lend impetus to the negotiations on services.
And he wants to start talks on preventing differences in environmental and labor standards from distorting trade. He insists, though, that the United States does not object to other countries' paying their workers less than Americans but only to practices like child and convict labor.
Finally, he wants agreement on a new code banning bribery and corruption in winning foreign orders, and another governing the rights of foreign investors.
"I'm not sure the W.T.O. needs glamorous, big negotiating rounds," Mr. Lang said. "We should aim for steady, small steps every year."
All the same, it is not clear that a major trade negotiation sometime soon can be avoided. The rules adopted in the Uruguay Round required W.T.O. members to open talks by the end of the decade on freeing agricultural trade and protecting intellectual-property rights.
"Call it a new round or what you will," Mr. Ruggiero said, "but there will be a lot on the table."
In the meantime, it is unclear just when Mr. Delaney, the Canadian executive, will be allowed to take his children to Disneyland again.


GRAPHIC: Just two years ago, the world seemed headed toward a global system of free trade that would take in ever more countries, products and services. Now, that vision seems increasingly elusive, as nagging trade disputes drag on.
 
Financial Services
Chart: "Precarious Balance"
 The United States has back away from talks on liberalizing trade in banking, insurance and securities, calling offers from the developing world inadequate. Other big industrial nations were ready to accept the dceal as better than nothing.
 
Telecommunications
 After the United States withdrew an offer to open its satellite phone market to foreign competition, negotiators failed to meet a May 31 deadline for a global agreement. America complained that other countries, especially in Asia, were not opening their markets sufficiently.
 
Maritime Trade
 The United States has refused to negotiate at all after dismissing other countries' offers as inadequate.
 
Disputes Between Nations
The United States has cases pending at the new World Trade Organization against South Korea, Japan, the European Union, Australia, Canada, Hungary, Portugal and Pakistan. And others -- Venezuela, Brazil, Costa Rica, India and the European Union -- have filed cases charging that the United States has not played by the rules it championed.
 
China
 The United States and China averted tit-for-tat snactions by reaching an agreement on combating piracy of CD-Rom's and recorded music. But a new battle immediately arose over China's efforts to regulate economic news carried by Western agencies. And Washington continues to oppose Chinese membership in the W.T.O.

HEADLINE: Virtual University Will Offer Authentic Degrees by E-Mail

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: OMAHA, June 24

 BODY:
Without so much as a ritual shovel to break the ground or a granite slab to mark the spot, the governors of 10 Western states today laid an intangible cornerstone for a new "virtual university" that they promised would soon allow students to take courses by computer and earn degrees on line.
At a meeting here, the governors pledged to raise the money and lower the bureaucratic barriers to the plan, which has been more than a year in the making. While details are still uncertain, the governors say the first students will be working in electronic classrooms next year. 
 Although there are already many examples of students learning at long distances from their teachers and colleagues, ranging from courses taught by mail or on television to those using the Internet, the Western Governors' University is the most ambitious yet.
The university would be an accredited regional institution, in the form of an independent nonprofit corporation, with power to grant certificates of proficiency that would be recognized by employers, course credits that would be recognized by traditional colleges and universities and full degrees.
At first, credentials would be offered in a limited number of specialties, but they could eventually be earned across the full spectrum of disciplines and at every level of accomplishment.
"This is not a replacement for the existing system of higher education," said Gov. Michael O. Leavitt of Utah, who, along with Gov. Roy Romer of Colorado, has led the effort. "It is a new element. It is a supplement. It is a way of creating new choices and new opportunities. But while this is not a replacement, it is an important part of a quality education for everyone. Because this is the way the world is going to work in the future."
Terry Hartle, vice president of the American Council on Education, an association representing 1,800 colleges and universities, said the governors were being driven largely by a rising population and an expected boom in enrollment in their region, which they could not realistically hope to meet by adding to traditional colleges and universities.
"Technology is already having a profound effect on all sorts of education," Mr. Hartle said. "The question is whether you can deliver quality higher education on a massive scale using existing technology. High quality higher education is hard enough to do when you have people on campuses and in classrooms. Whether or not you can do it successfully at distances and at a large scale we do not know. "
The governors envision a university in which teachers and students will obtain reading materials not just from libraries, but also from databases; where term papers will be handed in by E-mail, and where classes will meet in on-line collaborative sessions, perhaps using video and voice links as well as keyboards. The governors say the whole arrangement will not only spread opportunities across the region's vast distances, but will also make education cheaper.
At the same time, the university would be integrated with traditional educational settings -- libraries, high schools, community colleges and state university systems, along with training programs in the private sector and even county agriculture extension agents.
Neither the teachers nor the students would need to be in the Western states, but the agreement of so many states -- and of their education communities -- to support the project would add to its credibility, the governors say.
The main questions center on whether an education obtained at a keyboard and a cathode ray tube can be as good as one earned amid the ivied halls, sporting fields, and laboratories of the traditional system. Other difficult questions are where the money will come from, whether the on-line university will compete for students and resources with traditional schools, and how a corps of teachers skilled in the new communications technologies can be recruited and trained.
Another question is whether electronic learning will deliver education to the disadvantaged, or whether the differences between computer haves and have-nots will only widen an education gap when computer skills are a prerequisite for schooling.
The governors' agreement called for each of the states to contribute $100,000 to continue the planning process. The full start-up costs have been estimated at $6 million to $10 million.
Conspicuous by its lack of involvement is California, whose population, economy and university system dwarf those of the other Western states and which has not been as active as the others in the early planning.
Among the existing models of nontraditional schools that suggest the direction the governors' university could take are the Maricopa Community Colleges, a consortium in Arizona that is about to offer an associate of arts degree entirely over the Internet.
At a more experimental level, there are virtual-reality campuses on the Internet like Diversity University and Athena University, which are trying out novel educational programs of their own.
But enthusiasts say that what is available now is just a rough prototype of what visionaries in the field say is coming.
At a practical level, businesses are interested in employees with programming skills and the ability to run computer networks, subjects natural to learn on line. Several big computer companies are supporting the governors, as is Simon & Schuster, the big educational publisher.
The planning documents for the venture are available on the World Wide Web, at:
 http://www.westgov.org/smart/
vu/vu.html.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

USA Waste to Buy Sanifill for $1.2 Billion
The consolidation in garbage hauling continued as USA Waste Services said it would merge with Sanifill in a deal worth $1.3 billion plus the assumption of debt. The new company, which will retain the USA Waste name, expects to have revenue of about $1.3 billion a year.
Just six years ago, USA Waste had revenue of only $10 million. But it has acquired a number of companies and entered new markets, including New York. [Page D5.]
 
Big Merger Near in France
Two French arms-industry giants, the Government-owned Aerospatiale and the privately held Dassault Aviation, were said to be close to a merger agreement. [D4.]
 
TCI to Carry Fox News Service
Tele-Communications Inc. agreed to carry Fox's planned 24-hour news cable channel in 10 million homes when it is started this fall. The deal gives the Fox news service a base from which to challenge CNN and the service being started by NBC and Microsoft. [D6.]

Group of 7 Policies Are Backed
The No. 2 official in the Treasury Department defended the stewardship of the world economy by leaders of the Group of Seven industrial nations, a few days before their heads of government are scheduled to meet in Lyons, France. [D4.]
 
AT&T in Business-Services Venture
AT&T and Industry.Net, which matches buyers and sellers of industrial equipment on the Internet, plan to form a company to provide on-line information services for businesses. Jim P. Manzi, the former chief executive of Lotus Development, will lead the company, Nets Inc. [D2.]
 
G.M. Has Top Labor Costs for Parts
At General Motors, labor costs for auto parts are $440 higher a vehicle than at Ford and $600 higher than at Chrysler because G.M. buys fewer parts from low-cost outside suppliers, a study said. [D2.]
 
Sumitomo to Rotate Traders
Sumitomo, after its disclosure that it lost $1.8 billion in unauthorized copper trades, said it would rotate its traders every few years to prevent them from acquiring too much influence over one sector of the market. [D5.]
 
Stocks Rise, but Big Gain Erodes
Stocks rose, but profit taking kept the increase in check. The Dow industrials ended 12.56 points higher, at 5,717.79, after giving up a gain of more than 37 points. [D10.]
 
McDonnell Douglas to Pay Fine
McDonnell Douglas agreed to pay a $500,000 fine to settle regulatory charges that it violated securities laws by failing to take a loss on its C-17 military transport plane program in 1990, when the company was under financial pressure. It delayed the losses until a couple of years later, when its financial health was better. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D10.]
 
Interpublic to Grow Further
Interpublic, which has been among the most acquisitive players on Madison Avenue, agreed to expand further into media services by buying Media Inc., which handles media planning and buying for accounts with billings that the companies estimate at $175 million. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D8.]

A Pair of Radio Deals
Two transactions involving radio-station companies were announced. In one, Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst agreed to buy Commodore Media, the broadcaster. And Chancellor Broadcasting said it would swap three stations in Florida for one in California that is owned by American Radio Systems. [D6.]
 
New Type of AIDS Drug Is Approved
The Food and Drug Administration approved the first in a new class of AIDS medicines, clearing patients to start adding the drug, nevirapine, to their treatment combinations in August. It is made by Bohringer Ingelheim of Germany. [A16.]

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
An Olympic Moment For the Apple

BYLINE: By WILLIAM C. RHODEN 

 BODY:
MAYOR Rudolph W. Giuliani has offered a compelling gambit. Last weekend he announced the formation of a committee to study the feasibility of making a bid to bring the 2008 Olympics to New York City.
Initially I dismissed the idea as totally out of the realm -- or part of some hidden agenda.
With the Games in Atlanta this summer, how likely is it that they will return to America so soon? Was this all a slick public-relations maneuver? Or maybe part of a plan to build George Steinbrenner a stadium, a means of yanking him out the Bronx without having the Yankees leave New York?
In any event, New York made a bid for the 1984 Games in 1977, at a time when the city was crippled by financial woes. We lost the Games to Los Angeles, which turned a neat $215 million surplus.
But the city is better now, more enlightened. New York put on the Gay Games two years ago and will host the Goodwill Games in 1998. The city is in better financial shape but still in need of the sort of transfusion a huge event can bring. Not just in money or jobs, but a transformation of spirit.
"The Olympics epitomize peace and harmony, unity, honesty and excellence," said Canon Frederick B. Williams, rector of the Church of the Intercession in Harlem. "To bring that dynamic to this city, which is probably the most complex city in the world, to have that as a focus of our common life, would be akin to the week that Nelson Mandela and his wife came to visit. There was a four-day party. Crime went down. People spoke to one another. The mood was wonderful. Translate that into the Olympic arena, you get an opportunity to focus the city, to give the city a higher ideal, a higher view of what is possible."
That all sounds fine, but who will foot the bill?
Without blinking, he answered: "Jesus said that where your treasure is, there your heart will be also."
The dream has different dimensions.
Otha Brown is primarily a businessman, the owner of K & B Cleaners. For 25 years, he has sat at his sewing machine and watched the ebb and flow of daily life at the point where Harlem meets Washington Heights.
From a business angle, the idea of a New York Olympics is intriguing.
"It'll make money for the city to the community: hotels, restaurants, everything," he said. "It'll create jobs. They won't last long. But it creates jobs. If it doesn't help my business, it'll help people who live in the neighborhood to get a day's work or two or a month."
When I mentioned what Canon Williams said about the Olympics bringing New Yorkers together across racial lines, Brown, who is 69, frowned.
"It ain't going to help the racial thing," he said with finality. "That racial thing is there to stay. Once the Games are over, everybody goes their separate ways."
Brown was 9 years old, growing up in Greenville, Miss., when Jesse Owens turned in his brilliant performance at the Berlin Games in 1936 and became a national hero.
"He came back here and couldn't get a glass of water," he said. "If he had come to Mississippi and tried to get a drink, they would have lynched him. It's gotten a little better; but now they are burning down black churches. You think an Olympics is going to stop that?"
Jaibe Sivadel, age 47, teaches video production at Junior High School 45 in Harlem. On Monday afternoons, he's at St. Nicholas Park playing chess. The idea of a New York Olympics is exciting to him. He agrees that the city needs a spiritual boost, by any means necessary.
"If anything could revitalize the spirit of this city, with all the negativity we've had, racially, economically and socially, the Olympics might be something that could galvanize us," he said.
I recalled what Brown had said, about America being too infected by bigotry to be saved by an Olympic dream.
Sivadel wasn't so sure. "There's polarization, but there's also a group of people called New Yorkers who will get beyond that," he said. "They'll live beyond that, act beyond that and treat each other beyond that.
"I play chess here in the park with people of all races, Asian, European, Latinos, African Americans. We all play chess together.
"I don't think New York is beyond redemption. If New York is beyond redemption, America is beyond redemption."
So. Let the Games begin.

HEADLINE: Germany's Concerns Over Rights in Tibet Clash With Trade Ties to China

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: BONN, June 24

 BODY:
A diplomatic confrontation raising Bonn's worst fears of trade reprisals has broken out between Germany and China, leaving the Government here to face the same balancing of powerful economic interests against human rights concerns that confronts Washington.
The dispute boiled over on Sunday when China abruptly canceled a planned visit to Beijing next month by Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel, citing a German parliamentary resolution last week that condemned China's human rights record in Tibet. 
 China called the resolution an "open, flagrant violation of international law and a serious case of interference in China's internal affairs."
Today, a second German Cabinet minister, Construction Minister Klaus Topfer, canceled a planned trip to China next week, calling the journey "inappropriate given the current situation."
German officials said the action was intended to ease tensions, but the cancellation also seemed to illuminate the gravity of the confrontation, which represents a marked turn for the worse in a relationship that Bonn had hoped to nurture.
Only a few months ago, Chancellor Helmut Kohl was courting Beijing. Germany is China's fourth-largest trading partner, after Britain, Japan and the United States.
During a visit here last July by President Jiang Zemin, Chancellor Kohl played down human rights concerns as German industrialists negotiated billion-dollar contracts, squeezing out American competitors. Such activity has irked American officials, and the State Department's top official for Asian affairs, Winston Lord, recently accused China's other major trading partners of standing by while the United States forces Chinese compliance with copyright treaties.
But the issue then was trade, not human rights. The United States says it has ended the practice of threatening economic sanctions over human rights in China.
German politicians have long been anxious to accommodate Chinese wishes wherever possible, and this month they withdrew official financing from a privately organized conference in Bonn on Tibet that was addressed by the Dalai Lama, the Tibetan exile leader.
Germany, however, rejected a Chinese demand that the gathering be canceled. And, last Thursday, the lower house of Germany's Parliament passed a resolution condemning a series of what it called human rights abuses in Tibet.
Mr. Kohl said through a spokesman today that he viewed the cancellation of Mr. Kinkel's visit with "regret and incomprehension."
At stake in the dispute is trade that doubled between 1990 and 1995 to a value of $18 billion at a time when Germany's export-driven economy is in the doldrums.
The strains in the relationship have thrown Germany's political establishment into turmoil with Mr. Kinkel, backed by German industrialists, seeking to mend fences while other politicians protest loudly at China's action.
Mr. Kinkel went out of his way today to say Bonn did not support demands for Tibetan independence. "We'd like to see cultural autonomy there," he said. "We'd like talks to be held with the Dalai Lama." But he added: "That is in no way recognition of Tibet. We want Tibet to continue to belong to China."
"I appeal to both sides to to do everything possible to make sure this does not become a serious burden in our relations," he said. "They are too important for that."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE CHURCHES;
Public Supports Political Voice For Churches

BYLINE: By GUSTAV NIEBUHR 

 BODY:
In evidence of a striking change in Americans' attitudes about religion and politics, a majority of the public now believes that churches should be allowed to express political opinions, a reversal from what a majority believed a generation ago, according to a new nationwide survey of religious identity and political opinion.
Support for churches' expressing political opinions runs highest among white evangelical, or born-again, Protestants, a group that has grown enough over the past decade that it accounts for a quarter of the American electorate, roughly on a par with white Roman Catholics and members of mainline Protestant churches, like Episcopalians and Presbyterians. 
 The survey also shows that with the growth in their numbers, white evangelicals have emerged as a cohesive force shaping American political debate and holding more conservative views than other groups on issues including gay marriage, immigration policy and gun control as well as abortion. They are the group least enthusiastic about President Clinton, but they are divided about the Republicans' record in Congress, making it difficult to predict how they will behave at the ballot box this fall.
But, the survey also found that although Americans say they regularly hear clergy members speak out on a wide variety of political and social issues -- especially hunger, poverty, abortion and school prayer -- only about 1 of every 15 churchgoers reported being told how to vote. About twice that many, or 1 in 7, reported finding candidates' campaign literature in church before the 1994 mid-term elections.
The survey will be made public today by the Pew Research Center for the People and the Press, an independent research entity in Washington, formerly known as the Times Mirror Center, which is now financed by the Pew Charitable Trusts of Philadelphia. The report, "The Diminishing Divide. . . American Churches, American Politics," derived its findings from telephone interviews with 1,975 adults nationwide from May 31 to June 9. The survey had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 3 percentage points. The margin of sampling error for smaller groups was greater, plus or minus five percentage points for white evangelical Protestants, for instance.
The survey, which also used supplemental information taken from telephone interviews from July 1994 to October 1995, portrayed a nation in which 65 percent of the population can be characterized by one of three religious identities -- white evangelical Protestant, 23 percent; white mainline Protestant, 22 percent, or white Catholic, 20 percent.
Of the remaining 35 percent, 9 percent are black Christians, including those within evangelical, mainline Protestant and Catholic traditions. Eleven percent who identify with no religious tradition. Hispanic Catholics, other religious Hispanic people, Jews and Mormons account for 2 percent each, while smaller affiliations make up the balance of 7 percent.
One question the survey posed was whether churches should keep out of political matters, or whether they should express their views on day-to-day social and political questions. When this question was asked by the Gallup organization in 1968, 53 percent said churches should keep out of politics, while 40 percent said they should express their views.
But in the three decades since, according to the Pew survey, the public's views on this matter have reversed, with 54 percent saying churches should express their views, while 43 percent say they should keep out of politics.
Among religious groups, 70 percent of white evangelicals said they favored churches' expressing political views, while 68 percent of black Christians did also.
But the survey also showed that a majority of the public still did not want clergy members to become overtly partisan. Yet, even here a shift may be evident.
In 1965, when Gallup asked if it was ever right for clergy members to discuss candidates or issues from the pulpit, 22 percent said yes. In the three decades since, resistance to politicking from the pulpit has eroded, and 29 percent are now willing to allow clergy members to discuss candidates from the pulpit, the Pew survey found. Still, two-thirds of respondents opposed this idea.
The Pew report found that among the groups it surveyed, white evangelical Protestants had been the most politically dynamic. Citing previous surveys, the survey said they had increased their strength to 23 percent of the electorate, up from 19 percent of registered voters who identified themselves as evangelicals in 1987.
Even in 1987, the number of people who identified themselves as evangelicals had risen from the decade before. In 1978, a New York Times/ CBS News poll found that only 16 percent of the population identified themselves as white evangelicals.
Commenting on the new poll, Andrew Kohut, director of the Pew Research Center said, "The conservatism of white evangelicals is the most powerful political force in the country."
The survey showed that white evangelical Protestants took more conservative positions than other religious groups, both on moral issues and some secular issues.
For instance, white evangelical Protestants were the least likely to approve of gay marriage or to favor allowing public schools to provide birth control information. And 63 percent of this group say immigrants are a burden on the country, while 55 percent or fewer of the other major religious groups express that view.
In addition, 44 percent of white evangelical Protestants support handgun control, while over 50 percent of the other major religious groups do. And 34 percent of evangelical Protestants favor Mr. Clinton's decision to send troops to Bosnia as part of an international peacekeeping force, while more than 40 percent of the other major religious groups favor this decision.
James L. Guth, a professor of political science at Furman University in Greenville, S.C., said members of conservative Protestant groups, like the 15.6 million Southern Baptists, show a growing tendency to adopt the evangelical label, as a means of identifying both their theological and political beliefs.
"Evangelical Protestants are becoming an increasingly politically cohesive force," Professor Guth said. In addition, he said, political activity by conservative, Southern Baptist ministers, including discussing issues and candidates, is on the rise and is increasingly accepted by their congregations. "It's becoming almost routine or conventional activity of many evangelical churches and pastors in election years," he said.
Nancy Ammerman, a professor of the sociology of religion at Hartford Seminary, said evangelicals were gaining in numbers nationally because an ever-greater number of people, many within mainline Protestant denominations, are calling themselves evangelicals as a means of making a statement about their religious beliefs.
"People will identify themselves as evangelical in spite of what denomination they're in," she said. "I think it's another of the many signs of the weakening of denominational identity, and the growth of new ways of people talking about themselves and organizing themselves."
But Professor Ammerman also said the evangelical label should not always be taken to imply conservative politics by those who claim it. "We have something that's going to help us understand people's voting behavior, but it's not a perfect predictor," she said, adding that political choices are often influenced by local issues and the economy.
Also analyzing how much religious teachings influence public policy debates, the Pew survey found doctrine had its greatest effect on moral and sexual issues, especially on matters like abortion and homosexual marriage.
For example, a plurality of 37 percent said religion was most influential in forming their views on the question of whether homosexuals should be allowed to marry. Over all, the survey found that the idea of legalizing such marriages remained highly unpopular, opposed by 65 percent of those surveyed. The survey said conservative religious beliefs heavily contributed to that view.
But, in a finding that may prove unsettling to church authorities, the survey also said that religious teachings have remarkably little influence in shaping people's attitudes on broad social issues like welfare and the role of women in the workplace.
Although Catholic bishops in the United States and the National Council of Churches have criticized recent political efforts to restrict state and Federal welfare benefits, only 6 percent of those surveyed cited religion as having the greatest influence on what they thought about this issue. Most people said they formed opinions based on personal experience, education or news reports.
The Rev. Robert Friday, professor of moral theology at Catholic University, said that although the Catholic Church had issued many pronouncements about social justice over the past century, tradition caused people to associate the concept of sin with personal or sexual issues.
"You don't see cartoons of people in hell because they didn't pay a just wage," Father Friday said. "It's usually for adultery and all that."
Still, it is in the area of religion and politics that the Pew survey provides some of its most interesting data.
Majorities of Catholics, black Christians and mainline Protestants, according to the Pew survey, said they approved of the job that Mr. Clinton has been doing. But 56 percent of white evangelicals said they disapproved. An even larger evangelical majority, 59 percent, said they had an unfavorable view of the First Lady. Among social issues, the survey found that some of the strongest agreement on the issue of environmental protection. Majorities in every religious group said environmental regulations were "worth the cost," although support was markedly lower among white evangelicals and Mormons.

HEADLINE: In Search for Campaign Fuel, Dole and Clinton Cross Paths

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY

 BODY:
Racing their way through hotel ballrooms across midtown Manhattan, Bob Dole and President Clinton came to New York in search of money last night, using the burst of attention that attended the dueling appearances to advance their candidacies and assault each other's credentials.
"I know President Clinton's in town tonight," Mr. Dole said, opening the crosstown exchange with a spirited speech at one of four fund-raisers he packed into a 22-hour trip here. "I know he's probably making promises right now. He's probably telling people he wants welfare reform. He told us that in 1992. Don't believe him. He probably is going to tell them we're going to have tax cuts. Don't believe it." 
 Continuing what he called a litany of promises the President had broken, Mr. Dole said: "We haven't forgotten. We're not going to let the American people forget."
While Mr. Dole was finishing his speech at the Sheraton New York by joining the crowd in a round of Happy Birthday to one of his first supporters, Gov. George E. Pataki, who turned 51 yesterday, Mr. Clinton mounted the stage at the Waldorf-Astoria six blocks away. The coincidence in timing produced one of the more unusual moments in the Presidential campaign thus far.
Presenting a far different view of the choice at hand, Mr. Clinton declared that the election offered a contrast between Republicans who believe that "government is the problem and if you get just get it out of the way, everything will be fine," and Democrats, like himself. "I believe no great nation has ever done well without giving more and more people the opportunity to succeed."
"They passed their program once," Mr. Clinton said of Mr. Dole's former Republican colleagues in Congress. "And we stopped them. If there is no veto pen, and they can keep the Congress and have the White House, you don't have to guess what they'll do."
It was money, and not votes, that brought Mr. Clinton and Mr. Dole to town last night. And by the end of the night, aides to Mr. Clinton and Mr. Dole reported collecting nearly $6 million in contributions for their parties.
Still, the evening was a striking moment in Presidential political theater, as the two candidates brushed within four blocks of each other, though their motorcades never met. And it was potentially, if not certainly, a last for New York, because both campaigns consider the state solidly Democratic and out of contention.
For all the activity attending the parallel campaign swings last night -- the receptions, hotel shuttling, motorcades, police barricades -- the streets of midtown Manhattan were surprisingly calm. Even at the worst of moments, as Mr. Clinton went from the Waldorf-Astoria to the Plaza, and Mr. Dole from the Sheraton New York to the St. Regis, traffic did not approach such high-gridlock marks as the Friday after Thanksgiving. And the sidewalks were surprisingly empty considering the show on display.
Although Mr. Dole and Mr. Clinton were in town mainly in search of money -- Mr. Dole put a campaign stop on his schedule as a last-minute afterthought, while Mr. Clinton did not even go through the motions -- their appearances nonetheless provided a snapshot of the state of their debate right now. The two men presented what they have been saying in different venues on the road, though their remarks were arguably more pointed given their proximity.
Mr. Dole repeatedly hit Mr. Clinton on his veracity, tying it to campaign promises that he asserted the President had broken.
"I'll tell you one thing," Mr. Dole said. "I'll keep my word. I won't tell you one thing in an election year and then break every promise I made to the people I made it to last year, and the year and the year and the year before. We will keep our word to the American people. They deserve the truth."
Mr. Dole went so far as to adopt, apparently unknowingly, one of Mr. Clinton's most successful campaign themes of 1992, tapping into a fear discovered by pollsters and researchers that children today will not do as well economically as their parents.
"I did not risk my life for this country and spend years in public service only to see young Americans in the 1990's become the first generation in our history not to live better than our parents did," Mr. Dole said. "This must never happen in America, and if you elect me Ppresident it will not happen In America.""
And in one moment of regional self-awareness, Mr. Dole took a bow to a matter of traditional interest to New Yorkers, suggesting that he would stand by the new Israeli Government, and its Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, in the face of pressure from Arab leaders about concessions for peace.
"We will back him, and we will back his people as they make the decisions about their peace and their security," Mr. Dole said.
Speaking six blocks away and 30 minutes later, Mr. Clinton asserted that his Administration had turned around problems left by 12 years of Republican rule when he became President in 1993, and had turned back current Republican initiatives in Congress. When he took office, Mr. Clinton said, the country was mired in economic stagnation and high unemployment, and "we seemed to be coming apart as a people."
"We are better off then we were four years ago, but we can't say that our problems are solved -- that we still don't have challenges," Mr. Clinton said. He called the transition to the next century "a work in progress and we need to do much more."
Mr. Clinton's aides said he raised $3 million in his visit, from a $1,000-a-person reception at the Waldorf-Astoria, followed by a $5,000-a-plate private dinner at the Plaza Hotel. Mr. Dole raised about $2.5 million, according to his aides, with some people paying as much as $10,000-a-head at the St. Regis Hotel, according to one Republican who attended.
At 6 P.M., before the first fund-raiser, Mr. Clinton posed for pictures at the Waldorf-Astoria with Lionel Hampton, the band leader and Republican supporter who endorsed the Democratic President for re-election.
Still, neither Mr. Clinton nor Mr. Dole made much of an effort to pretend that their visit to New York was aimed at campaigning. Mr. Dole came the closer. Between the trip to the airport and his arrival at his hotel, Mr. Dole squeezed in a quick and time-honored New York campaign moment -- a pastrami sandwich at a New York delicatessen. In this case, he spent 23 minutes at the Stage Delicatessen, a restaurant popular with tourists and politicians, which was a short block from his hotel. (Mr. Clinton stopped by for lunch there in 1992.)
The restaurant owners were given 10 minutes notice of the visit, so everything was ready when he showed up. There was half a pre-cut sandwich's worth of pastrami ("a real heart-stopper," as Mr. Dole's waiter described it), along with a giant slab of cheesecake and a Diet Coke resting on the counter. What was supposed to be a simple campaign stop did not go entirely smoothly, however.
"Senator Dole," inquired Donna Besteiro, a lawyer from Yonkers who suddenly found herself breaking pastrami with the all-but-certain Republican candidate for President, "where are you standing currently on abortion rights?"
Mr. Dole stopped short in mid-cheesecake. Glancing up from his plate, Mr. Dole took note that his questioner was surrounded by reporters, who the candidate has said are far more interested than the public-at-large in his struggle to reconcile his party over the issue of abortion rights.
"What are you -- working for the press now?" Mr. Dole responded. "I know they put you up to it. Yeah. Right. We're going to work it all out, and the press is going to be very disappointed because they won't be able to come to the convention and beat us up."
In fact, Ms. Besteiro had volunteered to a reporter that she was concerned about Mr. Dole's opposition to abortion rights. But Mr. Dole was correct one point: it was another reporter who prodded Ms. Besteiro to query the candidate on the issue.
"The press loves it," Mr. Dole continued. "What we like is where the Democrats are on abortion. They have different views, too. But they're never printed anywhere that I know of. But we're going to work it out. we're an inclusive party. I want to broaden the base of the party. I want to win the election. And I, you know, that's what it's all about."
Throughout the day, there was a quiet subtext of competition between the two visiting teams. Aides to both candidates asserted that the other side was exaggerating their fundraising take. Michael D. McCurry, the White House press secretary, went so far as to argue that the President's motorcade presentation, from his helicopter arrival on Wall Street to his motorcade into midtown, was more formidable Mr. Dole could muster as an ordinary citizen running for President, notwithstanding his own Secret Service contingent.
"I think ours is still a more impressive one then theirs," Mr. McCurry said.
There was one element of truth last night. Mr. Dole had an escort of six New York City motorcycle officers outside his hotel. Mr. Clinton had 36.

HEADLINE: About Real Estate;
High-Technology Theater for Tourists

BYLINE: By MERVYN ROTHSTEIN 

 BODY:
The Plaza Theater on 58th Street just east of Madison Avenue, originally a stable for Cornelius Vanderbilt 2d, is entering the high-technology age.
The 500-seat theater, at 42-44 East 58th Street, has been leased and is being renovated for the opening in mid-October of "Show Me New York," a high-definition television travelogue, created especially for tourists, of life in New York City. The 20-year lease was valued at about $15 million. 
 David Niles, president and chief executive of Nileshow, the producer and owner of the travelogue, said the theater's capacity was being cut to 250 seats as part of creating a "total immersion environment." The theater's name will also be changed, to "Show Me New York."
"The lobby will be modeled after the New York of 100-150 years ago, with brownstone buildings," said Mr. Niles, who experimented with high-definition television -- which creates images as sharp and panoramic as those on film -- at the old Ed Sullivan Theater at Broadway and 53d Street in the pre-Letterman era. "There will be scenes in the windows and live actors in the lobby dressed as police officers, shoeshine men, grocery sellers. Then, on the way into the theater, audiences will pass a large diorama of New York in an imagined future."
The presentation itself will begin with a light show, followed by a 22-minute high-definition television travelogue in five parts. "There'll be a helicopter ride above the city, then a look at specific sections: Greenwich Village, SoHo, Central Park, Chelsea, the financial district. The third part will be like a thrill ride, taking tourists places they can't go: to the top of the Chrysler Building, on stage at Radio City Music Hall looking at the audience, in the driver's seat of a fire engine rushing through New York traffic."
The fourth part, which is to be updated every three or four weeks, will be a look at the city at that moment, he said: "The Thanksgiving parade when it's November, for instance, and there'll be samples of the current shows on Broadway, and a look at who's playing in the clubs."
The finale, Mr. Niles said, will feature "picture-postcard views of New York -- with the audience seeing themselves as giant people walking across the Brooklyn Bridge or Times Square; television cameras will be hidden in the diorama of the future and will take the audience's pictures for projection at the end of the show."
Mr. Niles said there would be as many as 20 shows a day -- every half-hour -- with audiences provided "by tour operators and the travel business, as well as walk-ins." He declined to disclose the cost of the production, but said that "it was a very expensive proposition -- the hardware alone cost from $8 million to $10 million."
The building that contains the theater was put up by Cornelius Vanderbilt 2d as a French Renaissance-style stable in 1879; it was easily accessible to the mansion he put up on the northwest corner of Fifth Avenue and 57th Street. The building housed not only carriages and horses but also sleighs that were used in winter in Central Park. Vanderbilt died in 1899, and in 1916 his heirs converted the stable to a dance hall.
In 1928, the Fifth Avenue house was replaced by the Bergdorf Goodman department store, and the next year the former stable was leased to a theater operator, who renovated it for a movie house. The Plaza Theater building is now owned by the heirs of Jules Stein, the founder of the Music Corporation of America; the most recent tenant was the Cineplex Odeon group of Toronto, which left early this year.
E. William Judson of Judson Realty, the agent for the property, said its re-leasing as a regular movie theater had been questionable because most movie operations now involve multiplexes, making a one-screen theater economically unfeasible. Mr. Judson said that he had received inquiries from retailers and restaurant operators -- including fast-food establishments.
Charles Cohen and Steve Fredericks of the Cohen Brothers Realty Corporation represented the tenant.
 
Around Manhattan
 Brobeck, Phleger & Harrison, a San Francisco-based law firm, has leased 56,000 square feet at 1633 Broadway, a 48-story, 2.4-million-square-foot office building at 50th Street. The law firm will be moving and expanding its New York office from 1301 Avenue of the Americas, at 53d Street. The 15-year lease was valued in excess of $30 million. Dale Schlather of the Cushman Realty Corporation's New York office represented the tenant.
Dow Jones & Company has leased an additional 45,187 square feet at the Harborside Financial Center, a nearly two-million-square-foot complex next to the Exchange Place PATH station in Jersey City. Dow Jones already occupies about 324,000 square feet at the center; the new space will be used by its financial news services division. James P. Quinn of Cushman & Wakefield, who represented Dow Jones, said the 10-year deal was valued at about $10 million.

HEADLINE: Good for Financial Market, Bad for Workers?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Stop Inflation Before It Starts" (Op-Ed, June 21), Stephen S. Roach, Morgan Stanley's chief economist, makes a fascinating argument:
(1) "Workers have long been underpaid," and they deserve a raise. 
 (2) Because a raise would cause inflation, it must be prevented.
(3) The Federal Reserve should raise interest rates to slow down the economy and increase unemployment.
(4) If more people are out of work, they will be able to perform the public service of threatening to replace workers who ask for raises they deserve.
(5) What is good for financial markets is bad for workers.

 
FREDERICK C. THAYER
Washington, June 21, 1996
 
The writer is visiting professor of public administration at George Washington University.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains and Then Dips In Trading Dominated by Lira

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar settled lower against the German mark yesterday after briefly rising when the German currency dipped to a 22-month low against the Italian lira.
The mark touched 999.00 lire in Europe, its lowest level against the Italian currency since August 1994, after Italy's Finance Minister, Vincenzo Visco, reaffirmed his country's intention to rejoin the European Exchange Rate Mechanism. 
 The mark's decline against the lira briefly helped push up the dollar against the German currency, as market participants sold marks for dollars in order to buy lire, currency traders said.
Mr. Visco also reiterated Italy's intention to meet fiscal and economic criteria for joining Europe's planned single currency for the start on Jan. 1, 1999.
The rate mechanism sets linked trading ranges for the currencies of 10 of the 15 European Union member countries and is a precursor to creating a single European currency in 1999. Italy withdrew from the mechanism in 1992.
But the dollar fell later in profit taking. Talk that the Bank of Italy was in the currency market in an effort to stem the Italian currency's rise also helped the mark rebound off its lows, pushing the dollar lower against the German currency, traders said.
In trading in New York late yesterday, the dollar settled at 1.5292 marks, down from 1.5303 marks on Monday. The dollar was unchanged at 108.95 Japanese yen. The dollar fell to 1,536 Italian lire from 1,543 lire. The British pound slipped to $1.5393 from $1.5405.
But trading was thin yesterday, with interest to trade the dollar muted before tomorrow's gathering of world leaders from the Group of Seven major industrial nations.
Analysts said few if any surprises were expected from the meeting, where the focus was likely to be how to relieve high unemployment and other issues.
They noted out that the dollar had appreciated some 37 percent against the yen and 15 percent against the mark since last year, when Group of Seven finance ministers called for an orderly reversal in the direction of the dollar.
"The G-7 meeting is likely to be a disappointment vis-a-vis the dollar because they're unlikely to say anything that will take the dollar higher," said Ben Strauss, assistant vice president at Bank Julius Baer.

HEADLINE: 6 Colleges With Bit of Genius Are Given $750,000 Rewards

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
The John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation, best known for its "genius" grants to creative individuals, is putting its stamp on six small, innovative liberal arts colleges that it says show a certain genius in how they educate students.
The foundation is to announce today that it is giving each of the six a one-time, no-strings-attached grant of $750,000. MacArthur hopes the $4.5 million in awards will call attention to the colleges and shore them up financially. 
 The colleges -- Alverno College in Milwaukee; Antioch College in Yellow Springs, Ohio; College of the Atlantic in Bar Harbor, Me.; Hampshire College in Amherst, Mass.; Johnson C. Smith University in Charlotte, N.C., and Marlboro College in Marlboro, Vt., -- occupy a small but precarious niche in higher education. In a society that increasingly questions the value of a liberal arts education, these colleges have hewed to the liberal arts model, but in highly original ways.
But as with many maverick ventures, they draw a self-selective following, which gives them limited tuition revenues, small alumni groups for fund-raising and few economies of scale. Their enrollments range from 209 students at College of the Atlantic to 2,400 at Alverno.
"Parents are increasingly asking whether this kind of education is worth it," said Woodward A. Wickham, director of MacArthur's general grants program. "With these grants we wanted to say that it is absolutely worth it, and to help insure that liberal arts and these innovative colleges and others like them flourish."
Arthur Levine, president of Columbia University Teachers College, called the colleges "path blazers."
"This is a set of institutions that are under pressure to give up their missions," Mr. Levine said. "These schools haven't done that. Instead, each one has been an innovator and given new vitality to liberal arts at a time when it is crucial."
Alverno, a Roman Catholic college for women, began its innovation in the late 1960's when it grew concerned about how it could attract more and better students. In addition to traditional subjects like history, mathematics and English, Alverno emphasizes eight areas for each student, like communications, analysis, problem solving and social interaction, using written and visual means like videotapes to record a student's progress.
"This place prides itself on teaching like other schools pride themselves on research," said Sister Joel Read, Alverno's president. "We do research, too, but on teaching and learning."
Antioch melds students' work experiences with classroom learning. Where many colleges encourage student internships, Antioch students are required to work off campus during 5 of their 12 trimesters.
At College of the Atlantic, which opened in 1972, students are required to take courses in the arts, sciences and humanities, and to demonstrate competence in writing, math and other skills. But they also have substantial freedom to make their own programs, and must complete internships and conduct final research projects that weave together the approaches of many disciplines.
Hampshire College also encourages interdisciplinary work along with entrepreneurial spirit, as it seeks to teach students skills like critical thinking, communication and how to act wisely and humanely.
"Our education is very process oriented," said Gregory S. Prince Jr., Hampshire's president. "We try to teach students how to frame questions and to develop strategies for answering them. We are not as content-oriented as traditional liberal arts education. Our students do miss important bodies of work. But in the end, they keep learning."
Interdisciplinary work is also central to Marlboro College, where most classes are small seminars, seniors take individual tutorials rather than classes, and college policies are decided in New England-style town meetings that include students as well as faculty and administrators.
Johnson C. Smith, a historically black institution, also pushes its students beyond campus, requiring that all do some kind of "service learning" in the community. It also emphasizes joint student-faculty research and faculty development.
Dorothy Cowser Yancy, the president of Johnson C. Smith, called the award "Christmas in June," and talked of enhancing academic programs and of the desperate need for more scholarships to help her university compete for students.
Besides the grants to the six colleges, MacArthur is giving $1 million to the American Council of Learned Societies in New York, to make smaller grants for specific innovative projects at poorly endowed liberal arts colleges.

HEADLINE: A Voice With Heart

BYLINE: By Stephen Jay Gould; Stephen Jay Gould is a professor of zoology at Harvard.

 BODY:
When Mel Allen, the Voice of the Yankees, died last week at 83, I lost the man who ranked second only to my father for the sheer volume of attention during my childhood. (My dad, by the way, was a Dodger fan and Red Barber devotee.)
As I considered the surprising depth of my sadness, I realized I was mourning the extinction of a philosophy as much as the loss of a dear man. And I felt that most of the warm press commentary had missed the essence of Allen's strength. The eulogies focused on his signature phrases: his invariable opening line, "Hello there, everybody"; his perennial exclamation of astonishment, "How about that!"; and his home run mantra, "It's going . . . going . . . gone!" 
 But I would characterize his immense appeal by two statements I heard him make during a distant childhood. They have stayed with me, one for its integrity, the other for its antic humor. One exemplifies the high road, the other an abyss, however charming.
The comments could not be more different, but they embody, when taken together, something precious, something fragile and invariably lost when institutions become so large that the generic blandness of commercial immensity chokes off spontaneity and originality.
The phenomenon is not confined to broadcasting. In my academic world, textbooks have become longer, duller and entirely interchangeable for the same reason. Idiosyncratic works cannot sell sufficiently, for curriculums have been standardized (partly by conventional textbooks), and originality guarantees oblivion. The great texts of the past defined fields for generations because they promulgated the views of brilliant authors -- Charles Lyell's geology, Alfred Marshall's economics -- but modern writers are faceless servants of a commercial machine that shuns anything unique.
One day in 1952, as Mickey Mantle struggled in center field the year after Joe DiMaggio's retirement, fans started booing after Mickey struck out for the second time in a row. In the midst of his play-by-play broadcast, an infuriated Allen shouted at a particularly raucous fan, "Why are you booing him?" The fan shot back, "Because he is not as good as DiMaggio." Allen busted a gut, delivering a ferocious dressing-down to the fan for his indecency in razzing an enormously talented but unformed 20-year-old just because he could not yet replace the greatest player of the age.
The Yankees were sponsored by Ballantine beer and White Owl cigars. Mel never lost an opportunity for endorsements. Home runs became "Ballantine Blasts." When a potential home run passed just to the wrong side of the foul pole, he would exclaim, "Why, that ball was just foul by a bottle of Ballantine beer."
One day, Mickey hit one that seemed destined for success, and Allen began his mantra, "It's going . . . going . . ." He stopped as the ball went foul by no more than an inch or two. "Folks, that ball was foul by no more than a bottle of Bal--." Then he stopped, thought for a fraction of a moment and exclaimed, "No, that ball was foul by the ash on a White Owl cigar!"
A man of grace and integrity, a shameless huckster of charming originality. But above all a man who could only be his wonderful cornball self -- Mel Allen, the inimitable human Voice of the Yankees. So join my two stories, and let us share Shakespeare's judgment in "Julius Caesar": "The elements so mixed in him that Nature might stand up and say to the world, 'This was a man!' "

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Increase New York City Prices Debt Offering

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices rose yesterday after reports suggested that economic growth would soon slow, allowing the Federal Reserve to delay an expected increase in short-term interest rates. Strong demand at a Treasury auction of new two-year notes eased concerns about supply, further bolstering the market.
The Treasury was not alone yesterday in offering new securities. New York City was the focus of attention in the municipal market as it priced a $1.2 billion offering in three parts. One part featured the first securities sold by an American municipality on the European market. 
 The Treasury and municipal markets were bolstered by data on consumer confidence.
The Conference Board, a business research group, said yesterday that its index of consumer confidence fell nearly 6 points, to 97.6, the lowest reading since January, indicating that Americans were becoming less optimistic about the direction of the economy. Economists surveyed by Bloomberg Business News had expected a reading of 102.
Anthony Chan, vice president and chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisers Corporation in Columbus, Ohio, said the Conference Board's confidence numbers surprised the market.
A report on existing-home sales by the National Association of Realtors showed some strength. But Mr. Chan said, "Since existing-home sales represent mostly contract closings rather than contract signings, some market players were willing to excuse the strength on the belief that it would just be a matter of time before these numbers would reflect the weakness seen in housing starts."
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 13/32 , to 873/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 7.04 percent from 7.08 percent.
Treasury prices were bolstered after the auction of new two-year notes came in strong, with a high yield of 6.30 percent and a bid-to-cover ratio of 2.56, much stronger than expected. The bid-to-cover ratio represents the dollar amount of bids received divided by the securities sold.
The Treasury will auction $12.5 billion of new five-year notes today.
In the New York City debt offering, the largest portion consisted of $820 million in general obligation bonds. Yields ranged from 4.50 percent for a bond due in 1998 to 6.550 percent in 2017. Another part consisted of $150 million of one-month taxable notes.
The third part consisted of a $180 million dollar-denominated offering in Europe. The issue was priced to yield from 6.58 percent for a bond due in 1997 to 7.48 percent for one due in 2000.

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL;
A Weighty Decision: All of Draft's Riches Can't Sway Utah's Van Horn

BYLINE: By TOM FRIEND 

DATELINE: SALT LAKE CITY

 BODY:
He is in his fire-red Nissan pickup truck (101,000 miles on it) when he sees his Lexus in the showroom window (zero miles on it). After he is done drooling, he drops his fiancee at the Italian restaurant where she works, drops his 1-year-old at his future in-laws and drops himself at the weight room.
He looks in the mirror there and does not like what he sees; there are not enough muscles on top of his muscles. Marcus Camby is scrawnier than he is, Stephon Marbury is shorter than he is and Kobe Bryant is more naive than he is -- but they must not be looking in the same mirror. He will be returning to sociology class in the fall; they will be the subject of sociology class in the fall. He will be playing for the Utah Utes; they will be playing against the Utah Jazz. But he is not melancholy. 
 Last one to the pros is a rotten egg, and the foul odor emanating from Keith Van Horn's stucco apartment comes from the wheat germ in the shake he drinks to gain weight. He could have been a lottery pick, he could have bought his daughter, Sabrina, a sturdier stroller, and he could have put the fire-red Nissan to sleep, but Van Horn is going to see how the other half lives. Or the other one-third.
A total of 33 underclassmen -- plus three high school students -- have declared themselves eligible for tonight's National Basketball Association draft, while the 6-foot-9-inch Van Horn has declared himself eligible for his senior year. The Toronto Raptors tempted him, attempting to alert him through an emissary that he would have been theirs at No. 2 over all, and the Vancouver Grizzlies whispered he would have been theirs at No. 3. But he lay on his futon at night, dollars and sense spinning in his head, and just said no. Final score: College 3 (Van Horn, Tim Duncan of Wake Forest and Jacque Vaughn of Kansas), N.B.A. 36.
So, not everybody has caught the epidemic. His 5-7 roommate told him, "I'd leave if $8 million was staring me in the face," and his cherubic coach -- at least initially -- seconded that, but Van Horn is still an amateur today because of a promise, because of an impending marriage, because of a baby and because of that mirror.
"I'm not going to get any worse, am I?" he said.
His season ended with a Kentucky triple-team -- Van Horn had 23 points and 8 rebounds in Utah's 101-70 loss during a regional semifinal of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament -- and he and his coach, Rick Majerus, agreed to meet the following week at their secret hiding place: the Bagelry.
Majerus needed another bagel like a hole in the head, but, over the last three years, Majerus had taken his star for sesame bagels during nearly every crisis.
The time Majerus yelled at him for never setting a pick, they made up over a bagel. The time Majerus said he could not guard a sixth grader, they made up over a bagel.
But, on this particular March day, they talked about Van Horn being able to afford plenty of bagels. The odd couple (the rotund coach, the skinny player) sat down at a corner table, and Majerus brought a steno pad so they could talk economics.
The coach estimated Van Horn's first contract would be worth $6 million over three years and began a gaudy line of questioning. He asked Van Horn what kind of car he wanted, and in a split second, Van Horn said: "Lexus. An SC 400." He asked him what kind of home he wanted, and Van Horn said, "One with a swimming pool." He asked him what his fiancee wanted, and Van Horn said, "Nursing school." He asked what his daughter needed, and Van Horn said, "A stroller she can't escape from."
Majerus drew up a budget and came to the conclusion that Van Horn should be on the next bus out of town. But then he remembered a night they had not gone for a bagel; he remembered a night Van Horn when had no appetite at all.
It was Van Horn's freshman year, in the middle of the season, and Majerus had fielded a 3 A.M. phone call from Van Horn's mother, May. She told Majerus that Van Horn's 6-8, 280-pound father, Ken, had died of a heart attack, and she asked the coach "to explain it to him and to stay with him."
Majerus pounded on Van Horn's dormitory door, and Van Horn woke up thinking: "I'm in trouble. Is it my defense?"
Majerus, meanwhile, had lost his father to a heart attack five years earlier, so he was stuttering as he broke the news.
They went to a "greasy spoon" restaurant at 4 A.M. -- the Bagelry was closed -- and Van Horn, then 18, spent the night flashing back. He remembered the time he ruined the transmission on his father's favorite boat, and that his father still kept calm. And the time his father implored him to graduate from college. "I promised him," said Van Horn, who has a 3.0 grade point average and an addiction to summer school.
Of course, there were other reasons to fatten his wallet right now. His mother -- the woman who dropped him at every basketball camp -- had sold her deceased husband's business, had turned in her Mercedes and had moved from a tailored home in Chino, Calif., to a modest residence in Reno. And his girlfriend, Amy Sida, had become pregnant during his sophomore season.
"None of us believe in abortion," Van Horn said.
So, she gave birth to Sabrina, on May 30, 1995 -- a night when Van Horn wrote a Health Education term paper in the delivery room -- and just the other month, as he and Amy sat on a shaded park bench, he kneeled on his right knee and proposed marriage. Van Horn now had three women to support.
"If anyone had a reason to go hardship, it was him," Majerus said.
He registered all right -- for Advanced Sociology 301. To the apparent dismay of Toronto General Manager Isiah Thomas (who, according to the N.B.A. senior vice president Rod Thorn, has been absolved of tampering because the Raptors never spoke directly to Van Horn), the surprise baby and the coming August marriage inspired Van Horn to wait. He wanted a year of changing diapers under his belt. His basketball scholarship would pay him $560 a month; his Christmas bonus would be $230; his financial aid was $3,000 a year; Amy's job as a waitress paid minimum wage, and his apartment was only $600 a month. He did not need an A in accounting to know that he could break even.
"It's not like we're in a high tax bracket or anything," he said. "Besides, I've seen a lot of dirt-poor people happier than rich people."
So, while the professional scouts were calling him a pale Detlef Schrempf, he did the unfashionable -- he stayed in school.
"Every time I heard someone leave, I kind of clapped to myself," Van Horn said. "Don't know if this sounds selfish, but with all these people leaving, it gave me more incentive to stay."
That, and the day he stepped on the scale and saw he still weighed 240 pounds. The way he figured it, Shaquille O'Neal's left leg weighs 240.
"One more year of these awful-smelling weight-gain drinks, and he'll be ready," his fiancee said. "But, yuck, I don't know how anyone could drink them. Yuck."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Keith Van Horn, at home with his daughter, Sabrina, intends to keep a promise to his father, who died three years ago, to graduate from college. (George Frey for The New York Times)
