HEADLINE: Indian Point 3 Again on List Of Worst A-Plants in U.S.

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
For the sixth time in three years, the state-owned Indian Point 3 nuclear power plant in Buchanan, N.Y., was listed yesterday by Federal regulators as one of the nation's worst nuclear plants, provoking new calls by critics for the New York Power Authority to close it permanently.
Since it stopped generating power in February 1993 for a 29-month overhaul of equipment and management, Indian Point 3 has produced less than $100 million worth of electricity while costing some $500 million, according to energy analysts. 
 Power Authority officials say the plant can still be turned around, but a variety of environmental groups, energy experts and some politicians say the plant is so inefficient that while it may not be an imminent hazard, the slight risk it poses can no longer be justified.
With electricity abundant and rates in New York likely to fall as the state's utility industry is opened to free-flowing competition late next year, keeping Indian Point 3 running makes less sense than ever, said Ashok Gupta, an economist at the Natural Resources Defense Council, a private environmental group.
"Given the energy glut and the problems at Indian Point 3," he said, "if there is a plant one could shut down, it would be this one."
Mr. Gupta said that the council had generally supported the Power Authority's recent efforts to improve the plant, but that its poor performance had continued for too long.
In its semiannual listing of the most worrisome of the nation's 109 licensed plants, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission included Indian Point 3, the three reactors at the Millstone nuclear power station in Waterford, Conn., and two reactors near Morris, Ill.
Indian Point 3 provides electricity not to individuals, but to a variety of muncipalities and other customers of the New York Power Authority, including New York City's commuter and subway rail systems and its housing authority. On the east bank of the Hudson 35 miles north of Manhattan, it sits next to Indian Point 2, a nearly identical plant run much more successfully by the Consolidated Edison Company.
Also on the site is Indian Point 1, a plant mothballed in 1974 when its design became outdated. Many critics would like to see Indian Point 3 go the way of its dormant neighbor.
When Indian Point 3 was restarted last summer after the overhaul, Power Authority officials said they were confident the reactor would generate electricity close to 80 percent of the time, the level deemed necessary to make it competitive with other sources of power.
But new problems identified by Federal inspectors forced the reactor to be turned off again from Sept. 14 until April 9. Other recent problems included a two-day shutdown in May to fix several valves and a small explosion on June 9 in a non-nuclear part of the plant, when hydrogen gas from a cooling system leaked into a box housing electrical wiring.
"It's like the last days of the Vietnam War," said Charles Komanoff, an energy consultant based in Manhattan, comparing the Power Authority's efforts to keep the ailing plant running to the Nixon Administration's efforts to portray the war as being at a turning point.
Power Authority officials insisted yesterday that the plant could still be made efficient and remain safe. The reactor has been generating electricity steadily for two and a half months, with one two-day break.
"We've invested a lot of money in that plant, and it deserves three or four years to prove itself," said Robert G. Schoenberger, president and chief operating officer of the Power Authority. He said many plants on the Federal watch list in the past -- prodded by increased scrutiny -- had risen to become top performers.
Moreover, he said, Power Authority customers have not had to bear any costs associated with the plant's problems. The $500 million spent on changes over the last three years came from a "rainy day fund" for such contingencies, he said.
Some critics say the cost is still being borne by New Yorkers. Richard L. Brodsky, the chairman of the State Assembly's environmental conservation committee and a Democrat of Westchester, said that using such money to fix Indian Point 3 amounted to a "public subsidy of a failed facility." That money could just as easily have been spent improving energy efficiency in New York City schools or returned to customers as rate cuts, he said.
Mr. Brodsky, whose committee held hearings in May on Indian Point 3, said the Power Authority's board, controlled by Gov. George E. Pataki, must face the facts and consider other options. "Viewing the plant through two independent prisms -- safety first and then economics -- it's more and more clear that it's failing on both counts," he said.
Michael McKeon, a spokesman for Governor Pataki, said yesterday that Mr. Pataki had previously asked Power Authority officials "to explore alternatives to the present management of the facility" but that no decision on its fate had been made.
In the past, the Power Authority has explored the idea of turning over management of Indian Point 3 to Con Ed or another private company as an alternative to closing it.

HEADLINE: Consumers Feel Less Confident, Survey Shows

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 25

 BODY:
Consumers felt markedly less confident about the economy this month, displaying a pessimism that could herald a slowdown in economic growth during the second half of the year, the Conference Board's monthly sampling of households showed today.
The business research group said its overall index of confidence skidded nearly 6 points, to 97.6, the lowest since January, and the second consecutive decline since reaching a six-year high of 104.8 in April. The rating was lower in seven of the nine geographic regions, with New England and the Southwest showing improvement. 
 A separate report found that resales of homes climbed 1.4 percent in May, stronger than expected. The rates on conventional mortgages have risen a full percentage point since the beginning of the year, and analysts said the May resales reflected commitments made earlier.
Neither set of figures was seen as significantly affecting the Federal Reserve's decision on whether to raise short-term interest rates at its policy meeting next Tuesday and Wednesday. Still, with no major indicators to be issued before then -- and with the Fed's decision considered an unusually close call -- analysts gleaned what they could.
"There is enough mixed data about the economy looking ahead to keep the Fed on hold through next week's Federal Open Market Committee meeting," said Joseph Liro, economist at CIBC Wood Gundy Securities in New York.
Mr. Liro said that the confidence findings themselves were hard to fathom in light of buoyant readings from the latest surveys by the University of Michigan and by ABC/Money magazine.
The Conference Board, which described its index as "choppy" recently, said it "slumped" this month, and found consumers less positive about current and future economic conditions, with weakness more pronounced about the present. At the same time, both components remain somewhat above the levels of 12 months ago.
"The decline in confidence is not alarming," said Edgar R. Fiedler, economic counselor to the board. Over all, he said, the index "continues to suggest economic growth for the months ahead, though not robust growth."
Confidence in the present situation dropped to 111.4, from 120.2 in May, while the expectations index fell to 88.4, from 92.4. Both components were revised slightly upward for May, lifting the overall index to 103.5, from the originally reported 101.2. A year ago, the present-situation index was 109.7 and the expectations index was 84.5
"I don't see this as a major deterioration," said Richard D. Rippe, chief economist at Prudential Securities, pointing to a reading that still hovered at a fairly high level.
New England, however, posted a confidence level of just 78.7, despite its 14.5-point June advance. And the Middle Atlantic states sank further into last place among the nine regions, dropping to 44.7, from 50.5, mainly reflecting lower expectations over the next six months.
Mr. Liro of CIBC Wood Gundy suggested that confidence tended to wane in election periods because negative campaigning depresses consumers. According to historic data provided by the Conference Board, this may have been the case in 1992, when confidence averaged 61.6, about seven points below the 1991 average, but confidence rose by double-digit percentages in 1988, 1984, 1976 and 1972 and rose slightly in 1968. The only other election-year decline within the last 30 years was in 1980, when Ronald Reagan was first elected President.
The board said that since its current survey program was begun a little over two decades ago, the incumbent party had remained in office whenever the index was 100 or more but lost when confidence fell significantly below 100.
As for sales of existing homes, the National Association of Realtors reported turnover climbed once again despite rising mortgage rates, reaching a robust annual rate last month of 4.26 million. The April pace was 4.20 million, slightly less than initially reported.
Sales rose in the Midwest and South but fell in the West and were virtually unchanged in the Northeast, the most sluggish of the four regions.
"May homes sales probably reflect mortgage commitments from a couple of months earlier," economists at Merrill Lynch told clients. Last week's report that builders broke ground on fewer new homes in May, it added, "may give a more current view of housing activity."
The median price of a resold home in May was $117,400, up eight-tenths of 1 percent for the month and 7.6 percent over the last year, the realtors association also reported.
The chief economist at Fannie Mae, David Berson, predicted today that the housing market would remain strong for the balance of the year despite moderately higher mortgage rates that ultimately should decline a bit as the economy slows.
He estimated mortgage originations at about $750 billion, 18 percent above the 1995 level and the first rise in three years. One result of this year's higher rates is that applications for refinancing have dropped about 80 percent, to the lowest level since May 1995.

HEADLINE: U.S. Finds Oldest Ally Is Renewing Friendship

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, June 25

 BODY:
For most of the postwar era, France and the United States have been quarrelsome allies, often differing over basic issues during the cold war like America's strategic role in Europe and how to deal with Russia and China.
Most of that ended with Jacques Chirac's election as President of France in May 1995. Relations are now so good that President Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton, who will be in Lyons, France, later this week for the economic summit meeting, are extending their stay by a day so that they can spend Saturday night with President Chirac and his wife, Bernadette, in Paris. 
 The American Ambassador, Pamela Harriman, a close political friend of the Clintons to whom French officials give much credit for the improved relations between the countries, said that the personal relationship the two men have struck in seven meetings over the last year explained some of the it, but that most of the improvement was due to Mr. Chirac himself.
"Although Chirac carries the banner of the Gaullist party, he is very pro-United States," she said. That is in direct contrast to the frictions and sensitivites that have marked French-American relations since the time of Charles De Gaulle.
Madeleine K. Albright, the American envoy to the United Nations, said during a recent visit, "I think that life changed a lot when Mr. Chirac became President."
That view could soon be put to the test over Mr. Clinton's decision to oppose the re-election of Boutros Boutros-Ghali as United Nations Secretary General when his term expires at the end of this year. Mr. Chirac supports Mr. Boutros-Ghali him and told Mr. Clinton so.
Mr. Chirac wants a Secretary General who speaks French, and Mr. Boutros-Ghali studied at the Sorbonne. France also insisted last year on finding a new NATO Secretary General who spoke French and held out against Washington's preferred candidate, former Foreign Minister Uffe Ellemann-Jensen of Denmark, because he could not speak the language as well as Javier Solana of Spain, who finally got the job.
That disagreement was quickly forgotten when Mr. Chirac announced at the end of the year that France would gradually reverse De Gaulle's decision 30 years ago to pull France out of NATO's military structures. France will rejoin all of them, Mr. Chirac said this month, if the United States continues to support changes in the alliance that will encourage a stronger European defense identity within it.
"When the chips are down, this French Government is very, very good to work with, despite the inevitable frictions and misunderstandings," said former Assistant Secretary of State Richard C. Holbrooke, who had frictions of his own with French diplomats during the Bosnia peace negotiations in Dayton, Ohio, last year.
The lack of defensiveness in his relationship with the United States has helped make foreign affairs Mr. Chirac's strongest suit. He has been unpopular at home since he set France on a deficit-cutting economic course late last year to prepare for possible monetary union with Germany by the end of the century.
Mr. Chirac's decision to conduct a series of French nuclear tests in the South Pacific was unpopular abroad, if not at home, and the Clinton Administration's expressions of disappointment over the tests were not appreciated in Elysee Palace.
But Mr. Chirac ended testing early this year and came out with French support for a comprehensive test ban treaty with no loopholes for small or "peaceful" nuclear explosions even before President Clinton did.
This spring, he reasserted a French and European diplomatic role in the Middle East in a way that might have caused a crisis in Washington had De Gaulle done it.
After Israel launched a strike against guerrillas in southern Lebanon that drove hundreds of thousands of Lebanese civilians from their homes only a few weeks after Mr. Chirac had visited Beirut, he sent Foreign Minister Herve de Charette on a diplomatic mission around the Middle East.
Mr. de Charette continued his efforts even when Secretary of State Warren Christopher arrived to take over, irritating some American officials as well as Mr. Christopher, people close to the Secretary said.
Mr. Chirac conceded the leading role to the United States, but asserted that France had helped the Americans achieve peace.
The French know that their President has had a soft spot for Americans since he spent a summer at Harvard in 1953. Surprisingly, even from the hardest-shelled Gaullists in his Rally for the Republic party, there has been little criticism of his reconciliation with Washington.
But differences with the United States over legislation that would punish European companies that do business with Cuba or Iran may give him many opportunities to reassert French independence.

HEADLINE: ITT Will Expand 2 Caesars World Casinos

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The ITT Corporation said yesterday that it would expand its Caesars World casinos in Atlantic City and Las Vegas, Nev., in a move that adds new construction to an expansion strategy dominated by acquisitions.
In Atlantic City, ITT plans to build a 20-story hotel tower and to increase its Caesars Atlantic City casino by almost 43 percent, to 100,000 square feet, according to documents filed with the New Jersey Casino Control Commission. 
 Financing for the Atlantic City project is expected to include "borrowing between $150 million and $200 million from Desert Palace Inc., with the balance coming from operating cash flow," ITT said in the filing.
At the Caesars Palace casino in Las Vegas, ITT plans to build a 30-story, 1,142-room hotel tower and to add 378,000 square feet of casino, retail and restaurant space, according to documents filed with the Planning Commission of Clark County, Nev.
Both plans were approved by regulators. Officials at ITT, the New York-based entertainment group that also owns Madison Square Garden, the New York Knicks and the New York Rangers, declined to comment.
The plans indicated that for now, ITT is more interested in building a casino than buying one, Jason Ader, a casino analyst at Bear Stearns & Company, said. "ITT views the economics of building as more attractive than buying," he said.
The expansion programs followed months of speculation that ITT would buy a casino operator to complement its Caesars World and Sheraton casinos. In April, ITT ended talks to acquire Bally Entertainment after balking at paying $30 a share for Bally, according to people familiar with the talks.
The Hilton Hotels Corporation bought Bally earlier this month for $29.29 a share, or $3 billion in stock and assumed debt.

HEADLINE: POLITICS;
Excerpts From Prepared Dole Speech on Clinton Foreign Policy

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, June 25

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the prepared text of a speech that Bob Dole delivered today to the World Affairs Council of Philadelphia.
America's interests in Europe are as compelling and as urgent as they were before the Berlin Wall was breached by the stronger forces of human yearning. Yet President Clinton has persistently deferred to our allies and to the Russians, subordinating American interests to the interests of a dubious or ineffective consensus. 
 That's not leadership. And that has harmed the interests of all of us, Russian, European and American alike.
Let me be absolutely clear. With the end of the cold war, we should be building firm foundations for a century of peace, fulfilling the promise of a new future for Europe. Instead, Bill Clinton's policy of indecision, vacillation and weakness is making the world a more dangerous place. And we are missing an opportunity that may never come again.
As President I will restore decisiveness and purpose to America's foreign policy.
Today's great tragedy is that this Administration is squandering the inheritance that America -- through 45 years of struggle and sacrifice -- won for free peoples everywhere when we won the cold war.
In an era of tectonic shifts in world affairs, we must not continue to entrust American leadership to would-be statesmen still suffering from a post-Vietnam syndrome. This historic moment will not wait upon Administration officials who believe that our cold war mission was mistaken, not principled and noble, and who are still suffering from the illusion that communism merely fell instead of being pushed.
Nothing better illustrates President Clinton's failure of leadership than his uncertain and vacillating policies toward Bosnia.
After three years of opposing Congressional efforts to enable Bosnia to defend itself -- arguing that lifting the arms embargo would involve America in a Balkan quagmire -- President Clinton committed American military forces on the ground in Bosnia. Although I believe this commitment would not have been necessary if we had done what I recommended from the start, I made the decision to support our troops. It was not popular, but I learned a long time ago that young Americans risking their lives should never doubt the support of their Government and the American people.
After haphazardly getting America into Bosnia, President Clinton now has no idea how to get Americans out or how to accomplish the mission they went to fulfill.
President Clinton promised to lift the arms embargo, and then changed his mind. He allowed NATO to act as a subcontractor to the whims of United Nations bureaucrats and Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali. He refused to allow the Bosnian people the fundamental right to defend themselves, and instead gave a green light for the terrorists of Teheran to establish a beachhead in Europe.
And, at long last, under Congressional pressure, he committed the United States to the arming and training of Bosnia -- 'I give you my word' he wrote. Yet six months after the Dayton accords, not a single bullet has been delivered, and Bosnia remains outgunned.
Unless we vigorously move to train and equip the Bosnians, the U.S. and NATO will face a 'stay or fail' dilemma in Bosnia: either pull out and ignore the resulting disaster, or become involved in an open-ended commitment with no clear purpose, no achievable mission, and no realistic exit strategy. . . .
Let me turn now to Russia.
President Clinton's misguided romanticism towards Russia has led him and his advisers to try to fine-tune the intrigues of Russian domestic politics instead of guarding against the nationalist turn in Russian foreign policy that has already occurred. Post-Soviet Russia has proved all too willing to repeat old patterns, challenging the interests of America and the West. And many of those challenges were excused, ignored and even encouraged by the Clinton Administration.
Make no mistake. I want the Russian people to succeed in their quest for enduring liberty and democracy. As President, my foreign policy will strive to consolidate our cold war victory in Europe. . . .
My policy will reinforce the independence of all the states of the former Soviet Union, will support the new democracies of Europe, will lead to the enlargement of the North Atlantic alliance and will advance effective counter-proliferation measures. In doing so, I will deal with the Russia that exists today, not the Russia we all hope to see.
Let's look at the reality.
Russian hard-line security services have regained much of their previous power. Too often, the privatization of state-owned enterprises has served to enrich pervasive organized criminal networks. The Jewish agency, laboring mightily to aid emigration from Russia, has been shut down, and ominous signs of anti-Semitism are reappearing.
Since December 1994, the world has witnessed the specter of a Russian democrat, Yeltsin, permitting the bombing of cities in Chechnya to appease Russian nationalists. More than 30,000 people have been killed, the vast majority innocent bystanders.
By remaining passive in the face of these and other troubling developments, President Clinton has given a green light to the most dangerous tendencies in the new Russia.
Forces in Russia have waged a campaign of subversion, intimidation and economic blackmail against other independent states of the former Soviet Union. I will make clear that Russian economic blackmail or military meddling in their former empire will carry costs in relations with the United States. . . .
Russian officials have conducted a campaign of threats against NATO expansion, and President Clinton got the message. He deferred and delayed, placing the threats of Russian nationalists before the aspirations of democrats in countries like Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic. . . .
I will stand firmly with the champions of democracy. I will not grant Russia a veto power over NATO enlargement.
While the threat of immediate nuclear holocaust has receded, the risk of accidental launch has increased. This makes missile defense more feasible and more necessary. Yet President Clinton is unwilling to have the United States defend itself against even a single incoming nuclear missile.
At the same time, President Clinton has been silent about Russian violations of arms control treaties such as START I and the Biological Weapons Convention. He has ignored the Russian decision to abandon the Bilateral Destruction Accord on chemical weapons. He rewarded Russian violations of the Conventional Armed Forces in Europe Treaty by giving Russia a better deal.
As President, I will link Russian adherence to existing arms control treaties to the provision of U.S. assistance.
As President, I will engage the Russians in a direct discussion about the mutual benefits of missile defense and urge them to cooperate with us on this critical issue.
But one thing will be certain in my Administration: the American people will no longer be left vulnerable to ballistic missile attack. When I am President, we will deploy an effective national missile defense. We can afford it. We can do it. We should begin now. . . .
The hope of the world still rests, as it has throughout this century, on American leadership. There is no escaping the fact that only America can lead -- others cannot, or will not, or should not.
How firmly we grasp the remarkable opportunities before us in Europe will determine whether the next century repeats the violence and tragedy of the last or opens up a new era of peace, freedom, and security.

HEADLINE: Revamping Is Approved For Mesa

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

DATELINE: DALLAS, June 25

 BODY:
Shareholders of Mesa Inc. approved a refinancing today that turns over control from T. Boone Pickens, the company's founder, to Richard Rainwater, a Fort Worth financier. But they did not go along peacefully
In substantial numbers, shareholders voted against the refinancing, which greatly dilutes their own holdings. In addition, shareholders refused to approve a 1-for-4 reverse stock split that management had recommended. Rarely do shareholders at any company vote down management proposals. 
 Mr. Rainwater will invest as much as $265 million on preferential terms that include control of the company. His money and his presence are enabling Mesa to reduce its billion-dollar debt load and lower interest rates on the rest. Mr. Rainwater has asked Mr. Pickens to step aside as chairman and chief executive. Mr. Pickens will remain until Mr. Rainwater finds a replacement and will continue as a director and significant shareholder.
 The loudest opposition to Mr. Rainwater's plans came from hostile investors led by David Batchelder, Mesa's former president and a Pickens protege. While Mr. Batchelder and his billionaire confederates, Marvin Davis and Dennis Washington, were certainly not seen or heard at today's meeting, their influence was clear. In the Mesa proxy statement for today's voting, they said that Mesa was harming its shareholders by letting Mr. Rainwater invest too cheaply. The company has said that no alternative offer was as good.
Although the Batchelder group never reported holding as much as 10 percent of Mesa's shares, 19 percent of the shares voted today went against the terms of the Rainwater investment. More than 71 percent went against the reverse stock split.
On a low shareholder turnout of less than 68 percent, the refinancing narrowly won the required majority with just 54 percent of the total shares approving, 13 percent against and the rest abstaining. The reverse stock split failed with 48 percent in favor and 17 percent opposed.
Management had recommended the split to make the shares more attractive to investors and brokers, many of whom avoid stocks priced as low as Mesa, which has traded between $2.625 and $5.50 the last 52 weeks. Mesa, based in the Dallas suburbs, closed today at $5.375, up 12.5 cents on the Big Board in busy trading. Mr. Batchelder, who now only represents Mr. Washington, noted in a brief phone interview that he was glad Mr. Washington's shares had risen back above his $5 purchase price.
No shareholders spoke against the reverse split, but it apparently became a vehicle for protesting the broader plan. Only one holder publicly attacked Mr. Rainwater's terms.
Otherwise, the meeting, held at a hotel banquet room here that was crowded with shareholders, investment bankers, lawyers and Mr. Pickens's friends, gave Mr. Rainwater a chance to introduce himself and his investment strategy.
Having decided that natural gas prices were ready to rebound, Mr. Rainwater said, he saw long ago that Mesa's prime properties and operations made the company a winning investment. "The tide has changed in the oil and gas industry," he said. "This company is perfectly positioned to take advantage of the opportunities."

Western Resources Plans A Hostile Bid for Utility
Kansas City Power and Light rejected a sweetened takeover bid of $1.9 billion from Western Resources, and the spurned utility immediately countered that it would take its $31-a-share bid directly to Kansas City Power shareholders.
A hostile takeover would be a first in the electric utility industry, but some analysts have said that Western Resources stands a good chance. [Page D4.]
 
$525 Million for Trump's Castle
Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts formally agreed to buy Trump's Castle Casino Resort in Atlantic City from Donald J. Trump for about $525 million. The transaction combines Mr. Trump's four casinos into one publicly traded company. Wall Street was not pleased with the deal, pushing the company's shares down $2.375, to $25.75. [D2.]
 
F.A.A. Admits Errors on Valujet
The head of the Federal Aviation Administration conceded at a Congressional hearing that the agency had reacted too slowly to safety problems it discovered at Valujet Airlines even before the crash in the Florida Everglades last month that killed all 110 people on board. [A12.]
 
Chile Joins Trade Bloc
In a move that expands free trade in South America, Chile agreed to join the Southern Cone Common Market, known as Mercosur. The move will give Mercosur access to Chile's robust economy and its Pacific ports, a gateway to commerce with Asia. Bolivian membership is expected soon. [D2.]

Shareholders of Mesa approved a refinancing that turns over control from T. Boone Pickens, the company's founder, to Richard Rainwater, a Fort Worth financier. But they did not go along peacefully, refusing to approve a 1-for-4 reverse stock split recommended by management. [D4.]
 
Technology Stocks Slide Again
Technology stocks fell sharply on worries about profits in the computer industry, but a late surge trimmed most losses in other sectors. The Nasdaq composite index fell 10.32, to 1,172.58. The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 5,719.27, up 1.48 points. [D10.]
 
Senate to Vote on Minimum Wage
After months of deadlock on a major Presidential campaign issue, the Senate's Republican and Democratic leaders agreed to schedule a vote on a proposed 90-cent increase in the Federal minimum wage. [B8.]
 
Internet Trade for Basketball Star
Underlining the heated competition for talent in Internet publishing, the basketball star Shaquille O'Neal will announce that he is moving from the Microsoft Network to Sportsline USA, a sports service on the World Wide Web. [D7.]
 
Web Journal Adds Print Edition
Slate, the political and cultural magazine that made its debut Monday on the World Wide Web, has been widely anticipated as an attempt by Microsoft to define a new medium. But even as the company scrambled to meet technical problems and unexpectedly heavy demand, it disclosed plans to also publish the journal as a conventional magazine. [D7.]
 
Familiar Faces in Advertising
Fred, the fictitious Dunkin' Donuts baker, is joining New York's former Mayor, Edward I. Koch, to promote the addition of bagels to the chain's menu. It's an example of a hot trend in advertising: the rise of the recurring character meant to personify desirable attributes of a brand, product or company. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D6.]

HEADLINE: Nursing Homes And Hospitals Hit by Strike

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
In another sign of financial struggles in New York's health-care industry, 6,000 workers went on strike late Monday against Brooklyn Hospital Center, Jamaica Hospital and 11 other hospitals and nursing homes after rejecting management's demands for cuts in wages and benefits for new workers.
Hospital managers said they needed the concessions to cope with budgetary strains created by Federal and state cutbacks in aid and the cost-cutting pressures from health-maintenance organizations. 
 "The basic problem here is these institutions' revenues are declining as a result of the changes going on in health care," said Bruce McIver, president of the League of Voluntary Hospitals, which handles bargaining for the affected institutions. "We're seeking some concessions, and that's the sticking point."
The strike involves maintenance, food and technical workers, and hospital executives said yesterday that they were able to continue those services because managers and dozens of newly hired replacement workers filled in for the strikers. Nonetheless, hospital officials said that the strike might take its toll on maintenance and cleaning after a few days, but they added that it would in no way damage health care.
The strike, by Local 144 of the Service Employees International Union, has affected seven hospitals with 2,097 acute-care beds and six nursing homes with 2,199 beds. Noisy pickets marched in front of the institutions yesterday, but hospital officials said the police made sure the strikers did not block any entrances.
Eager to squeeze down costs, management is demanding a two-tier wage structure in which new workers would be paid 15 percent less than their experienced counterparts, with their pay rising to 10 percent less, and staying there, after two years. At present, new employees are paid 7 percent less than experienced workers, but their wages rise to the level of experienced workers after one year.
The strikers include not only unskilled workers who do laundry and housekeeping and receive about $25,000 a year, but also skilled workers, like electricians and X-ray technicians, who often get more than $40,000 a year.
The hospitals and nursing homes are also demanding cuts in the number of sick days, now 15 days a year for all workers, to 12 days for experienced workers and 10 days for new workers. Management also wants to end the practice of paying workers for sick leave not taken.
The hospitals proposed a pay freeze for the first year and a 2 percent bonus in the second and third years of the contract -- but no permanent wage increase to be built into base pay.
"We didn't want to go on strike," said Frank Russo, president of Local 144. "What they want is givebacks and to create a two-tier, which doesn't make any sense."
The union's contract expired last Nov. 30. Frustrated by a lack of progress, Mr. Russo told the hospitals two weeks ago that his union would walk out unless an agreement were reached last weekend.
Mr. Russo said management had rejected the union's proposal, which he said would raise labor costs by 1.7 percent, well below the current inflation rate of about 3 percent. He declined to give further details of the union's demands.
Among the affected institutions are North Shore University Hospital at Forest Hills (formerly La Guardia Hospital), Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale, and Catholic Medical Center, which runs St. Mary's Hospital in Brooklyn and St. Joseph's Hospital, Mary Immaculate Hospital and Monsignor Fitzpatrick Pavilion in Queens.
The strike does not affect many large nonprofit hospitals, like Mount Sinai and Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Centers, because their maintenance, food and technical workers are represented by a different and far larger union, 1199, National Health and Human Services Employees Union. Their contract expires in 1998, and several health-care experts said yesterday that the current strike could be a sign of what is to come when other nonprofit hospitals bargain with 1199.
Gregory Tarpinian, director of the Labor Research Association, a union-supported group based in New York, said, "This is the first contract that the league has negotiated in this new era of enormous cutbacks in Medicare and Medicaid and the now-dominant role of the managed care organizations in setting rates. There's no question that employers are rethinking their bargaining relationships."
Mr. McIver said the hospitals needed concessions on the ground that Local 144's members receive better wages and benefits than members of 1199 -- an assertion that many members of both unions disputed.
David Rosen, president of Jamaica Hospital, said, "Unfortunately, the health-care industry is hurtling into a new competitive environment, and this is causing a tremendous amount of pressure on pricing, which in turn requires us to take all the necessary steps to reduce our costs, including labor costs."
The financial situation is so bad that some hospitals have missed payments to their pension funds while the city's nonprofit hospitals have announced that they plan more than 500 layoffs next month.
At Brooklyn Hospital, where 150 workers picketed yesterday afternoon, Frederick Alley, the hospital's president, said its revenues were down 3 percent in the first quarter from a year earlier. The hospital has just one week of cash on hand, he said, and is deliberately delaying payments to its vendors.
Those pleas won little sympathy from the strikers. Rickey Kellman, a 40-year-old striker who works in the hospital's medical records office, said, "If you don't give us anything more, fine, but we don't want to give anything back. You never recover from that."
Nathan Lambert, a driver at Brooklyn Hospital, was also angry about the demands for concessions. "I feel sad," he said. "We earned it, and now they want to cut us back."
Health-care experts said Mr. McIver was under pressure to deliver at the bargaining table because of criticisms that he had been too soft when he negotiated with 1199 two years ago and promised most of its workers job security.
Similarly, several experts said Mr. Russo also needed to deliver, saying that since he is part of his union's old guard he needs to show the service employees' new president, Andrew Stern, that he can stand up for his workers.
Both sides declined to predict the length of the strike.
"I bargain a lot of contracts," said Mr. McIver, who was New York City's Labor Commissioner for four years under Mayor Edward I. Koch. "Usually, I try to give as little as I can. Now I'm asking for concessions, and that changes the dynamic."

HEADLINE: Adolph S. Ochs of The Times, in the First Person Singular

BYLINE: By JEAN STROUSE; Jean Strouse, author of "Alice James: A Biography," is working on a life of J. Pierpont Morgan.

 BODY:
In August 1896, the head of a major New York life insurance company gave some advice to a young newspaperman from Chattanooga, Tenn.: "Don't do yourself anything you can get others to do as well. Confine your efforts to the impossible things." The younger man, Adolph Simon Ochs, was making a career of doing things other people thought impossible. At age 20, in 1878, he had bought the failing Chattanooga Times with borrowed money -- his father had had to sign the papers since Adolph was legally underage -- and within a decade had turned it into one of the most successful newspapers in the South. And in August 1896, the 38-year-old greenhorn was about to acquire a controlling interest in what he called "one of the greatest newspapers in the world": The New York Times.
An exhibition opening today at the Pierpont Morgan Library, "Documenting The Times: Adolph S. Ochs and the Early Years of The New York Times," tells this extraordinary story through letters, manuscripts, photographs, and cartoons from private Times archives. Artfully organized by the Morgan's associate curator of autograph manuscripts, Christine Nelson, the materials frame the events of 1896. There are thoughts by de Tocqueville and Thoreau on America's romance with the news, and a photograph of the first Times building, on Printing House Square. Only once, in 1883, did The Times use color on its front page, shown here, a stripe down one side announcing that the price would be cut. The paper hyphenated "New-York" on its nameplate until Ochs changed the adjective to a statement at the end of 1896. 
 Who was he? Ochs was born in Cincinnati to German-Jewish immigrants who moved to Knoxville when he was 7. He took his first newspaper job at 11, as a paper carrier for The Knoxville Chronicle. He left school at 15 to work as a printer's "devil" (gofer/apprentice) in The Chronicle's composing room, and over the next five years learned all aspects of the trade. Not much of a writer, he proved to be a gifted business manager and entrepreneur: he worked 18 hours a day to revive The Chattanooga Times, adding correspondents, upgrading equipment and establishing editorial independence at a time when journalistic opinions were for sale.
By the mid-1880's Ochs had married the daughter of Rabbi Isaac Mayer Wise, founder of Hebrew Union College, and he was a prominent Democrat on the greeting committee when President Grover Cleveland came to town. Ten years later, with the country in a depression, Ochs was looking to expand his publishing operations.
When he learned in March 1896 that The New York Times might be for sale, he rushed to Manhattan to make a bid. You can follow his progress, at the Morgan, in exhilarated letters he sent home almost daily to his wife, Effie, and 4-year-old daughter, Iphigene. "My darling wife and baby," he wrote in a neat hand on the stationery of the Fifth Avenue Hotel. "Here I am in New York arriving 24 hours ago," in negotiations for "the leading and most influential paper in America." New York ran on a different schedule from Chattanooga's -- "You can't see anybody here before 10 o'clock in the morning," he complained -- and since everybody he needed to see that summer left at 4 P.M. for the country, "I can't get as much done as I like." Still, one day in June he had 8 meetings before lunch, 11 after.
The Times, founded in 1851, had been the country's leading -- staunchly Republican -- paper during and after the Civil War. When it backed a reformist Democrat, Cleveland, against a corruption-tainted James G. Blaine in 1884, however, Republican readers and advertisers deserted it in droves. Cleveland won the election. Ownership of The Times passed into Democratic hands. Poor management expedited its decline. By 1896 it was $350,000 in debt and losing $2,500 a week. Paid circulation stood at 9,000 while its rivals sold hundreds of thousands of copies a day. Its stock could be had for 25 cents on the dollar.
"I have got the chance that occurs only once in a century," Ochs exulted to Effie. He obtained a letter of endorsement from President Cleveland (elected again in 1892, the only President to serve nonconsecutive terms), and managed to persuade The Times's chief stock and bond holders that he could resuscitate the paper, eliminate its debt and make it turn a profit without sacrificing quality or standards.
In trepidation he went down to Wall Street to ask one creditor, J. Pierpont Morgan, to exchange his old bonds for new ones. To Ochs's astonishment, the formidable banker rose to greet him, shook his hand, and said warmly: "So you're the young man I have heard about. Now, where do I sign the papers?" Ochs crowed to his wife in August, "The deed is did." She wrote back, "This is a great day for the little boy who tramped the streets of Knoxville selling papers."
It was not only Ochs's energy, self-confidence and track record with The Chattanooga Times that won him the confidence of high-powered men in New York. He saw an opening in a competitive market in which scandal-mongering "yellow" papers -- Joseph Pulitzer's World and William Randolph Hearst's Journal -- were in ascendancy. An 1898 caricature of Hearst, pasted into a scrapbook Ochs kept, shows a horse-faced rival dressed in yellow painting the town in slogans about "de Joynal." The Sun had well-written copy but little hard news; the Tribune was dull, the Herald preoccupied with society gossip. Ochs promised his backers he would create a "high standard daily journal, a model for fairness, cleanliness, independence and enterprise."
Furthermore, his political and economic views largely coincided with theirs in a crucial election year. It is hard to imagine, 100 years later, how bitterly the country was divided during the 1890's depression over the politics of money: whether to stay on a stringent gold standard, or try to ease the depression (and erode the value of the dollar) by coining silver. Populist silverites in the Democratic South and West accused Eastern plutocrats of prolonging the depression for private gain. Defenders of the gold standard warned that "cheap" money meant anarchy and the country's descent to the status of banana republic.
Ochs, like Cleveland, was a fervent "gold Democrat": his Chattanooga paper had come out for "sound" money when most of the South was for silver. While he negotiated for The Times in June 1896, the Republicans nominated the Governor of Ohio, William McKinley, on a platform committed to gold. In July, the Democrats rejected Cleveland in favor of the oratorical genius and devout silverite William Jennings Bryan. Bryan delivered his famous "cross of gold" speech to this cheering convention. Gold Democrats bolted the party in disgust. The day after the convention, Ochs told Effie, 150 Democratic members of the New York Stock Exchange carried American flags to the rostrum and put on McKinley buttons, crying, "Down with the red flag" -- symbol of anarchy -- "and up with the Stars and Stripes!"
In his first issue as publisher of The Times on Aug. 19, 1896, Ochs printed a statement of his journalistic credo. The words have since become famous, and it is fascinating to see the handwritten rough drafts, on hotel stationery and telegraph forms, as Ochs formulated his thoughts. He had a little domestic editorial help: "You will observe I trimmed it down considerably from what I showed you last Sunday," he told Effie, "leaving out the pyrotechnics as you suggested." It was his "earnest aim," he announced in the published statement, to give the news concisely, clearly, promptly and "impartially, without fear or favor, regardless of party, sect, or interests involved." He would invite intelligent discussion on all questions of public importance. And he would not depart from the policies that had distinguished The Times as a "nonpartisan newspaper -- unless it be, if possible, to intensify its devotion to the cause of sound money and tariff reform, opposition to wastefulness and speculation in administering public affairs, and in its advocacy of the lowest tax consistent with good Government, and no more Government than is absolutely necessary." It was a measure of this moment's moral absolution that, with no trace of cynicism, an honest proponent of sound money and small Government could proclaim them nonpartisan issues.
With McKinley in the White House, Ochs put his principles into practice. He refused to let reporters use free railroad passes, a "favor" that had been standard newspaper procedure for years. When Spencer Trask, a banker and chairman of The Times Publishing Company, objected to an editorial, Ochs wrote back: "I do not understand that you have any control whatsoever of the editorial conduct of The New-York Times."
Ochs himself coined the slogan, "All the news that's fit to print," stressing news and fit to distinguish the paper from its sensationalist rivals. Not convinced that the phrase entirely worked, he held a contest for a better one, an astute public relations move that focused national attention on the image of The Times. "Realizing that the sewer and morgue fields were fully occupied by The World and The Journal," noted a San Francisco paper, "Ochs determined to issue a clean paper for a change." Two thousand responses poured in. An independent judge found none preferable to the original. First prize went to "All the World's News, But Not a School for Scandal."
With his high ideals and hands-on knowledge of the business, Ochs turned The Times into the best daily paper in the United States -- the newspaper of record. He cut costs, increased advertising volume, jettisoned the fiction that was appearing on the front page, widened the space between lines of type, improved the quality of typeface, newsprint and ink, introduced rotogravure printing, expanded business coverage and demanded first-class news reporting. Within a month of taking over, he added an illustrated Sunday supplement and a Saturday book review section. Circulation rose from 9,000 in 1896 to 465,000 by the time Ochs died in 1935. The paper has been owned and run by his descendants ever since.
Among the many pleasures of the Morgan Library exhibition are responses to the new regime. One reader professed "shock" that the Sunday magazine was "filled with a lot of fashion plates," and six months later relayed a gripe about insufficient coverage of college sports. The head of the Shubert Theater was outraged when The Times gave Sunday space to a freelance piece critical of a current Shubert play after the daily paper had praised it: why couldn't the editors leave well enough alone?
When a 1901 book about the vices, ignorance and lack of ambition of the American Negro -- written by an American Negro, William H. Thomas -- got a favorable Times review, the paper published a strong letter of protest by a white Alabama preacher, and the editor sent both review and letter to Booker T. Washington, inviting him to reply. Washington thought the preacher's letter sufficed, but answered in private: "I think this book is one of the most despicable and indefensible publication[s] that has ever come before the public and all the more so as having come from a member of the race at which it is a direct blow."
Visual highlights of the show include an early photograph of printers operating linotype machines, and another of a paper-strewn newsroom with mustached reporters in three-piece suits and high-laced boots. There is a pencil sketch of "A. Smarty Ochs," drawn by his irreverent fiancee a year before they married. And in a poignant photograph of Ochs at 16 (going on 35), wearing a tall bowler, white waistcoat and neatly fitting jacket, he looks off into the high distance as if setting his sights on difficult things.
 
A Guide to the Exhibitions
 Exhibitions drawn from the archives of The New York Times commemorating the 100th anniversary of the purchase of the newspaper by Adolph S. Ochs are opening this week at four New York City cultural institutions.

Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about an exhibition of Adolph S. " (He did not say "speculation.")

HEADLINE: Responsible Water Use

 BODY:
To The Home Section:
The real nightmare in the June 13 article "Trickle-Down Showerheads:A Real Nightmare" was its glib argument that responsible water use is something to be paid lip service to but circumvented whenever possible. New Yorkers who remove showerhead water restrictors are not only breaking the law but thwarting one of their city's most important environmental protection efforts. 
 In the past, New York's water supply has been cheap and plentiful. As the city grew, increased consumer demand threatened to exceed the amount of water the city could reliably deliver to its customers and process through its waste-water treatment plants.
The city answered this challenge with the nation's most innovative water-conservation programs, including initiatives that promote low-flow showerheads. These programs save 150 million gallons a day, hardly a drop in the bucket. As a result, the city has avoided the need for new water sources and expanded waste-water treatment capacity, undertakings that would involve significant economic and environmental costs.
The article also misreported basic facts. Low-flow showerheads vary in performance; some are virtually indistinguishable from older, high-flow models. Tenants who don't like one model may choose another.
New York has one of the world's finest water supplies. Maintaining that legacy is a serious business that deserves more thoughtful coverage.
 
MARILYN GELBER
Commissioner
New York City Department
of Environmental Protection
Corona, Queens

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains Against the Yen But Weakens Later in Europe

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the Japanese yen yesterday in reaction to a bomb blast in Saudi Arabia but weakened against European currencies as optimism faded for interest rate cuts in Germany and Italy.
Currency traders feared the repercussions of the Saudi blast could destabilize the Persian Gulf and hurt Japan, which depends on Saudi oil. 
 Trading was light ahead of today's meeting of officials of the Group of Seven industrial nations in France. Traders were reluctant to make any major moves because of the possibility that the summit meeting might produce news that would affect exchange rates.
"When you have all those officials in one place for a couple of days, there are bound to be some statements coming out," said Elena Shperling, chief dealer at the Banco di Sicilia's New York branch.
In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar stood at 109.42 yen, up from 108.95 on Tuesday. The dollar traded at 1.5257 marks, down from 1.5292 marks. The British pound was quoted at $1.5407, up from $1.5393.
The dollar rallied in Asian dealings on the news of the deadly truck bombing at a United States military housing complex in Saudi Arabia, a leading oil exporter. But the dollar weakened later in Europe after the governor of the Bank of Italy, Antonio Fazio, doused hopes for lower Italian interest rates, telling a meeting of Italian bankers he wanted to see more evidence that inflation had fallen below 4 percent, as preliminary data indicated last week. Final figures are due July 5.
Mr. Fazio's remarks weakened the Italian bond market and dragged down the lira against the mark and other European currencies. The strength of the mark indirectly weakened the dollar.
The mark derived further strength against the dollar from the likelihood that the Bundesbank would not reduce German interest rates at the regular meeting of its policy-making council today.
That view was reinforced after Reimut Jochimsen, a senior Bundesbank policy maker and head of the regional central bank based in Dusseldorf, told a German news agency that the central bank had already taken bold steps in April to stimulate the economy by reducing interest rates.
Nonetheless, there was a minority view that the Bundesbank might make a small reduction in its securities repurchase rate.

HEADLINE: Despite U.S. Hope and Help, Ukraine's Star Fades

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: DONETSK, Ukraine

 BODY:
Three summers ago, Ludmilla and Aleksander Kozlov welcomed some foreign visitors into their modest home with wine served in long-stemmed glasses, a table laden with cold meats and salads and plenty of zest for the future.
Today, embarrassingly, there is no food for a guest, and the living room cabinet hides the glasses that have been stashed away, along with, it seems, their hopes. 
 Like millions of workers in Ukraine, from police officers to teachers, from doctors to civil servants, Mr. Kozlov, a 43-year-old coal miner, has not been paid in six months. His back pay, he said, amounts to the equivalent of nearly $1,000.
"We go down to the mine headquarters to demand bread, not what we are owed," Mrs. Kozlov said as she offered the only luxury on hand, instant coffee. "People are so angry they are ready to eat each other."
The image is far from the prosperous, independent Ukraine that Washington has bet on to dampen the dreams of Russian nationalists who want to re-create an empire.
Still, American policymakers describe the stability of Ukraine -- sandwiched and swayed by Russia to the east and by Poland to the west -- as a vital security interest. Toward that end, they have plied Ukraine with nearly a billion dollars in aid in the last four years, making it the third largest recipient of American assistance, ahead of even Russia and behind only Israel and Egypt.
Despite this, Ukraine, a place once big, rich and nuclear armed -- second only to Russia among the Soviet republics -- is today only big. Many of the citizens of this independent country of 52 million people now look with envy at the comparative economic success of their former Soviet neighbors, who are still struggling themselves.
But the Ukrainian Government has pleased Washington by managing, despite the country's almost total reliance on Russian oil and gas, to keep Moscow at bay. It has also given up its huge nuclear arsenal, a process that, helped by $400 million from the United States and many visits by Defense Secretary William J. Perry, was completed in June.
The President, Leonid Kuchma, the former boss of Ukraine's biggest rocket factory who was elected two years ago, has projected Ukraine toward the West by having the army take part in military exercises with the United States and Europe.
Mr. Kuchma, who visited Poland twice in June, has become more enthusiastic in recent months about an expanded NATO, part of a further tilt to the West and away from Moscow. And Ukraine, like Russia, joined the Council of Europe last year.
But these benchmarks of Ukraine's new place in the world have made little impression on ordinary Ukrainians, who have suffered sharp drops in their standard of living since independence in 1991.
Ukraine remains bedeviled by a corrupt and backward-looking political elite dominated by former Communists and socialists. The Government has prefered collectivization to privatization and snail-paced reforms that make Russia's middling efforts look revolutionary. Whether they look east or west, Ukrainians see people, once part of the same Communist system, who are now far better off.
The difference seems to be especially galling to them since Ukraine, with some of the world's best black soil, was once the breadbasket of the Soviet Union. Even today it retains an industrial base -- antiquated but vast -- of nuclear power plants, steel works, armament factories, engine plants and satellite research sites.
The Kozlovs, in the mineral-rich Donets Basin region in eastern Ukraine, once a center of industrial strength, look with envy at the comparative richness of their Russian neighbors.
The Kozlovs' 17-year-old son, Vanya, dropped out of school this year and went to Moscow to work at a construction site. The $500 he brought home was critical to the family's survival and allowed for a few frills, like toy cars for his 7-year-old brother, Maxim.
When he is not in Moscow, Vanya works as a car-park attendant, washing and guarding the cars of the mine bosses. "It's demeaning, but at least he is bringing in money," Mrs. Kozlov said.
In the city of Zhitomir, 100 miles west of Kiev, people like Viktor Gumankov, the director of a machine-making factory, talk about neighboring Poland and wonder why the economic turnaround there cannot be replicated at home.
Mr. Gumankov, the son of a landowner who was arrested and sent to the Siberian gulag by Stalin, has privatized the state factory he manages and kept the 152 employees from the Communist period working.
"But every day it's a struggle, and we are all very tired," Mr. Gumankov said. "We can't make enough from our machinery products, so I've had to do a joint venture with a Polish firm to sell potato crisps."
In a recent speech in Kiev that shook a room full of top Ukrainian officials and Western diplomats, who had just finished congratulating themselves on an improved economic picture, Jeffrey Sachs, a Harvard economist, warned that the Ukrainian economy was "worsening in many ways."
It was not good enough, he told the experts, that inflation had dropped sharply to 0.7 percent in May from triple digits two years ago. Or that a $900 million loan program with the International Monetary Fund, which was suspended in January because the Ukrainians had printed too much money, was back on track.
Ukraine's economy was so shaky that the monetary fund believed it was less of a risk to lend Russia $10.2 billion over three years, as it did earlier this year, than to lend Ukraine $900 million over one year, a Western diplomat said.
Production fell 11.8 percent in the first quarter this year, the biggest slump among the nations of the former Soviet Union. About 50 percent of the economy is in the black market, largely because of efforts to evade huge taxes. The total taxes on some businesses imposed by Parliament often amounts to 89 percent.
But perhaps the biggest restraint on economic growth, Mr. Sachs suggested, was the pervasive corruption. President Kuchma has been disappointingly weak in cleaning up corruption, an American official said.
"This country is still hostile to small business: people have to pay bribe after bribe after bribe" for even seemingly basic things like opening a bank account, he said.
Others have suggested that one of the reasons for the meager foreign investment in Ukraine -- $700 million, compared with $13 billion for Hungary, a country with one-fifth the population -- are the under-the-table payments required for entry into the market.
Another reason for Ukraine's dismal foreign investment is the hostility to the idea of property rights. Western businesses have balked at investing because they cannot secure company ownership of land or property from the state. A draft constitution now under discussion in Parliament to replace the Soviet Constitution was watered down in May so that property ownership is excluded as a basic right.
Washington's biggest fear in Ukraine is the potential for chaos, and that is the underlying reason for continuing high levels of assistance, including 52 programs financed by the United States Agency for International Development.
"The country won't make it without the support of the West," an American official said. "They don't have the self-confidence to do it without the feeling of having friends."

HEADLINE: How a Sure Summer Hit Missed

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB 

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, June 26

 BODY:
Sometime in early 1995, Lou Holtz Jr., a prosecutor in the Los Angeles County District Attorney's office, completed his first screenplay, a comedy called "The Cable Guy," and sent it to some friends who are producers. They introduced him to two agents, Tom Strickler and Ari Emanuel, at the fledgling Endeavor Agency.
Within days the agents had received an enthusiastic phone call from Bernie Brillstein, a top talent manager. He said the script was a perfect vehicle for one of his clients, Chris Farley, the former "Saturday Night Live" comedian whose movie career had taken off with the teen-age comedy "Tommy Boy." 
 The agents, with Mr. Brillstein and an associate, Mark Gurvitz, promptly took the script to Columbia Pictures. Desperate for a comedy to release in the summer of 1996, Columbia bought the script for $750,000, plus an additional $250,000 that would be paid to Mr. Holtz if the movie was made. Mr. Holtz took a leave of absence from his job, flew to New York and began meeting with Mr. Farley to discuss his potential role as a lonely cable repairman who makes a house call on a yuppie customer and then tries desperately to befriend him.
"It was a comedy about a needy cable guy you can't get rid of," Mr. Holtz said in an interview.
From this relatively modest start, "The Cable Guy" grew into a monster, though not, unfortunately for Columbia, one of the box-office kind. The final version, released two weeks ago, cost $60 million to make and market. Of that, $20 million went to the star, who was not Mr. Farley after all but the biggest and most-sought-after comic in the movies, Jim Carrey. By then Mr. Holtz was long gone, replaced by friends of Mr. Carrey, and the screenplay had been rewritten many times. Along the way, the quintessential Carrey character -- silly, sophomoric but essentially winning -- was lost. In the final version, the repairman is a violent, maniacal and generally unfunny person who almost destroys the life of the customer, a young architect played by Matthew Broderick.
The movie was greeted with scathing reviews (Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times that it offered "the shocking sight of a volatile comic talent in free fall") and disappointing attendance. It took in $19.8 million in its all-important first weekend, an amount that does not seem puny until it is compared with receipts for Mr. Carrey's last film, "Ace Ventura: When Nature Calls," which grossed $37.8 million in its opening weekend.
So far "The Cable Guy" has brought in gross revenue of more than $40 million. Its makers insist that it will eventually make a profit, and they are probably right. But that would not diminish the sense that this movie -- one of the most eagerly awaited and, because of Mr. Carrey's enormous salary, closely watched releases of the summer -- is one of its biggest letdowns, raising serious questions about decisions on both the creative and financial sides.
"The original script was basically a silly buddy comedy," Ben Stiller, who directed the movie, said in an interview. "What I wanted to do was make a comedy that satirized the psycho thrillers like 'Cape Fear' and 'Hand that Rocks the Cradle' and 'Fatal Attraction.' "
According to executives and others involved in the project, the deal to sign Mr. Farley ground to a halt almost as soon as Mr. Carrey expressed interest in the role. Mark Canton, chairman of Columbia-TriStar, quickly came up with the offer of $20 million, a figure that stunned the movie industry.
As is common practice among film stars, Mr. Carrey brought friends into the project. One was Judd Apatow, a comedy writer who had worked for HBO's successful "Larry Sanders Show" but whose films, "Celtic Pride," and "Heavyweights," had been box-office failures. Another was Mr. Stiller, an actor who had directed the Generation X film "Reality Bites."
Mr. Holtz, who is the son of the well-known comedian, not the football coach, was bounced as screenwriter.
"Carrey did not want to meet with me, did not want to give me any notes," Mr. Holtz said. "I was told I was out as soon as the studio could make a deal with Apatow."
At Mr. Carrey's request, Mr. Apatow revised the buddy script to make it bleaker. "There were four drafts, each with a completely different ending," Mr. Apatow said. "We were going for a funny version of the classic stalker films. That's what we wanted.
"Jim said: 'I can't keep repeating myself. My audience is going to get bored. I can't keep making Ace Ventura. If I don't progess as a creative person, I'm going to go stale and the audience won't come anyway.' "
At least one of the drafts called for ending the movie with Mr. Carrey's impalement on a cable dish. A more benign ending was finally written, but many critics denounced the film nonetheless for what they saw as mean-spiritedness and, worse, a lack of humor.
Before the movie's release, Mr. Apatow and Mr. Holtz also battled before the Writers Guild for screenplay credit, with Mr. Holtz winning. Mr. Apatow is listed as a producer.
Mr. Stiller maintains that "we made the movie we wanted to make." But executives at rival studios said that Mr. Carrey and his team seriously misgauged the star's audience. By all accounts, Mr. Carrey -- who refused to be interviewed for this article -- wants to model his career after that of Robin Williams, who moved from brash comedy roles to more dramatic parts in such films as "Dead Poets Society" and "Awakenings." Mr. Williams kept his audience, but many in the industry say that was because those roles and others he chose were essentially humane and gentle parts.
Top movie stars like Tom Hanks, Tom Cruise and Harrison Ford rarely deviate from certain roles. Mr. Cruise has played more or less the same character since he attained stardom in the 1983 comedy "Risky Business": that of the brash, ambitious and, ultimately winning hero, like his role in his current hit, "Mission Impossible."
"The audiences don't fall in love with Tom Cruise or Tom Hanks," said a top studio executive, speaking on condition that he not be named. "They fall in love with the characters they play. It's not about the stars. It's what they become on screen. That's where Jim Carrey didn't get it. It's not about him."
People involved in "The Cable Guy" said that Columbia Pictures and some of the film's producers had been dismayed when the first preview of the film was screened in Sacramento three months ago. But Columbia had locked itself into an opening date in June and refused to delay the release. Hasty efforts were made to revise the film.
Mr. Holtz saw it in a studio conference room in May. It was not exactly what he had in mind, he said, but he did not want to criticize it. "It's fair to say it's darker than I imagined it would be," he said.
The decision by Mr. Canton to pay Mr. Carrey $20 million, a record sum, brought a storm of criticism from rival executives, who said the deal would lead to a dizzying round of inflation in stars' salaries.
In an interview, Mr. Canton said that despite all the criticisms, the movie would turn a profit once overseas box office and video sales were counted.
"This is the most overscrutinized business success in recent memory," Mr. Canton said. "We're going to have a very profitable film."
"Would we have liked to have done better? Of course," he added. "But at the end of the day we're going to make money on this."

HEADLINE: Greece Gives a Last Sad Farewell to Papandreou

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: ATHENS, June 26

 BODY:
As jet fighters flew low overhead, hundreds of thousands of Greeks bid farewell today to Andreas Papandreou, the charismatic former Prime Minister who dominated Greek politics for more than a decade.
Mr. Papandreou died on Sunday of a heart attack at 77. In the following days, huge crowds have passed by his flag-draped coffin at the central Greek Orthodox cathedral in Athens. 
 Today, about 200,000 mourners from all over Greece braved 102-degree temperatures to line the route from the cathedral to the First Cemetery as Mr. Papandreou's coffin passed on a gun carriage.
His wife, Dimitra, 41, sobbed quietly as the coffin was lowered into a grave several yards from that of Mr. Papandreou's father, George, a centrist Prime Minister who influenced his son's entry into politics. Mr. Papandreou's former wife of 38 years, Margaret, and their four children hugged one another.
Greece's Orthodox Primate, Archbishop Seraphim, presided over the service at the cathedral, where air conditioning was installed specially for the funeral.
In his eulogy, Prime Minister Costas Simitis called Mr. Papandreou's entry into Greek politics in 1964 "a new period" in the country's leadership. He said that Mr. Papandreou had given up a successful career as dean of economics at the University of California at Berkeley, because he believed "in the humanization of society, in Greece's renewal."
Mr. Papandreou was active in the fight against a right-wing military junta from 1967 to 1974, founding a resistance group that was the precursor to the Panhellenic Socialist Movement he formed in 1974.
Elected Greece's first Socialist Prime Minister in 1981, Mr. Papandreou's first eight-year administration changed the country with social welfare policies that liberally distributed funds among the lower classes. He brought the Socialists back to power in 1993, but stepped down in January because of ill health.
Flags flew at half-staff today, which had been declared a day of national mourning. Representatives from about 80 countries attended the funeral, including Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin of the United States.

HEADLINE: Latest Offer For Utility Is $1 Billion

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
A subsidiary of the Southern Company said yesterday that it would offer $1.04 billion in cash for the nonnuclear power plants of the Cajun Electric Power Cooperative, a Louisiana electric utility.
The bid by the Atlanta-based Southern, which is the parent of five electric utilities and also one of the nation's most profitable utilities, is lower than some made this year. 
 Cajun, which serves about one million customers in Louisiana, is being reorganized under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, but outsiders are attracted to the company, which has 1,700 megawatts of mostly coal-generating capacity and sells power to 12 rural electric cooperatives.
William Tilles, the utility analyst for Smith Barney, said that Cajun's bankruptcy status provided a rare opportunity for other utilities and companies to buy regulated assets without having to deal with management, which currently has little say.
Cajun Electric has accumulated debt of $4 billion partly because of its investment in the River Bend nuclear power plant. A Federal agency, the Rural Utilities Service, urged the cooperative to invest in the River Bend plant in the 1980's as an economical way to increase capacity -- and offered Federal financing.
After Cajun bought a 30 percent stake in River Bend, the demand for electricity began to stagnate and construction delays and cost overruns made the plant more expensive.
The cooperative began to increase its rates to cover the servicing of its debt, but the Louisiana Public Service Commission ordered Cajun to lower rates, which put the cooperative in default on its debt to the Rural Utilities Service. Cajun filed for bankruptcy on Dec. 21, 1994.
The Rural Utilities Service and the Louisiana Public Service Commission are still battling in bankruptcy court over who has the right to set rates for Cajun Electric.
Mr. Tilles said a final decision on a reorganization plan would be made by Ralph R. Mabey, the court-appointed trustee, Frank J. Polozola, the bankruptcy judge, and Cajun's creditors. Cajun has until Aug. 24 to present its plan.
Bidders believe that they can get the assets at a good price and then run them better, Mr. Tilles said. "It extends your reach and your ability to move bulk power," he said.
Under Southern's plan, its subsidiary, Southern Electric International, would agree to 25-year contracts to provide all the electricity to the Louisiana cooperatives. Rates would be about one-fifth less than the current wholesale rate of 4.88 cents a kilowatt-hour, the company said.
Mr. Mabey has backed a $1.11 billion bid by the Ziegler Coal Holding Company and the Northern States Power Company. A $1.2 billion bid has been filed by Entergy Inc. and the Central and South West Corporation. There is also a $1 billion offer from the Enron Corporation, a natural gas company based in Houston.

HEADLINE: Orders for Durable Goods In Strong 3.3% Rise in May

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 26

 BODY:
Strong demand for new commercial aircraft drove up durable goods orders for May at the sharpest rate in nine months, the Commerce Department said today, in the latest sign that American manufacturing was reviving.
New orders for goods from airplanes to refrigerators jumped 3.3 percent last month to a seasonally adjusted $171.83 billion, triple the gain that had been forecast. 
 It was the biggest monthly rise in orders since August last year, when they increased 5.1 percent, and came after a decline of 1.8 percent in April.
Most of the May increase was accounted for by aircraft and parts, though the department did not separately value aircraft orders since the data are given confidentially by a few key producers like Boeing.
"Manufacturing hasn't died yet," said Astrid Adolfson, an economist with MCM Moneywatch Inc. in New York. "We get Boeing orders daily and auto production has been on the increase to catch up with demand."
But excluding the transportation goods category, which covers aircraft as well as cars and parts and other items like ships and military tanks, orders were up just seven-tenths of 1 percent in May after a 1.8 percent April gain.
Shipments of finished products picked up in May and order backlogs kept fattening, an indication that factories have business ahead that will bolster employment and income growth.
Transportation orders climbed 12.2 percent in May to a seasonally adjusted $42.9 billion after a drop of 12.1 percent in April.
The surprisingly robust report came as the National Manufacturers Association urged the Federal Reserve not to raise short-term interest rates when its policy-making committee meets Tuesday and Wednesday.
"A growth rate of 2.8 percent is possible if monetary policy, which has been restrictive throughout the early 1990's, is loosened," said a study issued by the Manufacturing Institute, which does research for the association.
The economy is widely expected to grow at an annual rate as high as 4 percent in the second quarter before slowing in the second half.
There were several signs of manufacturing-sector vigor in the durable goods report, buttressing other recent indicators including last week's survey by the Federal Reserve of business conditions around the country that said activity was improving in many regions.
Industrial machinery orders increased 2.5 percent, to $33.5 billion, after a gain of one-tenth of 1 percent in April, and primary metals orders posted a 1.4 percent rise, to $15.1 billion, after a 7.6 percent April increase.
Orders for nonmilitary capital goods, an indication of business investment in new equipment, rose 9.6 percent last month to $46.7 billion after falling 12.6 percent in April.
Shipments of durable goods, an indication of current demand, increased 1.9 percent in May to $170.5 billion after a 2.1 percent increase in April.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Durable Goods Orders" shows Manufacturers' total new orders for durable goods from Dec. 1994 to May 1996. (Source: Commerce Department)
