HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Post Mild Gains

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended little changed yesterday, displaying resiliency in the face of an economic report showing unexpected strength and a disappointing auction of new five-year notes.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond gained 3/32 , to 876/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, slipped to 7.03 percent, from 7.04 percent on Tuesday. 
 Bond prices dropped early in the session after the Commerce Department reported that orders for durable goods rose 3.3 percent in May, the biggest monthly rise since August 1995.
The market has been very sensitive to signs that the economy is growing at a faster pace, which could prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates soon.
But prices soon recovered as analysts noted that orders for aircraft and parts accounted for most of the increase. Still, Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, warned against dismissing the importance of the durable-goods reports.
"Even excluding civilian aircraft, durable goods orders rose nine-tenths of 1 percent in May on the heels of a 1.1 percent gain in April and eight-tenths of 1 percent increase in March, figures that should hardly be dismissed and clearly reinforce the continued forward momentum of the durable goods sector," Mr. Fine said.
In any case, the durable goods report did not change the market's expectations that the Federal Reserve was likely to raise short-term interest rates this summer, if not at next week's meeting of Fed policy makers than at the August meeting.
Many market participants expect the Fed's first tightening will be an increase of 25 basis points -- or hundredths of a percentage point. The Fed's policy making panel, the Federal Open Market Committee, begins a two-day meeting on Tuesday.
In addition to worries over inflation picking up and the Fed raising interest rates, traders and analysts have recently been concerned about the ability of dealers to absorb new securities coming to market.
But market participants largely shrugged off a mediocre Treasury auction of new five-year notes yesterday.
At the auction, the high yield was awarded at 6.674 percent. A high between 6.67 percent and 6.675 percent had been expected.
But the bid-to-cover ratio, which measures demand, was a bit weak, traders said, although small investors showed strong interest.
The only economic data facing the market today is the Labor Department's weekly report on the number of initial claims for state unemployment benefits. Analysts expect a small decline of 2,000, to 355,000, which would keep intact the trend in the claims numbers since effects of a strike against the General Motors Corporation ended this spring.
In the municipal market, the New York State Housing Finance Agency tentatively priced $489.7 million in mortgage revenue bonds through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc.
The New York agency's securities, whose interest and principal payments are secured by insurance issued by Financial Security Assurance, are rated triple-A by Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Yields range from 4.35 percent for an issue due in 1998 to 6.05 percnet in 2011, with a long maturity of 2015 priced to yield 6.20 percent.

HEADLINE: Lyons Talks May Prove Unpleasant For the U.S.

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: LYONS, France, June 26

 BODY:
When the United States once again failed to send a check this spring to the World Bank fund that provides aid to the world's poorest nations, the other contributors -- chiefly Europe and Japan -- decided to teach a deadbeat a lesson.
They barred American companies from bidding on a range of projects financed by the fund, which brings agricultural science, food and health programs to villages in Africa and India. The United States Treasury estimates the sanctions will probably cost American companies $250 million to $300 million. 
 As economic sanctions go these days, it was relatively small punishment. But the testiness behind the message was clear, and it explains why the summit meeting of the Group of Seven leading industrial democracies, which opens here on Thursday, was shaping up as an uncomfortable one for President Clinton.
Tonight, the exact agenda of the summit meeting was uncertain. President Clinton, who arrived here late tonight, said earlier in the day that the fight against terrorism should be the "first order of business" at the conference. He was speaking in the wake of a bomb attack on Tuesday in Saudi Arabia that killed 19 United States military personnel.
Before that attack, the White House had hoped to use the meeting to underscore America's economic success compared to its biggest rivals to an election-year audience back home: Nearly 10 million new jobs, far ahead of the field, and the group's lowest budget deficit, at least when measured as a percentage of national output.
But the host of the meeting, President Jacques Chirac of France, has made it clear that he plans to put foreign aid at the top of the agenda.
In the French Parliament on Tuesday, Mr. Chirac's Foreign Minister, Herve de Charette, cited statistics showing that the United States was falling to the bottom of the heap of major donors to needy countries.
"The American share is in constant decline, year after year," Mr. de Charette said. "That is the selfishness which is unacceptable. That is why President Chirac decided to put aid to the third world on the agenda of the G-7."
The Administration is arguing that the best way to help the world economy is to create jobs. "We have not met our own goals in terms of aid," Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin acknowledged. "On the other hand, this economy has created 9.7 million new jobs, compared to roughly zero elsewhere," he said, a reference to the stagnation that has gripped Germany, Italy, Japan and France, and the relatively modest job growth for Canada and Britain, the other two members of group.
The struggle to define America's performance as the world's unchallenged economic leader or as an increasingly miserly one will not, of course, be the only subject of conversation as the leaders meet and dine, and dine again, in this city awash in Beaujolais. The reconstruction of Bosnia, along with the Russian election next week, which is keeping President Boris N. Yeltsin from attending as an unofficial eighth member, are bound to dominate many of the political meetings.
So will the American effort to prevent Boutros Boutros-Ghali, the Secretary General of the United Nations, from winning a second five-year term. Mr. Boutros-Ghali will appear here on Saturday as a "special guest" of Mr. Chirac, along with the leaders of the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund and the World Trade Organization. They will all be meeting with the leaders to discuss development and trade issues, in a session that will be Mr. Boutros-Ghali's first encounter with Mr. Clinton and Secretary of State Warren Christopher since they announced their effort to oust him, and he announced his intention to fight back.
"I'm sure there will be smiles all around," one of Mr. Clinton's top foreign policy advisers said the other day.
Anti-terrorism was on the agenda even before the truck-bomb attack on Tuesday. But today Mr. Clinton's advisers were wondering aloud how the attack may alter the discussion over another tense division between Europe and Washington: The expanding movement in Congress, with the Administration's support, to punish foreign corporations that invest in Iran, Libya and Cuba.
Mr. Clinton's advisers say that despite these disputes, the President will not be on the defensive. Secretary Rubin, the President's chief economic strategist, said in Washington the other day that Mr. Clinton will "clearly be asserting economic leadership."
"In past years, we were viewed by many as an economy that was waning, and that hurt American Presidents at summit meetings," Mr. Rubin said. "Today, and whenever I go to an economic summit meeting, we are seen as the leader of the economic world."

HEADLINE: Auto Plant Closes And Developers See Opportunity;
North Tarrytown Focuses On Its Future Instead of the Past

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

DATELINE: NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y.

 BODY:
After 11 years as an electrician at the old, smoke-stained General Motors plant that rises over the bank of the Hudson River here, Nancy McCague might be expected to be saddened, perhaps even angry, as the plant fades into the history of American manufacturing.
The plant, to be closed on Friday, began assembling steam-powered cars in 1900 and has been making Chevys since 1915. And Ms. McCague's father, brother and sister all worked there. 
 But now, as one of 2,100 workers here who will be transferred, laid off, given early retirement or simply dismissed, Ms. McCague said she had accepted what had been inevitable for years.
"There just isn't a life for me here anymore," said Ms. McCague, 34, who spends more than two hours a day commuting from Wappingers Falls because she cannot afford to live closer. She will report in August to a G.M. plant in Doraville, Ga., just outside Atlanta, retaining almost all her Tarrytown salary in an area where housing costs are far less. "Sure, it's sad to see this old plant close," Ms. McCague said, "but I think it's for the best."
Not all of North Tarrytown's displaced auto workers are so sanguine, but Ms. McCague's sentiments are widely shared by business people, urban planners and government officials in Westchester County and across the New York region, who consider the plant here an economic anomaly at a time when heavy manufacturing and assembly-line production have become close to extinct in New York City and its suburbs.
And there are many in this fashionable suburb 25 miles north of Manhattan who are almost gleeful about the opportunity that will be created when G.M. cleans up the polluted 97-acre site and this prime parcel of riverfront property becomes available for development.
The land is coveted by developers. Unlike most of Westchester County's Hudson River waterfront, it is not separated from the river by Metro-North's train tracks because much of it was created as landfill between the tracks and the river during the 1930's.
"People at the plant may consider this the end of an American dream, but it is the beginning of a dream for the people of North Tarrytown," said Sean Treacy, the village's Mayor. He favors turning the G.M. property into expensive housing.
Other alternatives are being studied by a committee appointed last year by Gov. George E. Pataki. Although a final recommendation is not expected for at least a week, a summary of the committee's conclusions, obtained yesterday from state officials, proposed a combination of two alternatives: a "historic Hudson Valley village" of condominiums for young couples or retirees, and an industrial park for small high-technology companies.
Mayor Treacy said the prospects were exciting to most people in North Tarrytown, where the average selling price of a four-bedroom home last year was $341,000 and where residents were more likely to be investment bankers than auto workers. He said the plant was out of place. "Now we have the chance to recast our image," he said.
To many economists and business executives in the New York region, the only real surprise is that the plant survived as long as it did. In a region whose economy is now threatened more by layoffs of management workers at banks, insurance companies and other financial-service concerns, and by cuts at high-technology concerns like I.B.M. and AT&T, the experts say the demise of this plant simply underscores the forces that have been carving away at heavy manufacturing in the region for decades.
They also say the closing provides a cautionary tale to government officials, reflecting the waste that can result from government campaigns to prop up and retain declining businesses. In its last campaign to persuade G.M. not to close this plant, in 1987, New York State invested $25 million to raise rail overpasses between North Tarrytown and Albany, enabling the company to ship by rail instead of truck.
At the time, G.M. decided to refit its assembly line here for minivans, and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said he expected the agreement to keep North Tarrytown in the auto making business well beyond the millennium. But in 1992, faced with disappointing demand for its minivans, G.M. said the plant would close after four more years of production.
"That plant is a mismatch," said Rae Rosen, senior economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and a former auto industry analyst for Merrill Lynch. Just as the costs of assembling cars here proved too high for G.M., she said the cost of living in or near North Tarrytown make it a bad location for the kind of workers who would most benefit from heavy manufacturing.
The closing does not eliminate auto manufacturing in the New York region, however. New Jersey has two assembly plants, a Ford plant in Edison that employs 1,717 and a G.M. plant in Linden that employs 2,780.
But some analysts say that any large assembly plant that has survived within 100 miles of New York is living on borrowed time. "The wage levels, the presence of unions, the cost of houses and commercial property, the tax and regulatory burden: they all work against this region," said David Hensley, a regional economist with Salamon Brothers.
Those pressures have not been lost on workers here, who make an average of $19.01 an hour and have known since 1993 that their jobs would be eliminated this week. Some said they saw the writing on the wall long before that. "This plant is too old to compete, particularly when states in the Midwest are happy to give you the land and build the plant for you," said Carl Thane, who has worked here for 12 years, commuting from Clifton, N.J.
Like Ms. McCague, he has accepted a transfer to the Doraville plant, to which the company plans to shift the minivan production it is eliminating here. "They've given us three years to plan our lives, and I don't see any hardship in that," he said.
G.M. said that 1,300 workers, or more than half of its North Tarrytown employees, had accepted transfers to other plants spread across the eastern half of the nation, from Louisiana to Ohio.
Most of them -- 900 -- have already reported to their new jobs, the company said, and have been replaced by temporary workers here. Those workers were told that as a condition of being hired they would be dismissed without benefits when the plant closed.
Another large group of workers -- 660 -- accepted incentives to retire, including an offer of full pension benefits to anyone with 28 years of service, which is two years less than is normally required.
Still, the options offered workers here have not prevented sacrifices in many of their lives.
"I don't know what I will do," said Peter Katsaris, a carpenter here for 27 and a half years, not quite enough time to qualify for early retirement. Since his wife has recently had surgery and is undergoing physical therapy, and his son has just entered college in New Jersey, he said he had refused a transfer outside the New York region.
Instead, he said, he was hoping for a transfer to the plant in Linden, and will go on layoff until a carpenter position opens there. But he said he saw little hope of an opening in Linden any time soon. G.M. said 130 of its workers here had elected to go on layoff while awaiting jobs at plants of their choosing.
Given the plant's long history, plans for the final days at North Tarrytown plant may seem surprisingly low key. Sometime today, the last minivan will roll off the assembly line as workers stand by somberly, upholding a long tradition in the auto industry that looks something like a wake in honor of the last of a line of vehicles.
On Friday, G.M. said, workers will gather for brief exchanges of farewell comments inside the plant before it is padlocked for good. On both days, reporters and the public will be banned from the plant, the company said. Then, negotiations over what comes next for 97 acres of prime waterfront real estate under the Tappan Zee Bridge begin in earnest.
"General Motors wants to walk away as gracefully as it can, and our job is to bring the parties together," said Charles A. Gargano, chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation and Governor Pataki's chief economic adviser, who will preside over discussions between the company and North Tarrytown.
"No one likes to see jobs lost, but this is a situation where we have a great piece of property and we will make the most of it," he said.

HEADLINE: Head of Carpenters' Union Is Dismissed in an Office Raid

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB 

 BODY:
In a raid on his office by national union officials and private guards, the head of the carpenters' union in the New York City area was abruptly dismissed yesterday from his $360,000-a-year job on charges of corruption and favoritism to mobsters.
The union leader, Frederick W. Devine, who in the last five years had withstood a battery of investigations by Federal officials and complaints of nepotism and lavish living by challengers, was dismissed along with his four top aides by the national union's new general president, Douglas J. McCarron. 
 As president of the 26,000-member union since 1991, Mr. Devine, 58, was one of the region's most powerful trade union leaders. His decisions in labor negotiations affected commercial and residential construction costs, and his endorsement and financial support was solicited by political candidates for local and national office.
Taking the unusual step of removing Mr. Devine without a hearing, Mr. McCarron said he had acted after reviewing testimony by cooperating prosecution witnesses in Federal criminal and civil cases that Mr. Devine had been linked to Mafia figures in the Colombo and Genovese crime families.
Mr. McCarron also rebuked Mr. Devine for sanctioning the hiring of mobsters for lucrative trade show jobs at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center and in other sites at the expense of ordinary union members.
On Tuesday night, a group of national union officials accompanied by more than a dozen private guards took control of the headquarters of the region's union, the District Council of New York City and Vicinity of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners, at 395 Hudson Street in lower Manhattan.
Mr. Devine was not in his plush-carpeted, wood-paneled office overlooking the Hudson River when the takeover occurred, and his secretary said yesterday that he was out of town on business and could not be reached immediately.
Douglas J. Banes, the first vice president of the national union, who was appointed by Mr. McCarron as the temporary supervisor of the district council, said Mr. Devine had been dropped from the payroll and all the office locks had been changed.
"The district council has been out of line for many, many years," Mr. Banes said in an interview. "We intend to clean this up once and for all for the benefit of thousands of rank and file members."
Mr. McCarron, who was elected in November as the general president of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America, said in a statement that he had the authority to remove Mr. Devine and his aides for actions "detrimental to the welfare and interests of the membership."
Mr. McCarron cited Mr. Devine's support of Anthony Fiorino to handle job assignments for union members at the Javits Center even after he learned that Mr. Fiorino was the brother-in-law of Liborio Bellomo, reputedly the acting boss of the Genovese crime family. Last year, after state officials at the center ousted all suspected mobsters, Mr. McCarron said Mr. Devine had continued a corrupt job referral system for the mob at trade shows in hotels that generated about $1 million a year in wages.
Mr. McCarron said that Federal prosecutors and Kenneth Conboy, a former Federal judge investigating abuses in the district council, supplied evidence that Mr. Devine had accepted payments from two contractors and that he had been influenced by Thomas Petrizzo, whom prosecutors have identified as a captain in the Colombo crime family.
Mr. McCarron also said Mr. Devine had mismanaged the district council's funds, hired unnecessary employees to administer the council, leased luxury cars, run up excessive legal bills, fired dissidents from union jobs and used union money for his re-election campaign last year.
Last year, Mr. Devine secretly raised his annual salary to $360,791, making him one of the nation's five highest paid union officials. About 40 percent of the district's members were unemployed.
Under Mr. Devine's stewardship, the union spent $100 million for its headquarters building, which includes a tree-lined atrium next to his office.
Also dismissed were William Reardon, first vice president; William Hanley, second vice president; Robert J. Cavanaugh, secretary-treasurer, and Raymond O'Kane, trustees chairman.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Frederick W. Devine, the carpenters' union leader, who was dismissed from his job yesterday.

SECTION: Section D; Page 2; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
If the U.S. doesn't follow trade rules, why should others?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
IF at first you don't succeed, try, try again. Cray Research, the Minneapolis-based maker of supercomputers, seems to have taken that homily to heart. After failing to convince the National Science Foundation that it could build a better machine to simulate global warming than the NEC Corporation of Japan, Cray is attempting to nullify the foundation's decision through the back door. Friends of Cray in Congress have slipped a provision into the foundation's proposed budget that would effectively bar completion of the deal with the Japanese.
More is at stake here than the $35 million contract announced last month. "Since the late 1970's, America has been pressuring Japan to play fair on government procurement," said Gary Saxonhouse, an economist at the University of Michigan. By changing the rules when it suits American interests, Washington is risking hard-won progress in opening up the Japanese market. 
 Supercomputers -- machines that can crunch numbers at multiples of the speeds of the giant mainframes that dominated the computer market in the 1970's -- were once thought to be the key to the future of the data processing industry. It didn't work out that way, though. Supercomputers now dominate niches in electronic eavesdropping, nuclear weapons design, high-energy physics, weather forecasting and oil exploration -- important and prestigious uses, certainly, but ones unlikely to deliver a big technological or commercial payoff to the manufacturers.
That hasn't stopped NEC, Fujitsu or Hitachi, which all invested heavily in supercomputers in the 1980's, from fighting for sales. Indeed, Cray won equal consideration in bidding on Japanese Government contracts only after President George Bush threatened trade sanctions in 1989.
But the supercomputer market, long dominated by American brands, is now up for grabs. Hitachi currently owns bragging rights as the maker of the fastest supercomputer in the world. More important from Cray's perspective, recent sales in Canada and Europe suggest that NEC and Fujitsu machines are now highly competitive in weather forecasting. So it was no great shock to computer gurus when the Government's top science research agency chose a computer from NEC, despite Cray's none-too-subtle contentions that American jobs and security were at risk.
Ailing Cray, which was recently bought by Silicon Graphics after prodding from the Defense Department, has lots of friends in high places. Three days after the NEC award, the acting head of the Commerce Department's Import Administration wrote to the National Science Foundation to warn that the Japanese bid was "substantially" below the manufacturer's cost and thus potentially subject to antidumping penalties.
Greg Rushford, the publisher of the Rushford Report, a Washington-based newsletter on trade politics, said the warning was unusual for a variety of reasons. One Federal agency rarely interferes with procurements by another unless it is invited. More striking yet, the Commerce Department issued the warning before it had begun an independent inquiry or even given NEC a chance to defend itself.
But the surprises were just beginning. Two weeks ago, Representative David R. Obey, a Wisconsin Democrat with close ties to Cray, amended a draft of the science foundation's appropriations bill to deny funds for the salaries of personnel "who approve a contract for the purchase, lease or acquisition in any manner of supercomputing equipment" after a "preliminary determination" by the Commerce Department that the offering was "at any other than fair value."
This stealth attack was bipartisan: An effort by Representative Jim Kolbe, an Arizona Republican, to scratch the Obey amendment was brushed aside by fellow committee members. That suggests it has a good chance of surviving in the 1997 appropriations bill, which is supposed to be completed by Oct. 1.
The White House has yet to take a position on the Obey amendment. And for the moment Tokyo is apparently hoping the conflict can be resolved privately before it becomes a high-profile political issue back home. So far, the only reaction -- from Hajime Ito, a senior trade official at the Japanese Embassy in Washington -- is a mild expression of "serious concern." But Mr. Ito suggests that the initiative violates World Trade Organization rules. If true, that could lead to another embarrassing defeat for America in the new trade body.
Mr. Kolbe remains publicly optimistic that Congress will discard the Obey amendment. "This is such a flagrant violation of the spirit of our laws that I think it will come out," he said. But he does not hide his frustration that it has gotten this far. "We make a big point of telling other nations they must live by the rule of law," he notes, "and then we turn around and pull this kind of stunt."
